webTitle: Cambridge set the pace but rivals draw a blank

fields.headline: Cambridge set the pace but rivals draw a blank
fields.trailText: Cambridge United 0 - 0 Peterborough United
fields.byline: Richard Rae at the Abbey stadium
fields.body:
It won't be pretty, warned Barry Fry beforehand, and for once the big man knew of which he spake.

Not that the frozen fans cared. Though it might not be on the scale of some of the derbies being played this weekend, this is the biggest match of the season in the Fens, and with little enough to distract them on the pitch, both sets of supporters baited each other incessantly. Still, at least they had the Abbey Stadium's legendary bacon rolls to console them through the first goalless draw played by Cambridge for 41 games.

Their best chance of the first half came early when Matthew Gill's attempted long ball was blocked by Tom Youngs and rebounded into the path of Paul Connor. The centre-forward outpaced his marker but a clumsy touch gave Mark Tyler time to save at his feet.

It set a pattern of sorts. Cambridge, clearly still smarting from last weekend's ignominious FA Cup defeat at the hands of the struggling Conference side Morecambe, fairly snapped into their tackles, winning most of them. Once in possession, however, their lack of ideas was startling and Peterborough coped with a series of long, hanging balls with conspicuous ease.

The presence of the referee Graham Poll did not help; more than one promising opening was brought to an end by a premature whistle. Cambridge made another decent chance when Andy Edwards, having failed to catch Connor earlier, produced a wonderfully timed late tackle to rob Youngs in the act of shooting. Again the rebound found Connor in space but his shot went wide.

Matters improved slightly after half-time, in terms of entertainment if not quality. Andy Clarke shot straight at Lionel Perez from close to the penalty spot, but otherwise Cambridge continued to make the pace. Ian Ashbee's 25-yard shot forced a fine save from Tyler, and Youngs and Connor both began to find space previously denied them.

The introduction of Neil Mustoe gave the Cambridge attack much-needed width, and the midfielder twice set up Youngs for close-range shots from a narrow angle. Both times Tyler blocked solidly.

fields.headline: Celtic end Dalglish settlement claim
fields.trailText: Celtic have finally closed the chapter on the calamitous Kenny Dalglish era at the club with the award of more than £600,000 to the former director of football operations.
fields.body:
Celtic have finally closed the chapter on the calamitous Kenny Dalglish era at the club with the award of more than £600,000 to the former director of football operations.

The former Parkhead hero re-joined the club along with the head coach John Barnes in the summer of last year. But the pair failed to inspire the Hoops and Barnes was axed after the humiliating home Scottish Cup defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle and Dalglish was sacked in the summer.

To compound the injury to Celtic fans' pride, the team finished 21 points behind their arch-rivals Rangers in the title race. Dalglish's lawyers accepted the pay-out and in turn the club agreed to drop a counter claim against him.

A spokesperson for Celtic said: "In the Court of Session today, Kenny Dalglish obtained a judgment against Celtic for £612,522 plus interest and expenses. Celtic will comply with the terms of the court order and now considers the matter closed."

Dalglish had originally been seeking £950,000 along with £35,163 worth of pension contributions from Celtic after being sacked in June. But the former Celtic, Liverpool and Scotland legend agreed to take £585,000 and £27,522 along with interest payments.

Brian Napier, advocate for Dalglish, said it was agreed that the matter would be settled today. He asked Lord Macfadyen for a decree for the reduced sum be granted in return for the counter claim being dropped, which was granted. The hearing lasted about five minutes.

webTitle: Fergie's shadow leaves the future unclear

fields.headline: Fergie's shadow leaves the future unclear
fields.trailText: The departure of Alex Ferguson from the bench at the end of next season could prove a watershed this all-conquering Manchester United team.
fields.body:
It should not take a Nostradamus to predict, with reasonable assurance, that somewhere between now and the second weekend in May Manchester United will be proclaimed champions for a third successive year and the seventh time in nine seasons since the Premiership began.

It can also be assumed that the news will be greeted with critical acclaim grown mechanical by frequent repetition, along with the now-familiar, if none too optimistic hope that someone somewhere will give United a better contest next time.

Championship hat-tricks, unlike League and FA Cup doubles, are still comparatively rare. Only Huddersfield Town, Arsenal and Liverpool achieved the feat in the old Football League and even Anfield's triumph is now 16 years old.

Yet even if Sir Alex Ferguson does win the title three years running the plaudits will pale alongside those showered on the Manchester United manager just over 18 months ago when his team completed the treble of league, FA Cup and European Cup.

Intermingled with the applause, moreover, will be two questions concerning the future at Old Trafford: is this as good as it gets and when will the present vein of success peter out? Even the richest gold strikes become exhausted eventually.

It is never wise to assume a team have reached their peak but should United surpass their present consistently high standards of performance in the Premiership, while so obviously playing within themselves, then the prospects for potential challengers are grim indeed.

Last season Manchester United won the championship by 18 points from Arsenal. If they beat Liverpool at home tomorrow Arsène Wenger's team will go to Tottenham on Monday night nine points behind. And this remember, is only the beginning of the two-month period when United, free of distractions in the Uefa Champions League, usually take an unshakeable hold on events at home.

So where might it all end? Not in domestic failure this time, surely, although Ferguson might still regard the season as disappointing if his team fail to reach the last four of the European Cup at the very least.

No, the serious questions about Manchester United's future will start to be asked next season, at the end of which Ferguson is due to retire as manager. Originally he intended making a complete break with Old Trafford but now he is likely to stay at the club in some capacity.

Ferguson insists his role will not interfere with the running of the senior team but the mere presence of such a successful predecessor might prove daunting for his successor in the way that the shadow of Sir Matt Busby darkened the paths of Wilf McGuinness, Frank O'Farrell and Tommy Docherty who followed him at Old Trafford in the late 60s and early 70s.

Either way much of next season will be taken up with speculation concerning Ferguson's successor, with David O'Leary a likely favourite after the way his Leeds side have performed in the Champions League and Martin O'Neill not far behind him should Celtic break Rangers' hold on the Scottish title for only the third time in 15 years.

Whoever takes over from Ferguson there will be a break in the continuity which has sustained Manchester United since 1993, when they won the English championship after a prolonged interval of 26 years. And while there is no sign of the continuity on the field being disrupted, not when Ferguson can fill a team with youth for a Worthington Cup game and still take Sunderland to extra time on Wearside, the contracts of certain leading players will come up for renewal at around about the same time as the change of manager.

Doubtless the likes of David Beckham and Ryan Giggs will see out their playing careers at Old Trafford along with Roy Keane, but how far will United's plc go to bring the club's wage structure into line with the salaries being paid in Italy and Spain? And when it comes to buying more players, with the transfer system now likely to survive the rigours of European law, to what extent will United be prepared to match fees which will almost certainly reach £50million during the next two years?

Compared to the sums paid by Real Madrid for Luis Figo (£37m) and Lazio for Hernan Crespo (£35m) the success Manchester United have achieved under Ferguson has been cheap. His three most significant signings - Peter Schmeichel, Eric Cantona and Roy Keane - cost a total of £5.2m. The next United manager might spend 10 times this amount and get less for his money.

The crucial period will be when whoever is in charge has to turn the team around. Youth is on United's side for the moment but their leading scorer this season, Teddy Sheringham, is 34 and Keane and Andy Cole will both be 30 next autumn, though Cole and Sheringham are out of contract for next season.

The United of the 60s withered on the vine and were relegated six years after winning the European Cup. In the 80s nothing seemed more certain than the onward march of Liverpool, but they have marked time since 1990.

Next season, if not this one, could be the watershed of the latest, possibly the greatest Manchester United team. If only others hoping to take their place had similar enduring qualities. Even Arsenal cannot see that far ahead.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Villa rocked by James transfer bid

fields.headline: Villa rocked by James transfer bid
fields.trailText: David James embroidered Aston Villa's reputation as a club big names would rather leave than join yesterday when he handed in a transfer request.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's unwanted reputation as the club football's big names would rather leave than join was further embroidered yesterday when their goalkeeper David James submitted an official transfer request.

The England international's simmering, long-term disagreement with the midlands club reached an unpleasant but predictable climax when he announced he had no intention of accepting Villa's offer of a new contract and wished to leave.

The former Watford and Liverpool player is adamant his decision is in no way financially motivated but due simply to Villa not matching his vision. "For me, money is not the main concern, " said James. "It is all about the direction this club is heading in. I need to be satisfied that the club harbours the same ambitions as I do." Villa's captain Gareth Southgate cited almost identical reasons when he asked for a transfer last summer.

John Gregory, the Villa manager, offered James a new, 3-year deal last month which would have given him financial parity with the club's top earners, Paul Merson and Dion Dublin.

James's decision will strengthen the resolve of those Villa supporters who have been campaigning for sweeping boardroom changes, believing the club is no longer capable of launching a realistic challenge to the Premiership's elite.

Recently some Villa fans - a minority but a vociferous minority - has been demanding that the long-serving chairman Doug Ellis hand over the corporate chequebook to Gregory or stand down. It seems he is reluctant to do either.

If James departs he will follow a well-trodden path marked by such as Dwight Yorke, Stan Collymore, Benito Carbone and Steve Watson.

Although James recently won an international recall after three years, playing in the friendly in Italy, it is unclear where his next port of call will be if he carries out his threat to leave Villa Park.

The only leading Premiership club apparently actively seeking a new goalkeeper are Arsenal. But it is debatable whether Arsène Wenger would invest in a player who may well have lived down the nickname of "Calamity James" but who is still prone to lapses in concentration and inconsistency.

James's seeming inability to learn from countless mistakes ended his Liverpool career, Gérard Houllier offloading him to Villa 18 months ago for £1.7m.

Now, of James's desire to leave Villa, Ian Robathan, chairman of the Independent Supporters' Association, said: "I'm not shocked by this - I'm not even surprised. We now have two of our senior players wanting away because they say the club lacks ambition.

"David James can see he isn't going to win things at Villa. We are not challenging for things and this has finally hit home with the players. We are now bracketed with Leicester and Tottenham when we want to be bracketed with Manchester United and Arsenal."

The hunt for Robbie Keane intensified yesterday when Chelsea agreed a £12m fee with Internazionale for the Republic of Ireland striker.

But Chelsea are understood not to be confident about landing the 20-year-old because he would prefer to stay in Italy to prove himself after joining Inter only in August for £12m.

Keane said last night: "I've got a contract [with Inter] for five years and as far as I'm concerned I'm staying here. I'm very happy here at the moment. I just want to get myself back fit and hopefully work myself back into the team."

However, now Inter admit they are ready to sell, he must decide whether a return to the Premiership would be wiser.

Although Keane has a choice of Premiership clubs if he does come back - West Ham failed with a £10m offer on Thursday - the player would prefer Leeds. However, it is believed Inter want the Leeds midfielder Olivier Dacourt as part of the deal and David O'Leary is unwilling to approve that move.

Another option is for Keane to go on loan until the end of the season to another Serie A club, with Napoli the most likely.

All Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson would say about the projected deal yesterday was: "We have had discussions with Inter Milan about Robbie Keane."

At least Chelsea's offer shows they are determined to reinvest the £12m they received from Rangers for Tore Andre Flo.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Vega chance to sparkle while on loan to Celtic

fields.headline: Vega chance to sparkle while on loan to Celtic
fields.trailText: The Tottenham defender Ramon Vega has joined Celtic on loan until the end of the season.
fields.body:
The Tottenham defender Ramon Vega has joined Celtic on loan until the end of the season and could earn a permanent move if he impresses his new manager Martin O'Neill.

The 29-year-old Switzerland international, who recently lost his Spurs place to the 20-year-old Alton Thelwell, could make his Celtic debut at home to Aberdeen today.

Celtic have taken over Vega's Spurs contract, which expires in the summer. "He is free to speak to anyone he wants in January and it is the little period before Christmas that is important to us," O'Neill said. "Then after the break we will take it on from there."

Celtic have defensive injury problems as they prepare for five matches before the winter break. Vega's time at White Hart Lane was badly affected by injuries but O'Neill said: "Hopefully that's behind him."

Watford's manager Graham Taylor has signed Carlton Palmer on a three-month loan from Coventry. The midfielder won all 18 of his England caps under Taylor and arrives as Watford look to end a run of five successive defeats.

"I am looking for what I consider to be leaders," Taylor said. "This kind of player and person is more and more difficult to find these days."

Arsenal have sold the Liberian striker Christopher Wreh to the Saudi Arabian club Al-Hilal Al Saudi for an undisclosed fee. They have also loaned the 20-year-old forward Graham Barrett to Bristol Rovers.

The former Leeds goalkeeper Mark Beeney, who retired 18 months ago because of an achilles problem, has joined the Conference side Doncaster.

Uefa has finalised rules that will allow it to force clubs found guilty of promoting or allowing racist behaviour to play matches behind closed doors. "This is a very strong signal that Uefa is not willing to show leniency when these incidents occur," said Uefa's general secretary Gerhard Aigner.

Cowdenbeath have sacked their manager Peter Cormack after only 10 days in which he did not take charge of a match. The club said it would not discuss the reasons because the matter could go to an industrial tribunal.

Greenock Morton have been put into administration by their owner Hugh Scott. The Scottish Football Association is to investigate Arbroath after the club fielded two ineligible players in a Scottish Cup first-round game against Montrose.

webTitle: Sparks set to fly in steel city derby

fields.headline: Sparks set to fly in steel city derby
fields.trailText: Unlike Merseyside where families are divided, in Sheffield you are either a Blade or an Owl, and today's sell-out derby game will be one of the highlights of both clubs' season.
fields.body:
New year is normally the time reserved for hope and optimism, but today half of Sheffield will get an early consignment when Sheffield United entertain Sheffield Wednesday.

Unlike Merseyside where families are divided, in Sheffield you are either a Blade or an Owl, and today's sell-out game will be one of the highlights of both clubs' season.

The match has been given added spice by both managers squabbling over the lessons learned from their Worthington Cup tie earlier in the season, which Wednesday won 2-1 after extra time. Sheffield United manager Neil Warnock claimed a moral victory by stating that his side were in better shape than Wednesday, but Paul Jewell quickly added that he had only played the youth team .

Jewell was alluding to the fact that with so many players having left Hillsborough he has had to rely on several promising youngsters coming through the ranks. He is hopeful that the local derby will lift his players above the normal pride and passion associated with these games. He said: "In derby matches, form goes out of the window, and we must improve greatly on our last two performances to get a result. It is going to be tough for us but hopefully we will make it even tougher for them."

Jewell will be hoping that the work ethic he has attempted to instil in his players will return after last week's heavy home defeat at the hands of Stockport. He has brought in Terry Cooke on loan from Manchester City to provide the service to Andy Booth and Efan Ekoku, and he was one of the main inspirations behind Wednesday's mini-revival as they moved away from the bottom of the table in October.

Ekoku and Booth are both big target men who rely on the quality of the crosses for them to be at their best, so Cooke's contribution could be crucial. Ekoku was the two goal hero when Wednesday beat United at Hillsborough in October.

Across the city, manager Neil Warnock is glad to be playing Wednesday so soon after October's cup defeat. Warnock, who as a boyhood United fan is familiar with what the game means to the supporters.

Like Jewell he is a strict believer in the work ethic and doesn't anticipate a pretty game. "We're ready for anything and it will be physical , but we can cope with that," he said. "I've told the lads to make sure they enjoy themselves from the first minute to the last because it is a great occasion."

One man who can vouch for this is former Blades' goalkeeper Alan Kelly who spent seven years with the club. Kelly, now with Blackburn, remembers the derby games very vividly. "The 1993 cup semi-final at Wembley was my best ever footballing experience," he said, "even better than representing my country. There were 150,000 balloons, a tremendous noise, and it was an unbelievable but a great experience."

Kelly was the subject of a possible loan move to Wednesday earlier in the season, but he is glad his loyalty wasn't tested. webTitle: Old Firm back to square one

fields.headline: Old Firm back to square one
fields.standfirst: Rangers and Celtic angered by European decree, reports  Graham Spiers
fields.trailText: Uefa have flatly rejected a proposal put to them by Celtic, Rangers and other major clubs to form a new European league for the so-called big clubs from small countries.
fields.body:
Rangers and Celtic were dealt another aggressive blow from peace-loving Switzerland yesterday. Uefa's executive committee met outside Geneva and issued a decree that flatly rejected a proposal, put to them by the Old Firm and other major clubs on Tuesday, which sought a new European league for the so-called big clubs from small countries.

The Old Firm, along with 10 other teams including PSV Eindhoven, Ajax, Anderlecht and Benfica, have long struggled to fulfil their vast potential by breaking free from their financially constricting national leagues. In their quest they have met a dogged opponent in Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive.

Aigner was up to his old tricks yesterday - not for the first time he asked Rangers and Celtic to go home and think again. "The proposal to install a special league for a limited number of clubs is rejected," said Aigner. "We cannot look at a special league just for these clubs. Besides, is there really a market for another league?"

Aigner in the past 18 months has developed a habit of smiling at Rangers and Celtic officials before biting them with Uefa bulletins days later. On Tuesday, the Rangers secretary Campbell Ogilvie and Allan MacDonald, the Celtic chief executive, had a meeting in Switzerland with Uefa officials at which a distinct impression of sympathy and understanding shone all around. MacDonald and Ogilvie had both expected yesterday's announcement to include acknowledgement of their plight as well as some outlining of fresh plans. Instead, they now have to return to the drawing board.

It is the latest frustrating twist for the Glasgow giants, whose financial muscle would put them among Europe's elite were they able to capitalise on a market beyond Scotland. Polls and surveys have repeatedly put Rangers and Celtic among the top 25 richest clubs in the world, who nonetheless remain unable to capitalise on the fact through being tethered to the Scottish league.

The proposal they put to Uefa certainly needed tweaking but had been hailed by analysts as a decent enough formula. It proposed having Rangers, Celtic, Ajax and others playing in a new European league, which would be ready to run within the next two years, with a feeder system applying promotion and relegation each season from the indigenous leagues of the six countries involved. The top six of the new league would also, should Uefa acquiesce, be granted access to the continuing Champions League.

"The simple fact is that if we remain in Scotland we can certainly survive, but we cannot thrive as our size and potential would allow," said MacDonald. "If you look at both Rangers and Celtic we are easily drawing crowds of 50,000 to 60,000 each week, and in both cases it would be greater if our stadiums permitted. Ajax also play to big crowds in Amsterdam. These clubs have a bigger pull than many of the other top teams in Europe but are hampered by not being able to get a bite at the cherry."

The cherry in question is the increasingly succulent television money. The Champions League, already a very prof itable competition, is due up for a renegotiated TV deal at the end of 2001-02. By that time, teams completing a reasonable number of matches could walk away with at least £20m each. This season, merely by dint of belonging to the Premiership, teams like Bradford City and Southampton are earning around £8m a season. Rangers and Celtic, with a significantly greater fan base, currently earn less than £3m each from local television revenue.

But sympathy for the Old Firm must remain tempered. There is a feeling that both these teams are driven forward in part by the hash they have made of trying to make a bigger impact in Europe than they have. It is now 29 years since Rangers and Celtic were both in European competition beyond Christmas.

David Taylor, the chief executive of the Scottish FA, has been supportive of the Old Firm's case at Uefa, but yesterday said they had no option but to keep trying.

"It would seem highly unlikely that they could pursue their case going down any other road," said Taylor. "Football in the international arena is governed by the statutes of Uefa and Fifa. It would seem senseless for either of the Old Firm to pursue this without the footballing family."

The other teams involved - Feyenoord, Club Bruges, Sporting Lisbon, Brondby, FC Copenhagen and AIK Solna - must now re-group for a campaign that is requiring patience as much as persuasion.

webTitle: Turf war fear for Turf Moor

fields.headline: Turf war fear for Turf Moor
fields.standfirst: Old wounds will be reopened in the big Lancashire derby tomorrow, reports  Dominic Fifield
fields.trailText: Old wounds will be reopened in the big Lancashire derby tomorrow, reports Dominic Fifield.
fields.body:
Absence may make the heart grow fonder but, after 17 years of simmering frustration, the lid will be lifted tomorrow on east Lancashire's spiciest hot pot. Forget Manchester United versus Liverpool or the north London handbags; such annual bickering will pale into insignificance when Burnley welcome Blackburn Rovers to Turf Moor.

The two managers, flanked by their captains, attended a press conference this week in a joint appeal for calm at the match Alan Hansen predicted as the game of the season. "Is it a big game or something?" quipped the Blackburn manager Graeme Souness, his moustache dripping with sarcasm.

"Must be," replied Burnley's Stan Ternent before stressing good-natured rivalry, the need to cut out "hanky-panky" on the terraces and that all this was "just another three points". None of the 22,500 crammed into Turf Moor will be fooled.

Burnley have not beaten their bitter rivals since 1979. In 1982-83 Blackburn achieved a league double over the Clarets with Simon Garner scoring twice at Ewood Park in April in a 2-1 victory. The visiting Burnley fans responded by throwing a smoke bomb on to the pitch and a bottle at the Rovers goalkeeper Terry Gennoe before tearing down the roof of the Darwen End. When Garner slotted home the decisive penalty, the travelling support tried to burn the stand down, despite being in it at the time, as a full-scale riot erupted.

"Most rivalries cool off if you don't play each other for a long time, but ours has intensified," said the Burnley fan Jeremy Wilson. "It had always been a traditional local derby - feisty but fans did mix occasionally in the Cricket Field end - but there was more of a hooligan problem in the early 1980s. The Burnley Suicide Squad infiltrated opponents' ends and that helped create the tension. With the contrasting fortunes of the clubs ever since, bad feeling has been simmering for years."

Scuffles on the east Lancashire terraces were reported as far back as the 1880s and in 1971 widespread fighting broke out at a mid-season friendly that Rovers won 2-0. The long period without a derby has prevented either club from unleashing its own pent-up aggression. "There's been a lot of hype and bravado about his game," added Wilson. "It's supposed to be a big advertisement for east Lancs football and I really hope trouble doesn't kick off, but we could well end up looking at a hatefest."

The authorities are fully aware of that. Kenneth Wolstenholme will be at Turf Moor commentating for Burnley's website, but every effort has been made to ensure there will be no people on the pitch. Lancashire police has liaised extensively with both clubs, set up a tip-off line and drafted extra officers into the town in an attempt to quell any violence.

The police originally requested an 11am kick-off with away fans barred. But instead it goes on at 4pm, with live coverage on Sky. Some 3,000 Rovers fans will travel; many supporters, home and way, will arrive at Turf Moor after time in the pub, which holds the additional attraction of the live midday match broadcast of Manchester United v Liverpool.

"This could be a special day," Souness believes and for genuine supporters it promises to be just that. The clubs have had contrasting fortunes since that infamous game 17 years ago. Blackburn, having flirted with promotion to the old First Division, were restored to the top flight by Kenny Dalglish and Jack Walker's millions and gorged on success for six years, winning the Premiership along the way. Meanwhile, Burnley sank without trace.

On May 9 1987 they beat Leyton Orient in front of heaving terraces to preserve their League status. In 1991 they lost 2-1 on aggregate to Torquay in the Fourth Division play-offs while a light aeroplane circled above Turf Moor trailing the message: "Staying down 4 ever, love Rovers. Ha, ha, ha." Rumours abounded that Garner had paid for the stunt.

"That was a return of serve after Burnley fans staged a staying-down party when Crystal Palace beat us in the 1989 play-offs," said Dave Metcalfe, editor of the Rovers fanzine 4,000 Holes.

"I stood on the Longside watching the play-off game when the famous plane went over," said Burnley's leading scorer Andy Payton. "I don't want to stir any rivalry up, but obviously it is there."

There was a mini-revival, but while Alan Shearer held aloft the Premiership trophy in 1995, Burnley licked their wounds after relegation back to the Second Division. "The perception that Blackburn purchased their recent success has really grated with Burnley fans," said Wilson, which makes the Clarets' current two-point advantage all the more satisfying.

"We have been living in their shadow for a long time," added Peter Heywood, chairman of the Clarets' Independent Supporters' Association. "Rovers are our only rivals. We are a football town in a way that perhaps Blackburn is not and we've watched while they've had all this money thrown at them."

Not that the rivalry is one-way. On opening day this season Rovers, pre-season promotion favourites, beat Palace 2-0 but chants of "Bring on the bastards" echoed around Ewood.

"Burnley have had 17 years of low self-image watching our success, but that's exactly what we had to put up with in the 1960s while we were losing 7-1 at Shrewsbury and they were winning the League. The younger fans may not realise it, but this is role reversal," said Metcalfe. "We've had an Icarus-style fall from grace and playing Burnley again symbolises how far we have descended. Hence the fear this could be nemesis and they might win."

For the Rovers squad, supplemented by the £1.75m return of Henning Berg from Manchester United, this promises to be a new experience. And Souness, a veteran of derbies in Glasgow, Liverpool and Istanbul, was unprepared for the frenzied build-up. "I just hope it's an entertaining and exciting game; I'm really looking forward to it," he said.

For Burnley, Rovers' visit is the juicy filling in a sandwich of derbies - last week they lost at Preston; next week they host Bolton. It is the first time since 1961 this quartet have been in the same division; now they are all challenging for promotion.

A "fantastic" prospect, said Souness. Local pride may stretch to that view, but not tomorrow.

fields.headline: Tardelli condemns Inter bus bomber
fields.trailText: Internazionale's coach Marco Tardelli has fiercely criticised the fan who hurled a petrol bomb at Inter's bus on Thursday night, saying a tragedy was only narrowly avoided..
fields.body:
Internazionale's coach Marco Tardelli has fiercely criticised the fan who hurled a petrol bomb at Inter's bus on Thursday night, saying a tragedy was only narrowly avoided..

"I just cannot accept this type of violence bursting its way into football," he said. "For me, after the Heysel disaster, this is the worst that's ever happened to me in football. This was a tragedy that was only narrowly avoided."

In likening the incident to the Heysel disaster at the 1985 European Cup final between Juventus and Liverpool in Brussels in which 39 fans lost their lives, Tardelli indicated the fright suffered by the players.

The incendiary device, which was thrown by an unidentified supporter as the team arrived at the San Siro for an Italian Cup quarter-final against Parma, bounced off the bus windows and exploded on the tarmac, where it was soon extinguished by the team's police escort.

No one was injured but Tardelli stressed: "If the Molotov had broken through the bus window it would have been terrible. The problem about this incident is that it is not an isolated one. Football is becoming a real battleground these days. Next thing, they'll be shooting at us from the grandstand."

Players have in the past been insulted and a variety of missiles, including coins, tomatoes and bottles, have often been thrown at team buses, but this is by far the most serious incident of its kind at Inter.

The bus driver stopped to allow the players to get off as fast as possible, amid a haze of smoke and extinguisher fumes. Although Inter's owner Massimo Moratti asked in the dressing room if anyone wished not to play, all the players insisted they would go on with the game.

The match was a dreary non-event, ending in a 0-0 draw and played in front of only 1,000 spectators after Inter had lost the first leg 6-1.

Inter have had a desperately disappointing season, having been eliminated from the preliminary round of the Champions League by the Swedish side Helsingborg. They are 10th in Serie A, having lost four of their 10 matches.

fields.headline: Roman rite decides Eriksson's fate
fields.standfirst: The England manager-elect gets a warning from the owner at Lazio
fields.trailText: The England manager-elect gets a warning from the owner at Lazio ahead of the all-important derby game against Roma.
fields.body:
"In the derby, the only thing that matters is to win. A win would get us back on the right track. Unlike us, Roma can afford to lose. We, on the other hand, have to win."

The speaker is Lazio's millionaire owner Sergio Cragnotti. In case anyone had any illusions about how much is riding on tomorrow night's Rome derby between Lazio and Roma, Cragnotti spelt it out loud and clear this week.

Cragnotti's words were intended as motivation for his players. Inadvertently, however, he added weight to the suggestion that, if Lazio lose, England's manager-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson could be on his way to Blighty sooner rather than later.

Defeat would be Lazio's sixth of the season and their fourth in seven matches. Recent losses to Parma (Serie A), Leeds (Champions League) and Udinese (in a midweek Italian Cup elimination) have added to the pressure on the Swedish coach.

Notwithstanding the numerous votes of confidence from the Cragnotti family and the fact that most Lazio fans seem willing to stand by Eriksson, defeat by the loathed city cousins could prove one too many.

The Rome derby has long been the "hottest" of all in Italy. In a year when it brings together the reigning champions and the league leaders, it has gone nuclear.

Certainly, nothing would give Roma and their fans more pleasure than to put one across their city rivals, further complicating Lazio's already compromised season.

Not surprisingly, this is a game everyone wants to see. The Olympic Stadium will be filled with 75,000 fans, including the Hollywood stars Cameron Diaz and Leonardo Di Caprio, generating a record £1.27million box office. The match is also due to be watched by television viewers in more than 200 countries, not to mention by an 800-strong press gallery.

When tickets went on sale here this week police had to be summoned to restore order as fans, many of whom had camped out on the footpath all night, protested noisily at delays. Those who failed to get a ticket can find consolation by tuning in to the local pay television station Stream, whose coverage begins at 8am tomorrow, 12 hours before kick-off.

As for the team selections, again Eriksson appears in greater difficulty than his opposite number Fabio Capello. As against Leeds, Eriksson is forced to gamble on the unfit Argentine playmaker Juan Sebastian Veron and his out-of-form compatriot, the striker Hernan Crespo.

Eriksson may well field the temperamental Yugoslav defender Sinisa Mihajlovic, who did his already tarnished reputation little good by being sent off against Udinese on Tuesday.

Worse still for Eriksson is the fact that Marcelo Salas, by far his most in-form attacker, is an injury doubt. That, plus the sheer pressure of the occasion, may tempt him to opt for a five-man midfield which would leave Crespo alone up front and send Dino Baggio on a man-marking mission against Roma's playmaker and captain Francesco Totti.

Unlike Lazio, Roma have swept all before them in recent days, emphasised by a 3-0 Uefa Cup win at Hamburg that set up a fourth-round clash with Liverpool. Beaten only once (2-0 by Internazionale) in 10 Serie A games so far, Roma have to be favourites.

Capello, however, is unconvinced by the Lazio "crisis". "Sure, Lazio are in trouble as far as results are concerned," he says, "but not as far as the quality of their game goes. I saw them against Leeds and they played well. They're always a side you have to be wary of. They have so many talented individuals that you have to respect them."

Capello can call out all his big guns, starting with the biggest of all, the Argentine striker Gabriel Batistuta, partnered by Marco Delvecchio and supported by Totti. The Baggio-Totti clash and that between Batistuta and Lazio's captain Alessandro Nesta could hold the key.

And Eriksson? "If you look at Roma at the moment, they are very good," he says. "They're the best team in Serie A just now and deserve to be out in front ... It will be very, very difficult for us".

It sure will.

webTitle: Hitman Heskey reaps reward of Houllier's forward thinking

fields.headline: Hitman Heskey reaps reward of Houllier's forward thinking
fields.standfirst: Ian Ross  talks to the £11m striker who tomorrow confronts United after 12 goals in as many games
fields.trailText: Ian Ross talks to £11m striker Emile Heskey who tomorrow confronts United after 12 goals in as many games.
fields.body:
Mid-April, only weeks after a career change that had seen him swap a smallish pond for a very large pool, and Emile Heskey was enduring a spot of local difficulty. As an £11m striker, the supporters of his new club, Liverpool, more or less assumed Heskey would spend his Saturday afternoons using to good advantage his more celebrated physical attributes, namely a body-builder's physique and a turn of speed which is the envy of most county-standard athletes.

The expectation was that Heskey would become Liverpool's first battering ram-style centre-forward in many years - possibly since Michael Robinson ran himself daft in the famous red shirt back in the mid-80s in the mistaken, if endearing, belief that hard work will eventually a great player make.

With bated breath the masses waited and waited for Heskey to emerge. It was possibly stage-fright, it might have been insecurity, it could even have been an inferiority complex, but it seemed that each and every time Heskey collected the ball he headed not for goal but for the touchline, drawn inexorably from the centre of the action to the periphery.

His critics - and there were many at the time - had the answer. Not only was Heskey guilty of dereliction of duty, not only was he unable to cope with life in the fast lane, he was simply a waste of money.

"I take the point but I think it's what I did down the wings at Leicester City that earned me a reputation as a decent player," says Heskey in his defence.

Heskey scored three times in his 12 senior appearances last season. It was an unremarkable return but one made memorable by the frequent response of his manager. Gérard Houllier clambered on to his soap-box to launch spirited, chest-thumping defences of the most expensive player ever to join a club where there have been so many truly great contributors that the merely proficient have been swallowed up and forgotten.

Like a father chiding a wayward son, Houllier constantly reassured Heskey that he was a good player with the potential for excellence, that he did have the capacity to succeed and, perhaps most significant, that he was a far, far better player than he believed himself to be.

It was, it would seem, all a matter of confidence. Or rather the lack of it.

"I have said before that maybe at times I haven't had the belief in myself that I should have had, but I do feel that is starting to change now," said Heskey in an accent that betrays his Leicester roots.

"I heard comments from people questioning my ability when I signed but, to be honest, the same things were said about me at Leicester. I knew it would take time to adapt to life at a new club but I think I did quite well towards the end of last season.

"This year I knew exactly what it was I had to do and I have worked hard to ensure I give myself the best possible chance of playing well. I do enjoy working for the manager here. He's different to my previous manager at Leicester, Martin O'Neill.

"Martin was a great pre-match motivator; he really got you going. Gérard is calmer but he insists that everything is done correctly, everything must be done his way," he added.

To say the very least, the transformation has been dramatic. Heskey arrived on Merseyside wondering precisely how he was supposed to lay claim to a regular first-team place at a club which boasted Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler.

Now, after 12 goals in his past 12 full games, he is the man, the first choice. These days it is £25m-rated Owen and £15m-rated Fowler who apprehensively await the pinning of the team-sheet to the dressing-room door.

Heskey's worth to Houllier's new-look and still-maturing team was underscored last weekend when he was rested for the game against Ipswich Town - and Liverpool duly slipped to a first home defeat in seven months.

Afterwards, the Ipswich striker Marcus Stewart - admittedly with mischievous hat perched at a jaunty angle - insisted he and his team-mates sensed it would be their day when informed that Heskey would start the afternoon on the substitutes' bench.

"As a young player, I would like to play in every game," said Heskey. "Certainly as a striker in form I'd like to play every game. But, as the manager said, this will be a long, hard season. I'm happy to go with what he wants. He knows what he is doing and we all trust him.

"Things are going so well for me here at the moment but, you know what, I still don't feel as though I'm definitely first choice up front. Look at the players here - Owen, Fowler, Smicer, Berger, Barmby. It's some list, isn't it?

"It was different for me at Leicester. I took my place in the team for granted because we didn't have many forwards. At Liverpool it's not just a case of having to play well in matches ... I really believe you have to do well every day in training. You are always on trial here, always being watched and assessed. I sometimes feel that if I have a bad day in training I'll be left out of the next game."

He won't. Houllier loves the bones of him, the fans have swiftly revised their collective opinion of him and his team-mates are slowly coaxing out of its shell, the warm and endearing personality which for so long has remained hidden behind a mask of youthful shyness.

"I'm a quiet sort of a lad, I always have been," he said. "But I'm very happy here at Liverpool. The other players have been great to me and so have the supporters. I couldn't have asked for a warmer welcome."

Many seasoned Anfield observers have drawn comparisons between Heskey and Ian Rush, arguably Liverpool's greatest-ever striker and a man of similar temperament who was also intimidated by the prospect of saying boo to a goose during his formative years.

"Emile does remind me of myself," said Rush. "When I first arrived at Liverpool, I was so shy and withdrawn. But you grow up very quickly at a big football club and he'll be just fine. As he becomes more and more confident out on the pitch, so he'll become more and more confident away from it.

"If you are the man who is expected to score the goals, it's all about confidence. When he first joined the club he wouldn't take up the kind of goal-scoring positions he's getting himself into now. Six months ago it would probably have been Emile crossing the ball rather than getting on the end of a cross and scoring."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: The world view from the parish pump
fields.trailText: This week's world view from the parish pump.
fields.body:
 As usual, Fifa's world player of the year award provoked some imaginative voting from the 150 international coaches asked to select their top three. John H Layton of Pakistan gave the nod to Wolves reserve Sami Al-Jaber. Charlie Cook (Turks and Caicos Islands) saw similar virtue in Hibernian's Russell Latapy. But top prize for parochialism goes to Costa Rica's Gilson Nunes, who judged the world's three best to be Paulo Wanchope, Hernan Medford and Jafeth Soto. All of Costa Rica, naturally.

 A more welcome addition to the 1966 industry arrives this week, a curious collection of memories compiled by Norman Shiel, Voices of 1966 (Tempus). W Goss of the Amateur FA, for example, recalls the warmth of the hospitality extended to Brazil at the Crystal Palace National Recreation Centre, where the squad stayed overnight on the way home. "One had to have sympathy given the spartan nature of the 'cells' (for they were but little more) and for the fact that just about the only food which could be found in the restaurant was packets of crisps, it being declared 'too late for sustenance'."

 You know you can believe it when Harry Redknapp insists on West Ham's official website: "I never said I was interested in Henning Berg." Unless, of course, you read his equally official personal site, where he says: "There are two players here at home who interest me a lot. I'm keen on Christian Dailly ... The other is Henning Berg."

 An unusual problem for Notts County this week. They had to clear the pitch of a number of dead fish, washed in by the flooded River Trent. "I'm not sure what kind of fish they were," said a member of County's staff. Surely young salmon, dreaming of rising at the far post to nod home.

 It would be wrong to leave the subject of non-League nicknames without referring to Halesowen Town, who are known as The Yeltz. Why? The website www.yeltzland.net takes up the story: "The truth is - nobody really knows. A Yeltz is simply someone from Halesowen." Another mystery solved.

 It must have seemed like a good idea for Crystal Palace to prepare a souvenir reproduction of the programme from their game against Sunderland on August 13 1969, their first win in the old First Division. It was meant to come out for Tuesday's Worthington Cup tie. Unfortunately, Palace use the same printers as Charlton and the insert found its way instead into the programme for their game against Manchester United - though most were frantically removed in time. Then the Sunderland game was called off anyway. If you've got a surviving copy, it might be worth, ooh, at least £2.50.

 Australia's National Soccer League is rapidly filling up with new clubs, some solid, some flaky, but all at home with talk of "product" and "target markets". Parramatta Power and Eastern Pride meet in Bathurst today (neither is based there - it's a target market). A nod of appreciation, then, to the enduring virtues of Power defender Alex Tobin, who is due to break the NSL record of 445 games - all but 10 with one club, Adelaide City. "If I do a job on my bloke and we keep a clean sheet, that's enough for me," Tobin said. More power (though, ideally, less Power) to him.

 So, happy Christmas. Sadly, we cannot yet report that even the Great War is over. In his new book, Middlesbrough's Steve Gibson writes of Fabrizio Ravanelli: "He was not the sort of guy you needed in the trenches. The first thing you would do was shoot him because you knew he would shoot you." If Rav had known Boro saw football as the Somme revisited, maybe he would have stayed somewhere safer.

mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Tongues wag as students line up Caniggia

fields.headline: Tongues wag as students line up Caniggia
fields.standfirst: Jim White on the latest election saga
fields.trailText: Tongues wag as Dundee students line up Caniggia for rector and the truth about Wimbledon's woeful home form is revealed - it's not sex but Sam that is sapping the team's energy.
fields.body:
Now things are finally clear election-wise in America (the man who gained the smaller number of votes is the winner) we can turn our attention to another vital democratic contest. At Dundee University, everyone is getting very excited that Claudio Caniggia might, in early February, be elected the university's rector. If certain undergraduates get their way, Caniggia - the former Argentina international, coke head and the man once caught on camera snogging Diego Maradona (and, yes, tongues were involved) - could well be voted in as the students' representative on the university council.

Caniggia has been causing something of a seismic disturbance in the east of Scotland since he arrived in Dundee. And not just because his wife cuts such an exotic sight in the local branch of Tesco. In the past Dundee FC didn't attract players of his pedigree. But manager Ivano Bonetti, plus several hundredweight of loose change a week, persuaded the player to come over from Buenos Aires at the start of this season.

"He's going down an absolute storm," says David McKinnie, a football correspondent for Scottish Television who has seen him play several times this season. "Against Celtic last Sunday he was outstanding. What is amazing about him is that the pace is still there. I saw him putting in some extra training on his own the other week, so he's committed too."

Dundee fans love him: blond wigs to match his scraggly locks have become an essential fashion item at Dens Park. Whether small packets of substances in the back pocket are another is not yet clear. And student supporters of the club thought it would be a mark of their appreciation for the newcomer to nominate him for the post of rector, a position voted for by the students every three years.

"As yet the nomination is not official," says John Cunningham, the president of the students union. "Students have to gather 50 signatures to back a bid. But there appears to be a head of steam building up behind a nomination."

Were Caniggia to be voted in, he would not be the first footballer to find himself in such a position. And before accepting the job, he might be wise to have a word with John Colquhoun, the former Hearts player, who was elected rector at Edinburgh University in 1997.

"At first I just thought it might be a bit of a laugh," says Colquhoun. "I didn't know what it involved. But if you do the job properly, it's a fair commitment. Like most footballers, I was someone who had mentally ducked out of education at about the age of 12. So for me the learning curve was incredible. I suddenly found myself chair of the governing body of a community of 23,000 people. The moral and legal responsibility of that was staggering."

According to Colquhoun, being the rector of one of the Scottish ancients, as the old-established universities are known, is not a simple matter of turning up on campus to accept the adulation of the students. The minimum requirement is to attend university council meetings six times a year. But many rectors become far more involved.

"The job is what you make of it," says Colquhoun. "Edinburgh was very clever in using me to take their message into schools that might not normally consider sending people to the university. I enjoyed myself hugely, but I couldn't stand for a second term because I'd just started a business and I didn't have the time to do the job properly."

There has been a trend over the past few years to nominate celebrities for the post because the attention they bring can help publicise student issues. Stephen Fry, who was rector at Dundee for six years, is seen as the model.

"Fry was phenomenally good," says John Cunningham. "But the whole university can suffer if a celebrity rector can't commit the time. Just look at what happened with Ross Kemp at Glasgow."

The Labour-loving luvvie has been, it is commonly considered, a huge disappointment since leaving EastEnders for Glasgow. So how would Caniggia cope? He might have the time now (presiding over a university governing body beats the snooker hall as a way for a footballer to pass his afternoons) but would he be able to commit himself to the full three-year period of office?

Caniggia himself was not available for comment this week, as he was in Rome watching his old chum Diego receive Fifa's award as joint greatest player of the century. But a spokesman for Dundee FC tells me that he is very honoured by the attention.

"Claudio is a very erudite man," says the spokesman. "He is erudite in several languages, though at the moment that doesn't include English."

Never mind Florida and pregnant chads, there could be interesting times ahead in Dundee.

No sex, please - we're off goat-milking in Stavangar

Terry Burton, the Wimbledon manager, is an old-fashioned adherent to the belief that women weaken legs. Seeking a cause for his team's woeful home form, he has blamed nookie, reckoning his players exhaust themselves in the build up to big matches.

"Too many players are having sex the night before a home game," says Burton. "While for away matches they are in a hotel, away from their partners and get plenty of rest."

Since Wimbledon's away performances have been admirable, Burton is minded to make his squad stay in monastic seclusion in a hotel prior to home games, too. But reader Herbie Knott, a Wimbledon fan, writes to tell me it is not sex but Sam that is his team's problem. Sam as in Hammam, the former owner of the club.

"We're missing Sam," says Herbie." Whenever we had a bad spell in the past, Sam would threaten the players with something awful, like a trip to the opera and they'd soon sort themselves out."

fields.bodyText: Now things are finally clear election-wise in America (the man who gained the smaller number of votes is the winner) we can turn our attention to another vital democratic contest. At Dundee University, everyone is getting very excited that Claudio Caniggia might, in early February, be elected the university's rector. If certain undergraduates get their way, Caniggia - the former Argentina international, coke head and the man once caught on camera snogging Diego Maradona (and, yes, tongues were involved) - could well be voted in as the students' representative on the university council. Caniggia has been causing something of a seismic disturbance in the east of Scotland since he arrived in Dundee. And not just because his wife cuts such an exotic sight in the local branch of Tesco. In the past Dundee FC didn't attract players of his pedigree. But manager Ivano Bonetti, plus several hundredweight of loose change a week, persuaded the player to come over from Buenos Aires at the start of this season. "He's going down an absolute storm," says David McKinnie, a football correspondent for Scottish Television who has seen him play several times this season. "Against Celtic last Sunday he was outstanding. What is amazing about him is that the pace is still there. I saw him putting in some extra training on his own the other week, so he's committed too." Dundee fans love him: blond wigs to match his scraggly locks have become an essential fashion item at Dens Park. Whether small packets of substances in the back pocket are another is not yet clear. And student supporters of the club thought it would be a mark of their appreciation for the newcomer to nominate him for the post of rector, a position voted for by the students every three years. "As yet the nomination is not official," says John Cunningham, the president of the students union. "Students have to gather 50 signatures to back a bid. But there appears to be a head of steam building up behind a nomination." Were Caniggia to be voted in, he would not be the first footballer to find himself in such a position. And before accepting the job, he might be wise to have a word with John Colquhoun, the former Hearts player, who was elected rector at Edinburgh University in 1997. "At first I just thought it might be a bit of a laugh," says Colquhoun. "I didn't know what it involved. But if you do the job properly, it's a fair commitment. Like most footballers, I was someone who had mentally ducked out of education at about the age of 12. So for me the learning curve was incredible. I suddenly found myself chair of the governing body of a community of 23,000 people. The moral and legal responsibility of that was staggering." According to Colquhoun, being the rector of one of the Scottish ancients, as the old-established universities are known, is not a simple matter of turning up on campus to accept the adulation of the students. The minimum requirement is to attend university council meetings six times a year. But many rectors become far more involved. "The job is what you make of it," says Colquhoun. "Edinburgh was very clever in using me to take their message into schools that might not normally consider sending people to the university. I enjoyed myself hugely, but I couldn't stand for a second term because I'd just started a business and I didn't have the time to do the job properly." There has been a trend over the past few years to nominate celebrities for the post because the attention they bring can help publicise student issues. Stephen Fry, who was rector at Dundee for six years, is seen as the model. "Fry was phenomenally good," says John Cunningham. "But the whole university can suffer if a celebrity rector can't commit the time. Just look at what happened with Ross Kemp at Glasgow." The Labour-loving luvvie has been, it is commonly considered, a huge disappointment since leaving EastEnders for Glasgow. So how would Caniggia cope? He might have the time now (presiding over a university governing body beats the snooker hall as a way for a footballer to pass his afternoons) but would he be able to commit himself to the full three-year period of office? Caniggia himself was not available for comment this week, as he was in Rome watching his old chum Diego receive Fifa's award as joint greatest player of the century. But a spokesman for Dundee FC tells me that he is very honoured by the attention. "Claudio is a very erudite man," says the spokesman. "He is erudite in several languages, though at the moment that doesn't include English." Never mind Florida and pregnant chads, there could be interesting times ahead in Dundee. No sex, please - we're off goat-milking in Stavangar Terry Burton, the Wimbledon manager, is an old-fashioned adherent to the belief that women weaken legs. Seeking a cause for his team's woeful home form, he has blamed nookie, reckoning his players exhaust themselves in the build up to big matches. "Too many players are having sex the night before a home game," says Burton. "While for away matches they are in a hotel, away from their partners and get plenty of rest." Since Wimbledon's away performances have been admirable, Burton is minded to make his squad stay in monastic seclusion in a hotel prior to home games, too. But reader Herbie Knott, a Wimbledon fan, writes to tell me it is not sex but Sam that is his team's problem. Sam as in Hammam, the former owner of the club. "We're missing Sam," says Herbie." Whenever we had a bad spell in the past, Sam would threaten the players with something awful, like a trip to the opera and they'd soon sort themselves out."  Head Cyclone skis Tyrolia SL100 bindings, S+R, £219.90.

 Campagnolo thin roll-neck fleece (polyester), S+R, £22.

 Snow + Rock own label thermal longjohns (polyester), S+R, £26.95.

 Snow + Rock own label ski socks, S+R, £5.95.

 Phoenix Tornado gloves, S+R £19.95.

 Carrera Power goggles, EB, £19.99.

 Animal knitted "beanie" hat, EB, £11.99.

 Salomon First ski bag, EB, £19.95

Total: £139.73

On the cheap

Ring around your local ski shops and see if any are selling off last season's stock or used skis at reduced prices. (This is obviously more likely in March than in November.) Go to a ski show; some retailers use them to unload old or used stock at reduced prices.

Go to your local dry ski slope and check their noticeboard for used skis or skiwear on sale. Join your local ski club, and enquire about "ski swap" evenings, where members buy and sell used equipment and clothing. Get hold of a ski magazine and check their classified ads. In north London, an excellent second-hand skiwear business is run by Gillian Levy (020-7435 0124).

Stockists

All items listed are all available by mail order from the Ellis Brigham (EB) catalogue (0161-834 5555 or the Snow + Rock (S+R) catalogue (0845 1001000, and shops). New e-tailors such as 9 feet are entering the snowsports market.

Ski tips
Roger Bray

 It might have been expected that an offer of free lessons, lift passes and equipment hire to beginners would have sold out in a few days. But Freshers' Week, a joint initiative by a group of ski destination countries aimed at attracting first-time skiers and snowboarders to the slopes, has clearly not enjoyed quite the success they hoped for. According to a spokesman for the organisers, the Association of Snowsports Countries, several hundred of the January packages remain unsold.

Tour operators offering them are Airtours (08701 577775), Crystal (0870 848 7000), Erna Low (020 7584 2841), First Choice (0870 754 3477), Flexiski (0870 9090329), Neilson (0990 994444), Ski Independence (0870 5550555), Swiss Travel Service (01992 56123), and Thomson (0870 606 1470). The deals are available in 24 resorts in Austria, Canada, France, Switzerland, Slovenia and the US. Most are for the week ending January 27 but some are also available for the previous week.

 Skiers heading for Switzerland from regional airports can cut out the hassle of travelling via London this winter with a new range of fares to Berne on offer from KLM alps. A round trip from Manchester, with a change at Amsterdam's Schiphol, would cost £220.70 including tax, for example. The Swiss airport, which is likely to be much less congested than Geneva, is very close to the Bernese Oberland resorts, such as Grindelwald, Wengen and Murren. Minimum check-in time there is only 20 minutes and baggage reclaim should be significantly quicker than at busier airports.

The new fares must be paid two weeks or more before departure and passengers are required to stay at least one Saturday night. KLM alps is also offering them from a clutch of other UK airports, including Glasgow and Birmingham. The return fare from the former is £259.30 from the latter £210. The airline flies non stop to Berne - twice a day except on Saturdays when it makes one round trip - from London City Airport. Call 08705 074074 for reservations but be persistent. When I checked it took some time to persuade KLM's call centre that the deals existed.

 Vancouver-based developer Intrawest is to build a new mountain village in the French ski resort of Les Arcs. The pedestrian-only complex will be at 2,000ft and, on clear days, will offer views of Mont Blanc. It promises to be more photogenic than some of the earlier purpose-built ski developments in Savoie, avoiding the austere, monolithic look of the original buildings at La Plagne, for example, and following more closely the style of that resort's later addition, Belle-Plagne.

Construction of the village, which will incorpo rate 800 apartments or other accommodation units, is expected to start in 2002 and will take six to 10 years to complete. Resorts already owned by Intrawest include Whistler, Panorama and Mont Tremblant in Canada, and Copper Mountain in Colorado.

 For those who can tolerate a long road journey, Snowcoach (01727 866177) is offering 10-day, seven-night packages to St Gervais, with a departure on January 5, for the budget price of £288. That covers return travel from Watford, London Victoria or Dover, half-board accommodation based on two sharing, and includes afternoon tea and wine with dinner, at the Club Hotel Terminus. For a modest supplement, departures are also available from 30 other pick- up points in England and Wales.

 Still tempted by a last-minute dash to the slopes for Christmas or New Year? Although at this late stage you'll probably have to drive to the Alps, the huge self-catering specialist Interhome (020 8891 1294) has studios for up to two people and apartments for up to four in Chamonix for the week starting next Saturday. Prices are £257 and £368 respectively.

The firm also has studios in Siviez, part of the Four Valleys network whose main resort is Verbier, for £245. For New Year, it has studios in Tignes for £364 and apartments for up to five for £680. All these prices include a booking fee but not the bill for final cleaning.

Snow show
Liz Russell

Early season conditions could be better across the European Alps. Temperatures have been warm for this time of the year and therefore the great snow base that was created in some resorts in November has been depleted. A weather front is expected towards the end of the week but temperatures will have to drop for the snow conditions within some resorts to be dramatically altered.

America, unlike Europe is bitterly cold and has had huge snowfalls in the past couple of days, particularly in the mid-western states, which will mean excellent ski conditions for the next few days. Generally, the Canadian resorts have a good snow base for this time of the year.

Austria

There's still a lack of snow in Austria. St Anton is currently not open. Glacial resorts are the best to head for, such as Hintertux (***) or Pitztal (***), and even then the best skiing can be found at very high altitude, on the glacier.

France

The further south you head, the better the snow becomes. Serre Chevalier (***) has some great skiing and has received regular snowfalls over the last couple of weeks. However, Tignes (**) and the other more traditional early season resorts, are reported to have some good skiing on and off piste at high altitude.

Switzerland

Zermatt (***), St Moritz (***) and Saas Fee (***) are some of the best resorts to head for at the moment. Recent light snowfall has refreshed the slopes and some good conditions can be found on and off piste.

Italy

Warm temperatures have led to some melting but generally the snow base in the resorts in the Milky Way area, such as Sestriere (***), Sauze d'Oulx (***), is excellent for this time of the year. Cervinia (***) also has some great skiing and the ski links through to Zermatt in Switzerland are open creating a huge ski area for early season skiers.

Andorra

Soldeu (*) has very poor snow conditions although the resort does have a few lifts currently open.

America

While Europe suffers from warm temperatures, the US resorts are bitterly cold and have had huge snowfalls over the past couple of days. Squaw Valley (****), California has 20cm of new snow and Breckenridge (****), Colorado, has 15cm. This will ensure some fantastic powder skiing on and off piste over the next few days. Wrap up warm though.

Canada

Whistler (***) and Banff (***) have both had a dusting of new snow over the past few days which has refreshed the slopes and created some excellent conditions at high altitude. Fernie is yet to open.

Key to conditions

No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open.

* = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open.

** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition.

*** = plenty of good skiing.

**** = good conditions.

***** = fantastic conditions on and off piste.

 For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out Ski Club of Great Britain.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... South Korea

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... South Korea
fields.standfirst: Leon McCawley
fields.trailText: Leon McCawley
fields.body:
Why: I was performing in Japan and New Zealand and stopped off in between to meet my South Korean girlfriend's family. Few people would think of going to South Korea for a holiday, but I was surprised by the beauty of the countryside, and I loved the culture and the food. I spent a few days in Seoul and then went to the Yusong forest, a popular spa area in the south east. It is a beautiful place with rippling brooks, rugged and very green, a bit like Wales.

A lot has been lost through invasion, conquest and war, so there is a real sense that things should be preserved. The Piwon, the enchanted garden in the middle of the Imperial Palace in Seoul is just as you imagine an Oriental garden should be - very quiet, very contemplative. That inner peace and sanctuary is very important, and the tranquillity of the Piwon and the Yusong were what really attracted me to South Korea.

My perfect day: Food is very important to me, so it would have to centre around a wonderful meal at a village restaurant in the Yusong where lots of wonderful wild herbs are used. The food is hot and spicy but very complex. I would spend the rest of the afternoon in the spa. For me, relaxation is the heart of a holiday.

What's the best thing: Korea is unknown territory. You don't have any preconceptions about what it will be like before you go.

My advice: Be adventurous about exploring the country, the cuisine and the culture, and you will find that Koreans are very welcoming.

How do I get there?
Air China (020-7630 0919) flies Heathrow to Seoul from £712 return plus tax. Cheapflights can provide Air France return flights in mid-January for £349 plus tax.

· Pianist Leon McCawley will be performing with the Zenith Quartet on Monday at Christ Church Spitalfields as part of the Spitalfields Festival (box office 0207-377 1362).

Light show

Turner: The Great Watercolours marks the 150th anniversary of the artist's death and includes many works seldom seen on display.

Open daily 10am-6pm (8.30pm Fridays). Exhibition until February 11. Admission fees vary. The Royal Academy of Arts, Burlington House, Piccadilly, London W1 (020-7300 5959).

Elgar variations

Music fans can now pay their respects at the new Elgar Birthplace Museum which has opened in Worcester next door to the cottage where the composer was born in 1857.

Open daily. £3.50. Crown East Lane, Lower Broadheath, Worcester (01905 333224).

Magic bus

Catch the Santa Bus in Bury St Edmunds, a specially adapted vehicle which has been turned into an enchanted grove for Father Christmas and his helper elf.

Open on selected days until Christmas. £2.50 to include gift. Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk. Information: 01284 764667.

It's behind you!

Oh no it isn't. Oh yes it is. Pantomime Workshops run by the Theatre Museum of London will demonstrate different approaches to pantomime over the past 100 years.

Until February 11, 11am-7pm. Free with entry to museum (£3.50). Covent Garden Piazza, London WC2 (020-7943 4700).

Apocalypse now

Visitors to Drayton Manor Theme Park's Winter Wonderland Festival will find Apocalypse (the world's first stand-up tower drop), a zoo, Popeye and Olive Oyl in panto, and Santa and his helpers in a fairy grotto.

Open daily until Dec 24. £4/£3. Tamworth, Staffordshire (01827 252400).

Christmas past

Plum porridge, pulpatoon of pigeon and peacock pie are just a few of the traditional menu items on display in The Keeping of Christmas, England's Festive Tradition 1760-1840 at Fairfax House in York.

Open daily (except Dec 25/26 and Jan 1) until Jan 6. £4 children free when accompanied by paying adult. Fairfax House, Castlegate, York (01904 655543).

Join the band

Everyone's welcome to join Bilsdale Silver Band for the popular annual Christmas carol concert at Rievaulx Abbey.

Sunday 2pm-4pm. £3.40/£1.70, children under five free. Rievaulx Abbey, near Helmsley, Yorkshire (01439 798228).

Tell us a story

Rough Magic storyteller Don Newton tells traditional tales of Christmas past and seasonal folklore.

Sat/Sun, noon-4pm. £3.80/£1.90 (under 5s free). Pendennis Castle, near Falmouth (01326 316594).

fields.headline: The Grapes Hotel, Gwynedd
fields.trailText:
Address: Maentwrog, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Gwynedd LL41 4HN
Tel: 01766 590365/590208
Fax: 01766 590654
Web address: The Grapes Hotel
fields.body:
Address: Maentwrog, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Gwynedd LL41 4HN
Tel: 01766 590365/590208
Fax: 01766 590654
Web address: The Grapes Hotel

First impressions: On the edge of Snowdonia National Park, this Grade II-listed building is a 17th-century coaching inn continuing its tradition of wining and dining travellers. Especially welcoming on a wet winter evening.

What are the rooms like? In keeping with the traditional appearance of the hotel: cosy, some have exposed stonework. All are en suite and two of the rooms sleep four guests, so are good for families.

The bed test: Firm and comfortable - a good night's sleep guaranteed, especially after a few pints of Wye Valley Ploughman's in the bar.

The bathroom test: Basic but perfectly adequate; some rooms have baths, some showers. Takes a long time for the bath to fill though.

The restaurant: Five options: the local's bar, which is friendly and boisterous; the "visitor's bar" with pine pews and tables and an open fire; the veranda overlooking the River Dwyryd; the no-smoking lounge; and the medieval-themed breakfast room. All serve up hearty meals, such as ham and leek bake in cheese sauce, from £5.75 to £7.25 a head.

What is there to see within walking distance? There are some fine walks and mountain bike rides from right outside the hotel. Ffestiniog steam railway, which runs between Blaenau Ffestiniog and Porthmadog, has a station across the valley at Tan-y-Bwlch.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The national park's beautiful hills, valleys and estuaries; the award-winning Llechwedd Slate Caverns at Blaenau Ffestiniog; Portmeirion Village, setting for the cult TV series The Prisoner.

How much per night? £30 per person.
