fields.headline: One dam thing after another
fields.standfirst: Anna Melville-James finds plenty to see and do beyond the smoke of the cannabis cafés
fields.trailText: Anna Melville-James finds plenty to see and do beyond the smoke of the cannabis cafés.
fields.body:
There are more than enough ways to indulge yourself in hedonistic Amsterdam, but turn your attention away from thrillseeking and a very different city opens up - world-class museums, galleries, markets, café culture and nightlife are as much a part of the experience as the occasional wisp of fragrant smoke coming off a street corner.

The city has a dreamlike quality with its bridges and canals fading off into a watercolour distance. Crooked houses and warehouses subside with a sigh of relief along the five major canals that define the city centre, and Amsterdam's 21,000 listed houses benefit from a "non-straightening" restoration policy. Here you can lose yourself without any help - wandering, drinking strong Dutch coffee and gazing at the glassy water as it reflects back wide-eyed windows and wobbly gables.

As befits Amsterdam's fluidity, a 10-minute stroll can seamlessly blend the convivial charm of the trendy Jordaan District and the frantic pace of Dam Square.

From Nieuwmarket to the Southern Canal Belt and out to Vondelpark, a patchwork of tram-scored streets, jangling neon squares, quiet alleyways and secluded courtyards, map out every pace and mood. It's the key to an open-minded city that revels in unexpected surprises behind the smoke and mirrors.

Where to stay

The Grand Sofitel Demeure (Oudezijds Voorburgwal 197, tel: 555 3111, doubles from DG765 a night [£211], book from UK on 020 8283 4570) has gone through many identities, most recently until 1966 as Amsterdam's splendid town hall. Many original features remain, including a beautiful hand-painted wedding chamber, and its tranquil rooms with canalside or lush inner courtyard views are minutes away from the beating heart of Dam Square.

Hotel de L'Europe (Nieuwe Doelenstraat 2-8, tel: 531 1777, doubles from DG655) has a world-weary exterior that hides a plush oasis overlooking the sweeping river Amstel.

For ultimate privacy, Seven One Seven (Prinsengracht 717, tel: 423 0717, suites DG575-975) is a canal guesthouse hiding behind a discreet door plaque. Word of mouth ensures its eight individually-designed room/suites are in demand, so book well in advance for this hybrid of Old English country home and artist-colony eccentricity.

The Ambassade (Herengracht 341, tel: 555 0222, doubles from DG350) occupies 10 canal houses, offering unpretentious creature comforts from a central location.

Each room at the stately Hotel Filosoof (Anna van den Vondelstraat 6, tel 683 3013, doubles from DG155) is themed around a philosopher, while the small dining room also doubles as a library.

What to see

A stroll along the tree-lined waterways in the Southern Canal Belt can last a day. The three main outer canals, Herengracht, Keizersgracht and Prinsengracht were built ostensibly for wealthy residents, and the spindly architecture, resulting from a property "width tax", is a fascinating jumble of the beautiful and the curious.

The Anne Frank House (Prinsengracht 263, tel: 556 71 00, DG10), where her family hid during the second world war, gets incredibly crowded, and there's little to see behind the blackout curtains, but the simplicity and claustrophobia is moving.

The home of another of Amsterdam's famous citizens, Rembrandt (Jodenbreestraat 4-6, tel: 520 0400, DG12.50), is accessed through a hideous building, but once inside, accurate renovations successfully recreate his world.

A large collection of Rembrandt's work, along with that of other Dutch masters, hangs in the palatial Rijksmuseum (Stadhouderskade 42, tel: 674 7074, DG15). With 5,000 paintings on display in 200 rooms, the experience can be a little overwhelming, and it pays to be selective.

The Van Gogh Museum (Paulus Potterstraat 7, tel: 570 5200, DG15) behind the Rijksmuseum, is a model of space and light, displaying the progression of Van Gogh's paintings, from the dourness of The Potato Eaters to the colour explosion of his later work.

The Stedlijk museum of modern art (Paulus Potterstraat 13, tel: 573 2737, DG9) includes works by Cézanne, Picasso, Chagall and Mondrian.

The giant flea-market at Waterlooplein and the antiquarian book market at Spui are two of Amsterdam's 26 open-air bazaars, but the biggest draws are the flower markets, including a floating one on the Singel canal.

Tulips from Amsterdam come in many forms, including rubber, plaster and kitschy wooden varieties. If you stick to the real thing, you'll have 2,700 varieties to choose from. The Queen of the Night black tulip costs DG7,50 for 15 bulbs.

What to eat

Amsterdam's restaurant scene is a cosmopolitan delight, marred only by the irritations of early closing times and the lack of credit-card payment facilities and non-smoking sections.

D'Vijff Vlieghen (Spuistraat 294-302, tel: 624 8369) serves light new-Dutch cuisine in a dark gothic setting, spread over five adjoining 17th-century canal houses. Eat in the Rembrandt room and gaze up at four original etchings by the master on the wall. Main courses around DG48.

Former weighhouse In de Waag (Nieuwmarkt 4, tel: 422 7772) is now a cavernous restaurant/café, with a spartan, candlelit interior. Main courses DG35.

Café Roux (Oudezijds Voorburgwal 197, tel: 555 3560), formerly the city hall canteen, now Albert Roux's stylish restaurant, has excellent food at surprisingly affordable prices. Main courses average DG40, but top value is the set dinner menu, with a choice of starter, main and desert for DG79.50.

Café de Jaren (Nieuwe Dolenstraat 20-22, tel: 625 5771) has an informal menu (main courses DG18.50) and a modern, high-ceilinged ambience with a hint of 1960s public library about it. Its terrace, overlooking the Amstel, is a lively evening spot.

The numerous traditional brown cafés serve strident meals, coffee, beer and conviviality. Het Molenpad (Prinsengracht 653, tel: 625 9680) has chaotic service, but basic, hearty fare for DG9.50-16.50. De Prins (Prinsengracht 124, tel: 624 9382) serves sociable fondues and stews (DG23.50), on canalside tables.

Puri Mas (Lange Leidsedwarsstraat 37-41, tel: 627 7627) is one of many lively authentic Indonesian restaurants.

Bars and nightlife

Amsterdam loves a buzz, and at night the city erupts with energy at clubs, canalside pubs, concert halls and theatres. Café culture is a day-into-night affair - either in brown cafés like the Hoppe (Spui 18, tel: 420 4420) for a spot of Kopstodt (literally "thump on the head") - a combination of beer with a Jenever (Dutch gin) chaser - or ritzier venues like Café Americain (Leideskade 97, tel:556 3232).

The Concergebouw (Concertgebouwplein 2-6, tel: 675 4411) has near-perfect acoustics enjoyed by international orchestras and soloists, and the Stopera (Waterlooplein 22, tel: 625 5455) is home to the Netherlands Opera and National Ballet.

Bimhuis (Oude Schans 73-77, tel: 623 1316) is the jazz joint for big-name and local performers. The Supperclub lounge (Jonge Roelensteeg 21, tel: 638 0513) is the terrain of the hip, with excellent weekly guest DJ nights.

Melkweg (Lijbaansgracht 234, tel: 531 8181) is a lively one-stop shop, housing a cinema, art gallery, café, nightclub and concert hall in an old dairy.

Tuschinski Theater (Regulierbreestraat 26-28, tel: 623 1510), a glorious 1920s movie palace, complete with Wurlitzer pipe organ, is the last word in film viewing - especially from its private balcony with a glass of champagne. Films are shown in English with Dutch subtitles - watch out for the bewildering intermission or "pauze" -guaranteed to interrupt the most cliffhanging moment.

When to go

Amsterdam has a wealth of major festivals and one-off events. For further information, contact the Amsterdam Tourist Board (tel: 00 31 900 400 40 40).

The best-known include the Aalsmeer Flower Parade , an illuminated procession of floats through the city in September; the Saint Nicholas Parade in mid-November which launches the Christmas season; Amsterdam Blues Festival De Meervaart in March and the World Press Photo Exhibition at the Nieuwe Kerk in April.

Smaller events include the Amsterdam Kite Festival in June and the Jordaan Music Festival in September.

What to do for free

Amsterdam boasts that its free attractions would fill a week, and it's not an idle claim.

Some of the more interesting include the Civic Guards Gallery , where enormous 17th-century portraits of the Amsterdam Civic Guards (the most famous Rembrandt - The Nightwatch - hangs in the Rijksmuseum) hang in the passageway between the Kalverstraat and the Bejinhof. Vondelstraat hides the 19th-century Royal Riding School , inspired by the Spanish Riding School in Vienna.

The Zuiderkerk church tower can be climbed for a fine view, before a free lunchtime concert at the Concertgebouw (Wednesday 12.30pm-1pm, often public rehearsals by orchestras performing later) or the Stadhuis (Tuesdays 12.30pm-1pm). The Rijksmuseum garden is a haven of fountains, flowers, sculpture and a curious collection of building fragments from Old Holland.

The Magere Brug (Skinny Bridge) on Kerkstraat is a photographer's dream, especially when illuminated at night, while the world's narrowest house (one metre wide) is found along Oude Hoogstraat. For memorable sightseeing, join thousands of inline skaters congregating every Friday at 7pm, on Vondelpark to skate en-masse through the city. It's a family affair, with nearby skate-hire, but stick to the sides if you're wobbly to avoid being stampeded.

How to get there

KLM (0870 5074 074) flies to Amsterdam from London Stansted and 15 regional airports from £88 return. Two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 777 4445) during the January to March low season range from £176 in a one-star hotel including return flights from Gatwick to £369 in the Sheraton Pulitzer.

fields.headline: Cheap parking around Stansted airport
fields.standfirst:
We have an early flight from Stansted and need to stay the night before at a budget hotel. We will be away for a month and want to avoid the expense of parking at the airport. Is there anywhere close by offering cheap/free parking as an incentive to staying the night with them?
Patricia Holloway
fields.trailText: We have an early flight from Stansted and need to stay the night before at a budget hotel. We will be away for a month and want to avoid the expense of parking at the airport. Is there anywhere close by offering cheap/free parking as an incentive to staying the night with them?
fields.body:
 For budget and comfortable accommodation near airports, try the Women's Institute magazine, Home & Country (available at newsagents), which has pages of classified adverts for suitable places.
Jane Webb

 The Cricketers is a pub in a nearby village where you can stay overnight, park your car cheaply and be taken to and picked up from the airport. It's nothing special, but it's acceptable and fits the bill.
Robert Clark

 We took an early flight from Stansted last year, and stayed the night before at the Four Seasons Hotel near Thaxted (tel: 01371 830129), who were happy to let us park our car there for free while we were away. A taxi to the airport cost in the region of £12. We found the hotel in the accommodation guide produced by Uttlesford District (the area around Stansted), available from Saffron Walden Tourist Information Centre (tel: 01799 510444, e-mail: tourism@uttlesford.gov.uk).
Jacqueline Simpson

 We obtained a copy of the Stansted information/accommodation guide. This lists a variety of options in towns and villages such as Takeley and Thaxted - hotels and bed and breakfast in private houses with parking and transport to the airport - but do enquire early as the accommodation is limited.
M Bullows

 We stayed one night at the Yarrow Guest House, 27 Station Road Felstead, Essex (01371 820878) on returning to Stansted after a holiday in France. We had dropped the car off two weeks previously and were charged 50p per day parking fees. The proprietors arranged a taxi to and from the airport and cost £11 each way. The guest house is about 20 miles from the airport on the A120 (East). The total cost for one night's B&B for two people (double room en suite) parking and taxis was £68.

fields.headline: Castles in the air
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith  explores two Iron Age forts that offered little protection against Roman legionnaires and Cromwell's dragoons
fields.trailText: Roly Smith explores two Iron Age forts that offered little protection against Roman legionnaires and Cromwell's dragoons.
fields.body:
Hambledon Hill dominates the Vale of Blackmoor north of Blandford Forum in Dorset - Thomas Hardy's "Vale of the Little Dairies" - like a brooding giant. The sweeping, sinuous curves of the double embankments which contour around its summit make it one of the most impressive examples of an Iron Age hillfort in Britain.

Unlike its near-neighbour, Hod Hill (which we also visit on this walk), there's no evidence that Hambledon was ever attacked in ancient times. But during the English Civil War, it became the unlikely scene of one of the most pathetic episodes in the whole of that bitter conflict.

The walk starts in the village of Child Okeford, on the minor road north east of Shillingstone. Take the Steepleton Road past Fernhayes Copse, with the encircling earthworks of Hambledon prominent away to the left. A chalky farm track, signposted Hambledon Hill, leads off to the left and climbs through beeches to a stile that leads out on to the open downland.

The path heads steeply up to the right across the ridged sheepwalks, aiming for the obvious saddle between the embankments of the northern end of the hillfort to your left and the slighter earthworks of an earlier neolithic camp on the right.

At the top of the hill, turn left and walk along the embankments towards the 184m summit of Hambledon, enjoying its superb view across the Vale of Blackmoor towards prominent Melbury Beacon and the hilltop town of Shaftesbury to the north.

This was the site of the Clubmen's last stand. They were a bucolic band of local peasants, sickened by the Civil War in which they had no interest, but which was seriously affecting their day-to-day lives. Troops from the conflicting armies trampled their crops, pillaged their villages and commandeered their corn. They rose up with no greater motive than the desire to protect their own hearths and homes.

Led by the Rev Bravel, rector of nearby Compton Abbas, the Clubmen armed themselves with weapons hastily snatched from the farmyard: clubs, pitchforks, axes, scythes and some ancient halberds. Their badge was a white cockade, and they eventually mustered 5,000 red-faced men, drawn from the counties of Dorset, Wiltshire and Somerset with the rallying cry: "For England and our homes."

At first, they petitioned the King to stop the madness of the war, but they were ignored. Then they stormed the Parliamentary quarters at Sturminster Newton, but this brave action had no greater effect. Eventually, in the summer of 1645, they entrenched themselves on Castle Hill at Shaftesbury, only to be herded off like so many of their own downland sheep by Cromwell's well-drilled soldiers.

Enraged by this, the Clubmen, now down to only about 2,000, encamped within the 2,000-year-old ramparts of Hambledon Hill, determined to fight to the death to gain the release of their leaders. The Rev Bravel, obviously better-equipped and more determined than most of his rabble army, threatened to pistol any Clubman who surrendered.

The denouement was not long in coming. Cromwell sent 50 of his well-equipped dragoons to Hambledon, but their demand for the surrender of the hill was treated with contempt and a round of lead shot by the Rev Bravel. But the weathered Iron Age defences - once described as the "nuclear deterrent of their age" - proved no obstacle to the charging, sword-slashing dragoons, who swept through the entrance and over the ditches, overwhelming the yokels after what was described as "a short dispute".

Cromwell's coldly-clinical description of the event states: "They beat them from the work, and did some small execution upon them; I believe killed not 12 of them, but cut very many."

The luckiest of the Clubmen escaped by sliding down the steep slopes of the hill, but many were taken prisoner by the dragoons and held overnight in the church at Shroton or Iwerne Courtney (it is one of the few villages in England with alternative names), in the shadow of Hambledon to the east.

Cromwell's account of this rather sad episode in a letter to his commander in chief Sir Thomas Fairfax perhaps sums up his barely-concealed contempt for the disillusioned Clubmen. "We have taken about 300, many of which are poor silly creatures, whom if you please to let me send home they promise to be very dutiful for time to come, and will be hanged before they come out again."

From Hambledon Hill, retrace your steps south to the central col and the trig point which marks the site of the neolithic settlement. Continue south dropping down to the Cross Dyke and then up on the ridge through hawthorn scrub until the path descends steeply through Hambledon Plantation to reach the Child Okeford-Steepleton road near Keeper's Lodge. Bear right to the gate on the left which gives access to the National Trust's Hod Hill Estate.

The battle of Hod Hill was much the same story as that of Hambledon except that it took place 1,600 years earlier. The Roman Second Legion under Vespasian attacked the hillfort on its all-conquering assault on 20 southern hillforts of the local Celtic tribe known as the Durotriges. Maiden Castle, Dorset's most mighty and famous hillfort, had already fallen under the might of Vespasian's military power.

Excavations in the 1950s on what was thought to be the local chieftain's hut in the south-eastern part of the square-shaped hillfort made the dramatic discovery of 11 iron ballista bolts, still embedded in the chalk where they had been fired from a Roman siege engine in AD43. As there were no other signs of battle or war cemeteries on the site, it has been assumed that the Durotiges must have been so intimidated by this demonstration of state-of-the-art firepower that they simply surrendered.

And as if to rub in their superiority, the Romans proceeded to build one of their standard, playing card-shaped forts actually within the Iron Age hillfort - the only one of its kind in Britain.

Take your time as you walk round the 22-hectare fort, noting the fine defensive position chosen by the Durotiges on this headland above the winding River Stour, which can be seen in the valley below. There are also good aerial views towards Steepleton House in the wooded valley of the River Iwerne to the north.

Now, take the steep path down from the south-western corner of the fort through the undergrowth to a pleasant, tree-lined riverside track along the Stour and back out on to the Steepleton road again, west of the Keeper's Lodge. Turn left on the road, passing Hanford House School on your left, to re-enter Child Okeford.

The practicals

Child Okeford is north east of Shillingstone, about seven miles north-west of Blandford Forum off the A357. The suggested walk is about six miles long, and the stretch along the River Stour can be very muddy after wet weather. There are a couple of steepish climbs up to both Hambledon and Hod Hills, so strong footwear is recommended.

The best map is the Ordnance Survey's 1:50,000 Landranger No 194, Dorchester, Weymouth and surrounding area. The nearest tourist information centre is at the Marsh & Ham car park in West Street, Blandford Forum (01258 454770). For excellent accommodation and gourmet food, try the 17th-century Stourcastle Lodge, in Gough's Close, Sturminster Newton (01258 472320).

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: France | Grenada | Egypt
fields.body:
Europe

France: Kirker Holidays (020-7231 3333) is offering three nights' B&B for the price of two at the four-star Royal Alma hotel in Paris. The price, £256pp, is valid until March 29 excluding New Year, UK bank holidays, and Paris Trade Fairs and includes return travel on Eurostar, transfers and a Seine cruise.

Italy: Waymark Holidays (01753 516 477) is offering a seven-night cross-country skiing package departing on January 7 to the Dobbiaco region of the Dolomites. The cost, £495, includes return flights from Stansted, half-board accommodation, taxes, transfers and a qualified, English-speaking leader.

Italy: Save £71 on a two-night weekend break at the three star San Giorgio & Rex Hotel, Florence, departing January 5 or 6. The new price, £225pp, includes B&B accommodation, and return scheduled flights with British Airways from London Gatwick. Travelscene 0870 777 4445.

Caribbean

Grenada: One week's self-catering at the Lance Aux Epines Cottages at Prickly Bay during January starts from £735pp, including return flights with JMC, private transfers, maid service and watersports. Just Grenada 01373 814214.

Middle East

Egypt: A seven-night underwater-photography holiday at Sharm el Sheikh departing January 12 costs £629pp from Regal Holidays (0870 2201 777). The price includes flights, transfers, B&B accommodation at the Hilton Villas in Hurghada, six days' diving, free processing of three films and hire of scuba equipment.

Asia

Thailand: Travel between February 1 and March 31 and you can save £179 on the cost of an 11-night holiday with AsiaWorld (0870 990 8098). The new price, £779pp, includes scheduled flights from London Heathrow and 11 nights' room-only accommodation - three in Bangkok and eight in Pattaya.

Singapore: Austravel (0117 933 0450) is offering five nights in January in the Copthorne Orchid Hotel for £549pp including return flights with Singapore Airlines.

Africa

South Africa, Botswana, Zambia: Watch the total eclipse of the sun on June 21 from the Lower Zambezi National Park. The 15-night trip from The Imaginative Traveller (020-8742 8612) departs June 9 and costs £1,395pp, including return scheduled flights from Heathrow, all other transport and 14 nights' accommodation (one in a hotel with breakfast, 13 camping with all meals). Other highlights include a safari in the Okavango Delta, a cruise on the Chobe river and game-park walking excursions.

fields.headline: Miss this at your peril
fields.standfirst: www.unmissable.com
fields.trailText: www.unmissable.com
fields.body:
Unmissable. Isn't that one of those hackneyed words invented by advertisers?
To be fair, the site is as stern-minded as you. "Unmissability means different things to different people so the chances are that, when trawling through the site, you may not consider every item to be unmissable," it concedes.

I certainly have no desire to spend four grand on a chilly 11-day cruise round Antarctica.
It's just like you to be cynical. The ship has hot showers, daylight lasts for 20 hours and sightings of penguins, albatross and whales are promised.

The selection of floral landscapes seem rather lovely, but I don't see how I can get to all of them.
The primary aim of the site is to inspire rather than sell destinations to you, so not all the places mentioned have a holiday package attached. Instead, Unmissable.com invites you to e-mail them with an explanation of where and when you want to go. The eclectic selection of top 10s includes rollercoasters, jazz festivals, modern wonders and rail journeys.

But it isn't cheap.
Well, no. Search for a week's holiday in February and you'll only find 10 choices for under £500, making the Christmas gift vouchers an unlikely present. But the site is still a real pleasure to visit, and it would be perfectly possible to follow up one of the ideas on a budget if you were prepared to arrange accommodation and flights yourself.

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.standfirst: Follow the Netjetters
fields.trailText: Our Netjetters set off two weeks ago on their six-month trips around the world. The trio - Milly Newman, an 18-year-old gap student; Sam Rowbury, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant; and Sue Stubbings, a 51-year-old divorced mother of three.
fields.body:
Our Netjetters set off two weeks ago on their six-month trips around the world. The trio - Milly Newman, an 18-year-old gap student; Sam Rowbury, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant; and Sue Stubbings, a 51-year-old divorced mother of three, are keeping in touch with Netjetters each week and taking advice from our web users around the world. Read their weekly diaries, look at their photos, hear them talk about their experiences, and plan your own trip with the help of feedback and advice from readers all over the world.

Sue landed in Bombay and is travelling overland to Kathmandu, where she will be spending Christmas before heading for Singapore: "After a shaky start, I am now in traveller mode and loving every minute. Already, I have been on an Indian train, seen an elephant, eaten thali (delicious), drunk chai, taken one lot of Imodium, seen a Hindu wedding procession and been splashed by sacred cow wee when I did not jump out of the way quickly enough. (Is this a blessing?)

"Udaipur is a magical place full of temples and fountains surrounded by hills. Watching the sun set over the city from 2,468ft up at the Monsoon palace was an early highlight. We had English tea and cakes in the Fateh Prak Palace overlooking the Lake Palace (roughing it again)."

Feedback from Paul: "Don't miss the Kathmandu Valley outside the city itself. It's all manageable in a day, either by bus, bike or taxi. It's incredible how quickly you are away from it all and into untouched villages. Bhaktapur, 20km or so to the east of Kathmandu, is amazing if touristy, and a staging post for a great climb to Nargokot on the east of the valley. Great view of Everest at dawn at this time of year. Not to be missed ..."

Sam went from New York to Washington DC, and is currently on 30-hour train journey to the Rockies, where he's going to do some skiing: "Washington DC is full of museums and monuments. The Holocaust Museum is brilliantly set out and full of very moving images and exhibits. I also went to the National Museum of American History which had a ridiculous assortment of kitsch items, including my personal favourite: Evel Knievel's white leather jumpsuit."

Feedback from Fran: "If you're going to Vegas, then go midweek; the hotels are much cheaper. And stick $5 on number three for me."

Meanwhile, Milly has made contact from Vancouver. She and some new friends have decided to head east for some skiing in Banff. She's due in Sydney for Christmas, with a quick stop in Hawaii beforehand, but has yet to leave Canada: "One of my biggest worries was that I'd be travelling on my own, and I'd be all alone in a strange country. This couldn't be further from the truth. I first met someone on the plane on the way over - a Scottish guy who'd decided to leave home only two days before. We got into conversation and ended up spending the next couple of days together while we both found our feet. That night, I met a nice group of people at the hostel and we arranged to hire a van and drive to Whistler the next day.

"That's the great thing about travelling - if you keep an open mind and don't have any fixed plans, so many opportunities are open to you."

webTitle: International guide to the carnival season

fields.headline: The biggest shows on Earth
fields.standfirst: There's just enough time to recover from Christmas before the carnivals begin.  Charlotte Atkins reports
fields.trailText: There's just enough time to recover from Christmas before the carnivals begin. Charlotte Atkins reports.
fields.body:
Carne-vale - or "goodbye meat" - may not sound like much of a turn on. But next February, as 40 days of Lenten sacrifice approach, parties will erupt around the world. From Venice to New Orleans, Malta to Tenerife, Bacchanalia will reign. Mardi Gras (Shrove Tuesday) is on February 27 - but most festivities begin a few days before.

New Orleans

February 16-27

Mardi Gras, or "Fat Tuesday", is the biggest day in "the biggest free show on Earth". Over the 10 days immediately preceding Mardi Gras, the usual notions of taste are abandoned as an extravagant blow-out of parades, balls and free-floating jazz performances take a hold. By Shrove Tuesday, masked revellers are throwing coconuts, beads and doubloons to the crowds that jam the French Quarter, St Charles Avenue and Canal Street. As the revelry and spectacle reach great heights, so do the hotel prices.

One week with BA Holidays (0870 6000500) costs from £633pp.

Venice

February 17-27

Cover your face for the queen of Europe's carnivals, the Venice Mask Carnival. It opens with a parade of masked figures carrying drums and torches in historic St Mark's Square and revives the traditional masked balls with elaborate costumes and theatrical performances of the 18th century. Certain balls are open to the public who must buy tickets in advance and soon - space is already very limited. Log on to Meeting Europe or call 00 39 041 717065. In Venice's heyday the celebrations lasted six months. Now they're down to 10 days.

Lakes and Mountains Holidays (01329 844 405) offers a three-night break for £700pp, including B&B, tickets to the Casanova Masked Ball and a guided walking tour of the city, departing February 16. Extra nights from £80pp.

Details of local costume providers are available prior to departure. If you prefer to spectate, a three-night break in a central three-star hotel with Kirker Holidays (020-7231 3333) costs £358pp B&B.

Nice

February 8 to 27

The resort is host to one of Europe's largest and most colourful carnivals. As the 117th of its kind gets underway, expect daily float processions, flower-throwing and the burning of the carnival king. Just be prepared to share space along the Promenade des Anglais with around a million others.

Travellers Cities (01959 540700) offers breaks throughout the event. Three nights' B&B at the four-star Hotel Splendid, for example, seconds from the action, costs £289.

Malta

February 22-27

Malta's Mardi Gras is an island-wide celebration of masks and fireworks that dates back to 1535. Villagers put on their finery for religious processions, many children take their first communion, and ornate gold and silver church treasures are carried majestically through the streets. Decorated floats, masked processions and open-air dancing keep even the most dedicated sun worshippers off the beach. One week with Cadogan (023 8082 8306) costs from £287pp B&B.

Cyprus

February 18-25

A scaled-down Notting Hill is how tour operator Sunvil describes Carnival in Cyprus, with the most elaborate floats and costumes swanning down the streets of Limassol. Children and teenagers are well catered for, with seafront stalls selling balloons, carnival dances at most of the resort's hotels and various fair stalls and rock bands pulsating in the Zoo Public Gardens.

A week at the family-run three-star Alasia Hotel, near enough to be part of the action but quiet enough to sleep at night, with playground, tennis and heated pool, costs £350pp B&B with Sunvil (020-8568 4499). Children discounted if their sharing parents' room.

Tenerife

February 19 - March 4

The Canary Islands get crazily colourful each carnival, none more so than Tenerife in the resort of Santa Cruz de Tenerife. There's all the usual merriment, music and dancing. One particular highlight is the burial of a giant sardine effigy, after it has been paraded through the streets on a throne, followed by an entourage of pregnant men. Don't ask.

One week with Thomson (0990 502555) costs from £305pp.

Trinidad

February 26 and 27

Join in the Calypso at Trinidad's fantastic Carnival, the most famous in the Caribbean. The fun begins on the stroke of midnight on the Sunday before Lent. Carnival hits the streets of Port of Spain like a hurricane with a frenzy of dancing, bringing together the Caribbean's best musicians, along with truly spectacular costumes and a tropical sensuality. Get grandstand seats if you can - some of the costumes are more than 12ft high.

Seven nights in Trinidad with Hayes and Jarvis (0870 8989890) costs from £899pp. The Caribbean Tourism Organisation (020-7222 4335) has full details of all the islands' carnivals and tour operators.

Sydney

February 9-March 4

For Carnival with a difference, join the Sydney Gay & Lesbian Mardi Gras 2001. More of a cultural event, it involves all manner of theatre acts, exhibitions and city tours. The main week (from Feb 26) brings a huge influx of tourists for the major gay and lesbian harbour cruise, a Saturday street parade and a carnival evening party. The festival's website is Mardi Gras.

Man Around (020-8902 7177), Europe's biggest gay and lesbian tour operator, has 10-night packages to the Mardi Gras starting at £1,475pp. The price, based on two sharing, includes return flights, 10 nights' room-only accommodation, a welcome pack of guides, maps and discount vouchers, a gay harbour cruise, grandstand viewing seats for the Mardi Gras Parade and a ticket to the famous Mardi Gras Party.

Goa

February 25, 26 and 27

Carnival is the highlight of the Goan calendar, introduced by the Portuguese in the 18th century as a way of letting off steam before the abstinence of Lent. There's four days of paint-throwing, music, cross-dressing and masked balls as King Mom, lord of misrule, takes charge. Panjim, the capital, is the focus of the action.

One week with First Choice (0870 7500001) costs from £479pp. To celebrate in style, check into the Taj Exotica in Benaulim and join the celebrations in Margao, about 10km from the hotel, where thousands take part in a street festival of floats, dancers and bands - one week with Sovereign (08706 070770) starts from £905pp B&B.

Rio

February 24-28

Samba rules in Rio. Groups with a different theme and style of costume parade in not-so-strict formation. The best groups parade in the Sambodoromo. For about £100, visitors can receive a costume and tuition, enabling them to take part.

A week's B&B in the four-star Copacabana Hotel with Trips Worldwide (0117 9872626) costs from £1,593pp.

Quebec

January 26 - February 11

Around a Disney-esque ice palace, Quebecois indulge in snow bathing, snowmobiling, ice-carving competitions and float processions, all part of their Winter Carnival. The craziest event comes last, a canoe race across the frozen St Lawrence River (see Carnaval de Quebec for details). One week with Travelpack (0870 1272001) costs from £600.

Valencia

March 12-19

Spain's most spectacular fiesta, Las Fallas, erupts in an explosion of fire, art and noise. Huge papier-mché monuments (fallas) are erected in the city's various districts and ceremoniously set alight on the final night of the fiesta, St Joseph's Day. Costing millions of pesetas each, the fallas depict satirical scenes ranging from local politicians to international celebrities.

Be there with Mundi Color (020-7828 6021). A three-night break costs from £350pp B&B. The Valencia Region Tourist Board has all the gen.

fields.headline: Tickets to ride
fields.standfirst: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.trailText: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.body:
Six top destinations

Paris: £69
British Airways from Heathrow. Must be booked and paid for by December 21. Valid for departures until December 31.Travellers must be under 26 or full-time students with valid international student identification cards. Minimum/maximum stay one night. usit Campus (0870 240 1010).

Sydney: £575.30
Olympic Airways from Manchester via Athens and Bangkok. Must be booked by December 22. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures January 1 - March 31. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Airline Network (01772 727272).

Amsterdam: £100
KLM uk from Manchester. Valid for departures January 1 - March 31. No minimum stay, maximum three months. Trailfinders (0161-839 6969).

New York: £170
Lufthansa from Stansted via Frankfurt or Munich. Valid for departures until December 30. Minimum stay seven nights. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

Los Angeles: £289
Continental Airlines from Gatwick. Must be booked by January 2. Valid for departures January 1 - April 4. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum six months. Quest Travel (0870 4430745).

Hong Kong: £397
Cathay Pacific from Heathrow. Must be booked by January 31. Valid for departures February 1-28. Minimum stay three days, maximum one month. Trailfinders (020-7938 3939).

The pick of the rest

Brisbane: £519
Royal Brunei from Heathrow via Brunei. Must be booked by February 27. Valid for departures January 16 - March 31. No minimum stay. All travel must be completed by May 30. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 752 0066).

Vancouver: £271
TWA from Gatwick via St Louis. Valid for departures January 1 - April 6. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum 45 days. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400).

Karachi: £271
Qatar Airways from Heathrow via Doha. Valid for departures December 27 - April 30. Minimum stay seven days, maximum six months. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 752 0066).

And the rail alternative

Paris/Brussels: £70, Lille: £60
Eurostar from Waterloo and Ashford. Must be bought at least 14 days before departure. Valid for departures until March 22. Minimum stay one Saturday night or two other nights. Eurostar (08705 186186).

 Fares can change rapidly. These were available in reasonable quantities at the time of writing, but they can sell out in a sudden rush.

fields.headline: Desert cool
fields.standfirst: In a desert on the other side of the world there is a temple to comfort, style - and eco tourism.  Patrick Collinson  visits a modern-day oasis
fields.trailText: In a desert on the other side of the world there is a temple to comfort, style - and eco tourism. Patrick Collinson visits a modern-day oasis.
fields.body:
Nine thousand feet up in the Andes, the Atacama desert bills itself as one of the highest, driest and remotest locations on Earth, and its other-worldliness invited the Spanish conquerors to name its barren, volcanic plains and valleys Muerte, Diablo and de la Luna.

And it is here that you can stay in one of the world's hippest hotels, the Explora, set in 42 acres on the edge of San Pedro, an oasis wedged between the biggest salt flat in South America and the Andean mountain-tops. Explora, only two years old, has already made it into glossy style magazines and architectural coffee table books and, rather self-consciously, proclaims itself as a revolutionary travel experience.

"Explora is an enterprise founded to encourage a new attitude towards travel, which widens one's world and deepens the understanding of self. The architecture of Explora hotels makes it possible to inhabit the remote, it intends to reveal its mystery without solving it," says the brochure.

I approached the Explora hotel gingerly, fearing an outbreak of overpaid AbFab-types getting in touch with themselves and the wilderness. But Explora is more eco-puritan than eco-hippy. True, it gives you Bolivian slate floors and rugs in the bedroom, pungent cypress wood ceilings and walls, an enormous Jacuzzi in your bathroom, and a vast shower offering a monsoon-like experience. But it won't let you put CNN on in your bedroom or pipe music into the bathroom as you sit Joan Collins-like under the Jacuzzi bubbles. There's no TV or mini-bar at Explora, no room-service menu and no morning papers shoved under the door.

Once in your bedroom, you can't escape silence. Not that you care. Explora's most memorable aspect is its aspect; each bedroom has an almost 20ft wide panoramic window giving you an Imax-style view over the Atacama's weird landscape. A perfectly-formed volcano, snow-capped at its peak, sweeps down on your left, meeting another volcano on the right.

Below them, the huge expanse of red earth, dented only by two or three giant gulleys, runs down to the base of your window. Not a single building, road, vegetation or people; handy, that last fact, as there's never any need to pull the curtains. You can sit in the Jacuzzi day or night and just stare and stare. Forget the moon; this looks like the view from hotel Mars.

The abundance of water at the hotel nags at you; this can't be environmentally sustainable. But Explora says it has drilled its own deep water well, and every drop is recycled through irrigation channels to local farmers. Oh good, no guilt about using that monsoon shower, then.

But Explora is not just about the hip hotel - indeed they prefer it if you don't hang around. Explora wants you to get your boots on. Late every afternoon, the guides, enthusiastically environmental (one was even ex-Rainbow Warrior), meet you in the hotel bar area to discuss and suggest suitable expeditions by foot, mountain bike or horse back. My first trip - you share hikes with up to six others plus the guide - was to the Valle de la Luna. Courtesy of the hotel's fleet of four-wheel-drives, you start the hike at the interesting bit, escaping other travellers and avoiding the dull hour's walk to Luna from the hotel.

Luna is your first exposure to how totally lifeless and barren the Atacama is. It cuts through the salt, gypsum and clay of the "Salt Range", carving impressive but surprisingly fragile rock formations. Rain would erode and destroy Luna. It's just that it is never, ever forecast by the weathermen.

The eerieness of the Atacama is not just the landscape; after a while, you notice what is missing: there are no sounds. No birds flapping past, no wind blowing through trees and leaves, nothing. Not even flies. (I saw just one fly in a week in the Atacama.)

Some compare it to Arizona or Death Valley; I, a fan of trashy sci-fi, saw Hollywood. In Luna's deep gorges, you look up, expecting an attack from the sandmen in Star Wars or for Arnie to come tumbling down the long scree slopes in a scene from Total Recall. The landscape constantly invites comparison with the sets from Stargate, Starship Troopers and Mission to Mars. I was not alone in feeling a bit spacey in the Atacama: NASA road-tested its moon vehicles in the Valle de la Luna.

All visitors end a trip to Luna watching the sun setting on the copper-burnished rocks. Which is a shame really, because you have to share it with about 100 other tourists sitting on the same outcrop admiring the view. Bring a plastic bag to sit on, then use it as a sledge to fly down the scree on the other side to your waiting wagon. Just don't leave it there. It's a tribute to eco-tourism in the Atacama that at no time do you see discarded Coke cans or water bottles. Or a tribute to the fact that, though increasingly popular, tourist numbers are still minimal.

But hiking is for softies; the area is perfect for mountain biking. Being the Explora hotel, you get good bikes. Being the Atacama, you get the Diablo Valley. You reach it after cycling across dried-up river beds and through freezing streams running down from the Andes, then you skid and slide down tunnel-like gorges on the exhilarating ride home. All this under a beating sun; it was the Atacama's winter when I visited, but the temperature hovered around 25C most days, plunging to zero at night. In summer, however, the temperature ticks up only to around 30C.

You realise pretty quickly that you are altitude training; the air is thin and one breathless member of our cycling party abandoned the trip early on. Nose-bleeds are a common curse; all of us suffered. If you're unfit, asthmatic and prone to nose-bleeds, the Atacama's probably not for you.

The third trick in Explora's hand is its stables. I'm the sort of person who's scared of cats, but two days of lessons on Explora's silky horses and I fancied myself as a bit of gaucho, cantering over the desert. They even saddle you up in leathery chaps and Mask of Zorro style hats, so you get a bit of a kinky thrill out of it as well.

Dusty, tired and dirty after every trek, you understand why Explora spent so much on its bathrooms. But it doesn't skimp in the kitchen either; despite its desert remoteness, each day's menu is different and features fresh fish, with sea bream and conger eel clearly Chilean favourites. The hotel's owner, one of Chile's richest individuals, owns a large vineyard in the Maipu valley in the south, so the wine is superb, too.

But don't drink too much - many of the treks start early, and you won't want a hangover. At 7am one morning, we drove to the Puritama valley to start a hike at 10,000ft, finishing at 13,500ft. Oddly, life in this part of the Andes begins rather than ends at 10,000ft, as aridity is replaced by flowing meltwater. Giant cacti abound, wild donkeys stand completely placid on the rocky hillsides - it's something to do with the lithium in the soil. Plus there's ancient Atacamenian Indian huts, but with pre-Columbian historical data so flimsy, you politely agree with the guide that it's 2,500 years old and don't ask too many questions.

Shortly after the climb steepens for an hour, your footing slips, breathlessness sets in and nerves become frayed. Then you turn a corner and collect your prize: a tumbling mountain stream surrounded by pampas grass, but with steam rising off it. It's not meltwater, but a hot river cascading down from the world's highest geysers.

An hour later you approach the source, at 13,500ft. Ahead of you are a series of five pools - deserted but for staff from Explora, waiting for you with your luxury bathrobes. You slip into the hot pools, gazing out over the tips of the Andes, thinking this can't get much better. Then a waiter appears, placing wooden trays into the water, floating wine and canapes across to you. You grope for words to capture the serenity, beauty and luxury of it. Instead you say "Just how **** off is this?" And it really is.

There's still plenty more treks to do - we all rather fancied the two-day trek to the top of the volcano, but Explora deliberately gives you too much choice; they want you to return.

Five airports and 36 hours, later I am back at Heathrow. I take a black cab from Paddington station. Unbelieveably it breaks down and I'm turfed out on to a dodgy back street of Camberwell, South London, bags and all. The day before I was on the moon. Now it's back to reality.

The practicals

Prices for seven nights start from £2,470pp at Explora en Atacama based on two sharing and include: international flights on LanChile airlines, internal flights from Santiago to Calama, seven nights' full board (drinks and house wines), English-speaking guides, excursions, use of equipment and all transport. There is also an Explora en Patagonia. For further information and reservations, contact Journey Latin America on 020-8747 8315/0161-832 1441.

Seven other hotels where you can get away from it all in style
Joanna Israelsohn

Amangani, Wyoming, US

The ultimate in rustic Ralph Lauren chic, Amangani's huge bedrooms, complete with remote-control fires, overlook the spectacular Wyoming Rockies, home to grizzly bears, and wolves and more names on the Forbes 400 than anywhere else in the US. From £450 double. Amangani, Wyoming, US (00 1 307 734 7333).

El Questro, Western Australia

You can't get much further away from it all than the Aussie outback, which boasts some of the most ancient and untouched geology in the world. Unusually for an exclusive retreat, the ultra-modern El Questro accomodates a range of budgets - from riverside bungalows and luxurious tents to rooms in the main hotel, perched on the edge of a sandstone gorge. From £30 for a single tented cabin to £378 for a homestead single. El Questro, Kununurra, Western Australia (00 61 8 9169 1777).

The Desert Resort Mandawa

A collection of mud huts in the arid Rajasthani desert might not be your idea of holiday heaven, but The Desert Resort Mandawa is one of the most exotic hotels in the world. Its simple rooms are decorated with handmade silks and sanskrit texts and there's no chance of being disturbed by rush-hour traffic. From £25 for a single. The Desert Resort Mandawa, Shekhawati, Rajasthan (00 91 1592 231 51).

Amanwana, Moyo Island, Indonesia

Just getting there is half the fun - three flights, a cross-island drive and a boat ride bring you to Moyo Island, a virtually deserted slice of tropical Indonesian jungle. The resort is a collection of air-conditioned tents, complete with living room, writing desk, wardrobe space and double wash basins. All you have to do is choose your location: edge of beach or edge of jungle. Decisions, decisions. From £482 for a double inc all meals. Amanwana, Moyo Island, West Sumbawa Regency, Indonesia (00 62 371 222 33)

Ngorongoro Crater Lodge, Tanzania

Described by French Elle as "le Baroque ethnique", the sumptiously decorated hotel at this World Heritage Site perches on the rim of the 1,600ft deep Ngorongoro Crater. The hotel's 30 super-luxe suites all look out on to the three-million-year-old remains of the once active volcano. Talk about rooms with a view. From £323pp. Ngorongoro Crater Lodge, Tanzania (00 27 11 775 0000).

Blancaneaux Lodge, Belize

A little piece of paradise in the rainforest of Belize, Francis Ford Coppola's small eco-friendly retreat really has it all - a hydroelectric power source, river water clean enough to drink and Mayan ruins less than two hours drive away. It is also safe to say this is the only tropical mountain retreat complete with wood-fired pizza oven and espresso machine. From £107 for a double room. Blancaneaux Lodge, Cayo District, Belize (00 501 92 38 78).

The Ice Hotel, Sweden

The world's coolest hotel is rebuilt every winter in Swedish Lapland using 35,000 tons of snow and ice. Plan your stay carefully, for by spring the whole place - bedrooms, bar, cinema, gallery, chapel and all - will have melted away. From £126 for double room, inc breakfast. The Ice Hotel, Jukkasjarvi, Sweden (00 46 980 668 00).

And it is here that you can stay in one of the world's hippest hotels, the Explora, set in 42 acres on the edge of San Pedro, an oasis wedged between the biggest salt flat in South America and the Andean mountain-tops. Explora, only two years old, has already made it into glossy style magazines and architectural coffee table books and, rather self-consciously, proclaims itself as a revolutionary travel experience. "Explora is an enterprise founded to encourage a new attitude towards travel, which widens one's world and deepens the understanding of self. True, it gives you Bolivian slate floors and rugs in the bedroom, pungent cypress wood ceilings and walls, an enormous Jacuzzi in your bathroom, and a vast shower offering a monsoon-like experience. There's no TV or mini-bar at Explora, no room-service menu and no morning papers shoved under the door. Once in your bedroom, you can't escape silence. Not that you care. Explora's most memorable aspect is its aspect; each bedroom has an almost 20ft wide panoramic window giving you an Imax-style view over the Atacama's weird landscape. A perfectly-formed volcano, snow-capped at its peak, sweeps down on your left, meeting another volcano on the right. Below them, the huge expanse of red earth, dented only by two or three giant gulleys, runs down to the base of your window. Not a single building, road, vegetation or people; handy, that last fact, as there's never any need to pull the curtains. You can sit in the Jacuzzi day or night and just stare and stare. Forget the moon; this looks like the view from hotel Mars. The abundance of water at the hotel nags at you; this can't be environmentally sustainable. webTitle: Simon Veness: A pushchair | A nanny | Park maps

fields.headline: Simon Veness never travels without...
fields.trailText: A pushchair | A nanny | Park maps
fields.body:
A necessity: A pushchair for children up to the age of six, even if they have long grown out of using one at home. Buy or borrow one before you go to Orlando. The parks are big, and it is physically demanding to go round them. You see a lot of kids getting very whingey because they are tired.

A luxury: The nanny services. The Disney properties have kids clubs, but if you stay outside there are very good babysitting services. Then the parents can get out on their own in Orlando where there is lots for them to do - nightclubs, restaurants and bars both within the Disney and Universal complexes and in Orlando itself. You need to give 24-hours notice to get a babysitter, but then you can be grown-up for an evening.

A memento: The nicest thing is the park maps. You get given them for free when you go in. Disney World is 47 square miles, and things change from year to year. So you can't possibly remember it all without a map.

If only: Orlando in the summer can easily reach 100F with 100% humidity. If you are walking around all day, then you do need to be very careful of the heat. The absolutely perfect thing to get an instant cool down would be an air-conditioned suit.

 Simon Veness is the author of A Brit's Guide to Orlando and Walt Disney World 2001, published by Foulsham Publishing at £11.99. To order a copy for £9.99 plus 99p UK p&p, freephone 0800 3166 102.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: What young professionals want from a holiday | Guardian wins
fields.body:
What young professionals want from a holiday

Nearly 50% of young professionals will travel solo in 2001, and "cultural interest" and "the desire to travel to somewhere never travelled before" are their two main motivators, according to some new research.

The survey of 300 young professionals also confirms the growing importance of the internet and guide books in influencing holiday destinations. When asked which methods would be used to research holiday arrangements, 67.4% said advice from family/friends, 72% mentioned guide books and 72% the internet. The travel agent was used by 56%. (Respondents were allowed to give more than one preference.)

But the internet did not do so well when it came to paying for holidays, with 28% chosing it as a possible method; 28% were likely to go direct with an operator, 13.5% to phone up after seeing a classified ad in a newspaper or magazine, and 56% would expect to use a travel agent.

The young professionals preferred holiday destinations were spread throughout the world. Western Europe came top with 19.3%, narrowly ahead of Australia/New Zealand 18.5%, Eastern Europe 16.8%, Africa 16%, South/Central America 13.9%, Asia 9.7%, US 9.2%, Round the World 7.1%, and other 10.5%.

Asked what type of activities they enjoyed doing on holiday, culture came top, with cultural sites/attractions appealing to 77.3%. Eating scored 76.4%, relaxing 75.1%, walking 68.6%, socialising 63.3%, shopping 54.6%, adrenaline sports 32.8%, cycling 27.9%, sailing 17.5%, scuba diving 26.2% and climbing 17.9%.

The research was commissioned by Independent Traveller's World, a travel show running February 23-25 at the Business Design Centre in Islington, London. Tickets cost £5 in advance at ITW Show or 0870 3331456.

Guardian wins

The Guardian has been awarded the Germany Tourism Media Trophy. This trophy - a bust of Goethe - goes to the publication judged to have made the most outstanding contribution to the promotion of travel to Germany during the year.

The awards were made at a ceremony hosted by the German ambassador, Dr Hans-Friedrich von Ploetz.

In 1999, UK travellers spent 3.4 million overnight stays in Germany, surpassing the previous record of 1990 - the year that the Berlin Wall came down. This year the number of UK visitors has risen by 14.4% so far.

fields.headline: Game and match
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor picks the best safari sites
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor picks the best safari sites
fields.body:
With their speeding-cheetah graphics, pulsing menus and broken pictures, safari sites are the poor relations of travel on the web. Few offer a decent booking system and most seem to have remained untouched since 1997.

Africa Safari Consultants

This "safari consultant" specialises in trophy-hunting and will organise shooting trips for visitors, including some in Benin, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

GORP Africa Resources
The unmistakable whiff of advertorial pervades this site, and the prose occasionally struggles to prop up the advertising. But if you have the patience to stumble through it, some helpful information is on offer.

Discovery Initiatives

fields.headline: Remember me? Part 2
fields.trailText: Given his father's history in New York, it was inevitable a few ghosts would haunt him. Given his father's history in New York, it was inevitable a few ghosts would haunt him. Once, he stopped into "some bodega-type record shop" and saw Dream Letter, the Tim Buckley concert album. Whether out of sorrow or pain, he immediately walked out. Killing time at bookstores, he would look up his father in rock history books. "I'm always testing him," he wrote in a letter to Tim's friend, Larry Beckett. "Born, wrote, sang, changed, changed, grew, grew, grew, ignored, rejected, revolution over evolution, gotta move, don't have much time, critics, rejected, dead ... revered. You fucks."

"I've tried to really believe it, that he really loved me," he wrote to an inquisitive fan of Tim's that summer. "I question that. He longed to see me, I believe that. He regretted not seeing me, yes. But he was too afraid for a very long time, 'just a young kid going down his own road', right, I understand, but I don't get it. It seems so over-romanticised, all of the accounts of his actions . . . How does a baby keep you from making records? ... I don't know - he just didn't want to be stuck with Mary, so typical, no frills, no big deal, I totally understand. But, love me? I don't know what that means."

The same appetite Jeff brought to the arts - absorbing a musician's or writer's body of work - was applied to his search for Tim. When Judy Buckley, Tim's widow, gave him tickets to a concert by the Cocteau Twins, Jeff told a friend he kissed Judy on the mouth - partly, he said, out of appreciation, and partly to feel exactly what Tim had seen in this woman. Even as he attempted to sort out the good, bad and ugly in his family's story, there remained the matter of his own music and career. He made a demo of four songs, which he called the Babylon Dungeon Sessions tape, but had had no response from the record companies, and his lack of a band meant he couldn't perform.

Then, early in 1991, Jeff was back on the west coast when the phone rang at the house where he was staying. A woman was calling long-distance, from New York, to tell Jeff about an upcoming concert she was co-ordinating. It was a tribute to his father, and she asked if he would like to attend.

No one working on the Greetings From Tim Buckley tribute concert at St Ann's, an arts centre in Brooklyn Heights, had known there was a son. Early on, one of concert organiser Janine Nichols's tasks was to find a publicity photograph of Tim, and she tracked down the name and number of Tim's old manager, Herb Cohen. In his cut-to-the-chase manner, Cohen said he not only had photographs but news: "You know he has a kid?" And, he continued, the child was more talented than his father. Nichols didn't think much of the information; offspring of 60s rock stars had begun sprouting up on the fringes of the music business, and most of them inherited their parents' looks but rarely their talent. Nevertheless, she jotted down the kid's name and number; the least they could do was invite him to the concert.

Nichols dialled the Los Angeles number, and the first thing she noticed about the voice on the other end of the line was how tiny it sounded. When she told Jeff why she was calling, he was hesitant. He'd never sung his father's music in public, he said, and had spent only a very limited amount of time with Tim. Nichols could tell he was very conflicted, and the faint voice asked for time to think it over.

Jeff mulled over the unexpected invitation. He still had ambivalent feelings about the paternal figure he barely recalled, and he had long studiously avoided any public connection to him. Yet something about the idea intrigued him. He called his mother and told her about the call. "I said, 'Well, what's your purpose? What do you want to get out of it?'" Mary recalls. "And he said, 'I always missed not going to the funeral.' I said, 'There you go - there's your reason, you'll pay tribute to your father.' " At the same time, she warned him to stay away from anyone who approached him about becoming "the next Tim Buckley".

By the time Nichols called back, about a month before the concert, Jeff had warmed to the idea. Neither of the organisers was sold on the kid's talent. They had listened to the demo tape he had sent and found it noisy. Still, Jeff agreed to come.

The tribute concert was part way through when a new group of musicians took the stage. One of them was a long-haired kid wearing a black T-shirt. Danny Fields, Tim's one-time publicist, was in the audience, keeping an eye out for the supposed son. Though Jeff had his back to the audience as he tuned his guitar, the spotlight caught his profile and one cheekbone. "And I said, 'Whoa - there he is,' " Fields recalls. "I didn't have to wonder too hard. It could take your breath away." ("My God," Jeff said to a friend after the show, "I stepped onstage and they backlit it and it was like the fucking Second Coming.")

Jeff, who had billed himself as Jeff Scott Buckley, began strumming rigorously as Gary Lucas, formerly with Captain Beefheart's band, surrounded him with waves of soaring-seagull guitar swoops. It was I Never Asked To Be Your Mountain, Tim's song to Mary and her son. The audience suddenly stopped glancing at their watches. After an hour of esoteric music, here was one of Tim's most recognisable songs, emanating from a very recognisable face and sung in a familiar (if slightly deeper) voice. Just before he went on stage, Jeff had finished writing his own verse for the song: "My love is the flower that lies among the graves," it began, ending with a plea to "spread my ash along the way". Anyone familiar with the subject matter of the song knew that this performance was more than a faithful rendition of a 60s oldie. It was a tribute, retort and catharsis all in one.

When it was time for a finale, Jeff appeared on stage alone. "Uhh," he started, with a nervous giggle, "a long time ago, when I was a little kid, my mom sat in a bed and she put this record on. And, uhh, it was like the first song where I ever heard my father's voice. I must have been ... umm ... six. I was bored." He chuckled winsomely. "I was bored. I'm sorry. But you know, what can you expect from a cat who's into Sesame Street at the time?"

Then he began singing Once I Was. Here was Jeff, on stage, singing his father's wistful remembrance of an old affair. Suddenly, before the last chorus, a string broke on his acoustic guitar and Jeff sang the lines, "Sometimes, I wonder for a while/Do you ever remember me?" unaccompanied. If that weren't dramatic enough, his voice spiralled up on the last word - "me" - like a thin plume of smoke, holding on for a moment before drifting up to the ceiling. He took a quick bow, said "thanks", disappeared off stage, and the concert ended. The audience was abuzz. So that was the son. Within a month, four record companies were vying for him. The irony of the situation was not lost on Jeff: after years of avoiding any connection with his late father, he had awakened the interest of the music business as a result of singing Tim's music, and he was being checked out by veteran record executives old enough to remember and admire his father. "I'm convinced part of the reason I got signed is because of who I am," Jeff said in 1993. "And it makes me sad. But I can't do anything else."

© David Browne 2001. This is an edited extract from Dream Brother: The Lives And Music Of Jeff And Tim Buckley, published by 4th Estate, at £17.99.

webTitle: Quiz: Win your own height in books

fields.headline: Win your own height in books
fields.standfirst: Bol. com and the Guardian have teamed up to offer you a literary brainteaser for the festive season. Get all 50 of these fiendish questions about classic books right, complete the tiebreaker, and you could win your own height in Penguin Classics of your choice
fields.trailText: Guardian / bol.com classics quiz
fields.body:
1. The most famous story of the "mad woman in the attic".

2. This masterly writer of "sensation fiction" advised writers to "Make 'em laugh, make 'em cry, make 'em wait."

3. A natural selection for any library of science classics.

4. Based on the true adventures of Alexander Selkirk, this book has been the inspiration for generations of castaways.

5. Convict Abel Magwitch turns out to behave in very unexpected ways in this serialised novel of the 1860s.

6. Whose pursuit of wisdom is often sidetracked by his pursuit of Sophia Western, who in turn is running away from the malicious Blifil?

7. A heroine, shocking to some, destroyed by debt and thwarted passion in 19th-century France.

8. An Angel cannot save this heroine, despite her parents' claims to an ancient lineage.

9. A great novel of a fatal flaw in an antique piece of crystal.

10. This author's reputation was secured by three chaps who weren't particularly good in the water.

11. John Malkovich and Glenn Close both mustered their more dangerous sides in a film depiction of this book.

12. The author's name is now a figure of speech, in no small part due to this brief tome on leadership skills written during the Renaissance.

13. Starbuck was first mate on the Pequod. Who was his captain?

14. One of Henry VIII's closest advisors had a vision of a place that didn't exist. What did he write as a consequence?

15. Whose virtue was rewarded in this 18th-century bestseller later parodied by Henry Fielding?

16. "The Modern Prometheus" was written for a competition in 1818. What is it better known as?

17. Which novel, published in instalments in 1760, opened with the narrator describing his own conception?

18. Where does Gulliver first get washed up?

19. Becky Sharp is chased by debtors in this Novel Without a Hero. Who wrote it?

20. In which book by Mark Twain does a solar eclipse form a vital piece of plot?

21. Who is the evil counterpart to Basil Hallwood's good angel in this 1890 Faustian tale?

22. The definitive, if unfinished, depiction of an English pilgrimage.

23. Spy, adventurer, playwright and translator, this author's childhood in the West Indies probably inspired her most famous work of romantic prose. What is it called?

24. Who wrote the memoirs of a woman of pleasure?

25. What followed The Pioneers in the series of novels known as the Leatherstocking Tales?

26. This American author wrote notebooks on America, England, France and Italy, but is better remembered for a letter. What was it called?

27. This book was filmed by Peter Greenaway, with Ewan McGregor in a revealing role.

28. For whom did things go badly when he donned yellow stockings and cross-garters?

29. This two-volume work is often cited as one of the first books to acknowledge the status of artists as more than craftspeople.

30. Jacob Marley introduces three warnings - but to whom?

31. Having famously lived a life without incident, the author of this satire on the gothic novel died at the age of 41. What was the novel called?

32. Written in Venice, retrieved by an American editor and burned by Tina. Which tale recounted the history of these letters?

33. Mrs Grundy never appears on stage, but her role is vital to the enduring reputation of which play of the 1800s?

34. The play within a play in Shakespeare's Hamlet is said to be inspired in part by a similar enactment in which tragedy?

35. Wit, alcoholic, libertine, intellectual, poet - what was John Wilmot's title?

36. Eight tales and 21 books all about one legendary king. By whom?

37. Which gentle tale of village life by a Chelsea-born novelist and biographer first appeared in sporadic episodes in Dickens's magazine Household Words?

38. A famous 18th-century actor-manager produced a musical version of which of Shakespeare's late plays?

39. A battle for the ownership of family gemstones forms the central plot in one novel in a famous series. How many novels precede it in the sequence?

40. Gwendolen's mother particularly deplored the receptacle in which a foundling was deposited. Who wrote the play in which she appears?

41. What fictional name did Smollett give the actor in question 38 while sending him up in The Adventures of Roderick Random?

42. Which great volume of lyrics of 1794 was subtitled "Shewing the Two Contrary States of the Human Soul"?

43. Which writer immortalised the lexicographer, scholar and husband of "Tetty"?

44. A tale of three brothers and their coats, by the author alluded to in question 18.

45. What does the Bellman mistakenly think he is hunting? (It actually turns out to be a boojum.)

46. A fictional City clerk became a figure of speech (and of fun) after his depiction in an entertaining Victorian novel. What was his son's name?

47. In what form of transport did the desperate Ethan try to kill himself and Mattie?

48. What title links Lord Byron with Anne Michaels?

49. Who loses both his love and his flock in a bucolic novel?

50. The author of the book in question 13 had real experience of "long pig". He wrote about it in which book?

Tie-breaker: Explain in fewer than 20 words which of the books published this year deserves to become a classic, and why.

 The winner will get their height in Penguin Classics of their choice. Enter by email to ruby@bol.com or by post to Ruby, BOL, Greater London House, Hampstead Road, London, NW1 7TZ. The closing date is January 8, after which the answers will be posted on www.bol.com.

webTitle: Will Clinton boom turn to Bush bust?

fields.headline: Will Clinton boom turn to Bush bust?
fields.standfirst:
High debt plus a slowdown could even lead to recession

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: High debt plus a slowdown could even lead to recession
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
Jane Martinson in New York and Larry Elliott Saturday December 16, 2000 21:57 If George W Bush imagined the news that he was finally destined to move into the White House would provide a tonic for Wall Street he has been given a rude awakening. The countdown to his inauguration in January began with two of America's biggest banks cutting 5,000 jobs on the back of profit warnings, and trade figures showing the US sinking deeper into the red.

In Austin, Texas, yesterday, Mr Bush said he was concerned about the risks of recession. Pointing to high energy prices and signs of slowing consumer demand, he said: "People are concerned about the economy. I think there is concern about some of the manufacturing base."

His comments were widely seen by economists as part of a political bid to win support for his tax-cutting proposals. However, one senior Wall Street economist warned last night: "Let's hope his comments don't prove self-fulfilling."

2020Comparisons will inevitably be made between the 43rd president of the United States and the 41st, his father George Bush. But what is concerning the markets at the moment is that the man who defeated Al Gore could turn out to have as rough a ride as the 31st president, Herbert Hoover.

In the five weeks since the bitterly contested election on November 7, the signs of an economic slowdown have multiplied to the point that some analysts fear the US is on the brink of a recession.

The American economy does have significant strengths. Unemployment is low and the budget is in surplus. But a wave of corporate earnings disappointments has highlighted the fact that both companies and consumers are spending less. The technology-dominated Nasdaq stock market has halved in value since its peak, while investors in broader-based stock market indices are also suffering.

The fear of redundancy as well as record levels of consumer indebtedness have prompted much of the uncertainty. Law firms have expanded their insolvency departments and more than 100 internet firms have folded since the beginning of this year, according to consultant Webmergers.com, and the trend is likely to accelerate.

Such difficulties are going to make the government's stewardship of the economy one of its most pressing concerns. Mr Bush will be particularly keen not to take over just as a recession is about to start. Even a so-called soft landing, with growth at around 2.5%, may feel like a recession after the last couple of years of 4-5% expansion.

But in a completely divided Washington - with both House and Senate neatly split down the middle - his hands are tied on what to do about it.

His campaign promises, such as a much-vaunted $1.2 trillion tax cut to stimulate spending over the next 10 years, will be hard to pull off.

Instead, the new president will be relying heavily on Alan Greenspan, chairman of the central bank, the Federal Reserve, to stimulate growth with cuts in interest rates. Mr Greenspan has already started to drop hints that monetary policy could be eased, possibly in the new year, if evidence of a hard landing accumulates.

But three big concerns loom. The first is the sheer level of indebtedness, both for consumers and companies. Many of the firms that embarked on ambitious expansion s are now seeing the cost of servicing their debt rise at a time when demand is falling. The banks are starting to get nervous.

The second problem is the need to keep the dollar strong in order to attract enough foreign capital into the US to finance the current account deficit and keep inflation low.

Larry Lindsay, the supply-sider who is Bush's closest economic adviser, does not have close links with Wall Street, and while he is tipped to be the key figure in setting economic policy, he is likely to do so from inside the White House rather than the treasury.

fields.headline: Tech sell-off gains pace
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Investors fled the US stock market yesterday as profits warnings from some of the world's largest companies exacerbated fears of a recession.
fields.body:
Investors fled the US stock market yesterday as profits warnings from some of the world's largest companies exacerbated fears of a recession.

Microsoft prompted the latest sell-off after it warned that earnings and revenues would be lower than expected next year after a slowdown in consumer and corporate spending.

The company's first profits warning in more than 10 years surprised investors, who had hoped it would be less vulnerable to a slowdown in consumer spending because of its dominant position in the corporate market.

Shares in the company, which had already more than halved since January, lost a further 8% yesterday morning to trade at just over $51.

Microsoft is one of only two companies to be found in all three leading US stock indices, so its announcement had wide repercussions.

The technology-driven Nasdaq Composite index was down about 5% at midday at 2608. It has fallen almost 10% this week and 48% from its March high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 200 points, or 2%, to 10,471 by lunchtime.

In London the FTSE 100 index fell 88 points to 6175.8.

Microsoft's warning, blamed on a slowdown around the world but particularly in the US, came after a similar disappointment from JP Morgan and Chase Manhattan. The roster of hi-tech companies to have warned in the past month includes Dell, Apple, Compaq, Intel and Gateway.

Unless there is a sharp upturn in the coming week, the Nasdaq Composite will record the worst annual performance in its history.2626

webTitle: Express boss seeks to axe 100 journalists

fields.headline: Express boss seeks to axe 100 journalists
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond, owner of the Daily and Sunday Express, is seeking heavy job cuts among the editorial staff of both papers as part of his continuing drive to rip costs out of the newspapers.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond, owner of the Daily and Sunday Express, is seeking heavy job cuts among the editorial staff of both papers as part of his continuing drive to rip costs out of the newspapers.

Mr Desmond, who bought Express Newspapers for £125m last month, has outlined his demands at a series of meetings with senior staff this week. Staff are braced for at least 100 redundancies, almost a quarter of the newspapers' headcount.

Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott has been told to come up with a plan for the cuts, which she is understood to be strongly resisting.

The Express titles employ around 450 editorial staff, compared with some 600 at the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday. The Express has undergone a large-scale reduction in staff over the past few years, mostly when the Daily and Sunday operations were merged four years ago.

Relations between Mr Desmond and Ms Boycott plumbed new depths last week when 60 support staff were made redundant. In a letter, which she distributed among staff, Ms Boycott condemned "heavy-handed" treatment of workers. She expressed outrage that management had sacked a pregnant woman as well as a disabled man who had been promised a job for life.

A number of journalists have already left of their own volition. Columnist Peter Hitchens and political editor Anthony Bevins are among those who have quit because they would not work for the new owner.

Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell publishes OK magazine, as well as a portfolio of soft porn titles including Asian Babes and Forty Plus.

He borrowed around £97m from Commerzbank to fund the Express acquisition and has claimed to have put up "tens of millions" of his own cash.

Earlier this week Mr Desmond sold the group's four websites for a nominal sum to stockbroker Seymour Pierce, which acts as his financial adviser.

Mr Desmond acquired the newspaper group, which also includes the Daily Star, after a bidding war begun by the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings. He saw off competition for the titles from Conrad Black's Hollinger, which owns the Telegraph Group, the Daily Mail & General Trust and the wealthy Hinduja brothers.

MPs have criticised the disposal of the newspapers to a company which publishes soft porn.
