fields.headline: Self-portrait, Carel Fabritius (1654)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Carel Fabritius (1622-1654), Rembrandt's greatest pupil. After training in Rembrandt's studio in the early 1640s, he moved to Delft in 1650 and did illusionistic murals and views of the city that experiment with strange perspectives and feature lonely, desolate characters. He was the most promising artist in a city where Pieter de Hooch and Jan Steen were also at work. He was young, gifted and had connections with the court of Orange. But at 10.30am on October 12, 1654, the gunpowder magazine of Delft exploded, leaving a vast, water-filled crater and devastating a large section of the city. The 32-year-old Fabritius was among the dead.

Subject: The uncompromising way he looks at us and the experimental nature of this painting make it almost certain this is a self-portrait. Rembrandt painted several self-portraits in which he affected military dress, and his former pupil seems to be playing the same game here.

Distinguishing features: He might be studying himself in the mirror, there's such a critical, mocking acuteness to those big, dark eyes, an honesty about who he is - the unshaven, creased lower cheek, the unkempt hair under the fine woolly hat - that makes the military armour he is wearing ironic. We don't think for one minute he's a soldier. He's a young man adopting armour as a badge of dashing ways and perhaps also as an assertion of the nobility of art: the artist as hero. His eyebrows flare furiously and his gaze is intense; you can't look back for long.

This is the self isolated, framed alone in space, and heightened by the setting of a storm-threatening sky, which was very unusual in 17th-century art. Out of the heavens, this picture suggests, a turbulent rainstorm, a bolt of lightning might come at any moment. And the same is true of the young man in armour, whose martial dress signifies rage and violence. He's a passionate man, a tempestuous soul full of energy.

It's impossible to look at this painting without mournful hindsight. It is signed and dated C Fabritius 1654, so it must have been painted, at the most, months before his death. There is a painting, also in the National Gallery, by the Delft painter Egbert van der Poel of the scene just after the explosion. It shows a space cleared of houses, with nothing but dirt, water and broken timbers. Houses are shells, the sky is as tumultuous as that in Fabritius's self-portrait, and in the foreground survivors are pulled clear of the rubble, while corpses - perhaps Fabritius among them - are wrapped in canvas shrouds. Van der Poel did 12 versions, so there must have been a demand for what appears to be an eyewitness record of the horror.

Fabritius's death was regarded by contemporaries as a tragedy - he was the most talented of Rembrandt's pupils. This self-portrait proves he was special. It is not in the least derivative of Rembrandt: Fabritius has a very distinctive, pale palette and a sparse, rigorous dryness completely different from Rembrandt's dark luxury. Yet, as in a Rembrandt portrait, you feel this is not just paint on canvas, but a real, rather astringent human mind confronting you.

Inspirations and influences: Fabritius was most famous for his murals, which were said to perfectly deceive the eye with their perspective realism. His extant paintings - especially his View of the City of Delft (1652) in the National Gallery - deploy disconcerting, panoramic trick perspectives and seem to have been connected to the optical experiments that fascinated the 17th-century Dutch, including Jan Vermeer, who probably used a camera obscura for his interior views. Vermeer, also a Delft artist, owned paintings by Fabritius. The biggest influence Fabritius had on Vermeer is the emotional texture of his painting, which is seen in this self-portrait as well as his nearly empty cityscapes: a melancholia and a reticence.

Where is it? The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).

webTitle: What were you looking at? Part 2

fields.headline: What were you looking at? Part 2
fields.trailText:
June Whitfield

Actor
fields.body:
June Whitfield

Actor

My favourite book this year was undoubtedly Chocolat by Joanne Harris (Bantam, £6.99). I was spellbound from start to finish, savouring the atmosphere of the little French village and almost tasting the delicious chocolate creations of Vianne. I would recommend it to everyone, chocoholic or not.

David Hare

Playwright

Bernard Berenson: "Culture is like a match burning in infinite darkness." Cyril Connolly: "Why do people always want to blow it out?" Bernard Berenson : "They don't want to, they just have to blow." As director of the Proms and the Edinburgh Festival, John Drummond has lived a life of heroic defiance against Berenson's blowers. His autobiography Tainted by Experience (Faber, £25) is even better than you would expect: illuminating about great music and musicians, crotchety, cheerful and highly enjoyable.

Paul Theroux

Writer

I greatly enjoyed Nixon by Anthony Summers (Gollancz, £20), a superbly researched and documented biography which I think is the last word on this dark and devious man. The facts about the Amazon set out by Patrick Tierney in Darkness in El Dorado (Norton, £27) appalled me but everyone should know them. This year I also managed to track down a scarce book that has eluded me for many years, Club Types of Nuclear Polynesia (1913) by William Churchill - the "club types" are not hearty, snooty, sherry drinkers but rather war clubs, marvels of Pacific art.

Antony Sher

Actor and writer

I was a schoolboy in Cape Town in 1966 when Prime Minister Verwoerd was stabbed to death in parliament. In A Mouthful of Glass (Granta, £12.99), Henk van Woerden has written a delicate, haunting biography of the assassin, Tsafendas, who was shunned by his family and kicked from country to country like junk because he was of mixed race. After the assassination he was certified mad. But are we born mad or do we have madness thrust upon us? Van Woerden's compassionate book addresses this question superbly.

Angela Rippon

Broadcaster

I couldn't wait for He Shall Thunder in the Sky (US: Avon Books, $7.50), the 12th Amelia Peabody mystery from the pen of Elizabeth Peters, so I bought it on the internet and paid a fortune to have it shipped from America on publication day. The books are set in Egypt at the turn of the century and are funny, informative, engrossing and completely unputdownable, with a cast of characters that become real to the reader from the very first book in the series, Crocodile on the Sandbank.

John Mortimer

Writer

Did Boswell invent Johnson, taking the author of some rather dull plays and pontificating journalism and and turning him into a fictional character as lovable and immortal as Falstaff or Micawber? This idea lies behind Adam Sisman's Boswell's Presumptuous Task (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99). No doubt Johnson was a great old sage, but Boswell emerges as the man of today. Often vain, frequently insecure, constantly lecherous, but an honest observer of his own weaknesses -and splendid company. He and Johnson were lucky to have found each other and to provide the material for another constantly entertaining book.

Rolf Harris

Entertainer

The Last English King by Julian Rathbone (Little, Brown, £16.99) is about the time of King Harold, Edward the Confessor and William the Conqueror. It's a brilliant factual account in novel form which wonderfully explains what England was like before the Normans invaded.

Robert Harris

Novelist

I have to confess, guiltily, to having immensely enjoyed the second volume of Alan Clark's diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld, £20). It may not have been as good as the first, but there is something almost heroic about Clark's reckless self-obsession. Boswell's Presumptuous Task by Adam Sisman (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99) succeeded triumphantly in focusing on one great human endeavour - the writing of the life of Samuel Johnson - and conjured from it a variety of insights into the nature of authorship, literary rivalry, fame, ambition, jealousy and friendship. I also much enjoyed Nero: The Man Behind the Myth by Richard Holland (Sutton, £19.99) which sought to portray Nero in a better light than usual: musically gifted, spendthrift and a would-be superstar, he emerged as a kind of Roman Elton John.

Michael Foot

Writer and former Labour leader

William Hazlitt's self-portrait peers out from the cover of A C Grayling's The Quarrel of the Age (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £25) - a good way indeed to make the bid for book of the year. To produce a work worthy of that picture is a fierce challenge. Dr Grayling understands the greatness of Hazlitt both as a thinker and a writer. He was the truest voice of the revolutionary spirit of his age. And since that prophesy is not yet fulfilled, Hazlitt seeks to instruct our century even more potently than his own.

Melvyn Bragg

Writer and broadcaster

I have written elsewhere about my admiration for Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, £20) and Alan Jenkins's The Drift (Chatto and Windus, £8.99). Jenkins's moving, clear-eyed portrayal of a time in the life of himself and his family and makes this a very fine collection. I also found Martin Amis's Experience (Jonathan Cape, £18) wholly intriguing in its richly detailed account of the relationships between his father and mother.

Max Stafford Clark

Director

Stuart Browne's searing Dangerous Parking (Bloomsbury, £9.99) is a robust and defiant novel about alcoholism and sex written in the face of the author's own struggle with cancer. It's brave and entertaining. But I was also educated by Ian McIntyre's biography, Garrick (Penguin, £12.99), and intend to give it to Trevor Nunn for Christmas. Garrick was a great actor, but also the manager of Drury Lane Theatre, and his efforts to please patrons, fix salaries and above all find new plays that suited the taste of the town show that running a major theatrical institution has been a perennial impossibility.

After the assassination he was certified mad. But are we born mad or do we have madness thrust upon us? Van Woerden's compassionate book addresses this question superbly. Angela Rippon Broadcaster I couldn't wait for He Shall Thunder in the Sky (US: Avon Books, $7.50), the 12th Amelia Peabody mystery from the pen of Elizabeth Peters, so I bought it on the internet and paid a fortune to have it shipped from America on publication day. The books are set in Egypt at the turn of the century and are funny, informative, engrossing and completely unputdownable, with a cast of characters that become real to the reader from the very first book in the series, Crocodile on the Sandbank. John Mortimer Writer Did Boswell invent Johnson, taking the author of some rather dull plays and pontificating journalism and and turning him into a fictional character as lovable and immortal as Falstaff or Micawber? This idea lies behind Adam Sisman's Boswell's Presumptuous Task (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99). No doubt Johnson was a great old sage, but Boswell emerges as the man of today. Often vain, frequently insecure, constantly lecherous, but an honest observer of his own weaknesses -and splendid company. He and Johnson were lucky to have found each other and to provide the material for another constantly entertaining book. Rolf Harris Entertainer The Last English King by Julian Rathbone (Little, Brown, £16.99) is about the time of King Harold, Edward the Confessor and William the Conqueror. It's a brilliant factual account in novel form which wonderfully explains what England was like before the Normans invaded. Robert Harris Novelist I have to confess, guiltily, to having immensely enjoyed the second volume of Alan Clark's diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld, £20). It may not have been as good as the first, but there is something almost heroic about Clark's reckless self-obsession. Boswell's Presumptuous Task by Adam Sisman (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99) succeeded triumphantly in focusing on one great human endeavour - the writing of the life of Samuel Johnson - and conjured from it a variety of insights into the nature of authorship, literary rivalry, fame, ambition, jealousy and friendship. I also much enjoyed Nero: The Man Behind the Myth by Richard Holland (Sutton, £19.99) which sought to portray Nero in a better light than usual: musically gifted, spendthrift and a would-be superstar, he emerged as a kind of Roman Elton John. Michael Foot Writer and former Labour leader William Hazlitt's self-portrait peers out from the cover of A C Grayling's The Quarrel of the Age (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £25) - a good way indeed to make the bid for book of the year. To produce a work worthy of that picture is a fierce challenge. Dr Grayling understands the greatness of Hazlitt both as a thinker and a writer. He was the truest voice of the revolutionary spirit of his age. And since that prophesy is not yet fulfilled, Hazlitt seeks to instruct our century even more potently than his own. Melvyn Bragg Writer and broadcaster I have written elsewhere about my admiration for Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, £20) and Alan Jenkins's The Drift (Chatto and Windus, £8.99). Jenkins's moving, clear-eyed portrayal of a time in the life of himself and his family and makes this a very fine collection. I also found Martin Amis's Experience (Jonathan Cape, £18) wholly intriguing in its richly detailed account of the relationships between his father and mother. Max Stafford Clark Director Stuart Browne's searing Dangerous Parking (Bloomsbury, £9.99) is a robust and defiant novel about alcoholism and sex written in the face of the author's own struggle with cancer. It's brave and entertaining. But I was also educated by Ian McIntyre's biography, Garrick (Penguin, £12.99), and intend to give it to Trevor Nunn for Christmas. Garrick was a great actor, but also the manager of Drury Lane Theatre, and his efforts to please patrons, fix salaries and above all find new plays that suited the taste of the town show that running a major theatrical institution has been a perennial impossibility.

fields.headline: Journeys into space
fields.standfirst: He staged his first Hamlet when he was seven. Now 75, he is one of the world's great theatrical innovators and his quest for truth has embraced eastern mysticism and hallucinogens.  Michael Billington reports

fields.body:
Peter Brook is an enigma. His productions, emanating from the Bouffes du Nord theatre complex in Paris, circle the globe. His writings on theatre, especially his pioneering book The Empty Space, have acquired canonical status. He is universally regarded, in the words of his friend Peter Hall, as "the leading director of his generation". Yet, although no one is more accessible, Brook remains strangely mysterious. Mick Gordon, one of his younger admirers who until recently ran London's Gate Theatre, describes him as "religiously private".

The work is the key to the man. That certainly seems the view of Brook's children, Irina and Simon, offspring of his marriage to the actress, Natasha Parry. Both live in Paris and both are directors: Irina of plays and Simon of television documentaries. In February, Simon starts shooting a film for French television, and, with luck, the BBC, in which he tracks his father round the major theatrical capitals: London, Paris, New York.

"I will try to unlock his personality," says Simon, "through getting him to talk about his past. One clue to him is that there is no sharp distinction between private and professional life. He has lots of interests, curiosities and friends, but everything feeds the work. He's certainly not the kind of man who goes to smart dinner-parties or fashionable restaurants." Peter Hall, who at 70 is five years younger than Brook, makes a similar point: "he doesn't litter his life with irrelevancies."

It would be wrong, however, to think of Brook as monkishly austere. Visit him in his office, at the top of a curving staircase in the Bouffes du Nord, and you find the space uncluttered, immaculate, but furnished with slightly more than the bare necessities: not only a state-of-the art CD player but a surprisingly large TV set. Does he actually watch much television? "I live off CNN," he says, "because it is irresistibly fascinating. And I've been glued to the American election crisis. It's actually Shakespearean because both Gore and Bush believe they're right. Bush and all his clan believe that he has honestly won according to the rules of the game. Yet Gore believes with equal sincerity that if every vote were to be recounted he has won.

Given Brook's insatiable curiosity, it's no surprise to find he is fascinated by politics. He has an omnivorous mind. John Heilpern in The Conference Of The Birds, a classic study of an exploratory journey Brook took through Africa with a group of actors, writes: "Apart from sport, almost anything interests him." And even Brook's mental block over sport has gradually begun to collapse.

"I always found," says Brook, "there were two things I'd skip in the newspaper: the sports pages and the financial pages. Now, I read the finance pages because I find the extraordinary global convulsions of the markets as intriguing as nuclear physics. Similarly with sport. I got caught up in the wave of soccer enthusiasm following France's victory in the world cup." Comforting, somehow, to think of Brook curling up in front of the Gallic equivalent of Match of the Day.

He becomes reticent only when questioned about the influence he has had on modern theatre. It is not just the productions from 1970's Midsummer Night's Dream onwards. The opening sentences of The Empty Space - originally delivered as a set of lectures and published in 1968 - have reverberated in theatres, makeshift and grand, across several continents: "I can take any empty space and call it a bare stage. A man walks across this empty space, whilst someone else is watching him and this is all that is needed for an act of theatre to be engaged."

Since Brook wrote that, the cumbersome trappings of conventional theatre have been discarded in basements and rooms all over the world: it is not all due to Brook, but he gave an accelerating historical movement an articulate voice. His emphasis on theatre as shared communal experience, rather than illusionist spectacle, has also had a decisive influence on a whole generation of directors. In Britain alone Deborah Warner, Declan Donnellan, Simon McBurney, Katie Mitchell and Mick Gordon are all, in a sense, Brook's children.

But, although they have all attended Brook's workshops in Paris, he hates to be thought of as a teacher, guru or proselytising missionary. "I'm wary," he says "of talking about influences. Everyone influences everyone else. Today it's standard to say that my work here in Paris has become so simple. But I know this is the end of a long process. If anyone looking at that work were to start out by saying I'm going to be 'minimalist' and 'simple' then I would be a bad influence.

"An influence can be healthy when things become startling and important because done for the first time. When, for instance, someone first said 'fuck' on the stage, that was an important act of liberation. When people started putting Shakespeare into unlikely period costumes - such as Robert Helpmann's Victorian Hamlet at Stratford in the 40s - that too helped break the mould. What you find with time is that all those broken conventions and taboos gradually lose their power - today I see Shakespeare productions where people are still in the same uniforms Orson Welles was using for Julius Caesar - and that formal influences can be dangerously misunderstood. All that can valuably be passed on needs to be renewed by each generation." However much he denies it, Brook has had as profound an influence on British theatre as Brecht: on its spaces and structures as well as its style. And others acknowledge it even if he doesn't. Diana Rigg has spoken of his "Svengali effect".

"The great thing about him," says Peter Hall, "is his capacity to go on reinventing himself. Don't forget that in the London theatre of the 40s and 50s he was the great post-war decorator. But I think his real legacy, since the move to Paris, is to have created a multi-racial company and to have brought theatre back to its absolute basics. We don't any longer go to the theatre to see a replica of the Titanic being sunk on stage. We can get that in the cinema. But if you have an actor holding a model of the Titanic in his hand and immersing it in water while actors express the grief and anguish of the event, then you have theatre. Peter's genius is to have seen that before anyone else."

Mick Gordon, who directed the Brook-influenced Intimate Death at London's Gate theatre, concurs, while seeing that facile imitation is a pitfall. "For my generation," he says, "The Empty Space was a kind of Bible. The danger is that people think they just have to follow Brook's precepts. But easy is not the same as simple. It requires great life-experience to achieve Peter's kind of simplicity. His mastery lies in his relation with the actor in the present. What he tries to have is as naked a human being on stage as possible."

Brook's stripped-down simplicity is the end-product of a long theatrical journey. But, if you search carefully, you can find hints of the later Brook in the early dazzling theatrical exhibitionist and even as far back as childhood. Brook's first stroke of luck was to be born, in Chiswick, west London, in 1925, into a highly intelligent immigrant family: as he lovingly describes them in his recent memoir, Threads Of Time, they take on the eccentric colouration of a family from a Stephen Poliakoff play. "I had learned as a child that I was Jewish and Russian," he writes, "but these words were abstract concepts to me; my impressions were deeply conditioned by England."

Their name, Bryk, was anglicised by a Dover immigration officer. Brook's father, Latvian by birth, was a manufacturing chemist and amateur inventor: his mother, from a German region of the Baltic, had sacrifice medical ambitions to become a chemist herself. Brook's father had invented army field telephones during the first world war, wrote revolutionary articles for émigré journals and later built up a pharmaceutical business, while his mother had manufactured antidotes to poison gas.

From his father Brook inherited energy and steel: from his mother his artistic temperament and capacity for reconciliation.But hints of the later Brook can be found in his fascination with the way things worked and in his precocious ability to see himself as the writer's collaborator. On his very first visit to the theatre as a toddler he cried loudly because he thought the painted frontcloth meant there'd be no movement. On his second visit, to the Chiswick Empire, he was disappointed because the actor playing Richard III was seen visibly breathing after his death. Only on his third visit, to JM Barrie's Dear Brutus, was he excited because he thought the doors and windows of the set all led to some magical world beyond.

Even more revealing is that Brook's own first venture into directing came at the age of seven: a four-hour Hamlet staged for his parents in which he acted every part himself. He kept a notebook of the production, inscribing it, "Hamlet by P Brook and W Shakespeare". You could say that life has come full circle and taught him the value of modesty: in his current adaptation of Hamlet at the Bouffes du Nord, Shakespeare at least gets top billing.

It was film, however, rather than theatre that fired the young Brook's imagination. He loathed his formal education at a variety of exclusive schools and seems to have learned most during a year in Switzerland with a misdiagnosed glandular complaint: he devoured books, especially detective stories, and became a keen filmgoer. Back in England he left school at 16, with audible relief, to write scripts for commercials: clearly, however, his Wellesian bravura ran somewhat ahead of his employers. John Heilpern in The Conference Of The Birds recounts a story about a rejected Brook ad.

"An amazingly sexy actress comes off stage and starts to take everything off - her clothes, her wig, her make-up, her eyelashes, her eyebrows, her wooden leg - until revealed before the camera is a wrinkled old hag who suddenly flashes a perfect smile. 'But these ,' she says, 'are all my own, thanks to Gibbs SR!'"

Brook's passion for cinema was requited more fully when he went up to Oxford in 1942. According to a contemporary: "It was as if he'd come up by public request. Rather like a high-pressure executive arriving to take over a dying business." Brook quickly assumed control of the university film society and, raising £250 from friends, shot his own hour-long version of Sterne's Sentimental Journey. The whole project aroused the ire of the Magdalen College authorities and, to guarantee his Oxford survival, Brook was asked to sign a pledge that he would have nothing to do with theatre or cinema again.

Of greater long-term significance was Brook's youthful chutzpah in visiting John Gielgud backstage at the Haymarket and asking if he could borrow some costumes from Love For Love for the film: with his usual impulsive generosity, Gielgud obliged, little knowing that his own faltering career would be redefined less than a decade later by Brook at Stratford in a landmark production of Measure For Measure in 1950.

What is staggering is the speed of Brook's ascent through the British theatre. On coming down Oxford, he was soon directing Cocteau's The Infernal Machine at a London theatre club: "I felt," says Brook, "like a boy given a vast box of toys to play with and that the text was mine as well." By the age of 20 he was directing Shaw and Shakespeare at Birmingham Rep. A year later he was at Stratford where his Watteauesque Love's Labour's Lost stunned all who saw it: not least a young Peter Hall who thought it "ravishingly beautiful" and vowed on the spot that he himself would one day run the Stratford theatre.

By 22 Brook had become director of productions at Covent Garden and learned to deal with the quirks of the operatic world. "Let's pretend to obey him now," he overheard one famous singer say to another. "Later on we can dictate." He also recalls that electricians would sometimes miss lighting cues because they were entranced by the music. "I suddenly realised," he says "how useful it is not to like what you are doing."

Brook left Covent Garden as rapidly as he arrived: he was fired after a production of Salome in which Strauss's score came a poor second to Salvador Dali's eccentric, Alice in Wonderland-like designs. But, despite his reputation as an enfant terrible, from 1945 to 1960 Brook shuttled between London, Stratford, Paris and New York pursuing a hectic career that voluptuously embraced plays, musicals, operas and movies. He listed "air travel", as well as playing the piano and painting, as his hobbies in Who's Who. When the critic Kenneth Tynan met Brook in the 1940s he wrote: "He is a small, sausage-shaped man: he looks edible, and one gets the notion that if one bit into him he would taste like fondant cream or preserved ginger... the eyes are tiny and deep-set - twinkling ice-picks... one feels he has never travelled anywhere on foot or on buses, but is wrapped up in silk and carried."

Not everything in Brook's frenetic 15 years of cultural commuting was a success: his 1952 film of The Beggar's Opera was a resounding flop foundering on his vision of Macheath as a Hogarthian rakehell which conflicted with Laurence Olivier's view of him as a gentleman highwayman. But three years later the two men were reunited at Stratford in a sensational Titus Andronicus that restored a forgotten play to the modern stage.

With its rape, amputation and cannibalism, the play seemed to anticipate Brook's later experiments in the Theatre of Cruelty, derived from the work of the French actor, poet and theoretician, Antonin Artaud. But, where Artaud envisaged a theatre in which the director was all- powerful, Brook, while designing the set and composing the music, worked in tandem with a great actor: together he and Olivier elevated a play that had always been thought of as bloodthirsty hackwork into a dry run for King Lear.

Today, this period of Brook's career in which he was in love with the theatre of shock, sensation and exotic effect, is a distant folk-memory. But it is vital to recall it for a complete understanding of the man. Tynan wrote in 1953: "Nobody could accuse Peter Brook of simplicity, though in the last year or so he has been straining every nerve to achieve it. He cooks with cream, blood and spices: bread-and-water addicts must look elsewhere."

Tynan goes on to depict Brook as a scourge of the avant-garde: "At the inaugural meeting of one highly progressive theatrical group, he rose and said that he was growing a little tired of people whose lives a chance visit to the Chinese theatre had changed. He had just returned from a trip to New York. 'What would happen to the Chinese theatre,' Brook wondered, 'if a Chinaman happened to drop in on Guys and Dolls?' The question came out magisterially, crisp as a biscuit and quite unanswerable."

And yet there is more continuity than one may suppose between the pathfinding Brook of today and that earlier scourge of the progressive. Tynan's anecdote shows that Brook has always had the capacity to pose subversive questions about the nature of theatre. Stylistically, Brook was also constantly aware of the magical property of an empty space: he cites the ending of his Covent Garden Boris Godunov where the hero is left alone bewailing the cycle of Russian tyranny. And, on the personal level, he has always been a nomadic, rootless figure searching for a spiritual meaning to life.

In 1951 he married a raven-haired, darkly beautiful actress of Russian origin, Natasha Parry. Fortunately she shares his wanderlust and their life together has taken them all over Europe, America, Asia and Africa. But the real revelation of Threads Of Time was that, even at the height of his commercial fame, Brook came under the spell of the Russian occult teacher, Gurdjieff, who has been variously described as a sage and a charlatan. To his followers, he was a wise man who sought for secret knowledge among the holy men of the east.

While working for a silkily autocratic West End impresario like Binkie Beaumont, Brook was also attending regular group-encounter sessions in north London with a close-cropped American Gurdjieff disciple, Jane Heap. Brook is tantalisingly vague about what precisely he was searching for: he calls it simply "something else". But throughout his life sceptical pragmatism and mystical belief have been held in a delicate balance. He has also disclosed that for a time he experimented with hallucinogenic drugs.

"I swallowed a pill made from the Mexican mushroom," he wrote in his autobiography... "it awoke an infinite sensibility just in the point of my index finger... had I penetrated to the heart of the fleeting moment?"

The turning-point in his professional life came in 1960 with the foundation of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Invited by Peter Hall to join as a co-director, Brook was able to create theatre in a more stable climate and with longer rehearsals: the first fruit was a famous, bare-stage King Lear that bore the imprint of both Brecht and Beckett and approached the play in a spirit of inquiring moral neutrality.

Brook also displayed his private loyalty to Hall. "He's one of my three or four closest friends," says Hall "but if I had a normal crisis I wouldn't ring him. If I had a major crisis, then I would. When I had a complete breakdown during rehearsals of The Wars of the Roses in 1963 it was Peter who, along with my first wife and Peggy Ashcroft, was magnificent and who, in spite of the doctors' warnings, urged me to get back to work; and he was right."

Hall matched Brook's loyalty. When the latter asked for time and money in 1964 to set up at a London drama school an experimental season called Theatre of Cruelty, based on Artaud's belief in a theatre that would give expression to the audience's dreams and obsessions, Hall instantly agreed; and the result, chiefly memorable for the sight of Glenda Jackson taking off her clothes and being garbed in the drab uniform of a female prisoner, was pivotal for Brook. "This," he says, "was the big turning-point: the moment when I realised that my ideal was not simply to mount existing texts but to explore the nature of theatre itself."

This didn't stop him directing Peter Weiss's somewhat turgid debate about political and sexual revolution, the Marat -Sade, and turning it in 1964 into an unforgettable physical spectacle. In 1970 he went on to create a celebrated airborne production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Viewing a clip of it on television today in Richard Eyre's Changing Stages series, Brook says: "Thank God I resisted all the pressures of the time to make a film of it - that little fragment is far more evocative than if one had the whole thing pretending to be a permanent record." But even before The Dream it was clear that Brook was growingly impatient with British theatre's preoccupation with product rather than process.

Tynan wrote prophetically: "Phlegmatically, we await the Messiah. Let us pray that someone will buy him a theatre, give him a company of 20 actors... a permanent staff of playwrights and a free hand. Only by such benefactions are styles born and developed. All that is needed is £100,000 and the patience to to wait 10 years for effective results." But it was to be the French, rather than the British, who were to offer Brook the support and sanctuary his pioneering approach to theatre required.

As Hall recalls: "Peter came to me in 1966 and told me that he was trying to set up a research group in Paris. I begged him to stay here and do it under the umbrella of the RSC. I promised to do everything I could to fund it. He said 'It won't work. Research and development aren't accepted in the arts in Britain.' And he was right. But I still think he was a great loss to us."

With hindsight, Brook's decision to move to Paris in 1970 and set up the International Centre for Theatre Research and eventually to take over a battered, crumbling shell of a theatre, the Bouffes du Nord, was instinctively correct. It has given him creative freedom. It has enabled him to stage an astonishing body of public work starting with Timon of Athens in 1974 and continuing through The Conference Of The Birds, The Cherry Orchard, Carmen, The Mahabharata, The Man Who, and Le Costume, which comes to the Young Vic in January under the banner of the London International Festival of Theatre.

Touring, in fact, is economically vital to the Bouffes: it is financed as much by its own foreign earnings as by the French ministry of culture. But Brook absolutely does the work he wants: which is why, as the critic Irving Wardle once pointed out, his productions follow an organic pattern, each giving birth to the next, in a way that is more common amongst writers than directors. Where once he imprinted himself on a play, Brook also now directs with an invisible thread. But admiration is by no means universal: The Mahabharata, in particular, was coolly received by many New York critics including Frank Rich of the New York Times who called it "a smorgasbord of Oriental stagecraft". And in Paris many of the young allegedly find Brook "old-fashioned" though they conspicuously pack out his theatre.

Looking back, at the age of 75, Brook has no regrets about leaving England. "I didn't," he says, "take the decision dramatically. I didn't have any reason for feeling badly treated at home: I just knew that Paris would be more conducive to the kind of research work I wanted to do. And I honestly don't think I would today have the same freedom and tranquillity in England that I have here. When I look at all the pressures on people I know in England I'm appalled: the constant media spotlight, the preoccupation with who's in and out of fashion, the hassles over funding. I see what poor Trevor [Nunn] is going through at his moment and I feel grateful to be in Paris."

Brook is anxious, however, to dispel the notion that he has found the holy grail or that the Bouffes is some kind of religious temple: in the end, it is a converted vaudeville and musical house that puts on shows. "I don't believe, for one moment," he says, "that theatre should be a substitute for religion. The ideal is to be able to link elements in the same way as in traditional societies the shoemaker makes his shoes and is not cut off from the person who goes to the mosque on Friday. The shoemaker doesn't go to the pantheistic point of thinking shoes are god and that, in fashioning them, he is fulfilling a spiritual exercise. One tries to keep a sense of proportion and make theatre as best one can.

"Theatre is not a monastery. Which is where my great friend, Grotowski, and I agreed to differ. He withdrew completely from performance and his last work was with six people created in monastic conditions and exhibited once a year. He was a great man who underwent a huge spiritual journey. I am making practical theatre as best I can. Which is why I did Woza Albert after The Mahabharata, and Le Costume immediately before Hamlet."

Le Costume, a poetic South African fable set in 1950s Sophiatown, the Johannesburg black township, and dealing with a husband's strange revenge on his unfaithful wife, is Brook at his most buoyant. The Tragedy Of Hamlet, recently opened, is Brook at his most reflective: it is as if he finds in Hamlet's constant questioning an echo of his own spiritual restlessness.

Professionally, it would be punningly easy to say the commercial showman turned into the art-house shaman: easy but wrong since the two have always been inextricably intertwined in Brook's career. On a personal level, Brook remains unknown except to close family and friends. He is horrified at the prospect of anyone writing his biography: he argues that no one would find his life remotely interesting. What he has chosen to disclose is there in Threads Of Time. All one can deduce is that he remains protectively loving towards his wife, Natasha - who plays Gertrude in Hamlet - and that he depends heavily for the organisation of his daily life on her sister, Nina: the Bouffes is very much a family business. But, in many ways, his most intimate friendship seems to be with his young amanuensis, Marie-Hélène Estienne, who casts all his shows and who acts as his constant counsellor and artistic collaborator.

Brook's children provide the most revealing glimpse of him. Irina, now 38 and a mother, recalls the sheer fun of being Peter Brook's daughter. "The first production of his I saw was A Midsummer Night's Dream when I was about eight. I became a complete Dream groupie and backstage brat seeing it about 85 times and falling in love with all the boys and girls. Obviously, I had a nomadic childhood and I'd join my parents for Christmas in Africa, America or Iran or wherever. Peter was always travelling but he was far better than any normal father because he was so inventive and imaginative with children. He'd tell marvellous stories or find funny ways of giving presents by following arrows or inventing quizzes."

The 34-year-old Simon also feels that the inevitable absences were more than made up for by the vitality of Brook's presence. "He couldn't have been a better father," says Simon "in that he left me curious about everything. I suppose what I've learned from him in making documentaries is never to arrive with preconceived ideas: the importance of not imposing a form from the outside but of discovering the form that is there. I recently was in Ethiopia and made a film about a tribe who take a root and place it in a muddy stream and thereby clarify the water. I think that's very much how Peter works. He takes what was previously opaque and obscure and makes it seem transparent."

Life at a glance: Peter Stephen Paul Brook.

Born: March 1, 1925.

Education: Westminster, Gresham's 1936-41. Magdalen College, Oxford, 1942-44.

Married: 1951 Natasha Parry (daughter Irina born '62, son Simon born '66).

Career: Directs first play, Dr Faus tus, Torch Theatre, London 1942; director of productions Covent Garden 1948-9; director West End and Broadway '50s; RSC associate director from '62 staging King Lear, Theatre of Cruelty season at LAMDA and A Midsummer Night's Dream; films Lord of the Flies '61; creates International Centre for Theatre Research, Paris '70, director Bouffes du Nord '74-: productions include Timon Of Athens, The Cherry Orchard, Carmen, The Mahabharata, The Tragedy Of Hamlet.

Some publications: The Empty Space, 1968; Threads Of Time (memoir) 1998; Evoking Shakespeare 1999

 Le Costume is at the Young Vic, London from January 24 to February 3. Box Office: 020 7928 6363.

He becomes reticent only when questioned about the influence he has had on modern theatre. It is not just the productions from 1970's Midsummer Night's Dream onwards. The opening sentences of The Empty Space - originally delivered as a set of lectures and published in 1968 - have reverberated in theatres, makeshift and grand, across several continents: "I can take any empty space and call it a bare stage. A man walks across this empty space, whilst someone else is watching him and this is all that is needed for an act of theatre to be engaged." Since Brook wrote that, the cumbersome trappings of conventional theatre have been discarded in basements and rooms all over the world: it is not all due to Brook, but he gave an accelerating historical movement an articulate voice. His emphasis on theatre as shared communal experience, rather than illusionist spectacle, has also had a decisive influence on a whole generation of directors. In Britain alone Deborah Warner, Declan Donnellan, Simon McBurney, Katie Mitchell and Mick Gordon are all, in a sense, Brook's children. But, although they have all attended Brook's workshops in Paris, he hates to be thought of as a teacher, guru or proselytising missionary. "I'm wary," he says "of talking about influences. Everyone influences everyone else. Today it's standard to say that my work here in Paris has become so simple. But I know this is the end of a long process. If anyone looking at that work were to start out by saying I'm going to be 'minimalist' and 'simple' then I would be a bad influence. "An influence can be healthy when things become startling and important because done for the first time. When, for instance, someone first said 'fuck' on the stage, that was an important act of liberation. When people started putting Shakespeare into unlikely period costumes - such as Robert Helpmann's Victorian Hamlet at Stratford in the 40s - that too helped break the mould. What you find with time is that all those broken conventions and taboos gradually lose their power - today I see Shakespeare productions where people are still in the same uniforms Orson Welles was using for Julius Caesar - and that formal influences can be dangerously misunderstood. All that can valuably be passed on needs to be renewed by each generation." However much he denies it, Brook has had as profound an influence on British theatre as Brecht: on its spaces and structures as well as its style. And others acknowledge it even if he doesn't. Diana Rigg has spoken of his "Svengali effect". "The great thing about him," says Peter Hall, "is his capacity to go on reinventing himself. Don't forget that in the London theatre of the 40s and 50s he was the great post-war decorator. But I think his real legacy, since the move to Paris, is to have created a multi-racial company and to have brought theatre back to its absolute basics. We don't any longer go to the theatre to see a replica of the Titanic being sunk on stage. We can get that in the cinema. But if you have an actor holding a model of the Titanic in his hand and immersing it in water while actors express the grief and anguish of the event, then you have theatre. Peter's genius is to have seen that before anyone else." Mick Gordon, who directed the Brook-influenced Intimate Death at London's Gate theatre, concurs, while seeing that facile imitation is a pitfall. "For my generation," he says, "The Empty Space was a kind of Bible. The danger is that people think they just have to follow Brook's precepts. But easy is not the same as simple. It requires great life-experience to achieve Peter's kind of simplicity. His mastery lies in his relation with the actor in the present. What he tries to have is as naked a human being on stage as possible." Brook's stripped-down simplicity is the end-product of a long theatrical journey. But, if you search carefully, you can find hints of the later Brook in the early dazzling theatrical exhibitionist and even as far back as childhood. Brook's first stroke of luck was to be born, in Chiswick, west London, in 1925, into a highly intelligent immigrant family: as he lovingly describes them in his recent memoir, Threads Of Time, they take on the eccentric colouration of a family from a Stephen Poliakoff play. "I had learned as a child that I was Jewish and Russian," he writes, "but these words were abstract concepts to me; my impressions were deeply conditioned by England." Their name, Bryk, was anglicised by a Dover immigration officer. Brook's father, Latvian by birth, was a manufacturing chemist and amateur inventor: his mother, from a German region of the Baltic, had sacrifice medical ambitions to become a chemist herself. Brook's father had invented army field telephones during the first world war, wrote revolutionary articles for émigré journals and later built up a pharmaceutical business, while his mother had manufactured antidotes to poison gas. From his father Brook inherited energy and steel: from his mother his artistic temperament and capacity for reconciliation.But hints of the later Brook can be found in his fascination with the way things worked and in his precocious ability to see himself as the writer's collaborator. On his very first visit to the theatre as a toddler he cried loudly because he thought the painted frontcloth meant there'd be no movement. On his second visit, to the Chiswick Empire, he was disappointed because the actor playing Richard III was seen visibly breathing after his death. Only on his third visit, to JM Barrie's Dear Brutus, was he excited because he thought the doors and windows of the set all led to some magical world beyond. Even more revealing is that Brook's own first venture into directing came at the age of seven: a four-hour Hamlet staged for his parents in which he acted every part himself. He kept a notebook of the production, inscribing it, "Hamlet by P Brook and W Shakespeare". You could say that life has come full circle and taught him the value of modesty: in his current adaptation of Hamlet at the Bouffes du Nord, Shakespeare at least gets top billing. It was film, however, rather than theatre that fired the young Brook's imagination. He loathed his formal education at a variety of exclusive schools and seems to have learned most during a year in Switzerland with a misdiagnosed glandular complaint: he devoured books, especially detective stories, and became a keen filmgoer. Back in England he left school at 16, with audible relief, to write scripts for commercials: clearly, however, his Wellesian bravura ran somewhat ahead of his employers. John Heilpern in The Conference Of The Birds recounts a story about a rejected Brook ad. "An amazingly sexy actress comes off stage and starts to take everything off - her clothes, her wig, her make-up, her eyelashes, her eyebrows, her wooden leg - until revealed before the camera is a wrinkled old hag who suddenly flashes a perfect smile. 'But these ,' she says, 'are all my own, thanks to Gibbs SR!'" Brook's passion for cinema was requited more fully when he went up to Oxford in 1942. According to a contemporary: "It was as if he'd come up by public request. Rather like a high-pressure executive arriving to take over a dying business." Brook quickly assumed control of the university film society and, raising £250 from friends, shot his own hour-long version of Sterne's Sentimental Journey. The whole project aroused the ire of the Magdalen College authorities and, to guarantee his Oxford survival, Brook was asked to sign a pledge that he would have nothing to do with theatre or cinema again. Of greater long-term significance was Brook's youthful chutzpah in visiting John Gielgud backstage at the Haymarket and asking if he could borrow some costumes from Love For Love for the film: with his usual impulsive generosity, Gielgud obliged, little knowing that his own faltering career would be redefined less than a decade later by Brook at Stratford in a landmark production of Measure For Measure in 1950. What is staggering is the speed of Brook's ascent through the British theatre. On coming down Oxford, he was soon directing Cocteau's The Infernal Machine at a London theatre club: "I felt," says Brook, "like a boy given a vast box of toys to play with and that the text was mine as well." By the age of 20 he was directing Shaw and Shakespeare at Birmingham Rep. A year later he was at Stratford where his Watteauesque Love's Labour's Lost stunned all who saw it: not least a young Peter Hall who thought it "ravishingly beautiful" and vowed on the spot that he himself would one day run the Stratford theatre. By 22 Brook had become director of productions at Covent Garden and learned to deal with the quirks of the operatic world. "Let's pretend to obey him now," he overheard one famous singer say to another. "Later on we can dictate." He also recalls that electricians would sometimes miss lighting cues because they were entranced by the music. "I suddenly realised," he says "how useful it is not to like what you are doing." Brook left Covent Garden as rapidly as he arrived: he was fired after a production of Salome in which Strauss's score came a poor second to Salvador Dali's eccentric, Alice in Wonderland-like designs. But, despite his reputation as an enfant terrible, from 1945 to 1960 Brook shuttled between London, Stratford, Paris and New York pursuing a hectic career that voluptuously embraced plays, musicals, operas and movies. He listed "air travel", as well as playing the piano and painting, as his hobbies in Who's Who. When the critic Kenneth Tynan met Brook in the 1940s he wrote: "He is a small, sausage-shaped man: he looks edible, and one gets the notion that if one bit into him he would taste like fondant cream or preserved ginger... the eyes are tiny and deep-set - twinkling ice-picks... one feels he has never travelled anywhere on foot or on buses, but is wrapped up in silk and carried." Not everything in Brook's frenetic 15 years of cultural commuting was a success: his 1952 film of The Beggar's Opera was a resounding flop foundering on his vision of Macheath as a Hogarthian rakehell which conflicted with Laurence Olivier's view of him as a gentleman highwayman. But three years later the two men were reunited at Stratford in a sensational Titus Andronicus that restored a forgotten play to the modern stage. With its rape, amputation and cannibalism, the play seemed to anticipate Brook's later experiments in the Theatre of Cruelty, derived from the work of the French actor, poet and theoretician, Antonin Artaud. But, where Artaud envisaged a theatre in which the director was all- powerful, Brook, while designing the set and composing the music, worked in tandem with a great actor: together he and Olivier elevated a play that had always been thought of as bloodthirsty hackwork into a dry run for King Lear. Today, this period of Brook's career in which he was in love with the theatre of shock, sensation and exotic effect, is a distant folk-memory. But it is vital to recall it for a complete understanding of the man. Tynan wrote in 1953: "Nobody could accuse Peter Brook of simplicity, though in the last year or so he has been straining every nerve to achieve it. He cooks with cream, blood and spices: bread-and-water addicts must look elsewhere." Tynan goes on to depict Brook as a scourge of the avant-garde: "At the inaugural meeting of one highly progressive theatrical group, he rose and said that he was growing a little tired of people whose lives a chance visit to the Chinese theatre had changed. He had just returned from a trip to New York. 'What would happen to the Chinese theatre,' Brook wondered, 'if a Chinaman happened to drop in on Guys and Dolls?' The question came out magisterially, crisp as a biscuit and quite unanswerable." And yet there is more continuity than one may suppose between the pathfinding Brook of today and that earlier scourge of the progressive. Tynan's anecdote shows that Brook has always had the capacity to pose subversive questions about the nature of theatre. Stylistically, Brook was also constantly aware of the magical property of an empty space: he cites the ending of his Covent Garden Boris Godunov where the hero is left alone bewailing the cycle of Russian tyranny. And, on the personal level, he has always been a nomadic, rootless figure searching for a spiritual meaning to life. In 1951 he married a raven-haired, darkly beautiful actress of Russian origin, Natasha Parry. Fortunately she shares his wanderlust and their life together has taken them all over Europe, America, Asia and Africa. But the real revelation of Threads Of Time was that, even at the height of his commercial fame, Brook came under the spell of the Russian occult teacher, Gurdjieff, who has been variously described as a sage and a charlatan. To his followers, he was a wise man who sought for secret knowledge among the holy men of the east. While working for a silkily autocratic West End impresario like Binkie Beaumont, Brook was also attending regular group-encounter sessions in north London with a close-cropped American Gurdjieff disciple, Jane Heap. Brook is tantalisingly vague about what precisely he was searching for: he calls it simply "something else". But throughout his life sceptical pragmatism and mystical belief have been held in a delicate balance. He has also disclosed that for a time he experimented with hallucinogenic drugs. "I swallowed a pill made from the Mexican mushroom," he wrote in his autobiography... "it awoke an infinite sensibility just in the point of my index finger... had I penetrated to the heart of the fleeting moment?" The turning-point in his professional life came in 1960 with the foundation of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Invited by Peter Hall to join as a co-director, Brook was able to create theatre in a more stable climate and with longer rehearsals: the first fruit was a famous, bare-stage King Lear that bore the imprint of both Brecht and Beckett and approached the play in a spirit of inquiring moral neutrality. Brook also displayed his private loyalty to Hall. "He's one of my three or four closest friends," says Hall "but if I had a normal crisis I wouldn't ring him. If I had a major crisis, then I would. When I had a complete breakdown during rehearsals of The Wars of the Roses in 1963 it was Peter who, along with my first wife and Peggy Ashcroft, was magnificent and who, in spite of the doctors' warnings, urged me to get back to work; and he was right." Hall matched Brook's loyalty. When the latter asked for time and money in 1964 to set up at a London drama school an experimental season called Theatre of Cruelty, based on Artaud's belief in a theatre that would give expression to the audience's dreams and obsessions, Hall instantly agreed; and the result, chiefly memorable for the sight of Glenda Jackson taking off her clothes and being garbed in the drab uniform of a female prisoner, was pivotal for Brook. "This," he says, "was the big turning-point: the moment when I realised that my ideal was not simply to mount existing texts but to explore the nature of theatre itself." This didn't stop him directing Peter Weiss's somewhat turgid debate about political and sexual revolution, the Marat -Sade, and turning it in 1964 into an unforgettable physical spectacle. In 1970 he went on to create a celebrated airborne production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Viewing a clip of it on television today in Richard Eyre's Changing Stages series, Brook says: "Thank God I resisted all the pressures of the time to make a film of it - that little fragment is far more evocative than if one had the whole thing pretending to be a permanent record." But even before The Dream it was clear that Brook was growingly impatient with British theatre's preoccupation with product rather than process. Tynan wrote prophetically: "Phlegmatically, we await the Messiah. Let us pray that someone will buy him a theatre, give him a company of 20 actors... a permanent staff of playwrights and a free hand. Only by such benefactions are styles born and developed. All that is needed is £100,000 and the patience to to wait 10 years for effective results." But it was to be the French, rather than the British, who were to offer Brook the support and sanctuary his pioneering approach to theatre required. As Hall recalls: "Peter came to me in 1966 and told me that he was trying to set up a research group in Paris. I begged him to stay here and do it under the umbrella of the RSC. I promised to do everything I could to fund it. He said 'It won't work. Research and development aren't accepted in the arts in Britain.' And he was right. But I still think he was a great loss to us." With hindsight, Brook's decision to move to Paris in 1970 and set up the International Centre for Theatre Research and eventually to take over a battered, crumbling shell of a theatre, the Bouffes du Nord, was instinctively correct. It has given him creative freedom. It has enabled him to stage an astonishing body of public work starting with Timon of Athens in 1974 and continuing through The Conference Of The Birds, The Cherry Orchard, Carmen, The Mahabharata, The Man Who, and Le Costume, which comes to the Young Vic in January under the banner of the London International Festival of Theatre. Touring, in fact, is economically vital to the Bouffes: it is financed as much by its own foreign earnings as by the French ministry of culture. But Brook absolutely does the work he wants: which is why, as the critic Irving Wardle once pointed out, his productions follow an organic pattern, each giving birth to the next, in a way that is more common amongst writers than directors. Where once he imprinted himself on a play, Brook also now directs with an invisible thread. But admiration is by no means universal: The Mahabharata, in particular, was coolly received by many New York critics including Frank Rich of the New York Times who called it "a smorgasbord of Oriental stagecraft". And in Paris many of the young allegedly find Brook "old-fashioned" though they conspicuously pack out his theatre. Looking back, at the age of 75, Brook has no regrets about leaving England. "I didn't," he says, "take the decision dramatically. I didn't have any reason for feeling badly treated at home: I just knew that Paris would be more conducive to the kind of research work I wanted to do. And I honestly don't think I would today have the same freedom and tranquillity in England that I have here. When I look at all the pressures on people I know in England I'm appalled: the constant media spotlight, the preoccupation with who's in and out of fashion, the hassles over funding. I see what poor Trevor [Nunn] is going through at his moment and I feel grateful to be in Paris." Brook is anxious, however, to dispel the notion that he has found the holy grail or that the Bouffes is some kind of religious temple: in the end, it is a converted vaudeville and musical house that puts on shows. "I don't believe, for one moment," he says, "that theatre should be a substitute for religion. The ideal is to be able to link elements in the same way as in traditional societies the shoemaker makes his shoes and is not cut off from the person who goes to the mosque on Friday. The shoemaker doesn't go to the pantheistic point of thinking shoes are god and that, in fashioning them, he is fulfilling a spiritual exercise. One tries to keep a sense of proportion and make theatre as best one can. "Theatre is not a monastery. Which is where my great friend, Grotowski, and I agreed to differ. He withdrew completely from performance and his last work was with six people created in monastic conditions and exhibited once a year. He was a great man who underwent a huge spiritual journey. I am making practical theatre as best I can. Which is why I did Woza Albert after The Mahabharata, and Le Costume immediately before Hamlet." Le Costume, a poetic South African fable set in 1950s Sophiatown, the Johannesburg black township, and dealing with a husband's strange revenge on his unfaithful wife, is Brook at his most buoyant. The Tragedy Of Hamlet, recently opened, is Brook at his most reflective: it is as if he finds in Hamlet's constant questioning an echo of his own spiritual restlessness. Professionally, it would be punningly easy to say the commercial showman turned into the art-house shaman: easy but wrong since the two have always been inextricably intertwined in Brook's career. On a personal level, Brook remains unknown except to close family and friends. He is horrified at the prospect of anyone writing his biography: he argues that no one would find his life remotely interesting. What he has chosen to disclose is there in Threads Of Time. All one can deduce is that he remains protectively loving towards his wife, Natasha - who plays Gertrude in Hamlet - and that he depends heavily for the organisation of his daily life on her sister, Nina: the Bouffes is very much a family business. But, in many ways, his most intimate friendship seems to be with his young amanuensis, Marie-Hélène Estienne, who casts all his shows and who acts as his constant counsellor and artistic collaborator. Brook's children provide the most revealing glimpse of him. Irina, now 38 and a mother, recalls the sheer fun of being Peter Brook's daughter. "The first production of his I saw was A Midsummer Night's Dream when I was about eight. I became a complete Dream groupie and backstage brat seeing it about 85 times and falling in love with all the boys and girls. Obviously, I had a nomadic childhood and I'd join my parents for Christmas in Africa, America or Iran or wherever. Peter was always travelling but he was far better than any normal father because he was so inventive and imaginative with children. He'd tell marvellous stories or find funny ways of giving presents by following arrows or inventing quizzes." The 34-year-old Simon also feels that the inevitable absences were more than made up for by the vitality of Brook's presence. "He couldn't have been a better father," says Simon "in that he left me curious about everything. I suppose what I've learned from him in making documentaries is never to arrive with preconceived ideas: the importance of not imposing a form from the outside but of discovering the form that is there. I recently was in Ethiopia and made a film about a tribe who take a root and place it in a muddy stream and thereby clarify the water. I think that's very much how Peter works. He takes what was previously opaque and obscure and makes it seem transparent." Life at a glance: Peter Stephen Paul Brook. Born: March 1, 1925. Education: Westminster, Gresham's 1936-41. Magdalen College, Oxford, 1942-44. Married: 1951 Natasha Parry (daughter Irina born '62, son Simon born '66). Career: Directs first play, Dr Faus tus, Torch Theatre, London 1942; director of productions Covent Garden 1948-9; director West End and Broadway '50s; RSC associate director from '62 staging King Lear, Theatre of Cruelty season at LAMDA and A Midsummer Night's Dream; films Lord of the Flies '61; creates International Centre for Theatre Research, Paris '70, director Bouffes du Nord '74-: productions include Timon Of Athens, The Cherry Orchard, Carmen, The Mahabharata, The Tragedy Of Hamlet. Some publications: The Empty Space, 1968; Threads Of Time (memoir) 1998; Evoking Shakespeare 1999  Le Costume is at the Young Vic, London from January 24 to February 3. Box Office: 020 7928 6363.

fields.headline: Richard Goode talks to his piano
fields.standfirst:
Richard Goode
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Richard Goode
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
A near-capacity audience turned out for the latest instalment of this year's Harrods International Piano Series, including, unusually, a fair number of children. "Look! It's the piano!" shouted one of them excitedly as we queued up to enter the hall, craning to see the instrument on the outside monitor. Blasé adults may have smiled condescendingly, but if they'd been asked for their own reaction in mid-recital they might have come up with the same level of revelation.

There are few people who can put across the sheer joy of playing the instrument better than American pianist Richard Goode. To watch him play is to look through a window on to a very private world - utterly absorbed in the music, he plays as if nobody else is there, even humming along. His face is never still; he seems literally to be attempting conversation with the piano.

Goode's genuinely un- affected approach brought out the best in his programme of Bach, Chopin and Beethoven. What stood out was not the novelty or individuality of each composer, but in fact how similar their intentions were. To all of the works Goode brought a remarkable clarity of line, and it was this transparency that made apparent the likenesses between them.

The threads of counterpoint in the Allemande of Bach's first French Suite were unbroken, woven closely together but never knotted. In the eight Chopin pieces that followed, his playing never became indulgent. He revealed the clear melodic lines within, charging each note with purpose. Counterpoint like this is not something we associate with Chopin but, given the composer's respect for Bach, its presence shouldn't be a surprise.

Goode ended his programme by making Beethoven's Sonata Op 110 sound almost as cleanly logical as the Bach. Musical corners were turned so neatly that the first movement seemed an endless stream of song, and a whole host of characters were lent to the theme of the fugal finale. As the lights went up and the spell was broken, it was quite a surprise to realise that Goode had known we were there all along.

webTitle: Leader: Stem cell research offers hope for MS victims

fields.headline: Stem cells offer hope
fields.standfirst:
Parliament needs time for proper debate

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The debate in the House of Commons yesterday on whether to allow stem cell research to go ahead on human embryos was always going to be deeply emotional. Fiona McTaggart, MP for Slough, offered a particularly poignant example of the dilemmas.
fields.body:
The debate in the House of Commons yesterday on whether to allow stem cell research to go ahead on human embryos was always going to be deeply emotional. Fiona McTaggart, MP for Slough, offered a particularly poignant example of the dilemmas. She is both infertile and has multiple sclerosis; the fertilised embryos she has donated can only be used, under current legislation, for research into fertility, yet it is the multiple sclerosis which now poses the biggest threat to her life.

Ms McTaggart's argument was that such a restriction on the use of embryos - put in place after Mary Warnock's landmark report on how to regulate the growing science of embryology - made little sense when there are now huge potential benefits in developing new tissue from the fast-growing stem cells found in embryos for common and vicious diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.

Her position is compelling; there is no point of principle between allowing one kind of research on embryos rather than another, as the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, noted in his report on the issue last summer. This is underpinned by the considerable confidence which has been generated by the effective and strict regulation of all embryo research by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) in the last decade.

But there are other aspects to this debate which are less clear cut. The government has been very nervous to broach this topic and with good reason. The HFEA first brought out its report calling for extension of the research allowed on embryos two years ago. Given the public sensitivities around BSE and genetic modification, the government kicked it into the long grass and handed the issue to Professor Donaldson and another committee. Now it has finally reached parliament, but the government has provided only four days between publication of the new regulations and a vote; and it is squeezed in before Christmas when many minds are elsewhere.

The government's nervousness is two-fold. First, it is concerned that the issue could be used by the pro-life lobby to challenge the sensible pragmatism of Warnock. Second, and far more important, this change in the regulations is inextricably linked to the emotive cloning debate. Stem cell research on fertilised embryos prepares the way for therapeutic cloning. And that, say the critics, is to slip down the slippery slope towards cloning human beings; it could mean developing techniques which, while banned in the UK, could be used abroad by the less scrupulous.

In reality, the scope for therapeutic cloning is always likely to be limited because of the lack of donor eggs and the high failure rate of cloning (Dolly the sheep required 277 attempts). Besides, the slippery slope argument is a poor one: the HFEA has shown that a line can be drawn and held. Some of these anxieties could also be set to rest by more energetic attempts to achieve a global ban on human cloning.

The benefits stem cell research offers may not be as clear-cut as health minister Yvette Cooper would have had us believe yesterday; it is still early days in the search for cures. But it does offer the only remaining hope for relieving the suffering of many. In the meantime, the government deserves a rap on the knuckles for rushing such a vital issue through parliament at such a time. Given the extraordinary pace of scientific development, there is a real danger of public debate not keeping up. The result could be a backlash against "Frankenstein science" which benefits neither scientific research nor its accountability.

In the meantime, the government deserves a rap on the knuckles for rushing such a vital issue through parliament at such a time. Given the extraordinary pace of scientific development, there is a real danger of public debate not keeping up. The result could be a backlash against "Frankenstein science" which benefits neither scientific research nor its accountability.

fields.headline: 'Unfair' bandings stir up rumbles of unrest
fields.standfirst: Local authorities fear serious discontent if council taxes are not brought in line with rising house prices, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Local authorities fear serious discontent if council taxes are not brought in line with rising house prices, reports Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
The government must review the council tax banding system if plans to bring local tax charges in line with house prices goes ahead, property experts warned this week.

Council tax bills will soar unless bands are increased in line with rising prices, they said. And more bands need to be created at the bottom end of the housing scale to prevent the system from becoming discredited. In some parts of the UK, where house prices are low, homeowners in both modest and large homes are paying the same council tax.

The ups and downs of the property market have led council tax bands, fixed in the early 90s, to become out of step with house prices.

The government has signalled it wants to review the council tax and bring charges in line with current values.

Local authorities and professionals had until last week to comment on the government's green paper on local government finance that includes these proposals. Some took the opportunity to call for an urgent review of council tax bands.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) says anomalies are appearing in the system as property values change at different speeds in different locations. Two properties placed in the same council tax band in 1993 might, on today's values, be banded quite differently.

The Local Government Association (LGA), which represents councils, said delays in revaluing could see Britain return to the same level of discontent as in the days of the poll tax.

The community charge, or "poll tax", became one of the most unpopular measures ever to be introduced by a government. It was supposed to replace domestic rates, which were levied against individual properties according to their rentable value. Delays in reviewing domestic rates led to the system being discredited. The poll tax, on the other hand, was an individual tax, charged per person.

Under that system the residents of a mansion in Belgravia, one of the smartest parts of London, paid the same as those squashed into a two-up, two-down in more modest Salford, in the north-west. Unsurprisingly, this was seen as unfair and provoked widespread civil unrest and the birth of poll tax "martyrs", happy to go to prison rather than pay up.

Like the domestic rates, council tax is charged on houses and flats. In order to calculate the amounts, properties are placed in one of eight valuation bands, starting at A - up to £40,000, based on their value in 1991.

As any householder knows, the last nine years have seen tremendous movement in property values, a fact confirmed by official figures.

Land Registry records show that from October-December 1995, the average price of a home in greater London was £95,084. Five years later, from July-December 2000, the price was £193,911. In other parts of the country the rises have been less dramatic. The average price of a home in the East Midlands from October-December 1995 was £54,589. From July to December this year it was £76,146.

In the green paper, ministers said they had no plans to change the council tax system in this parliament but that it was time to consider a fixed cycle for council tax revaluation to improve the fairness of the tax. Business rates are statutorily reviewed every five years. Revaluations of council tax might take place every six, eight or 10 years to complement the business rate cycle, the paper said.

The idea is supported by the LGA. The organisation says that although council tax is seen as fairer than its predecessors, unless it is kept up-to-date, the government is in danger of repeating the mistakes of the 70s and 80s. "A revaluation should be set in train as soon as possible to pick up these movements in house prices with a timetable set for regular revaluations."

The LGA wants the government to go further, and says, "in order to improve the fairness of the tax and to enhance its long-term stability, the number of council tax bands and the ratios between them should be reviewed".

Jerry Schurder, chair of the Rics rating and local taxation panel, echoes the LGA's concerns. "Regular revaluations are necessary to maintain the broad link between the value of the taxpayer's home and the amount of council tax they pay," he says.

He feels a case could be made for splitting the lowest band A into several bands. "In some local authorities in the north-east, where prices have risen slowly, they have a very high proportion of council tax payers in band A. In those cases, it is almost a poll tax because everyone is paying the same amount regardless of their property."

Head of capital finance and local taxation at the LGA, Keith Beaumont, agrees. In these local authorities, one person may live in a house worth £20,000 and another in a property worth £39,000 - yet they are in the same band and pay the same tax, he explains. Locally that is seen as unfair.

If homes throughout the country had all doubled in price over the past nine years it would be a simple matter to double the values of the bands, says Mr Beaumont. But in some local authorities prices have stagnated or even fallen and in others have risen steeply. "If the prices in the south-east have doubled and only increased by 50% elsewhere then revaluing properties would result in people in the south-east paying more council tax."

People become disenchanted with the system if they cannot relate the band they're in to property values, says Mr Schurder. They would see more sense in a system where the value of their house was related to the value of the band they're in.

Home improvements are also supposed to have an effect on a property's value. But properties are not re-banded until they are sold. Buyers of homes that have been upgraded since 1993 should be prepared to pay more council tax than the sellers have paid.

The council tax system was designed to be fair, but any revaluation will inevitably bring winners and losers. Local taxes are politically sensitive and any changes are unlikely to be introduced before the next election.

Even when ministers give it the go-ahead, carrying out the revaluations takes time and experts predict that it could be another five years before new charges are in place.
