webTitle: Riot worry as Haider and tree head for Vatican

fields.headline: Riot worry as Haider and tree head for Vatican
fields.trailText: Riot police mobilised outside the Vatican last night as the Pope's meeting today with Austria's Jörg Haider sparked uproar in Italy.
fields.body:
Riot police mobilised outside the Vatican last night as the Pope's meeting today with Austria's Jörg Haider sparked uproar in Italy.

Hundreds of police will this morning seal off streets leading to St Peter's Square to block demonstrations for and against the far-right politician.

An air of siege surrounded Pope John Paul II on the eve of one of the most controversial ceremonies of his papacy, in which Mr Haider heads a delegation to present an 81-year-old, 80ft fir tree from the Austrian province of Carinthia, of which he is governor.

Leftwing activists, second world war partisans, Israel, gay groups and Italian politicians lobbied in vain for a last-minute cancellation.

Vatican aides hinted that the Pope will try to reverse a public relations disaster by denouncing the anti-immigrant xenophobia associated with Mr Haider's Freedom party. Protesters will try to erect a six-by-four metre banner depicting the Nazi concentration camp at Auschwitz to block the view of the tree.

The choice of Carinthia to donate this year's tree was made three years ago before Mr Haider became governor. In going ahead, the Vatican cited protocol and its policy of opening doors to everybody.

Israel protested that the meeting risked legitimising a pariah shunned in Europe for bringing Nazi nostalgia into Vienna's government.

The 80-year-old Pope's lifelong goal of healing wounds between Catholics and Jews became a highlight of this year's jubilee, or holy year, when he made a historic apology for church persecution.

Seeking to check waves of protest, Vatican officials said the meeting was a pontifical audience rather than a formal meeting of heads of state.

The Pope would preach respect for human rights and tolerance, as he did when he met the then South African president, PW Botha, in the 1980s.

The World Jewish Congress was not impressed. "It is clear that the Pope will not specifically denounce Mr Haider's racist attitudes but just make general comments. The meeting between the two represents a moral and historical failure on the part of the Vatican."

Mr Haider, who is a Roman Catholic, will be received in a morning audience as civil head of the 250-strong Carinthian delegation, including a choir and brass band that will perform during the afternoon lighting of the tree which has been under guard since arriving in a police convoy earlier last week.

Before catching a flight to Rome, Mr Haider promised to show "hysterical communists" that he was an "angel of peace". He met the Pope in 1993.

Urging Austria to veto proposed EU guidelines on family reunification and a unified European asylum law, he stirred a diplomatic storm by saying Italy was being too generous in allowing in immigrants and refugees.

President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi denounced the attack, while prime minister Giuliano Amato wrote a protest letter to the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel.

Italy's centre-right opposition, led by Silvio Berlusconi, scrambled to distance itself from any association with Mr Haider. "It has nothing to do with us," said Mr Berlusconi.

Mr Haider, whose entry into Austria's government led to sanctions by EU partners, has turned Italy into a second political front in the past year.

He has started Italian lessons, made at least five visits and courted sympathetic local politicians in the northeast, mortifying their leaders.

Over the past few days, leftwing groups have held torch-lit protests in Rome, carried banners saying "Haider, Rome doesn't forget", and showered the Pope's car with leaflets depicting the fir tree as a gallows.

A light aircraft trailing other slogans has allegedly been hired to buzz the Vatican today.

webTitle: Pinochet and Me by Marc Cooper

fields.headline: Chronicle of a death postponed
fields.standfirst: Marc Cooper,  an American, was working for President Allende in 1973 when Pinochet seized power in a brutal coup. This is Cooper's account of that terrifying time and his flight to freedom
fields.trailText: Marc Cooper, an American, was working for President Allende in 1973 when Pinochet seized power in a brutal coup. This is Cooper's account of that terrifying time and his flight to freedom
fields.body:
7am, Tuesday September 11 1973
The fresh spring chill in the air and the blossoming jacaranda made that Chilean morning glorious. I stood in the yard of my friend Melvin's house in Santiago and glanced at the lingering snowcaps on the Andes. I had got up early because my Chilean residency visa expired that day and I needed to renew it. For a year now I had been working as a translator to Salvador Allende and I was scheduled to travel with him the next week.

An early start was imperative. Taxis had become harder to come by as many of the cab companies had joined the work stoppage led by the truckers' association - a group floated with CIA dollars. Retail merchants, doctors, lawyers, and almost everyone more elevated than manual workers and farmers had joined the stoppage. In daily entreaties, they pleaded with the armed forces to do away with the popularly-elected President Allende.

Indeed, Chile had already pitched itself into a dizzying dance of chaos and blood. As Allende's reforms deepened, as he nationalised the American copper mines and the telephone company, as large rural estates were handed over to their sharecroppers, as wages soared and taxes on the rich increased, the political right and eventually the centre jettisoned their attachment to the rule of law.

Opposition groups fielded chain swinging thugs. Oil pipelines were dynamited. Industrial production was sabotaged. Just a week previous to this morning, on September 4, the Chilean left held its last great gathering to commemorate the third anniversary of Allende's election. While the president stood granite-faced on a balcony, more than half a million Chilean workers marched before him chanting: "We want guns! We want guns!" It was a horrible, wrenching moment, one permanently seared in my consciousness. Yes, guns. But what guns? From where? My friends and I walked home that evening with a dark foreboding. The end was surely near.

In the seven days that followed, the right drew the noose tighter. Commerce and transport ground to a halt. The night before September 11, the transport stoppage had waylaid me and my girlfriend at Melvin's. We had gone out as a foursome, wound up snacking at Melvin's, and got stranded without a way back to my apartment.

After an hour-long wait on the corner I was able to flag down a passing cab. "Can you take me downtown to the immigration office?" I asked. The cabbie replied: "But, sir, there are problems downtown."

These were highly polarised times. You never knew who you were talking to. But a sinking feeling in my gut told me the worst was upon us. I asked: "Problems with men in uniform you mean?"

"Yes, sir, problems with men in uniform," the cabbie said. He took what he probably knew would be his last foray into freedom for some time and added: "Yes, the fucking fascists are overthrowing the government."

7.55am, Tuesday September 11
Everyone else in the house was still asleep. I switched on the radio: virtually every station was playing the same military march. I stopped the dial on Radio Corporación, the station of the Socialist party. Allende was speaking, a nervous inflection in his voice: "This is the president of the republic speaking from La Moneda palace. Confirmed reports indicate that a sector of the navy has isolated and occupied the port city of Valparaiso, which means an uprising against the government is under way . . . Under these circumstances, I call upon the workers of the country to occupy your workplaces . . . but I urge you to stay calm . . . I am here defending the government that represents the will of the people..."

On just about every other radio station a stern-voiced announcer suddenly materialised. By order of the military junta, he said all stations were immediately to link up to the armed forces network or "they will be bombarded". The names of the four commanders making up the junta were then read: leading the national police was a general, César Mendoza; for the air force, Gustavo Leigh; for the navy, Admiral José Merino; and for the army, General Augusto Pinochet. Pinochet had two weeks earlier taken over as commander-in-chief, swearing his loyalty to the president he was now trying to overthrow.

Some more marches. And then another announcement. An ultimatum to Allende. I sat shaking as military communique number two was announced: "The Moneda palace must be evacuated before 11am otherwise it will be attacked by the Chilean air force. The workers must remain in their workplaces and homes... If they disobey, they will also be attacked..."

I sat paralysed. A few moments later came communique number three: "The population is hereby warned not to let themselves be carried away by incitements to violence from either foreign or national activists... Any resistance will be met with the full rigour of military justice."

Yet another announcement proclaimed a curfew "until further notice". Anyone found on the streets "will be shot on sight". I had roused the others. We sat dumbfounded in the living room listening to Radio Magallanes, the Communist party station, resisting the order to broadcast the armed forces network. Over the air, workers were being urged to report to their factories and organise defence committees. But we knew this was an empty gesture.

10am, Tuesday September 11
I had had virtually no contact with the US embassy, up on the 14th floor of an office building opposite the Moneda. But I phoned that morning hoping that some safety provisions were being made for resident Americans.

I figured it was only a matter of hours before I would be swept up in the military dragnet. The embassy phone answered on the first ring. When I asked if the embassy had issued any special instructions, my respondent only laughed: "No special orders. Just stay off the streets." And then she added: "I'm looking out the window now with binoculars. Looks like Mr Allende is finally going to get it." She hung up.

11am, Tuesday September 11
Allende's voice is coming live over Radio Magallanes. Via telephone, from inside the Moneda, with troops and tanks poised outside, Allende spoke: "This is surely the last opportunity I will have to address you. The air force has bombed the towers of Radio Portales and Corporación. My words are not bitter but they are full of disillusionment. And they will serve as moral sanction for those who have betrayed their oath of loyalty: the soldiers of Chile, the branch commanders... I can only say this to the workers. I will not resign... With my life I will pay for defending the principles dear to our nation... History cannot be stopped by repression or violence... Surely Radio Magallanes will be silenced and with it my voice. But that's of no importance. You will continue hearing me as I will always be by your side... You must know that, sooner rather than later, the grand avenues on which a free people walk will be open and a better society will be at hand... These are my last words..."

I sat stunned and devastated. I can only remember the four of us listening and sobbing for I don't know how long. We had no access to any information except what the military broadcast over the radio. The phone lines were now dead.

4pm, Tuesday September 11
A non-stop cascade of military communiques: that the Moneda had been bombed, that the Allende government was no longer, that all political activity was banned, that a dawn-to-dusk curfew was in effect, that the citizenry should denounce all "suspicious foreign ers". I knew I was a prime target: Allende's translator, an activist in the radical wing of the Socialist party and a foreigner to boot. I thought of my apartment, in a downtown high rise located directly across the street from the new junta headquarters. On my desk were copies of the work I had translated for Allende. In my top drawer was my passport, a visa to Cuba which I was scheduled to visit with Allende, and to top it all off, a .22 revolver with a couple of boxes of ammunition.

Tuesday night to Thursday night, September 11 to 13
Those days were passed in the sort of blur produced by a state of deep shock. I didn't sleep that first night. I imagined Allende riddled and bloodied on his office floor. The following morning, an official communique announced that Allende had committed suicide.

The resumption of Chilean TV. A wavering, black-and-white image of Pinochet sitting ramrod straight in the presidential chair, his accomplices standing beside him. I thought of the poor neighbourhoods and factories, now surrounded by vengeful troops. I wondered about my friends. How many would I ever see again? How long would it be before the troops came crashing through Melvin's door to take me away?

On Wednesday a statement from the supreme court chief justice, Enrique Urrutia, affirming the court's "pleasure" with the military takeover. A terse military statement suspending habeas corpus and announcing a declared state of siege. Military communique number 29 dated September 13: "On this date the government junta has decreed the following: the closure of the National Congress and the vacancy of all its parliamentary seats. Signed, the governing junta of the armed forces and carabineros of Chile."

I remember getting up at four in the morning and shaving off my beard. I remember opening my wallet and taking out my union card, my Socialist party membership, my ID from the Moneda and setting them ablaze.

The only food in the house was a freezer full of Eskimo pies, several sacks of onions and a case of Pisco liquor. This odd diet, peppered with fear, drove me into a feverish retreat. I could barely talk to my Chilean girlfriend, Patricia. I slept, I paced, ate ice cream, read novels, cried and waited. Lists of the wanted were read over the air: Allende's cabinet ministers, party activists, union leaders were ordered to surrender at the ministry of defence. How they were expected to breach the curfew without being shot was not explained.

10am, Friday September 14
Melvin and his girlfriend have drunk themselves into a stupor. As the radio announces that the curfew will be lifted today for five hours, Patricia and I decide we must leave Melvin's. She had to check on her family. I had to figure a way to safety.

Noon, Friday September 14
I was now desperate. I focused on a long shot. An American friend of mine had told me some months before that a guy named Dennis Allred, who served as the US embassy's student affairs counsellor, was a decent man, who took secret delight in handing out US scholarships to the most radical of Chilean students.

I phoned the embassy. Allred wasn't in. But, being an American, I could have his home phone number. "Dennis, you don't know me," I told him after he answered his phone. "But I'm an American and I'm in trouble. I need . . ."

"OK," he said, cutting me short. "I don't care about the details. If you need a place to stay you're welcome here. Come now. I'm at Merced 280."

I thanked him and hung up. Merced 280? That would put him next door to the heavily guarded US consulate. Could I get past the troops? Patricia and I made a plan. She would catch a bus to her parents' home. I would walk the seven miles to Allred's house as I had no ID and buses were being boarded and checked by soldiers.

By four o'clock I was on the perimeter of the US consulate. The neighbouring park was an armed camp. Armoured carriers bristled with machine guns and troops. In front of the consulate, a company of soldiers lounged on a tank. I could hear my heart beating. I walked straight ahead, my eyes fixed on the door of Allred's building. Like passing through a time warp, I floated in uninterrupted.

A red-headed Bostoner, Allred greeted me alone in his apartment. I could hardly talk at first. And then I began to talk too much. "I don't need to hear the details of your story. You can stay here as long as you have to," he said. He then offered me a tumbler full of Old Grandad which I gulped down like water. With a sleeping pill Allred gave me, I slept soundly for the first time in almost 100 hours.

6pm, Sunday September 16
Over the weekend the apartment filled up with other hunted prey. A few had been beaten by troops who had broken down their doors. Others, like me, had nowhere to go. Allred had taken the courageous step of abandoning his direct-dial diplomatic phone to us.

In Allred's study we set up a mini information clearing house. We called around to check on the safety of friends and co-workers. Once the information was compiled we were able to pass the information on to family, media and human rights groups in the US. Painstakingly, we cobbled together lists of those safe, those arrested and those missing. But there was still no way out of Chile. A friend of mine, a Mexican reporter, called me. Would I be interested in getting on a list that the Mexican embassy was putting together to be evacuated? "Absolutely," I answered.

Noon, Monday September 17
Word had come that some Americans were missing. David Hathaway had been taken from his apartment. Frank Teruggi was unaccounted for. Some time that day, our friend Charlie Horman would be seized. I would next see Charlie and Frank a decade later, and then only as celluloid ghosts conjured up in the Costa Gavras film Missing.

That afternoon, the whole apartment shook with a thud. From Allred's balcony we saw two tanks squatting in the park and shelling the fine arts campus of the University of Chile across the river.

8pm, Tuesday September 18
One week since the coup, and the call came through from the Mexicans. I was to be on a flight organised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for the next morning. I was ecstatic at the thought I might get out but terrified that something might go wrong. I was also depressed, laden with survivor's guilt: my only prospect for joy was to flee the slaughterhouse of my friends.

7am, Wednesday September 19
The moment the curfew was lifted, I called Patricia and asked her to meet me at the Sheraton. I hugged Allred goodbye. I walked past the encampment of soldiers outside Allred's door. On the corner, a daring taxi driver was ready for the post-curfew fares. Inside the Sheraton lobby I was met by UN and Mexican officials. There was to be about 50 of us on this flight. There were some Spanish clergy. Some Mexican teachers. An American researcher black and blue from a beating. A Texas high school swimming team that had passed through Santiago on the wrong day.

Just before I boarded the bus to the airport Patricia arrived for a short goodbye - she would arrange to meet me later. Under heavily armed escort we were taken to the Cerrillos military airport. We were herded on to a 737.

There was an eerie silence as we took off. No one was sure of anyone else on the flight. Twenty minutes into the flight, a crackling voice came over the intercom. "Ladies and gentlemen," the captain announced crisply. "We have just entered Argentine air space."

The entire plane exploded into yelps of joy and applause. Soon we were all on our feet embracing each other. We were greeted in Buenos Aires as heroes. And that night we marched with 100,000 Argentines to protest against the Chilean military dictatorship.

Two months later, Patricia came to the US and we have been married ever since. Allred resigned from the US foreign service.

In his final speech on Magallanes Radio, Allende promised us that one day there would be a "moral punishment" for the crime and treason that killed him and his Chile. We are still waiting.

fields.bodyText: 7am, Tuesday September 11 1973 The fresh spring chill in the air and the blossoming jacaranda made that Chilean morning glorious. I stood in the yard of my friend Melvin's house in Santiago and glanced at the lingering snowcaps on the Andes. I had got up early because my Chilean residency visa expired that day and I needed to renew it. For a year now I had been working as a translator to Salvador Allende and I was scheduled to travel with him the next week. An early start was imperative. Taxis had become harder to come by as many of the cab companies had joined the work stoppage led by the truckers' association - a group floated with CIA dollars. Retail merchants, doctors, lawyers, and almost everyone more elevated than manual workers and farmers had joined the stoppage. In daily entreaties, they pleaded with the armed forces to do away with the popularly-elected President Allende. Indeed, Chile had already pitched itself into a dizzying dance of chaos and blood. As Allende's reforms deepened, as he nationalised the American copper mines and the telephone company, as large rural estates were handed over to their sharecroppers, as wages soared and taxes on the rich increased, the political right and eventually the centre jettisoned their attachment to the rule of law. Opposition groups fielded chain swinging thugs. Oil pipelines were dynamited. Industrial production was sabotaged. Just a week previous to this morning, on September 4, the Chilean left held its last great gathering to commemorate the third anniversary of Allende's election. While the president stood granite-faced on a balcony, more than half a million Chilean workers marched before him chanting: "We want guns! We want guns!" It was a horrible, wrenching moment, one permanently seared in my consciousness. Yes, guns. But what guns? From where? My friends and I walked home that evening with a dark foreboding. The end was surely near. In the seven days that followed, the right drew the noose tighter. Commerce and transport ground to a halt. The night before September 11, the transport stoppage had waylaid me and my girlfriend at Melvin's. We had gone out as a foursome, wound up snacking at Melvin's, and got stranded without a way back to my apartment. After an hour-long wait on the corner I was able to flag down a passing cab. "Can you take me downtown to the immigration office?" I asked. The cabbie replied: "But, sir, there are problems downtown." These were highly polarised times. You never knew who you were talking to. But a sinking feeling in my gut told me the worst was upon us. I asked: "Problems with men in uniform you mean?" "Yes, sir, problems with men in uniform," the cabbie said. He took what he probably knew would be his last foray into freedom for some time and added: "Yes, the fucking fascists are overthrowing the government." 7.55am, Tuesday September 11 Everyone else in the house was still asleep. I switched on the radio: virtually every station was playing the same military march. I stopped the dial on Radio Corporación, the station of the Socialist party. Allende was speaking, a nervous inflection in his voice: "This is the president of the republic speaking from La Moneda palace. Confirmed reports indicate that a sector of the navy has isolated and occupied the port city of Valparaiso, which means an uprising against the government is under way . . . Under these circumstances, I call upon the workers of the country to occupy your workplaces . . . but I urge you to stay calm . . . I am here defending the government that represents the will of the people..." On just about every other radio station a stern-voiced announcer suddenly materialised. By order of the military junta, he said all stations were immediately to link up to the armed forces network or "they will be bombarded". The names of the four commanders making up the junta were then read: leading the national police was a general, César Mendoza; for the air force, Gustavo Leigh; for the navy, Admiral José Merino; and for the army, General Augusto Pinochet. Pinochet had two weeks earlier taken over as commander-in-chief, swearing his loyalty to the president he was now trying to overthrow. Some more marches. And then another announcement. An ultimatum to Allende. I sat shaking as military communique number two was announced: "The Moneda palace must be evacuated before 11am otherwise it will be attacked by the Chilean air force. The workers must remain in their workplaces and homes... If they disobey, they will also be attacked..." I sat paralysed. A few moments later came communique number three: "The population is hereby warned not to let themselves be carried away by incitements to violence from either foreign or national activists... Any resistance will be met with the full rigour of military justice." Yet another announcement proclaimed a curfew "until further notice". Anyone found on the streets "will be shot on sight". I had roused the others. We sat dumbfounded in the living room listening to Radio Magallanes, the Communist party station, resisting the order to broadcast the armed forces network. Over the air, workers were being urged to report to their factories and organise defence committees. But we knew this was an empty gesture. 10am, Tuesday September 11 I had had virtually no contact with the US embassy, up on the 14th floor of an office building opposite the Moneda. But I phoned that morning hoping that some safety provisions were being made for resident Americans. I figured it was only a matter of hours before I would be swept up in the military dragnet. The embassy phone answered on the first ring. When I asked if the embassy had issued any special instructions, my respondent only laughed: "No special orders. Just stay off the streets." And then she added: "I'm looking out the window now with binoculars. Looks like Mr Allende is finally going to get it." She hung up. 11am, Tuesday September 11 Allende's voice is coming live over Radio Magallanes. Via telephone, from inside the Moneda, with troops and tanks poised outside, Allende spoke: "This is surely the last opportunity I will have to address you. The air force has bombed the towers of Radio Portales and Corporación. My words are not bitter but they are full of disillusionment. And they will serve as moral sanction for those who have betrayed their oath of loyalty: the soldiers of Chile, the branch commanders... I can only say this to the workers. I will not resign... With my life I will pay for defending the principles dear to our nation... History cannot be stopped by repression or violence... Surely Radio Magallanes will be silenced and with it my voice. But that's of no importance. You will continue hearing me as I will always be by your side... You must know that, sooner rather than later, the grand avenues on which a free people walk will be open and a better society will be at hand... These are my last words..." I sat stunned and devastated. I can only remember the four of us listening and sobbing for I don't know how long. We had no access to any information except what the military broadcast over the radio. The phone lines were now dead. 4pm, Tuesday September 11 A non-stop cascade of military communiques: that the Moneda had been bombed, that the Allende government was no longer, that all political activity was banned, that a dawn-to-dusk curfew was in effect, that the citizenry should denounce all "suspicious foreign ers". I knew I was a prime target: Allende's translator, an activist in the radical wing of the Socialist party and a foreigner to boot. I thought of my apartment, in a downtown high rise located directly across the street from the new junta headquarters. On my desk were copies of the work I had translated for Allende. In my top drawer was my passport, a visa to Cuba which I was scheduled to visit with Allende, and to top it all off, a .22 revolver with a couple of boxes of ammunition. Tuesday night to Thursday night, September 11 to 13 Those days were passed in the sort of blur produced by a state of deep shock. I didn't sleep that first night. I imagined Allende riddled and bloodied on his office floor. The following morning, an official communique announced that Allende had committed suicide. The resumption of Chilean TV. A wavering, black-and-white image of Pinochet sitting ramrod straight in the presidential chair, his accomplices standing beside him. I thought of the poor neighbourhoods and factories, now surrounded by vengeful troops. I wondered about my friends. How many would I ever see again? How long would it be before the troops came crashing through Melvin's door to take me away? On Wednesday a statement from the supreme court chief justice, Enrique Urrutia, affirming the court's "pleasure" with the military takeover. A terse military statement suspending habeas corpus and announcing a declared state of siege. Military communique number 29 dated September 13: "On this date the government junta has decreed the following: the closure of the National Congress and the vacancy of all its parliamentary seats. Signed, the governing junta of the armed forces and carabineros of Chile." I remember getting up at four in the morning and shaving off my beard. I remember opening my wallet and taking out my union card, my Socialist party membership, my ID from the Moneda and setting them ablaze. The only food in the house was a freezer full of Eskimo pies, several sacks of onions and a case of Pisco liquor. This odd diet, peppered with fear, drove me into a feverish retreat. I could barely talk to my Chilean girlfriend, Patricia. I slept, I paced, ate ice cream, read novels, cried and waited. Lists of the wanted were read over the air: Allende's cabinet ministers, party activists, union leaders were ordered to surrender at the ministry of defence. How they were expected to breach the curfew without being shot was not explained. 10am, Friday September 14 Melvin and his girlfriend have drunk themselves into a stupor. As the radio announces that the curfew will be lifted today for five hours, Patricia and I decide we must leave Melvin's. She had to check on her family. I had to figure a way to safety. Noon, Friday September 14 I was now desperate. I focused on a long shot. An American friend of mine had told me some months before that a guy named Dennis Allred, who served as the US embassy's student affairs counsellor, was a decent man, who took secret delight in handing out US scholarships to the most radical of Chilean students. I phoned the embassy. Allred wasn't in. But, being an American, I could have his home phone number. "Dennis, you don't know me," I told him after he answered his phone. "But I'm an American and I'm in trouble. I need . . ." "OK," he said, cutting me short. "I don't care about the details. If you need a place to stay you're welcome here. Come now. I'm at Merced 280." I thanked him and hung up. Merced 280? That would put him next door to the heavily guarded US consulate. Could I get past the troops? Patricia and I made a plan. She would catch a bus to her parents' home. I would walk the seven miles to Allred's house as I had no ID and buses were being boarded and checked by soldiers. By four o'clock I was on the perimeter of the US consulate. The neighbouring park was an armed camp. Armoured carriers bristled with machine guns and troops. In front of the consulate, a company of soldiers lounged on a tank. I could hear my heart beating. I walked straight ahead, my eyes fixed on the door of Allred's building. Like passing through a time warp, I floated in uninterrupted. A red-headed Bostoner, Allred greeted me alone in his apartment. I could hardly talk at first. And then I began to talk too much. "I don't need to hear the details of your story. You can stay here as long as you have to," he said. He then offered me a tumbler full of Old Grandad which I gulped down like water. With a sleeping pill Allred gave me, I slept soundly for the first time in almost 100 hours. 6pm, Sunday September 16 Over the weekend the apartment filled up with other hunted prey. A few had been beaten by troops who had broken down their doors. Others, like me, had nowhere to go. Allred had taken the courageous step of abandoning his direct-dial diplomatic phone to us. In Allred's study we set up a mini information clearing house. We called around to check on the safety of friends and co-workers. Once the information was compiled we were able to pass the information on to family, media and human rights groups in the US. Painstakingly, we cobbled together lists of those safe, those arrested and those missing. But there was still no way out of Chile. A friend of mine, a Mexican reporter, called me. Would I be interested in getting on a list that the Mexican embassy was putting together to be evacuated? "Absolutely," I answered. Noon, Monday September 17 Word had come that some Americans were missing. David Hathaway had been taken from his apartment. Frank Teruggi was unaccounted for. Some time that day, our friend Charlie Horman would be seized. I would next see Charlie and Frank a decade later, and then only as celluloid ghosts conjured up in the Costa Gavras film Missing. That afternoon, the whole apartment shook with a thud. From Allred's balcony we saw two tanks squatting in the park and shelling the fine arts campus of the University of Chile across the river. 8pm, Tuesday September 18 One week since the coup, and the call came through from the Mexicans. I was to be on a flight organised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for the next morning. I was ecstatic at the thought I might get out but terrified that something might go wrong. I was also depressed, laden with survivor's guilt: my only prospect for joy was to flee the slaughterhouse of my friends. 7am, Wednesday September 19 The moment the curfew was lifted, I called Patricia and asked her to meet me at the Sheraton. webTitle: MPs agonise over matters of life and death

fields.headline: MPs agonise over matters of life and death
fields.standfirst: Pleas from the disabled and ill, charges of Nazism - and then a free vote
fields.trailText: Pleas from the disabled and ill, charges of Nazism - and then a free vote
fields.body:
When an MP who uses a wheelchair because she has an incurable bone disease expresses the hope that a new line of research could help her, another offers to sacrifice two of her embryos, and a third accuses supporters of such research of thinking like Nazis, it is clear that something more than usually fundamental is happening in the Commons.

The question, debated in parliament yesterday and up for a vote on Tuesday, is whether scientists should be able to carry out experiments on a particular kind of human cell in the hope of treating serious degenerative illnesses such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's.

Given that there are trillions of cells in the human body, and we slough off millions of them every day as we shed dead skin, that does not seem so controversial. And it might not be, but for two words intimately linked to the debate: "embryo" and "clone".

The cells in question are human embryonic stem cells, between two and 100 of which make up the human embryo in its first days after conception. Scientists want to see if they can persuade them to grow into replacement components for people whose original cells have failed: to replace nerve cells, for instance, in the brains of Parkinson's sufferers.

The embryos in question are human in potential only. They cannot think or feel. They have no distinct organs. They are trillionths of the size of babies, and are far below the time threshold for abortion. They are surplus to requirements for couples having IVF treatment for infertility; they are already fertilised, and would be destroyed if couples did not give their consent for them to be used for research.

Despite all this, they are still human embryos, and for this reason the Catholic church and the broader anti-abortion lobby is opposed to the rules being changed next week to allow stem-cell research to be widened.

Anne Begg, the Aberdeen South Labour MP who has the bone-softening disease osteoporosis and gets around the Commons in a wheelchair, said it was too late for her to hope for a cure. But "perhaps there may be something in the stem cell research which could help".

Fiona MacTaggart, Labour MP for Slough, suffers from multiple sclerosis, and has been unable to have children. Her speech in the Commons could not have been more personal and poignant.

"At the moment there are two fertilised embryos of mine in a medical facility, which are available for research," she said.

"It is ironic that they could be used in research that could help to deal with my infertility, and not be used in research which could be of help to deal with the thing about which I am more anxious, my multiple sclerosis. Unless we pass these regulations that will be the case for everybody."

The Catholic and anti-abortion movement's insistence that not one human embryonic cell should be sacrificed was put by Edward Leigh, Tory MP for Gainsborough, who described the research as "the killing of innocents".

"The Nazis surely were saying that some humans are sub-human, therefore they are expendable ... it is the same argument. People are arguing that these embryos are sub-human. That is a point of view I reject."

The government is backing the change in the rules, and the human fertilisation and embryology authority, the HFEA, will still have the last word on whether scientists get a research licence.

The parties have given MPs a free vote on the issue, treating it as a matter of individual conscience. The government is likely to get its way, but an energetic constituency-based letter-writing campaign by the anti-abortion movement has alarmed its opponents, who find it harder to rally their foot soldiers.

"It's difficult for a family or an individual to say 'This is a matter of life or death for me,' because at the moment, it's not," said Alastair Kent, head of the Genetic Interest Group, an organisation for genetic disease charities.

"It's a promising avenue of research. It may well lead to treatments which become a matter of life and death, and at that point you'll watch people queuing up to get hold of them."

The "pro-lifers" have some curious allies in their campaign - an offshoot of the environmentalist movement, not normally standing shoulder to shoulder with Catholics and opponents of the right to abortion, is against the change because it sees it as a step towards human cloning.

Dave King, who runs a campaign against genetic engineering, does not object to experiment on stem cells but does not want to see the rules changed until a worldwide ban on human reproductive cloning is in place: something which will be extremely difficult to negotiate and may never happen.

But the rule change as drafted makes no mention of cloning. What's the connection?

Stem cells are so called because they have the potential to grow into any kind of specialised human tissue. As leaves grow off the stem of a plant, chemical messages inside stem cells instruct them to divide into ever more specialised cells, until they have formed cells for the liver, heart, skin, nerve, blood and scores of other tissue types.

If scientists succeed in unravelling the mysteries of those chemical messages they will be able to grow replacement cells for people whose own supply has been destroyed by degenerative disease.

That achievement is still a long way off. But even if researchers get that far, there is another barrier to successful treatment. Cellular spare parts grown from alien cells are likely to be rejected by the immune system.

One way to get around this would be the cloning technique used to create Dolly the sheep: take a human egg, remove its own DNA, insert the nucleus from an adult patient's cell, apply a jolt of electricity, and create a cloned human stem cell. This could then be used to grow replacement cells which would be 100% compatible with the patient's own.

The government points out that, surprisingly, doing this for humans is not actually illegal at the moment, subject to HFEA approval, although no-one has yet applied for a licence. In other words, they say, there is no need to vote on it. But campaigners for a no vote next week maintain that the change in the rules on embryo research would create a huge incentive for scientists to begin this kind of limited human cloning.

fields.headline: Watchdog's paws burnt by Equitable
fields.trailText: The Equitable Life crisis took a new twist yesterday with the revelation that more than 100 staff at the City's chief financial watchdog are among those affected.
fields.body:
The Equitable Life crisis took a new twist yesterday with the revelation that more than 100 staff at the City's chief financial watchdog are among those affected.

The disclosure could prove embarrassing for the financial services authority because it has been criticised for allegedly failing to protect the insurer's policyholders, many of whom are likely to suffer financially as a result of Equitable's dilemma.

Three City regulators that have been merged into the FSA have Equitable Life as the provider of their AVC schemes - top-up pension plans which allow staff to boost the value of their company pensions.

The FSA was earlier this week accused of failing to protect consumers by not taking earlier action against the insurer and for allowing the company to carry on selling new policies despite a question mark over its financial health.

Equitable closed its doors to new business a week ago after losing a multi-billion pound legal battle involving pension promises it made to some customers. It had hoped to find a buyer but nobody wanted to acquire it.

Equitable has warned up to 1m policyholders --including those in with-profits AVC schemes - that they can expect lower investment returns in future, and will be hit with a 10% penalty if they transfer their funds to another provider. Policyholders have also lost seven months' worth of bonuses.

The FSA confirmed that Equitable provides AVC schemes to staff of three regulators - the personal investment authority, the securities and futures authority, and the securities and investments board.

webTitle: BBC and Foreign Office clash over euro screening

fields.headline: BBC and Foreign Office clash over euro screening
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The government was embroiled in a fresh row with the BBC yesterday after a Foreign Office official was ejected from a special screening of a television documentary which takes a hard-hitting look at Britain's stance on the euro.
fields.body:
The government was embroiled in a fresh row with the BBC yesterday after a Foreign Office official was ejected from a special screening of a television documentary which takes a hard-hitting look at Britain's stance on the euro.

In a sign of the government's sensitivity over the single currency, the official from the Foreign Office's EU department tried to join the press screening of The Battle for the Euro in order to monitor an interview with the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz.

"We made it clear to you that this is just for the press," the press officer, Colin Govan, told Damian Potter, as he escorted him out of the screening room at the Atrium restaurant in Westminster. Mr Govan said afterwards that he was defending the journalistic principle that government officials should not be given access to screenings before transmission.

"We value our editorial independence and have to protect that principle in the same way that newspapers do," Mr Govan said.

It is understood that Mr Potter wanted to see the programme in advance of its screening on BBC2 tomorrow night because of fears that it cast Mr Vaz in an unfavourable light. The programme features anti-euro campaigners who dog Mr Vaz's every step during his nationwide campaign to defend the EU.

It will make uncomfortable viewing for the government, featuring interviews with the former deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, a former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, and the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, who all accuse Tony Blair of failing to take a lead on the euro. The cross-party Britain in Europe pressure group is also criticised for releasing inaccurate information.

Mr Clarke and Mr Heseltine tell the programme, which is presented by reporter Jane Corbin, that the prime minister had an opportunity, after Labour's election landslide, to move decisively towards British membership of the euro. But they accuse Mr Blair of throwing away his chance after Labour's dismal performance in last year's European elections and in the light of a sustained tabloid campaign against the euro.

"They are an indecisive lot, they are a pretty lightweight government," Mr Clarke says. "We got them on the platform for the launch of Britain in Europe, but they didn't follow it up properly."

Mr Heseltine said the prime minister should ignore opinion polls which show overwhelming opposition to the euro. fields.bodyText: The government was embroiled in a fresh row with the BBC yesterday after a Foreign Office official was ejected from a special screening of a television documentary which takes a hard-hitting look at Britain's stance on the euro. In a sign of the government's sensitivity over the single currency, the official from the Foreign Office's EU department tried to join the press screening of The Battle for the Euro in order to monitor an interview with the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz. "We made it clear to you that this is just for the press," the press officer, Colin Govan, told Damian Potter, as he escorted him out of the screening room at the Atrium restaurant in Westminster. Mr Govan said afterwards that he was defending the journalistic principle that government officials should not be given access to screenings before transmission. "We value our editorial independence and have to protect that principle in the same way that newspapers do," Mr Govan said. It is understood that Mr Potter wanted to see the programme in advance of its screening on BBC2 tomorrow night because of fears that it cast Mr Vaz in an unfavourable light. The programme features anti-euro campaigners who dog Mr Vaz's every step during his nationwide campaign to defend the EU. It will make uncomfortable viewing for the government, featuring interviews with the former deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, a former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, and the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, who all accuse Tony Blair of failing to take a lead on the euro. The cross-party Britain in Europe pressure group is also criticised for releasing inaccurate information. Mr Clarke and Mr Heseltine tell the programme, which is presented by reporter Jane Corbin, that the prime minister had an opportunity, after Labour's election landslide, to move decisively towards British membership of the euro. But they accuse Mr Blair of throwing away his chance after Labour's dismal performance in last year's European elections and in the light of a sustained tabloid campaign against the euro. "They are an indecisive lot, they are a pretty lightweight government," Mr Clarke says. "We got them on the platform for the launch of Britain in Europe, but they didn't follow it up properly." webTitle: Market forces: Equitable starts the sell-off

fields.headline: Equitable starts the sell-off
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
Beleaguered insurer Equitable Life created some excitement in the City yesterday. It is understood that the mutual insurer, which must sell off £25bn in equities, began the process this week. It is likely to take months for all the stock to be sold but big names such as Vodafone and BP Amoco kicked off the rebalancing.

The dealings by Equitable follow the decision to close its doors to new business last week when all its potential buyers pulled out. It needs to sell equities and replace them with bonds to reduce the risk in its £33bn portfolio, so it can continue to pay the policies of existing customers.

While Equitable's dealings, on which the insurer refused to comment, helped to boost turnover, they did little to hold up the market. The FTSE 100 lost another 88 points bringing it down to 6,175.8, its lowest close in nearly two weeks, heavily influenced by a poor Wall Street opening.

According to analysts, the weakness stemmed from the United States and was spreading to the rest of the world.

A profit warning from Microsoft led to IBM and Hewlett Packard falling. Bank, oil and pharmaceutical stocks were also weak.

HSBC slumped in Hong Kong trading, falling 48p to 938p and BP Amoco lost 9.5p to 533p. Shell dropped 9p to 509p.

In pharmaceuticals, Nycomed Amersham fell 30p to 525p, Glaxo Wellcome 42p to 1943p and SmithKline Beecham lost 25p to 878p.

Technology sectors continued to drop after declines in the tech-heavy Nasdaq market. Bookham Technology fell 115p to 1060p and Baltimore Technology lost 28p to 375p.

Shares in Durlacher shed 7p to 22p after it gave warning that it expects to report a "substantial loss" for the six months to the end of December. The internet investment provider has seen its shares underperform its sector by 89% in 2000.

RTS Networks , the IT company, which reported a significant increase in second half revenues also saw its share price drop 7.5p to 45p.

The company said fourth-quarter revenues would not be as high as previously anticipated. The group said it was undertaking larger projects that take longer for orders to come through, which would lead to higher revenues in the first quarter of next year.

Jarvis, the support services company, was up 11.25p to 191p, having started the week at 182p. The increase is thought to be due to better than expected results announced this week, improved investor sentiment and anticipation that the company will benefit from increased government spending on infrastructure and education.

Chemicals groups were on the up yesterday on the back of the agreed bid of £1.36bn for British speciality chemicals - manufacturer Laporte from Degussa. The German chemicals company made a cash offer which values Laporte at a 17% premium to its closing price on Thursday. Laporte jumped 96.25p or 16% to 692p after announcing the 697p per share offer.

The statement boosted British Vita, up nearly 6% or 10p to 189.5p, and Scapa Group, up 8p to 144.5p.

Tesco, the supermarket chain, saw its shares up slightly, 3p to 269p, as the group said it was entering a new market in Malaysia. A joint venture plans to open 15 hypermarkets at a cost of £215m. Carrefour of France is the only other European operator in Malaysia.

Marks & Spencer, however, dropped 7.25p to 187p after talk of disappointing clothing sales in the vital run up to Christmas. Last week, according to reports, menswear sales were down 13% compared with last year and womenswear down between 6% and 7%.

The figures do not seem to be matching up to the Belgian chief executive, Luc Vandevelde's predictions of "a wonderful Christmas" for the retailer .

webTitle: Birth of a new deal for parents

fields.headline: Birth of a new deal for parents
fields.standfirst:
Human Rights Act forces employers to change paid maternity leave agreements for the mothers of adopted children

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Human Rights Act forces employers to change paid maternity leave agreements for the mothers of adopted children
fields.body:
Oliver Smyth is chortling gently as he plays with his Lego on the floor. Blue eyes wide open, he grasps a farmyard fence and rushes to give it to his mother. One of the family cats slips in and he scampers after it, caught up in the joy of being two years old.

The Smyths' home is testament to a much longed for child, from the numerous photos and jumbled toys to the letter fridge magnets spelling his name.

Yet, when he arrived, his mother, Rosie, a 29-year-old nursing assistant for an NHS community trust in the west country, was granted just 16 days' maternity leave, in contrast to the 18 weeks given to most new mothers.

The reason is that Oliver is adopted and, at present, adoptive parents have no statutory right to paid maternity leave.

It is an issue which the government last week announced it will address after a three-month consultation on the green paper on work and parents. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, admitted that he had been unaware of the discrepancy and signalled his determination to change this.

Rosie and her husband Nigel, who are waiting to adopt again, do not want her to return to work again after six weeks as she was forced to through financial necessity.

And so, in the first case of its kind, they have successfully used the Human Rights Act to claim that their child was being discriminated against, and force her employer to offer adoptive parents the same maternity leave as birth parents.

Sense of injustice

Rosie's realisation that her employers, an NHS community health trust, would treat her differently to birth mothers came when she approached them after hearing that she could adopt Oliver as a four-month-old, in the spring of 1998.

The issue of maternity leave had not occurred to her before - she had been too preoccupied with three failed IVF attempts. She was surprised by the response. "I was told there was a draft policy agreement that gave six weeks on half pay but that, since the board had not approved it, it was up to individual managers to choose whether to implement it."

Her managers did not implement the draft policy but offered 10 days "special leave for family reasons". An appeal to a second manager, who had adopted a child, brought a further six days. But the offer fell a long way short of the eight weeks on full pay and 10 weeks on half pay offered to birth mothers.

With Oliver's arrival imminent, Rosie and Nigel, 33, felt they were in no position to fight. Rosie borrowed money and enjoyed a mere six weeks with her baby before she was forced to return to work part-time. She said: "My bosses offered me more unpaid leave - they weren't going to force me back before I was ready. But money was."

Leaving Oliver was, she admitted, very hard. "It wasn't fair and I thought it was particularly unfair on him. I thought the trust was discriminating against him as a baby. He was denied the chance to have a full-time mum for the same amount of time as any other baby," she said.

The sense of injustice continued to rankle and it did not help when a colleague became pregnant. "All the time I was aware that she and her baby would have 18 weeks together while my baby and I just had three weeks," she said. With the realisation that she would want to adopt again, she began 18 months of campaigning, writing to politicians and her union, Unison.

She argued that maternity leave was important to allow her to bond with her baby. Sympathy was offered, but the message was the same: maternity leave, in the words of the Department of Social Security, was offered "to protect women from the exertions of work immediately prior to giving birth and to allow a period of rest immediately following the exertion of childbirth".

And then she had a breakthrough. On the advice of a judge, she contacted a family lawyer who told her that her employer, as a public authority forced to adhere to the European convention on human rights, may have breached article 14 of the Human Rights Act.

Deprived of mother's time

"The article is quite broad and bans discrimination on grounds not only of sex, race and social origin but birth," explained Chris Hall, of Crosse & Crosse solicitors. "Oliver, as an adopted child, appeared to have been discriminated against because he was being deprived of time with his mother that a child with a birth mother would have had."

A human rights barrister at Matrix backed up this view, arguing that it was given force because article 8 of the act, covering the right to family life, also appeared to have been flouted. Faced with being sued under the Human Rights Act, the trust changed its mind and offered six weeks' paid leave at nine-tenths of her salary followed by 12 weeks on half pay plus the equivalent of statutory pay.

The policy may not have been quite equal to that for birth mothers, and Oliver may not have had his mother at home for 18 weeks, but at least it would apply to their next adopted child.

The chief executive of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, Felicity Collier, said: "This is an issue that we are concerned about as it restricts the number of people coming forward to adopt. The success of adoption will depend on how successful those first few months are. When a child joins your family, it is vitally important there is time for at least one parent to be at home with the child."

webTitle: Zigzag trip to the summit and back

fields.headline: Zigzag trip to the summit and back
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: "What was the Summit, Daddy?"
fields.body:
"What was the Summit, Daddy?"

"Well son, a long, long time ago, before America had a new president and our future king got into cleaning South American toilets, the heads of government of the 15 states of the EU met far away from the rains and the trains. And they sorted out the future."

"Who won, Daddy?"

"No, no, it wasn't a game. Some say we won, some say we lost. It depended on what you wanted to happen."

"OK, so nobody won but surely you can tell me what happened. I mean, what did the papers say? That's the way you find out what happened, isn't it?"

"Well, it's not quite as simple as that. Let's start with Tony Blair. He said, according to the Daily Mirror, 'We secured all our objectives without it even being suggested we were an obstacle in the way of enlargement. It is possible to fight Britain's corner, get the best out of Europe for Britain, and exercise real authority and influence in Europe. That is as it should be. Britain is a world power'."

"So it all went very well. Did Mr Hague agree?"

"No. He said that if he were in power he would refuse to ratify the Nice treaty, which was a major step towards a European superstate."

"Well they're just politicians, and they have to say things they don't believe. But surely the papers told us what had happened in Nice, so that we could decide whether it was good or bad for Britain?"

"Up to a point, son. The Sun, for example, called it an 'EU summit fiasco' giving us 'more red tape, more secrecy and more lunacy'.

The summit wrung surrender from Britain over 30 vetoes, twice as many as the limit set by foreign secretary Robin Cook. It took the first steps to create a legally binding European constitution and despite denials plunged ahead with plans for a European army unaccountable to Nato.

"The Daily Mail, which until the summit ended had concentrated its fire on the European rapid reaction force, agreed with the Sun, but less stridently than is its habit."

"Daddy, I thought you said people took different views about the facts. Seems to me they all thought it was pretty much a disaster."

"Wait a minute, son. You haven"t heard the half of it. The Financial Times is a very serious paper read by people who know about money. And while it was not exactly ecstatic about Nice, it was more positive than negative. 'This outcome should provoke relief rather than disappointment The vigorous defence of national interests suggests that the European superstate is a long way off'. The new pragmatism in Europe should give pause, among others to the British Conservative party which has already pledged to oppose ratification of the treaty.

"The Guardian echoed the cautious welcome theme, summing up the summit as 'All in all, a good weekend's work.' But the paper had hoped for something better, that Blair would have been 'less obsessed with Britain's narrow interest.' He had seen off the potential "rightwing backlash, perhaps neutralising Europe as an issue in the coming (general election) campaign." But the paper had hoped for a different (more integrated Europe?) tone in Nice.

"The Times was the most equivocal at its conclusion. 'It is at best a ramshackle palace that has been cobbled together'.This protracted yet hasty summit has built up stores of trouble to come.'

"The Daily Telegraph, firmly opposed to further strengthening of the EU, was very circumspect in its assessment of Nice, warning against rushing to judgment until we had read the small print of the treaty. But it did ask: 'In what concrete way are we better off now than last week? As with every Euro summit, victory has somehow been redefined to means the maintenance of the status quo."

"So there we have it, son. Mixed reaction to a mixed bag of a summit."

"But Daddy, you haven"t really told me what happened, except that people got very tired."

"Interesting you should mention that, son. One of the most fascinating pieces about Nice was hidden away far from the summit coverage, on a page in the Guardian called Working Lives.

It said that all-night working can be 'grimly satisfying, working under extraordinary circumstances to achieve the impossible, to salvage a lost cause, to pull a rabbit out of a hat.

This is of course largely an illusion, or perhaps more accurately a hallucination, brought on by severe sleep deprivation'."

"You mean the summit never happened, Daddy?"

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Cherie's punk years that never were

fields.headline: Mirror image of Cherie's punk years that never were
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: They were the pictures that had returned to haunt Cherie Blair, cackled the Mirror yesterday under a spread of images purporting to be of the prime minister's wife cavorting as a punk at a 1980s party.
fields.body:
They were the pictures that had returned to haunt Cherie Blair, cackled the Mirror yesterday under a spread of images purporting to be of the prime minister's wife cavorting as a punk at a 1980s party.

It was a charming tale - but a quick phone call to Downing Street would have elicited a killer fact: the snaps were not of Mrs Blair. In fact, the pictures were of a former left-wing council leader, as far removed from Blairite affections as could be imagined.

The Mirror and the BBC, which had planned to show footage of the party, were left dripping in egg yolk yesterday when No 10 pointed out the error. The BBC had pored over film from a Greater London council fundraising bash in 1985 as part of research for Before They Were Famous, a show, which digs out embarrassing pre-celebrity pictures of well-known figures.

The BBC made the footage the centrepiece of its Christmas show and supplied a tape to the Mirror, which ran the pictures yesterday. "This is Mrs Blair looking more like Siouxsie Sioux of the Banshees than a future prime minister's wife," tittered the copy.

Downing Street pointed out the error yesterday morning and the BBC later apologised.

A corporation statement said: "The pictures were obtained from library footage of a 1985 GLC fundraising event, and the production team believed them to be of Cherie Blair. However, Mrs Blair's office have told us it wasn't her, and she wasn't at the event. We regret the mistake was made."

The Mirror said it had received the pictures in good faith and had not checked with No 10.

Last night Julie Fitzgerald, a former leader of Camden council in north London, told the Guardian she was the woman in the pictures. "I'm amazed that whoever passed the pictures to the Mirror thought there was a similarity."

Both Ms Fitzgerald and Mrs Blair are 46. "The only similarity is that we're both female and of a similar age," said Ms Fitzgerald. She added that the picture was of a dance routine she had performed for a charity performance while she worked at the GLC.

Ms Fitzgerald said she found the Mirror's blunder "mildly amusing" and that she would like them to donate money to a charity of her choice by way of an apology.

webTitle: Today programme bans politicians from personality of the year contest

fields.headline: Politicos barred in Today roll of honour
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC's Today programme has banned politicians from its personality of the year contest because of fears they would try to rig the outcome.
fields.body:
The BBC's Today programme has banned politicians from its personality of the year contest because of fears they would try to rig the outcome.

The competition, once an annual fixture on the Radio 4 programme, was ditched in 1997 after repeated attempts to fix the result. Today said it was impossible to prevent party workers voting for their favoured leaders in droves.

This year, the competition has been resurrected in a new form, hero and villain of the year - and politicians are banned. Rod Liddle, editor of the programme, said yesterday: "I have decided to bar politicians because there is a real danger they or their supporters will try to rig the vote."

Tony Blair was disqualified in 1996 when it was found that a letter from Labour's campaign staff had urged party members to vote for him. John Major was declared the winner, at a time when he was unpopular in the polls, but 4,000 votes were disqualified after evidence of multiple voting. Previous winners include Mikhail Gorbachev, Margaret Thatcher and the Pope.

The poll was first called off in 1991, when it emerged that many votes for the apparent winner, Lal Krishnan Advani, leader of the Bharatiya Janata party in India, came from the same areas of Birmingham and Bradford.

Last year, Today listeners voted William Shakespeare the personality of the millennium, and producers now feel that members of the listening public can be trusted again.

The road to a shortlist begins on Monday with the first of a series of essays, in which contributors make suggestions for heroes and villains.

 Nominations close on December 23. The shortlist will be unveiled on December 27 and listeners will have until midnight on December 28 to vote. The winner will be announced on December 30.

webTitle: Italy's media tycoon, Berlusconi, has shrugged off criminal charges

fields.headline: Italy's Houdini poised to pull off his greatest trick
fields.standfirst:
Media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi has shrugged off criminal charges and looks set to stride to electoral victory

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi has shrugged off criminal charges and looks set to stride to electoral victory
fields.body:
Sunk deep in a sofa in his Roman palazzo, Silvio Berlusconi grins and explains why Europe has nothing to fear from his coming revolution. Italy is to be physically and culturally transformed but European Union partners can rest assured that his comeback, though spectacular, will be perfectly safe.

They call him the Cavalier but it might as well be Houdini. Not so long ago he was dead in the water, apparently a disgraced loser and convicted crook bound for jail.

The showman who was said to have sprung from the womb buying low and selling high was accused of massive corruption and acquired another nickname, the Watersnake.

But now, the 64-year-old media tycoon and leader of Italy's centre-right opposition feels so close to victory he can almost touch it. "I've been a property developer, it's what I'm best at. Soon I'll be able to develop the whole country."

Humiliation

A cross between Rupert Murdoch and Ross Perot, Mr Berlusconi exploded into politics to save the right. However, not all the billions in his bank accounts, nor the legions of journalists who did his bidding, nor the slickest marketing in Italy's history could save him.

His government collapsed in 1994 after seven months, a humiliation sealed two years later when the centre-left won power and prosecutors piled on new charges.

Six years later he seems invincible. Opinion polls suggest he will trounce the ailing centre-left government in elections due in spring. For Mr Berlusconi the day cannot come too soon.

Still Italy's richest man, worth around £13bn, he has successfully shaken off the convictions for various crimes of corruption through a series of appeals, emerged as the martyr of biased prosecutors, rebuilt his coalition and exploited the government's infighting. All that's left is to win respect abroad.

Hence the courting of foreign journalists. "I've been up all night writing out the answers," he says, showing scribbled replies to questions faxed by the Guardian.

Told he missed some good programmes on his three television channels, the man who made a fortune bringing showgirls and quiz shows to Italian screens shakes his head sadly. "I never have time to watch, I'm always working."

Critics worry that he is an unpredictable maverick who may be beholden to extremist allies.

Dressed casually, the famed tan, charm and smile are in place. The latter fades when asked about a potential conflict of interest between his public and private roles. It's not just the enormity of his business empire, it is that it decides much of what Italians read and watch.

Fininvest, an unlisted company, indirectly controls several newspapers and magazines, three TV channels and Italy's biggest publishing house, Mondadori.

Partisanship is rampant. A news anchor, Emilio Fede, interrupts reports to denounce the left. Participants in Italy's version of Big Brother ridicule politicians except the one who happens to own the network that produces the show.

Mr Berlusconi responds that he has no involvement in day-to-day management and that the state TV network, Rai, is biased towards the government. True, but soon he is likely to be the government.

He flatly rules out selling off Fininvest and instead promises to pass a law regulating such conflicts of interest and putting his companies into a blind trust. Useless, say critics, as long as his brother, son and daughter remain in charge.

Jewish groups are queasy at the alliance with the post-fascist National Alliance but more controversial is his alliance with Umberto Bossi's immigrant-bashing Northern League.

Suspected of plotting separatism behind an agreed devolution programme, it was Mr Bossi's defection that brought down Mr Berlusconi's first government. Can he be trusted this time? "Yes, because Bossi knows well that he can reach his eternal goal, federalism, only by allying with us," says Mr Belusconi.

The northern regions of Lombardy, Piedmont and Veneto are straining for more autonomy. Mr Berlusconi has struggled to cap such impulses within his own Forza Italia party but reckons national unity is so strong there will be no separatist genie when he opens the bottle.

Pro-European, Mr Berlusconi is at pains to appear a mainstream conservative of the same school as Jose Maria Aznar, Spain's prime minister.

He links crime with illegal immigrants and accuses the government of foisting a multi-ethnic Italy on an unwilling public. Only those who can show proof of work, accommodation and health care should be allowed in.

Arguing that lefties have brought the country to its knees and only he can repair the damage, his programme's ambition is stupendous. "We are preparing a Copernican revolution to refound the state."

The number of parliamentary deputies is to be halved, bureaucracy swept away, taxes slashed, laws reformed, utilities privatised, bridges and roads built. "A huge task, maybe too large for a small man." The twinkle suggests he doesn't believe that for a second.

The government took Italy into the euro, stabilised the economy and cut taxes but ducked major reforms for fear of upsetting interest groups.

Hinting that the unions are vulnerable, the owner of AC Milan football club insists he will pay the price of short-term unpopularity to get things done.

Pressed on a sensitive point - that he is allegedly a closet Tony Blair fan - he runs for cover. "No, my programme is totally embedded in the Italian situation."

Bonhomie becomes toxic when conversation turns to the left. Mr Berlusconi, his voice rising, says communists control the centre-left behind the mask of telegenic moderates. "I really consider the communists a risk to my country, liberty and well-being."

Mr Berlusconi has a tendency to compare himself to the Messiah. No one is quite sure whether he is joking.

fields.headline: Feuding loyalists agree peace deal
fields.standfirst:
Paramilitaries acknowledge suffering of communities

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The bloody feud between loyalist paramilitary groups, which claimed the lives of seven men and drove hundreds of Belfast families from their homes, is over after a peace deal was agreed yesterday.
fields.body:
The bloody feud between loyalist paramilitary groups, which claimed the lives of seven men and drove hundreds of Belfast families from their homes, is over after a peace deal was agreed yesterday.

A statement from the Ulster Volunteer Force and Ulster Defence Association, whose members have been involved in a bitter battle on the Shankill Road and in the north of the city since the summer, said they were committed to an "open-ended and all-encompassing cessation of hostilities".

It added: "We fully recognise the pain and suffering that has been inflicted on our community and we resolve that under no circumstances will such events be repeated."

The deal included the UVF's allies in the Red Hand Commando.

Politicians on all sides welcomed the statement, which said that a series of mechanisms had been agreed at leadership and local levels in all three organisations to ensure disputes could be resolved in a peaceful way.

The mainstream paramilitary groups, who support the Good Friday agreement, said they would disown any violence carried out in the name of dissident loyalists.

"Neither the Loyalist Volunteer Force nor any activity carried out under its name or any flag of convenience such as the Red Hand Defenders, Orange Volunteers or Loyalist Freedom Fighters has the support of any organisations bound by this agreement," they said.

It is understood that Johnny Adair, the jailed Shankill Road boss of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, affliated to the UDA, was not involved in the peace talks which took place in secret for the past few months between the commanders of the loyalist organisations.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, had revoked Adair's early release from prison in August because of his alleged influence in sparking the feud, and Mr Mandelson is to contest the sentence review commission's finding that he should be released soon.

Trouble flared at a UDA band parade on the Shankill in August when several people were injured in a shooting in the Rex Bar. This prompted tit-for-tat murders which spread to north Belfast.

An 11-year-old girl, the daughter of a former paramilitary prisoner, was also badly injured when gunmen fired through the window of her home in Coleraine, Co Londonderry.

Hundreds of Belfast families were forced to leave their homes, and many were sleeping on floors in relatives' homes and in church and community halls.

Mr Mandelson who had urged both sides to make peace, said last night: "I know from my extensive contacts with many people in the Shankill and north Belfast area that this is what they have been looking for for quite some time and I am deeply grateful, as they will be, to those who have worked so hard to bring this about.

"They have done a great service to their community and to the people of Northern Ireland."

A Stormont assemblyman, David Ervine, whose Progressive Unionist Party speaks for the UVF and the Red Hand Commando, said: "This statement has massive validity because of the length of time it took to get to this point. I'm convinced it will work.

"These communities have suffered enough and there is an indication in the statement the groups are cognisant of that. Genuine people have been working very hard to bring it to an end and, most fundamentally, create the circumstances in which it will never happen again."

Gary McMichael, leader of the Ulster Democratic Party which represents the UDA and UFF, said the peace deal meant many families would sleep easier in their own beds this Christmas.

"Those in loyalist communities who could have had a very anxious Christmas will now be able to look forward and celebrate in peace and comfort," he said. "All of us are glad the terrible suffering is now at an end."

However, an Ulster Unionist councillor, Chris McGimpsey, said it would take months for displaced families to get back to normal. "I welcome this and I hope any further disputes can be resolved through mediation rather than violence ... but even when families are rehoused there are all sorts of bureaucratic issues and problems," he said.
