webTitle: Freedom delayed after 27 years - the lawyers aren't ready

fields.headline: Freedom delayed after 27 years - the lawyers aren't ready
fields.trailText: Stephen Downing, who supporters claim is the victim of Britain's longest-running miscarriage of justice, learned yesterday he would spend his 28th Christmas in prison because of a legal bungle at the court of appeal.
fields.body:
Stephen Downing, who supporters claim is the victim of Britain's longest-running miscarriage of justice, learned yesterday he would spend his 28th Christmas in prison because of a legal bungle at the court of appeal.

Supporters of Mr Downing, who was jailed in 1974 for the murder of Wendy Sewell, a typist, reacted with fury when he was denied bail after a barrister for the crown prosecution service confessed he had not had time to prepare his side of the case which had been referred back to the appeal court.

Julian Bevan QC, who left Britain last night for a Christmas trip to Africa, said he had only been notified of yesterday's high court bail hearing at 4.30pm the day before.

"I received briefing papers 10 days ago. I was not aware that a bail application would be made and therefore I did not read the papers with any degree of urgency," he told the court. "I am not in a position to give the merits or demerits of the crown position because this takes considerable analysis."

However, Mr Bevan, referring to prison psychiatric reports which say that Downing is "in denial" of murder, urged that the court should be "slow in granting bail".

The judge, Mr Justice Crane, said that without a view from the prosecution bail could only be granted when the prospects of success at appeal were clear.

"This is not one of those clear cases or straightforward cases in which it is right to grant bail."

Downing, 44, had his case referred back to the appeal court by the criminal cases review commission on November 14.

The bail hearing was told that an investigation by the CCRC had cast doubt on the reliability of the confession Downing made on the day of the murder, and on the forensic evidence.

Don Hale, editor of the Matlock Mercury, who has campaigned for the former cemetery gardener's release for six years, said the prisoner and his parents would be devastated.

"I think we're all stunned by the decision. It is another ridiculous statement.

"The crown prosecution service has had 27 years to prepare for this case. The CCRC has had it for three and a half years. Stephen Downing is in jail for his 28th Christmas for a crime he didn't commit."

Downing's father Ray, 66, a taxi driver who still lives in Bakewell where the murder was committed in 1973, said the family were resigned to the court's decision.

Patrick McLoughlin, Downing's MP, described the circumstances surrounding the bail hearing as outrageous and demanded a statement from a minister in the Commons yesterday.

A spokesman for the CPS blamed the defence for not serving notice of the bail hearing until Wednesday.

Downing, who was 17 at the time, but had the reading age of an 11-year-old, was taken into custody by Derbyshire constabulary after he found Ms Sewell badly battered but still alive in the graveyard where he worked.

His counsel, Edward Fitzgerald QC, yesterday outlined at the bail hearing the main findings of the CCRC.

Downing's confession and the forensic evidence, "the two main planks" of the original prosecution case, had been undermined. He had been denied a lawyer during his police interview despite repeated requests, the court heard.

At the original trial, a forensic examination of his bloodstained jeans had helped convict him, but an expert who looked again at the evidence expressed "serious concerns," Mr Fitzgerald said.

Downing can renew his appeal for bail if the prosecution takes a favourable view after studying the case. It has been given until January 20 to do so.

webTitle: Cyber sweet nothing goes public via loose lips in City

fields.headline: Cyber sweet nothing goes public via loose lips in City
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: When an unknown 26-year-old tapped out a saucy compliment to her lover on Thursday she had no inkling it would end up in newspapers, on TV and with a press pack laying siege to her family home.
fields.body:
An unknown 26-year-old yesterday acquired notoriety in a scandal hatched by the all-pervasive power of email. When Claire Swire tapped out a saucy compliment to her lover on Thursday she had no inkling it would end up in newspapers, on TV and with a press pack laying siege to her family home.

Its recipient, 27-year-old City lawyer Bradley Chait, was so flattered that he sent it to six male colleagues. In his email Mr Chait referred to what sounded like an oral sex session adding: "Now that's a nice compliment from a lass, isn't it ?"

Minutes later, one had sent it on to 11 colleagues. In a testament to the whirlwind speed of email, the message - now headed "Do you know Claire Swire ?" - had left solicitors firm Norton Rose in an hour and was all around the City. It was chortled over by friends at corporate lawyers Allen Overy, investment bank J P Morgan and the Arts Council.

Reporters tracked Miss Swire down to her family home in Uckfield, East Sussex. where her parents said they believed the email was a prank that had got out of hand.

Although she was not talking Miss Swire had returned to sending emails. In a message to some of the people who had forwarded the message, she said: "What do you care about my social life? Shouldn't you all be working?" She told the female readers not to judge her, and the men that: "all you're going to get is a fantasy".

Mr Chait now faces disciplinary proceedings along with four colleagues involved in forwarding the emails.

Mr Chait now faces disciplinary proceedings along with four colleagues involved in forwarding the emails.

webTitle: Palestinians feel the brunt of Israeli firepower

fields.headline: Palestinians feel the brunt of Israeli firepower
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
Six Palestinians were killed on a rain-sodden day
of funerals and protests yesterday, overshadowing
a burst of diplomatic activity aimed at ending the
conflict in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Six Palestinians were killed on a rain-sodden day of funerals and protests yesterday, overshadowing a burst of diplomatic activity aimed at ending the conflict in the Middle East.

Israeli diplomats confirmed that a revival of the peace talks in Washington before President Clinton leaves office on January 20 was being explored: a summit meeting between the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, may be convened.

But even the most determined efforts to return to the negotiating table may be overwhelmed by events on the ground and Israel's growing political instability as Mr Barak faces a tough fight for re-election.

Palestinian militia leaders in the enclaves under Mr Arafat's control in the West Bank and Gaza have been stockpiling weapons - mostly acquired from Israeli army arsenals and passed through Israeli middlemen - in quantities that could keep the confrontation raging for months.

With an assured supply of weapons, the gunmen are strong enough to resist a peace deal that does not meet their demands.

webTitle: Fears for jobs as fish quotas cut to bone

fields.headline: Fears for jobs as fish quotas cut to bone
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: Hundreds of fishermen will lose their jobs under the new European catch quotas for 2001, but fish stocks around Britain are likely to go on plummeting.
fields.body:
Hundreds of fishermen will lose their jobs under the new European catch quotas for 2001, but fish stocks around Britain are likely to go on plummeting.

Although the quotas are lower than ever, they are higher for some species than the scientists recommended, raising the fear that the decline in the fishing industry is probably terminal.

After 13 hours of negotiations in Brussels, the fisheries minister, Elliott Morley, said he had won back quotas for Britain worth £35m.

A balance had been struck between rescuing threatened fish stocks and the needs of UK fishermen, he said.

Cod stocks are so low that ministers heeded the scientific advice to cut the North Sea quota by 45% - from 81,000 tonnes to 48,500 tonnes. But even this figure is unlikely to be reached: fishermen have been unable to find their cod quota since 1995, and cod is likely to become a luxury fish. A few years ago the average catch was 300,000 tonnes.

The ministers will meet again in January to develop a recovery plan for cod, which will involve closing large areas of the North sea during the spring spawning season and changing nets so that the smaller fish can escape rather than be caught and wasted, as at present.

The permitted catches of haddock, hake, whiting, prawn and flatfish in the North sea channel and Irish sea were increased. This includes an extra 750 tonnes of haddock and 800 tonnes of hake. The planned 75% reduc tion in the permitted catch of hake was whittled down to 41%.

Neither the conservation groups nor the fishermen are satisfied with the deal.

Euan Dunn, fisheries policy officer of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said: "The scientists tell us that fish stocks are at historically low levels, with two-thirds seriously depleted, some to the point of collapse.

"Yet the horse-trading in Brussels means that ministers are still compromising on scientific advice."

The Scottish Fishermen's Federation secretary, Ian Duncan, said: "The quotas from Brussels make bleak reading. Each of the key stocks upon which Scottish fishermen depend has been cut. There can be no doubt about what such figures mean.

"Fishermen will lose their jobs and the income of the average fisherman will fall, recruitment into the industry will become increasingly difficult and, without support, the fishing industry of Scotland as we know it will cease to exist."

He said the cuts would cost the Scottish industry a net loss of about £60m: up to 110 vessels would be forced out of the fleet and at least 300 jobs lost.

"This figure may seem small, but it should be borne in mind that these jobs are in some of the remotest parts of the British Isles. There are few if any alternative sources of employment," he said.

Barry Deas, of the National Federation of Fishermen's Organisations, said: "It looks like a terrible outcome. We may have reduced the cuts in some areas, but we came from an appalling starting point."

In Grimsby, fishermen and fish producers said the cuts would have a severe impact on the industry.

Martin Boyers, chief executive of the Grimsby Fish Merchants' Association, said there would be job losses and higher prices for consumers.

"The effects probably won't be felt for several months, but when fishermen reach their quota limits in the middle of next year, jobs will go - and for every fisherman's job that goes, eight more shore jobs will follow."

Nathan de Rozarieux, chief executive of the Cornish Fish Producers Organisation, who was in Brussels for the EU summit, said as he arrived back: "I am bitterly disappointed with the outcome, and I told the minister so."

fields.headline: Prescott in tube retreat
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText:
The government is preparing to back down in its
confrontation with Ken Livingstone over public-private
partnership plans for London Underground in what is
likely to be seen as a significant retreat from its
flagship part-privatisation programme for the public
services.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Seumas Milne  and David Hencke
fields.body:
The government is preparing to back down in its confrontation with Ken Livingstone over public-private partnership plans for London Underground in what is likely to be seen as a significant retreat from its flagship part-privatisation programme for the public services.

Tony Blair has instructed his deputy, John Prescott, to find a compromise with the mayor of London after months of increasingly damaging political wrangling over an issue that risked spinning out of control amid the continuing chaos in the privatised rail network.

The about-turn follows weeks of talks between Downing Street and Mr Prescott's department and intense pressure from Bob Kiley, Mr Livingstone's new transport commissioner for London and the man credited with turning round the New York subway.

Mr Kiley, who this week described the government's partial selloff plans for the tube as "fatally flawed", met Mr Prescott yesterday for the second time this week and it is understood that Mr Livingstone has also been in contact with the prime minister about the standoff.

In the first concrete sign of movement from the government side, Mr Prescott - who has been unhappy with the initial private sector bids to run the tube's track and signalling - has agreed to delay signing any of the planned 30-year contracts from next month until the end of March.

The credibility of the government's part-privatisation scheme was dealt a further blow yesterday by a report from the national audit office, which cast doubt on whether it would be cheaper, safer or more flexible than a publicly funded alternative.

Earlier this week, Mr Kiley published his own plan to rebuild the underground, using revenue-backed bonds to underpin a £10bn investment programme. Mr Kiley branded the government scheme unsafe, replicating the fragmentation of the privatised railway network and failing to transfer risk to the private sector.

Both Mr Livingstone and Mr Kiley have also made clear that they are prepared to shift ground, including keeping the PPP name, and taking on board elements of the government scheme.

Amid widespread scorn for their existing plans, ministers have had to weigh the risks of legal action by the mayor, a world-class transport manager resigning in protest or, worst of all, a serious underground accident, if they press ahead with handing over half the tube to the private sector.

The pressure on Mr Prescott intensified when the leaders of the rail unions issued a warning on Thursday that they would ballot tube workers for a strike unless they were given guarantees on safety under the planned PPP regime

Jeremy Colman, assistant auditor general for the NAO, parliament's financial watchdog, said yesterday that the case for the public-private partnership scheme was "clearly not proved", adding: "We are giving the government a flashing amber light."

The NAO report said a government decision based solely on taking the best private sector bid, compared with the government's still secret estimate of comparative cost if the tube remains in public hands, would be "unsound". Mr Colman said: "We are not saying think again. We are saying think."

Mr Livingstone welcomed the NAO's findings. "The government clearly wanted the national audit office to endorse the PPP. It has refused to do so. The way out lies in the discussions that have started between John Prescott and Bob Kiley."

Last night the Department of Transport said it and London Underground would study the report in detail.

webTitle: Home Office told asylum seeker his claim was 'pants'

fields.headline: Home Office told asylum seeker his claim was 'pants'
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText:
A refugee was told by the Home Office that his asylum
application had been turned down because Jack Straw
considered it "a pile of pants".
fields.body:
A refugee was told by the Home Office that his asylum application had been turned down because Jack Straw considered it "a pile of pants".

The formal letter of refusal passed to the Guardian - signed by Steven Cunney, an official at the immigration and nationality directorate's Croydon office - states in its fourth paragraph: "With regard to your claim to be a national of Afghanistan, the Secretary of State [Mr Straw] thinks that this is a pile of pants."

"We're speechless, we've never seen anything like it," said Deri Hughes-Roberts, the appeals case manager of the Refugee Legal Centre, which represented the asylum seeker.

Refugee support groups said the offensive wording was an insight into the climate of disbelief and contempt with which some immigration officials treat asylum applicants.

The refugee was given the letter - with the motto "Building a safe, just and tolerant society" - by a Home Office official during an interview at Oakington Barracks centre near Cambridge, on the afternoon of December 4.

The Home Office only spotted the offensive comment an hour and half after the letter had been handed over to the man's representative, Naomi Nicholson, a case worker with the Refugee Legal Centre. She had to explain the meaning of the letter to her client, who only speaks Urdu and Pushtu (an Afghan language).

"I was trying to paraphrase the letter starting from the top, but when I got to the fourth paragraph I didn't know what to say, I was so shocked," Ms Nicholson said. "I was very embarrassed. It was my country that was saying this to him."

Immigration staff tried to replace the letter with a hurriedly amended one that merely states "the Secretary of State is not satisfied that you have established that you are an Afghan national".

Emma Jane Davies, the centre's team leader at Oakington, said officials rang when they eventually spotted the sentence. "They said it was something to do with sabotage at the Home Office, and implied it wasn't to do with the author," she said.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said: "We are quite simply horrified that life and death decisions are being made in such an offensive, casual and flippant manner. By showing such little respect to the human suffering that asylum seekers endure, it is no wonder the asylum process lacks credibility."

The revelation of the offensive letter strengthens calls for an overhaul of asylum processing, and for staff to receive effective training and supervision in dealing with the complexities of individual cases.

The man was sent to Oakington after arriving in the UK in late November. Asylum seekers at the converted army barracks are given "fast track" treatment by the immigration directorate, cases being dealt with in five days. Officials are given only two or three days between initial interviews and legal representations to make decisions. Refugee rights workers say the compressed process leads to slipshod errors and erratic decisions.

Each letter is meant to be checked by senior immigration officials before being given to applicants. But the succession of mistakes in decision letters suggest that supervision is often non-existent.

The Home Office said last night: "This is completely unacceptable, and we are sending a formal letter of apology. The matter is being thoroughly investigated."

fields.headline: Democrats likely to rebuff Bush
fields.standfirst:
Opponents wary as president-elect prepares to appoint core of his cabinet today

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Opponents wary as president-elect prepares to appoint core of his cabinet today
fields.body:
President-elect George W Bush is expected to nominate the core of his cabinet today amid predictions that he will attempt to lure some Democrats across party lines to join the new administration.

The Democrats are expected to resist any Republican attempts to upset the delicate post-electoral balance by inciting defections, but President Bill Clinton signalled that Mr Bush would get a political "honeymoon" to forge consensus on bipartisan legislation.

Speaking to journalists on board Air Force One, as he left Britain yesterday, Mr Clinton said: "We basically believe in government, we believe in the possibility of doing things. And so I think the Democrats will give him a honeymoon and an opportunity for him to get his feet on the ground and pass some of his programme and do some things, and I think they ought to."

The first politician to make the pilgrimage to Austin since Al Gore's concession was a leading Democrat, Senator John Breaux, who was due to meet Mr Bush yesterday to discuss the prospects for political compromise.

With Mr Bush expected to announce key cabinet appointments today at his Prairie Chapel ranch, two hours outside Austin, some Republican sources suggested that Senator Breaux might be offered the job of energy secretary.

The conservative Louisiana Democrat has hitherto refused to rule out such a move, but poltical analysts said his defection would cause uproar at a time when the Senate is precisely balanced with 50 senators on each side of the aisle.

If Mr Breaux left the Senate, his replacement would be appointed by the Louisiana governor, Mike Foster, a Republican, tilting the hung Senate in Mr Bush's favour. Stephen Hess, an analyst at the Brookings Institution thinktank in Washington, said he did not think Mr Breaux would take the political risks of defection at such a finely balanced moment.

"It's going to be hard to tempt a ranking senator when the odds are in favour of the Democrats to take control of the Senate in 2002, and he would most likely become a committee chairman," Mr Hess said.

Instead it was thought more likely that Mr Breaux would recommend Bennett Johnston, a retired Democratic senator and another Louisiana conservative, for the energy department job. He was also expected to discuss the future of a bipartisan legislation for the reform of Medicare, the government-funded pensioners' health system.

More certain bets for the top jobs due to be announced today include the retired genersal Colin Powell, virtually certain to be given the stewardship of foreign policy as secretary of state, and Condoleezza Rice, expected to be appointed national security adviser: the first time black Americans have risen to such senior posts. Bush aides predicted that leading Hispanic politicians would also be given senior jobs, to reflect Mr Bush's philosophy of inclusion.

Ari Fleischer, a Bush spokesman said: "He governed in a bipartisan fashion in Texas, and he's going to bring that spirit to Washington."

Mr Bush established a reputation for working across party lines as governor. One of his closest allies was the late Democratic lieutenant governor Bob Bullock. But political observers in Austin point out that such bipartisanship is much easier in the Lone Star state, where many Democrats are more conservative than Republicans elsewhere in the US.

"The trouble is in Washington you don't have people like Bullock," said Tom Pauken, a former chairman of the Texas Republican party.

Mr Bush will also face rightwing opposition from his party's political base to attempts to appoint Democrats or even moderate Republicans, such as Governor Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania or Governor Christie Whitman of New Jersey, to sensitive positions.

The Rev Jerry Falwell, the Christian fundamentalist leader, fired a warning shot as speculation about cabinet posts grew. He said: "The worst thing Mr Bush could do is bring Democrats into his administration or reach out to Governor Whitman or Governor Ridge for key positions, when these people do not believe what his constituency believes or what he believes."

fields.headline: The birth of a notion
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: It is hard for us today to engage with the reality of events 2,000 years ago. The cosy tinsel of convention is barrier enough, but there is a more substantial partition separating us.
fields.body:
It is hard for us today to engage with the reality of events 2,000 years ago. The cosy tinsel of convention is barrier enough, but there is a more substantial partition separating us.

Whether historical fact or allegory, the nativity of Jesus Christ both affects and reflects the most fundamental article of the Christian - and universal - faith communities. God's translation into truly human being had to be undertaken in a manner which made the divine ousios immune to the common, inherent, inescapable condition of humanity, original sin.

Theology has built immaculate ramparts around the bare earth of the nativity in order to protect its holy product from this contamination. To achieve this, it constructed a complex thesis to contrive that the delivery of life support to the divine foetus was undertaken by uteran, placental and umbilical processes which were not infected by the human "virus". In doing so, it has concealed the true miracle of the nativity.

Mary became pregnant before marriage; this was a serious breach of Judaic law, as well as a matter for moralistic scandal. Her fiancé, Joseph, was a carpenter, a builder, which, in an occupied land, meant working for the enemy. So, a publican and a sinner, they would have received neither the human compassion which extends to the deprived not the protection which social engineering contrives for the rich.

Even in a liberal culture, such circumstances constitute a crisis - made into a drama by Mary's unlikely explanation - but this was Judaism, where an individual peccadillo contaminated the entire community.

From the outset therefore, the confinement was subject to severe stress; social ostracism carries with it daily hostilities which are particularly demoralising for a young couple with an unplanned pregnancy. They would have needed unusual trust, love and resilience to tough it out.

They certainly did not want any extra pressure, material or social, so the dilemma of a census was the last burden they needed, because it clearly offered fiscal advantages for full family attendance, and was part of Rome's ongoing attempts to disrupt Jewish solidarity. Should they attend? Would it not lose them the few friends they had left? Above all, would the journey damage the baby?

And the journey itself; their option to attend alienating them further, in the company of quisling strangers, falling behind with every mile, undignified with constant "pit stops", the fear of premature birth growing with exhaustion and pain, harried by the urgency of registering with an authority which demanded punctuality, overwhelmed by small-town fear of the city, and by its reality upon arrival into an unruly mardi gras of jostling crowds who would have viewed a young pregnant couple as a butt for ribaldry.

There was nothing silent or holy about this night, and they would have been totally demoralised by the time they found "no room at the inn".

And so to the stable, a flophouse for latecomers who would not have taken kindly to finding themselves billeted with a woman about to go into labour. This overcrowded midden, where spooked animals milled and relieved themselves, along with their human guests, was about as life-threatening as a delivery room could be.

Finally, labour itself. No epidurals, no friends, no midwife, no hygiene, the unknown of first birth, the heckling and remonstrations of the crowd, the pain, the panic, the terror of transition and into second stage.

This was how it was. The record is unequivocal, in spite of 2,000 years of theological mistranslation by men - men, who, of course, were disturbingly ignorant of obstetrics, who had no concern for women's matters and who considered women to be the vessel of the devil. The raw meaning of that desperate event has been institutionally suppressed. Yet, in spite of this, the record remains.

That is how it was, and none of it was necessary. It was God's choice; he opted to incorporate into his incarnation elements of risk which were gratuitously human, and the focus of the risk was the foetus. The circumstances chosen by God with such wilful exaggeration are precisely those which induce premature babies, damaged babies, non-viable babies, handicapped babies, neonatally vulnerable babies, dead babies.

This selection of hazard was so gratuitous in its exaggeration, so exaggerated in its precision, so precise in its foetal target, that it must surely be a divine statement about the nature of Christ, and thereby the nature of man. Far from undergoing the immaculate process of a laser-beam miracle, which insulated him against original sin, God's son was carried through and delivered under the most damaging and life-threatening circumstances that nativity can have.

God chose a conception, gestation and delivery which announced his total confidence in the integrity of his own creation. It was a warning to us against the conceits of our own explanation and the hubris within them. Man has no original sin to be ashamed of, rather a seminal heroism to be realised. From Nazareth to Bethlehem, God celebrated his trust in man.

Now that really is a Christmas message.

Stewart Dakers works with people with learning disabilities

webTitle: Fraud case fund boss unfit to stand trial

fields.headline: Fraud case fund boss unfit to stand trial
fields.standfirst: Stress in the City: jury hears of sex change agony of former high-flyer
fields.trailText: Stress in the City: jury hears of sex change agony of former high-flyer
fields.body:
The stresses and strains of working in the City are legendary. The relentless pressure to make money means traders burn out fast. Yesterday, a crown court jury heard that the pace of work had driven a star fund manager into a cycle of mental instability, culminating in life-threatening injuries following repeated attempts to castrate himself.

Peter Young, 42, once one of the City's biggest stars, was declared unfit to stand trial for an alleged £220m fraud that left thousands of investors disadvantaged.

Six-foot, bespectacled Mr Young earned £300,000 a year at the German-owned merchant bank Morgan Grenfell until 1996, when it emerged that the top performing funds he ran were riddled with irregularities. Morgan Grenfell's parent company, Deutsche Bank, was forced to pay compensation of £180m and another £100m to shore up the fund, as well as pay the highest fine ever in the City of £2m.

Mr Young was charged with conspiracy to defraud investors, conspiracy to create misleading information and three counts of dishonestly concealing misleading facts. The prosecution has claimed he used some of the cash to buy the £350,000 Buckinghamshire home he shared with his Dutch-born wife Harmanna and their two toddlers, George and Henry.

But as pre-trial hearings commenced, he stunned onlookers by arriving dressed as a woman. He walked out of court yesterday dressed in a cerise top, grey flecked skirt and high-heeled shoes and carrying a purple shoulder bag, after showing no emotion when he was dismissed under the 1964 Insanity Act.

A spokesman for the serious fraud office said: "There was a variance in opinion about Peter Young's mental health. In the interests of the public, the only course open to us was to challenge his claim to be unfit."

The road that eventually led to a diagnosis of schizophrenia began long before suspicions were aroused at work.

Early examples included a trip to the supermarket to buy 30 jars of gherkins. Eventually, the Oxford graduate began hearing voices urging him to change sex.

The jury of six men and six women at Southwark crown court decided unanimously that he was "under such disability of mind" that he was unfit to stand trial. The details are lurid.

The court heard that his "passion" to change sex led to him inflicting appalling injuries on himself which eventually led to him losing a testicle. He used a craft knife, a length of fishing line and a pair of scissors in repeated attempts to castrate himself. The twice-married father of two told psychiatrists that he heard two voices - one male, the other a woman called Sarah - telling him to become a woman.

His wife, who is pressing for divorce, said that after six years of marriage his behaviour suddenly became erratic. "He started growing his hair long, plucking his eyebrows and waxing his body hair."

He calls himself Elizabeth, after the daughter of one of his friends.

It was a dramatic change for a man who was described as a child as a "near genius". Guildford-born Mr Young had an upper-second degree in maths from Oxford. The funds he eventually ran at Morgan Grenfell were such strong performers that even high-flying colleagues invested in them. In 1996, just months before irregularities in his funds emerged, he was invited to the Royal Albert Hall to share the secrets of his success with an audience of his high-earning peers.

His public fall from grace began with a terse statement to the stock exchange announcing that three of his funds had been frozen pending an investigation by regulators. In the days and weeks that followed, it emerged that he had been buying shares in scores of little-known private companies in far-flung corners of the world, in direct contravention of regulations. A web of cross-holdings emerged, some centred around a Luxembourg-registered company called Russ Oil and a US firm called Solv-Ex. A little-known broking firm called Fiba Nordic Securities was also entangled in the alleged web of deception.

An Old Bailey trial with a fresh jury will still go ahead to establish the facts of Mr Young's investments. The crown claims he was deliberately breaking investment rules in an attempt to win six-figure bonuses and promotion. He will walk free, but he is accompanied everywhere by a nurse. Two other men, his former Morgan Grenfell colleague Stewart Armer and Erik Langaker, a former Fiba Nordic broker, still face charges.

Initially, Mr Young's appearances as a woman were greeted sceptically. Richard Latham QC, prosecuting for the SFO, said he had lied about his dealings and had told the "fitness to plea" hearing that he was capable of standing trial. "Peter Young may be vulnerable and confused about his gender, but he was in a jam and for the first time starts to talk about being mad.

"It was only just before the balloon went up in September 1996 that he said any thing about mental illness." At an initial hearing on Mr Young's fitness to stand trial, the jury was dismissed after failing to agree on a verdict.

Defence counsel Clare Montgomery told the court, however, that Mr Young was "now dealing with mental illness".

She said: "He has gone from being a man of the highest intellectual achievement to living the life of a mental patient.

"Now he sits at home staring at the ceil ing unless instructed by his mother or brother to get up and perform some menial task."

Miss Montgomery continued: "Some people fake mental illness to get out of a sentence - Ernest Saunders is a notorious example of that. Others win release from a mental hospital and go on to kill themselves or other people. Peter Young harmed himself in the most bizarre circumstances because he was severely unwell."

Family man whose life fell apart

Born in Guildford. Graduates with maths degree from Oxford. Trains as actuary and starts career at Equity & Law

Joins Mercury Asset Management in 1990, before joining Morgan Grenfell Asset Management in 1992

Marries second wife, Dutch-born Harmanna, in 1991. Two children, George and Henry

May 1994 takes control of European Growth Trust, one of the funds involved

September 2, 1996, Morgan Grenfell, owned by Deutsche Bank, suspends dealings in European Growth Trust and two others, Europa and European Capital Growth Fund. Young suspended and later fired for "gross misconduct"

Serious Fraud Office investigation begins shortly afterwards. During 1996, five Morgan Grenfell employees are dismissed and compensation system set up for 90,000 investors. April 1997, City regulator imposes a £2m fine on firm

Young charged by SFO with conspiracy to defraud in 1998

November 1998, appears at magistrates court dressed as woman

November 2000, first jury undecided on claims he should not stand trial. December, declared unfit to stand trial after graphic descriptions of his attempts to complete his transformation to a woman

fields.headline: Greenspan's Christmas spirit sorely tested
fields.standfirst:
Soft landing now harder to achieve

Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: This week Microsoft cast itself in the role of Scrooge, spoiling any chance of the markets celebrating the festive season. So, with prices in a spin on both sides of the Atlantic, the question has to be asked: will Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan be prepared to don Santa's robes?
fields.body:
This week Microsoft cast itself in the role of Scrooge, spoiling any chance of the markets celebrating the festive season. So, with prices in a spin on both sides of the Atlantic, the question has to be asked: will Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan be prepared to don Santa's robes?

Let's be clear. Microsoft is no ordinary company. To the extent that there is a bellwether of the new economy it is the company that Bill Gates co-founded. Equally worryingly, the company is a bellwether of the old economy, too. Plenty of the traditional blue chip companies use Microsoft products. If the Seattle outfit says it is going to miss performance targets - even by relatively modest amounts - it is a safe bet that America's economy is beginning to hurt.

As such, yesterday's official data showing a fall in manufacturing output were slightly beside the point. The markets were already in sell mode after Microsoft's bombshell that was delivered after trading had finished on Thursday night, warning that second-quarter earnings would miss expectations by around 5%.

Certainly its litany of explanations was comprehensive: a weakness in worldwide economic conditions was leading to a slowdown in PC sales, corporate IT spending and consumer online services and advertising. So what else can go wrong?

Just as the investment boom was a self-fulfilling prophecy, so too will be the downturn. Companies have spent heavily in the expectation that the 1990s good times would roll on for ever. Quite simply, the supply of goods and services is outstripping demand, leaving companies with rising inventories and deteriorating earnings. Today's profits warnings will be tomorrow's job losses.

So can Mr Greenspan provide the markets with a Christmas cracker, either by cutting rates this week or delivering a hefty hint they are on the way down sometime soon? Should he?

There is an element of moral hazard here. The fact that even the hint of a rate cut from the Fed chairman earlier this month led to a sharp if brief recovery in the Dow Jones and Nasdaq indices was a sign that there are still plenty of bulls out there waiting for any excuse to get back into the market.

That means, however, that any boost Mr Greenspan seeks to give the real economy on main street is almost certain to give a much larger one to the bubble economy on Wall Street. But in keeping "irrational exuberance" in check Mr Greenspan may have to keep rates on hold for longer than he would like and the US economy can stand.

Steering a course between hard landing and asset price bubble will require all Mr Greenspan's skill and experience.

Tap turned off

Geoffrey Chamberlain's Durlacher, the fringe stockbroker that mutated into a specialist internet-related investment company, has become a fully fledged member of the 90% club. In fact, after yesterday's investment write-down and another 7p fall in the share price to 22p, against last spring's peak of 441p, the firm qualifies for the more exclusive 95% club.

Durlacher remains an impossible company to value. Blind punting almost turned it into a Footsie company, yet by this weekend its market capitalisation has shrunk to around £120m - and there is no evidence, using traditional valuation yardsticks, that it is even worth this much.

Yesterday's write-down amounted to £13m, which insiders say is equivalent to about a third of the total cash investment in its portfolio of stakes in internet start-ups.

The "bull" case (yes, there are still a few proponents of the view that internet-related valuations will rise again at some stage in the future) says that many of these businesses on which Durlacher has bet its money might now be worth many times their early-stage valuations in Durlacher's books. Even if a good portion of these young firms eventually go to the wall, it only needs a couple of winners ...

The "bear" case, on the other hand, says that when it was making these initial investments Durlacher was probably working on the assumption that the time would have arrived by now when it could start selling them off - booking its profits rather than crystallising its losses.

It seems inevitable that many of these young ventures have reached the point where they need additional funding, just as the capital tap has been turned off.

This is a funders', rather than an entrepreneurs', market. And, for any of these businesses planning to go out and either sell themselves or complete fresh funding rounds, their negotiating position has just been dealt a dreadful blow. Having a major shareholder which appears to be in trouble just does not look good.

webTitle: Four held after boy, 13, found stabbed

fields.headline: Four held after boy, 13, found stabbed
fields.trailText:
Four people, including a teenage girl, were being
questioned by police last night after a 13-year-old boy
was left critically injured after being stabbed in what
may be a racially motivated attack.
fields.body:
Four people, including a teenage girl, were being questioned by police last night after a 13-year-old boy was left critically injured after being stabbed in what may be a racially motivated attack.

Daniel Herbert was found unconscious early yesterday in a pool of blood near his home in Littlehampton, West Sussex. He had suffered multiple stab wounds and was taken to Worthing hospital, and then transferred to Guy's, in London, where he remained in a serious condition.

Police were called to the South Terrace area of Littlehampton at 3.04am, after a passerby found Daniel lying on a green surrounded by broken glass.

Sussex police estimate the boy, who is of mixed race, had been attacked some 15 minutes earlier. Detectives said they believe "race may well be an issue" in the attack.

Acting Detective Superintendent Steve Scott said: "I will take it as a racial attack until it is proved otherwise."

A man, two women and the 16-year-old girl, all local, were being held for questioning.

The green, 50 metres from Littlehampton beach, was cor doned off yesterday for a fingertip search and police began door-to-door inquiries.

A flat nearby has also been sealed off. It is believed to have been the venue for a party on the night of the attack.

The boy's family, including his sister, 10, and three-year-old brother, are believed to have moved from Scotland to live in Littlehampton in the last six weeks.

Police officers are trying to es tablish his movements in the hours before the attack. He had not been reported missing.

Newsagent Ken Hubert said: "He used to come in after school and at weekends with friends. He was never on his own."

Magistrates last night granted police an extra 24 hours to question three youths held in connection with the death of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor almost three weeks ago in Peckham, south London.

webTitle: Dobson gets key job in Labour's poll campaign

fields.headline: Dobson gets key job in Labour's poll campaign
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Frank Dobson, who suffered a humiliating defeat at the
hands of Ken Livingstone this year, is to be brought in
from the cold and given a frontline role in Labour's
general election campaign.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson, who suffered a humiliating defeat at the hands of Ken Livingstone this year, is to be brought in from the cold and given a frontline role in Labour's general election campaign.

After months of silence, the former health secretary is to head Millbank's "Billy Bandwagon" unit, which will highlight Labour's claim that William Hague jumps on to populist issues in an opportunistic way.

Mr Dobson, whose appointment has been approved by Tony Blair, kicked off his new campaign last night with a speech in which he criticised Mr Hague for a "catalogue of rightwing opportunism".

Condemning Mr Hague's attack on the Macpherson report, Mr Dobson said: "Hague's bandwagons are like faulty shopping trolleys - they keep veering off to the right. He believes that by jumping on every passing bandwagon the Tories can divert attention from the fact that [they] will slash billions from health, education, transport and law and order."

Mr Dobson's return to frontline politics will be welcomed by Labour MPs, who believe that the jovial Yorkshireman was treated unfairly by Millbank during the London mayoral campaign.

Downing Street encouraged Mr Dobson to run against Mr Livingstone in the hope that such a popular party figure would sway voters. Mr Dobson was pushed into an embarrassing third place after Millbank's character assassination of Mr Livingstone backfired.

The appointment shows Mr Blair still has a high regard for Mr Dobson's skills in reaching out to the Labour grassroots. Millbank is concerned that constituency parties are ill-prepared for the election which is expected next May. One Labour official said: "The prime minister sees Frank Dobson as someone who can pack a punch. He will generate enthusiasm among Labour supporters and take on William Hague with the full support of Downing Street."

Mr Dobson's unit will be based at Labour's Millbank headquarters. Other MPs will be called in to help him.

Mr Dobson said last night that Mr Hague's law and order speech on Thursday, in which the Tory leader blamed the Macpherson report for a drop in police morale, showed that he had not grown up politically.

Speaking to party activists in Pontefract, Mr Dobson said: "William Hague is still playing at student politics. This fundamental flaw, the lack of a coherent political approach, leads him to jump from one bandwagon to another. As often as not, he has to jump off altogether."

Mr Dobson contrasted Mr Hague's "lack of judgment" with Margaret Thatcher and John Major, who were "serious people with a serious policy agenda".

The new Dobson unit started its work yesterday by releasing a dossier of six "bandwagon" Tory policies. They are:

 Ann Widdecombe's pledge to fine all cannabis users, a policy which collapsed within days;

 The Tories' pledge to cut tax on petrol within days of September's protest, despite having introduced the fuel duty escalator while in office;

 Mr Hague's pledge to "overhaul" the law on self-defence following the trial of Tony Martin, who was jailed for shooting a burglar at his home;

 The pledge to lock up all asylum seekers. Labour said this was based on the advice of the shadow cabinet office minister, Andrew Lansley, that immigration plays "particularly well in the tabloids";

 The Tory front bench's opposition to the Millennium Dome despite approving it in government;

 Mr Hague's criticisms of the government over mad cow disease.

webTitle: Man sues lover for passing off baby as his

fields.headline: Man sues lover for passing off baby as his
fields.trailText: A man yesterday launched an unprecedented legal  action in an attempt to sue his former lover for  £250,000 in damages after he discovered the child he  had raised as his own for eight years was not in fact  his son.
fields.body:
A man yesterday launched an unprecedented legal action in an attempt to sue his former lover for £250,000 in damages after he discovered the child he had raised as his own for eight years was not in fact his son.

He plans to sue his former partner for "deceit", the emotional distress caused by the discovery and costs plus interest he incurred while bringing up the boy for eight years during which he regarded him as his son.

The 53-year-old businessman, from the West Midlands, and his former partner cannot be identified due to a court order protecting the identity of the child.

He became suspicious that the child was not his when in 1994 the results of a sperm test showed that he was infertile. He had been surprised when his lover became pregnant in 1988 as in 1975 he underwent a vasectomy. In 1996 a DNA test established that the child was not his.

Mr X and the boy's mother, Mrs Y, have remarried. Mrs Y and the child live in the north-east. At a preliminary hearing at Birmingham crown court Mr X's solicitor, who also cannot be named for legal reasons, said the action would attempt to prove a tort - a civil wrong - had been done to the claimant.

The solicitor said the couple had never married, adding: "Mr X did have a very positive relationship with the child when he thought the child was his. We think this is a valid course of action." The solicitor added that the woman being sued maintained that she honestly believed that Mr X was the father of her son.

Harvey McGregor QC, representing Mr X, yesterday outlined the claimant's case at a preliminary hearing in the queen's bench division of the high court.

Mr McGregor told the court: "The claimant contends that he was deceived by the defendant into believing that the child to whom she gave birth was his."

Mr McGregor said that a further round of tests in January this year had proved Mr X was not the child's father and the child's birth certificate has now been "corrected".

Alistair Smail, representing Mrs Y, asked Mr Justice Stanley Burnton whether it was right in law that a woman could be sued for fraud for representing to a man that he was the father of her child when he was not.

Mr X's suspicions over the parentage of his "son" were aroused in 1994 when Mrs Y left him, taking the child to the north-east to set up home with her current husband.

Shortly after she left she demanded a cash payment of £280,000, which she regarded as her share of his property, maintenance of £600 a month and a Porsche to replace the one she had been using while living with Mr X.

In response Mr X set about proving that the child was not his. The initial solicitors he retained he considered unsatisfactory, and he is running a parallel legal action against them.

According to his solicitor recovery of the money spent on raising the child is secondary to recompense for the distress the episode has caused.

Since 1996 Mrs Y has prevented him seeing the child. Asked if Mr X has any desire to see the child his solicitor said: "I'm not sure he's bothered either way. He will treat him on a friendly basis if he does meet him again, but the truth is he is not his son.

"He is also reluctant to visit the child, who is well settled in a new environment, for fear of disrupting his upbringing."

Judgment was reserved on whether the lawsuit can go ahead. It is expected to be delivered in writing in London next year.

fields.headline: RAF crisis as personnel quit
fields.standfirst: Flight crews are frustrated by underfunding and lack of adequate training, says senior officer
fields.trailText: The RAF is suffering a severe loss of personnel, with 30% more leaving than being recruited, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The RAF is suffering a severe loss of personnel, with 30% more leaving than being recruited, according to figures released yesterday.

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, said that 2,320 people left the RAF between May and October. Only 1,777 were recruited over the period.

He gave the figures in response to a question from the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan-Smith, and disclosed that because of defects in the RAF's Tucano aircraft, young pilots were completing their basic fast jet training in Australia.

In a highly unusual public intervention earlier this month, Air Chief Marshal Sir Peter Squire, chief of the air staff, told The Officer magazine that RAF flight crews were becoming frustrated because inadequate funding was depriving them of equipment to do sufficient training.

Sir Peter told The Officer it was increasingly difficult to meet the 3% annual efficiency savings demanded by the Treasury. He said the RAF's inability to buy enough "mission-critical" equipment had stretched bases in the UK. "There is a lack of quality training back at the main base," he said.

Pilots were getting only half or two thirds of the flying hours needed to refresh their skills. The problem is compounded by computer problems involving long-delayed plans to upgrade Tornado bombers.

RAF engineers are having to rob spares from one aircraft to use in another - "not an efficient way of doing business," said Sir Peter.

Pilots on average earn about £40,000 a year, including £10,950 flying pay.

The maximum they could hope to earn as a squadron leader, the highest flying rank, is about £50,000. This is significantly lower than the salaries paid even by short-haul airlines offering cheap flights.

"Pilots in their thirties can earn £10,000 more at a civil airline and the gap widens," an RAF officer said.

The RAF is short of some 100 fast jet pilots. This has added to problems of overstretch, with pilots spending more time on operations - including the no-fly zones over Iraq.

"All the money is being put into overseas operations," Andrew Brookes, airforce expert at the International Institute for Strategic Studies and a former pilot, said yesterday.

"The only way to save money is on fuel. It is a complete and utterly ridiculous state of affairs," he said.

He added that even flying scholarships for young pilots had been abandoned. A flight simulator designed to save money on fuel had been shown not to be up to the job.

Meanwhile, lack of funds and bad management meant that it took five years to train a pilot in the RAF compared with two years in the US airforce.

He said many pilots were leaving flying altogether. They were not attracted by the higher pay and allowances in the civil airline sector, because they wanted a settled job with their families.

Many RAF personnel - not just pilots - were leaving for business where skills they learned in the services and their military background were sought after.

The armed forces review board is expected in its forthcoming awards to improve pilots' pay by up to £20,000 a year. There is a shortage of navy and army helicopter pilots as well as pilots for RAF multi-engined aircraft, the national Audit Office pointed out in a recent report.

It estimated that almost £42m of £155m spent on training RAF fast jet pilots in 1998/99 was lost to wastage and delays in training.

The MoD also admitted recently that almost a third of the navy's trained Sea Harrier pilots were considering resigning their commissions and leaving the service. It admitted there was concern over the possible loss of up to 13 pilots - equivalent to the strength of one of the Fleet Air Arm's two Sea Harrier squadrons.

webTitle: Leader: Blair must dump his plans for the tube

fields.headline: Bonds Street
fields.standfirst:
Blair must dump his plans for the tube

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: What happens to London Underground is not a metropolitan meander. It concerns everyone interested in building public infrastructure in the wake of the disastrously fragmented privatisation of the railways.
fields.body:
What happens to London Underground is not a metropolitan meander. It concerns everyone interested in building public infrastructure in the wake of the disastrously fragmented privatisation of the railways.

Ken Livingstone, notwithstanding our pre-electoral doubts about his qualifications as London's mayor, has done very well to secure Robert Kiley as his commissioner for transport. If Mr Kiley, an American who has revived the second and third oldest tube systems in the world (Boston and New York), cannot revive the oldest, then who can? He comes, unlike New Labour, with a refreshing lack of ideological baggage.

A tough businessman, he claims that the government's public-private partnership (PPP) is "fundamentally and fatally flawed". He wants a £10bn bond issue secured against tube revenues so as not to count against public borrowing. He received unexpected support yesterday from the national audit office which said "the case for PPP is clearly not proved".

It is unusual for the NAO to comment on a scheme before it has been started, rather than when it is too late to remedy things. It should do it more more often. Politics apart, the choice would be easy: adopt Mr Kiley's plan and let him bring in new managers at the top of LU and unleash the frustrated energies of middle-managers, while contracting out risk-bearing refurbishment to the private sector. Control would be vested in a unitary board to avoid the chaos of British Rail. Since this would be funded by bonds, it could be packaged as a sensible compromise within the Treasury's PPP mantra.

Except, except ... for the politics. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, and Lord Macdonald, his transport minister, may, privately, be more sympathetic, but Gordon Brown could not accept defeat for pure PPP, which has become a virility symbol for the Iron Chancellor. And neither Mr Brown nor Mr Blair could stomach the sight of Mr Livingstone dancing a pre-electoral victory jig. Yet to delay a decision until after the election would enable the Tories to taunt Labour over a u-turn in the pipeline.

Maybe Mr Livingstone should promise not to gloat if the u-turn is dressed up as a workable compromise within current PPP policy. Ken should remember what President Truman is reported to have said (when he agreed to the post-war Marshall Plan being so named): there is no limit to what a man can achieve if he is prepared to let someone else take the credit.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Michael Storey, President and ceo of Inmarsat Ventures
fields.trailText: Michael Storey, President and ceo of Inmarsat Ventures
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

At the age of 8, as a winner in a "happy smiles" competition in a now defunct national newspaper. I told the reporter I wanted to be an explorer.

What has been your best moment in management?

There is no single occasion; I have an ongoing feeling of satisfaction every time anyone in Inmarsat takes responsibility for making things happen.

And your greatest mistake?

Trusting people with flawed values.

How would you describe your management style?

Strategic, trusting, demanding, informal.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

The restructuring of British Telecom in 1984.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Any sense of sycophancy.

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?

More a gossamer welcome; currently 40% of Inmarsat's senior management team are women.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Communications, as opposed to "razor-sharp-coms".

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Take risks, take responsibility and don't be afraid of failure as a learning experience.

Which management guru do you believe in?

None.

Who is your management hero?

None, but Jack Welch is an excellent exemplar.

Who is your favourite politician?

Nelson Mandela, but even he fell short of changing a continent.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

The need to embrace and drive insightful change.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

"This is not rocket science" - however, in our business, it is!

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Sailing, reading, thinking, squashing.

What annoys you most?

When telecoms service providers do not understand that you are a customer.

How do you relax?

By having a good conscience about what I do professionally.

What was your last cultural experience?

Visiting the new space museum in New York with my son.

What is your favourite city?

London, Paris, Amsterdam, Washington DC, New Orleans, San Francisco and New York.

Do you have a favourite web site?

www.cnbc.com

What is your greatest regret?

I don't have any regrets - I was just a different kind of explorer!

What is your biggest fear?

Failure to deliver on my values.

What would you really like to have been?

The fictional character Commodore Jack Aubrey of the Royal Navy in Patrick O'Brian's seafaring novels, for his management skills.

fields.headline: Master plan gets a timely makeover
fields.standfirst: The MBA went from being the mark of an elite to two a penny. But, says Gary Miles, it has recently bounced back by offering more flexible learning that stresses self-reliance and closer links with business
fields.trailText: The MBA went from being the mark of an elite to two a penny. But, says Gary Miles, it has recently bounced back by offering more flexible learning that stresses self-reliance and closer links with business.
fields.body:
This Christmas, while snoozing on the sofa after lunch, spare a thought for those embarking on MBA courses early in the new year. They will decline that last glass of port to spend time on their reading list.

The MBA has been a victim of its own success. The classic MBA, which stems from 50s America, became the elite master's qualification - only to suffer humiliating doubts about its validity because too many graduates pursued an MBA and the sheer numbers began to dilute its exclusivity.

Showing admirable resilience, the MBA has bounced back. In today's dot.com world of innovation, the qualification is ironically becoming even more relevant as managers increasingly recognise they need a broader base of skills if they are to add real value to their businesses. An MBA may no longer be a shortcut to instant career success, but it is still the world's most popular business qualification - and suppliers have been quick to respond to the managerial demand.

Today, around 800 business schools and other institutions in the US and Europe offer MBAs to an annual intake of more than 100,000. Although a wide variety of programmes fall under the MBA banner - including modular, consortium, specialist, company and distance-learning MBAs - the bulk of them are imitative, not innovative, in style. Most are housed within more traditional academic institutions and feature standard methods of delivering and assessing learning.

This presents a challenge for today's potential students who have to shop around in the global MBA marketplace to find the programme that best suits their needs. Because programme styles are so similar, many students base their choice on a "beauty parade" of the top providers.

Hence, all MBAs are equal, but some are more equal than others. There is an understandable temptation to opt for the relative safety of a recognised brand name and those providers who are unable to trade on reputation or who are offering "me-too" programmes will struggle to survive.

Business schools have begun to respond to this threat. Many are actively striving to differentiate their programmes and this seems to be an on-going trend. The overly structured curriculum format is looking tired. In its place, a new model for MBA is developing.

As organisations undergo constant change, individuals also need to go through a process of self-renewal, in terms of refining their existing skills, learning new skills and managing their careers. To be truly effective, an MBA programme has to assist the individual in this endeavour.

Many MBAs focus on strategic thinking, technical expertise and the traditional skills of marketing and finance. New model MBAs cover these aspects, but also focus on "softer" skills, such as interpersonal sensitivity, which help to develop more rounded and effective managers.

The concept of self-renewal hinges on the fact that it doesn't matter how much experience you've got, there's always more to learn - and the learning doesn't stop after the course ends. That openness to learning is vital for potential participants of the new MBAs. With traditional MBAs, participants don't get the opportunity to have an input on the design of the course. The new model shifts the emphasis from the assumed interests of the group to the specific needs of the individual.

Being locked into a structured curriculum may suit some, but, for others, it may not necessarily deliver what they need. In a world of rapid change, managers need to be flexible, yet the traditional-style MBA reinforces old patterns of behaviour. New model programmes mirror what's happening in the changing corporate environment. They offer more scope to build on existing expertise and concentrate on managers' business priorities.

Providers can actually allow participants to design their own MBA - by helping them determine what and how they will learn, in the context of their own needs. All of this raises an issue for providers. They need to be rigorous in their selection to ensure that applicants are comfortable with the self-managed concept and, equally, they need to be able to support that approach.

This demands a change in the delivery of MBAs. On traditional MBA programmes, the primary means of disseminating knowledge is through a faculty of academic staff and a network of visiting contributors. Without the restrictions of a conventional faculty, new model programmes have greater freedom to draw from wider sources. As well as input from practitioners, they can also utilise seminars, books, company visits and other sources of learning.

Another difference is the role of the academic staff themselves. New model programmes place far greater emphasis on skills such as facilitation to help participants manage their own learning. The very foundation of new model programmes should be that learning is delivered and assessed in a way that is closely linked to the business environment.

"Differentiate or die" has long been a rallying cry on many traditional MBAs. Now, providers must learn that lesson. The fight is on for providers to offer students an MBA relevant to their organisation, to their day-to-day work and to their future development - one that incorporates sound theory which they can use in practice.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: In retrospect, London Zoo was the perfect venue. Zoos today exist largely because of their role in conserving diversity - and here were 70 or 80 people busily beavering away to create yet more diversity. But the business people present were worried. At   a time when they are increasingly bombarded with new management standards, and middle managers are already punch-drunk with new initiatives, this event was designed to boost diversity not by rescuing endangered species but by adding yet another standard to the already squirming heap.
fields.body:
In retrospect, London Zoo was the perfect venue. Zoos today exist largely because of their role in conserving diversity - and here were 70 or 80 people busily beavering away to create yet more diversity. But the business people present were worried. At a time when they are increasingly bombarded with new management standards, and middle managers are already punch-drunk with new initiatives, this event was designed to boost diversity not by rescuing endangered species but by adding yet another standard to the already squirming heap.

You can probably tell I am not a management standards fetishist. Of course, no one depending on consumer safety and quality standards would deny they have helped improve our quality of life. Where would we be without the MSDOS embedded in our computers? And who would argue against performance standards for public service providers, such as railway companies, even if they seem unable to meet them? But I am surely not the only one worried that management standards can encourage a "tick box" mentality, rather than encouraging people to think outside the box.

The number of boxes to be ticked has exploded. In the field of sustainable development, business faces an avalanche of new standards. They cover everything from employee rights and environmental management systems through to corporate sustainability, reporting and stakeholder engagement. AA 1000, EMAS, FSC, GRI, IiP, ISO 14000, MSC, SA 8000, TNS are acronyms for just some of the new standards. And all this in the wake of research showing that the end results of applying mainstream stan dards, have often been disappointing.

Given my aversion to standard-setting processes, it is ironic that I get involved in so many. The ones I can remember are an attempt to evolve the European Commission's environmental management and audit standard (Emas) into a sustainability management standard; the early testing of the British Standard Institution BS 7750 standard; the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI); AccountAbility 1000 (AA 1000); and the mother of all sustainability standards, the Sigma Project.

Odd, yes, but standard- setting is where the sustainability community has been investing a growing proportion of its resources in recent years. And some of the most useful outcomes flow from standard-setting processes rather than standards themselves. The need to debate what a standard is for and how it should be applied and verified spurs engagement between a wide range of business, government, NGO and other stakeholders.

All of which suggests that the Sigma Project (www.bsi-global.com/sigma) is in with a chance. The project, led by BSI, Forum for the Future and the Institute for Social and Ethical Accountability (Isea), is also backed by the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions and the Department of Trade and Industry. It is designed to be the world's first triple bottom line management standard, embracing the economic, social and environmental aspects of an organisation's performance.

Business people fear another layer of bureaucracy. But business must increasingly manage and account for financial, human, manufactured, natural and social forms of capital. The $64,000 question is: can Sigma break out of the zoo, driving convergence among competing standards? If the answer is yes, or even maybe, some of those punch-drunk middle managers might even be persuaded to sign on.

 John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (www.sustainability.co.uk) and co-author of The Global Reporters.

webTitle: Learning to cater for a variety of tastes

fields.headline: Learning to cater for a variety of tastes
fields.trailText: After 10 years with Bass Hotels & Resorts, Sue Wilkinson, 35, is newly appointed director of sales for Crowne Plaza London, responsible for the entire sales, marketing and advertising operation of the 203-bedroom hotel due to open next summer.
fields.body:
After 10 years with Bass Hotels & Resorts, Sue Wilkinson, 35, is newly appointed director of sales for Crowne Plaza London, responsible for the entire sales, marketing and advertising operation of the 203-bedroom hotel due to open next summer.

She decided in secondary school that she wanted a career in a service industry. After O Levels she did a two-year Higher National Diploma in hotel management at Guildford College of Technology, before joining Crest Hotels as a reception cashier in London on £4,000 a year, a position that would now pay £10,000-£12,000 a year. "Rather than join a management trainee programme I decided to go straight into a position and work my way up," she says.

Her next move, aged 21, was to Consort Hotels, now Best Western, as sales executive for the London market, on a salary of £16,000 plus a car. She stayed for three years and became regional sales manager.

She then joined the Royal Garden Hotel, in London's Kensington, as senior sales executive, staying for two years. Then came a move to Bass Hotels & Resorts, giving her the chance to develop her career in one major international organisation. She has taken on a variety of sales-related roles where salaries are in the £35,000-£50,000 range, culminating in her chance to be involved in the opening of a major new hotel.

Paul Madden, 26, the food and beverage manager at the Cumberland Hotel in London, acquired the taste for the business early in life; his father was a hotelier in Ireland. He did a four-year hotel degree course at the Shannon College of Hotel Management, which included a management training placement in his final year with Forte at the Cumberland.

"I joined as a student on £10,500 a year as Christmas coordinator, which meant coordinating all the festive functions involving £1.5m worth of sales during December," he says. He was promoted to back-of-house manager, in charge of all the behind-the-scenes aspects of food and beverage and, on graduating, was taken on permanently as assistant food and beverage operations manager. Since then, he has swiftly risen through the ranks to end up as food & beverage manager for the 904-bedroom hotel.

"The food and beverage department generates approximately £9m revenue per annum and I manage a team of 200 people," he says. He is reluctant to reveal his current salary. "It depends how good you are. If you are good you can demand a good salary, as in any other industry. Salaries can rise dramatically as you progress up the career ladder.

"You don't need a degree so much as a desire to get on," he says. "On the fast-track programme here at the Cumberland it's possible to go from being a waiter to food & beverage manager within five years." So, on a career path he sees as offering, "fantastic opportunities to develop and travel the world", what's the downside? "I wouldn't work in it if there were a downside," he says.

fields.headline: Garden? It's  really a farm
fields.standfirst: Having a bigger garden than the Inland Revenue deems reasonable could result in an unpleasant surprise when moving home, writes Richard Colbey.
fields.trailText: Having a bigger garden than the Inland Revenue deems reasonable could result in an unpleasant surprise when moving home,  writes Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
When Dr Geoffrey Longson got divorced in 1995 his house at Velstead Farm, near Fleet in Hampshire, along with seven and a half hectares and some stables, was sold for some £2.75 million.

The buyer intended to develop most of the transferred land. Dr Longson had never farmed the land, using it instead to keep his family's horses on, and considered that it was all really part of his home in the way most people regard their back garden.

The property had gone up in value dramatically while the Longson family were living there. This was, perhaps, fortunate, as his children had developed a taste for expensive equestrian hobbies. His daughter took part in three-day eventing at a high level and his son had become an accomplished polo player.

Dr Longson had hoped to avoid paying capital gains tax on the basis that the land, as well as his house, was his main residence, and therefore exempt from that tax. The local tax inspector disagreed. He claimed that Dr Longson did not require seven hectares for the reasonable enjoyment of his property.

Only half a hectare automatically qualifies for exemption from tax. The nature of this property meant that it would be reasonable to increase the exempt area to just over an acre. The fact that Dr Longson required the land for his horses was a sep arate consideration that did not entitle him to tax relief. He did not have to keep horses there to enjoy the property.

Although Dr Longson appealed against the decision, the High Court, in a decision that will send shivers down the spines of many owners of large homes, last month ordered him to pay £560,000 capital gains tax.

The Revenue's own guidelines suggest that the exemption will still be allowed in respect of anything that is what it describes as "naturally and traditionally" the garden of the house. The use of land for commercial purposes such as market gardening or commercial stabling would take it outside this definition.

Previously, in grey areas such as this, both the Revenue and the courts have tended to be generous to taxpayers. In a 1990 decision, involving Lady Beryl Rook, the Court of Appeal upheld the long-standing principle, which may shortly be reconsidered, that a staff cottage in the grounds of a larger home was usually part of the main home.

Interestingly, although Lady Rook was selling more than four hectares of land along with her house and cottage, the Revenue at that time did not then seek to argue that it was outside the exemption.

The relatively hard line that has been taken in Dr Longson's case may be symptomatic of the Revenue's intention to take a closer look at transactions involving homes of the wealthy in future.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister
