fields.headline: Lenders given human rights
fields.standfirst: When the Human Rights Act came into force in October, no one could have believed its first beneficiaries would be loan companies, writes Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: When the Human Rights Act came into force in October, no one could have believed its first beneficiaries would be loan companies,  writes Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
However, in a provisional ruling the Court of Appeal has indicated that the Consumer Credit Act, which protects consumers against dubious money lenders, may deprive such businesses of their "human" rights.

A Mrs Wilson borrowed £5,000 from First County Trust (FCT), which took a charge over her BMW to secure the loan. It added £250 to the loan as a "document fee". Not, perhaps unreasonably, FCT described the total amount of the loan as £5,250.

Mrs Wilson found it hard to repay the instalments. She visited solicitors who told her the rate of interest charged was so high that a court might reduce it. They also advised that describing the loan as £5,250, rather than £5,000, was incorrect. The £250 was a charge for credit, not credit it self. So strict is the Consumer Credit Act that even a technical error like that can make a loan unenforceable.

The county court judge agreed that a lower interest should be set, but rejected the argument that it was completely unenforceable. Mrs Wilson repaid the amount the judge considered a reasonable rate of interest to remove the charge over the car.

However, she appealed, contending she should not have been required to pay anything. The Court of Appeal decided her lawyers had got it right. They considered a ruling earlier this year where it had been decided that many "credit hire" agreements were unenforceable. These involved companies which hired cars to people whose own cars had been damaged in accidents. Payments would only be required after the other driver was found liable, and their insurance company agreed to pick up the tab. This, the Court of Appeal ruled, offended against the Consumer Credit Act, as the company was effectively lending the cash equivalent of the hire charge until liability was sorted out, without complying with the legal formalities.

However, in Mrs Wilson's case, English law, which had seemingly been settled in her favour by the credit hire case, might not be the end of the matter. It had probably not occurred to FCT that Article One of the Protocol to the Human Rights Convention, which provides "No one shall be deprived of his possessions except in the public interest and subject to the conditions implied by law", could help.

The judge of the Court of Appeal raised the matter, thus turning a routine appeal into a case with huge implications.

On the face of it, FCT was entitled to either Mrs Wilson's car or the money she had agreed to pay back. Ruling that the company could have neither could be said to be depriving it of its possessions.

The courts have to give the government an opportunity to be represented before ruling an act of parliament invalid, and therefore the Court of Appeal has adjourned the case to hear arguments from the Attorney General.

Reluctant though many may be to sympathise with the consumer credit industry, it has to be accepted that the Consumer Credit Act does go "over the top" on occasion.

The sort of error FCT made did not really prejudice Mrs Wilson. At most, FCT could have fairly been deprived of the £250 it had added to the loan, rather than the entire sum. The real unfairness was the interest FCT charged.

A new Citizens Advice Bureaux report highlights rip-off rates charged, particularly to poorer borrowers.

If the technical provisions of the Consumer Credit Act are disallowed by the Court of Appeal, there may be a corresponding growth in courts' willingness to tackle the more serious abuses.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

It had probably not occurred to FCT that Article One of the Protocol to the Human Rights Convention, which provides "No one shall be deprived of his possessions except in the public interest and subject to the conditions implied by law", could help. The judge of the Court of Appeal raised the matter, thus turning a routine appeal into a case with huge implications. On the face of it, FCT was entitled to either Mrs Wilson's car or the money she had agreed to pay back. Ruling that the company could have neither could be said to be depriving it of its possessions. The courts have to give the government an opportunity to be represented before ruling an act of parliament invalid, and therefore the Court of Appeal has adjourned the case to hear arguments from the Attorney General. Reluctant though many may be to sympathise with the consumer credit industry, it has to be accepted that the Consumer Credit Act does go "over the top" on occasion. The sort of error FCT made did not really prejudice Mrs Wilson. At most, FCT could have fairly been deprived of the £250 it had added to the loan, rather than the entire sum. The real unfairness was the interest FCT charged. A new Citizens Advice Bureaux report highlights rip-off rates charged, particularly to poorer borrowers. If the technical provisions of the Consumer Credit Act are disallowed by the Court of Appeal, there may be a corresponding growth in courts' willingness to tackle the more serious abuses.  Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Judges reserve judgment in Hamilton appeal

fields.headline: Judges reserve judgment in Hamilton appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hamilton v Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton, the disgraced former MP, may have to wait until the new year to discover whether he has been successful in his appeal
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton, the disgraced former MP, may have to wait until the new year to discover whether he has been successful in his appeal against the verdict in his failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed, after three appeal court judges including Lord Phillips, the Master of the Rolls, reserved judgment yesterday.

Mr Hamilton is appealing against the verdict of a libel jury last year that found him to be corrupt.

Mr Hamilton brought the action against Mr Fayed after he claimed, in a Channel 4 Dispatches programme screened in January 1997, that Mr Hamilton had demanded and accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods.

Judgment could be delivered as early as next week, but is more likely to be next month.

During the five-day hearing at the royal courts of justice in London, Mr Hamilton accused Mr Fayed of paying £10,000 for legal documents allegedly stolen from the rubbish bins of Mr Hamilton's lawyers.

The documents, including cross-examination notes, were used to coach witnesses called by Mr Fayed, the court was told.

The documents were said to have been stolen by Benjamin Pell, known as Benjy the Binman, who has in the past sold documents taken from rubbish bins to national newspapers.

Yesterday Mr Hamilton's counsel, Anthony Boswood QC, told the judges: "This was an act of gross misconduct and a serious abuse of process."

He maintained that the fairness of the trial had been fundamentally undermined and it was likely the jury would have reached a different conclusion.

He also said it was "not possible" that the trial judge would have ignored the allegations had they been made at the time and would certainly have changed his summing up.

Mr Fayed's counsel, Michael Beloff QC, dismissed Mr Hamilton's case as "so flimsy" that it did not require factual rebuttal. He submitted that even if the appeal judges were to find that the trial judge and the jury were misled, the most Mr Hamilton would be entitled to was a retrial.

Mr Beloff said the documents were in the dustbins because they lacked "the sensitivity or confidentiality which made it necessary for them to be shredded".

"This was a race that was truly won without the benefit of artificial aids and the verdict should stand in Mr Fayed's favour," he said.

Mr Boswood said during the hearings that Mr Pell claimed that David Leigh, a Guardian journalist, had suggested he get documents from dustbins for Mr Fayed.

No evidence was heard from Mr Pell, and the court was subsequently told by Mr Beloff that Mr Leigh had written to Mr Hamilton's lawyers denying the allegation.

webTitle: Wet spell - Magician caught by new floods

fields.headline: Wet spell - Magician caught by new floods
fields.standfirst:
Weeks of rain have forced undertakers to postpone funerals until the new year in Surrey and parts of London, writes Martin Wainwright.

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Weeks of rain have forced undertakers to postpone funerals until the new year in Surrey and parts of London, writes Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
Ground checks in graveyards showed that pumping would be needed to stop graves filling with water as soon as they were dug.

The river Severn yesterday topped the high water levels reached in October as the number of severe flood warnings fell from 15 to 11 nationally. Seven of the warnings were on the Severn.

Clearer weather came too late to save hundreds of homes and businesses in Worcester, Tewkesbury and Gloucester.

Seepage through waterlogged banking added to the effects of the Severn breaching defences in about six areas, but the en vironment agency said that levels were falling in the river's headwaters.

The Thames was last night the subject of new flood alerts, with a severe warning imposed at Maidenhead and 17 houses evacuated in Oxford. The agency said that high water levels were making their way downstream and would peak in Berkshire overnight.

The magician Paul Daniels and his wife, Debbie McGee, had to use a boat to reach shops from their flooded home at Wargrave near Henley.

webTitle: 'Unique' verdict on death of conjoined twin

fields.headline: 'Unique' verdict on death of conjoined twin
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The coroner conducting the inquest into the death of the conjoined twin Mary yesterday took the unusual step of recording a verdict which simply described the circumstances of her death.
fields.body:
The coroner conducting the inquest into the death of the conjoined twin Mary yesterday took the unusual step of recording a verdict which simply described the circumstances of her death.

Leonard Gorodkin said the usual verdicts of accident, misadventure, unlawful or lawful killing did not fit the circumstances of Mary's death during an operation to separate her from her twin, Jodie.

He said it would be wrong to return an open verdict because he knew exactly the circumstances which had led to Mary's death.

She had died within minutes of separation during a 20-hour operation at Manchester Royal Infirmary on November 6. The twins' parents, strict Roman Catholics, from Gozo, off Malta, had opposed the operation, but the high court and court of appeal had ruled it was lawful, since without a separation, both twins would have died.

After hearing two hours of evidence from a consultant paediatrician and a paediatric pathologist at Manchester coroner's court, Mr Gorodkin ruled simply: "Mary died following surgery separating her from her conjoined twin, which surgery was permitted by an order of the high court, confirmed by the court of appeal."

Mr Gorodkin said the case had been unique to the court of appeal. He said: "It is as unique for me as a coroner as it was for the judges. I don't believe any coroner has had to consider a death from surgery when it was known beforehand the patient was going to die. All surgery carries with it a mortality rate but in the case of Mary that was a 100% rate."

He said he might have considered a verdict of lawful killing, but "the purpose and the reason for the separation was not to kill Mary even though her death arose from it".

He said a verdict of unlawful killing was not applicable, "although some people emotionally believe that Mary was murdered, of course that is not the case".

Adrian Bianchi, a paediatric consultant who helped perform the separation, told the hearing that Mary had had no chance of survival without her twin. He said: "The only reason she was able to survive was because she was linked to her sister, who acted as a life support machine."

Mr Bianchi said reports from a child psychologist showed Jodie was now a "bright, alert and interested child" functioning at a level normal for a 4- to five-month-old baby, and was therefore advanced beyond her age.

Anna Kelsey, a paediatric pathologist, told the inquest that Mary's heart had almost filled her chest and weighed 72g when the normal weight was 23g for a baby of that age. She said Mary's lungs were "miniature" versions of the norm, weighing only 7.2grams, compared to an average baby's 65grams. Mary had died from cardiac and respiratory complications.

After the verdict, Mr Gorodkin said that when Mary died, he had let the twins' parents, Michaelangelo and Rina Attard, keep her with them for a day. "That showed how much the parents felt for the deceased baby," he said.

Mr Gorodkin said the parents must have been "horrified" at the discussions on whether the babies should be seen as two separate people. "For them, they clearly had two daughters whom they loved equally."

John Kitchingman, the parents' solicitor, said the couple accepted the coroner's verdict.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Debt campaign targets 'robbers'
fields.body:
Debt campaign targets 'robbers'

The average person owes £3,425 in unsecured debt. But many individual households top the £20,000 mark. And the deeper a family is in debt, the more likely it is to suffer from ultra-high interest rates.

Now the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux has started a campaign for effective regulation of extortionate credit.

Daylight Robbery, published this week, details the lack of interest rate ceilings and the weakness of the Consumer Credit Act in helping victims of ripoff rates. The courts have only tackled a handful of cases since 1974, while having to find a £120 court fee when a borrower tries to reopen a credit agreement is a major disincentive.

And Nacab believes many credit-worthy people pay higher rates than they need. It says: "Many borrowers are introduced to the high rate loan as an adjunct to a major purchase." It cites kitchen companies, double glazing firms and car sales outfits as sources of "oppressive loans". One victim who had cash to pay for work done was ordered to take out a loan as it was "company policy".

Help for elderly with tax returns

Charity Help the Aged is offering guidance to elderly people who received a tax return but have yet to complete it. It reminds elderly tax payers that after the Christmas break there is less than a month before the taxman expects the completed return on January 31, 2001.

A qualified specialist will complete each tax return to Inland Revenue standards and send it back within 28 days for a flat fee of just £75. The return is also verified by a second tax expert. Further information about Help the Aged Tax Services, tel; 020-7474-3310.

Halifax and police fight for net safety

Halifax, which was the UK's first bank to provide its online customers with free anti-virus software, is now supporting a police initiative to provide consumers with a survival guide to online financial transactions.

The guide, available from January, is issued in conjunction with West Yorkshire Police. Around 150,000 copies will be distributed free across Yorkshire, Humberside and North Lincolnshire.

Included in the new booklet, which will be particularly useful for people who get PCs for Christmas, is information on how customers can protect themselves from fraud, hints and tips on what to look for before undertaking a transaction on the internet plus a helpful glossary of commonly used internet terms.

The bank also offers its online customers free anti-virus software for their home PC, which can be downloaded from its website (www.halifax-online.co.uk). The software, provided by Trend Micro, will detect and eliminate any existing known viruses which may be present in the customer's PC

Ski the web for best insurance

Winter sports enthusiasts can save more than 75% over package deal insurance prices by skiing the net. Thomson Holidays quoted £86 for a woman and her school-age daughter; www travelplan-direct.co.uk came up with £21 for the two.

And £9 on top of the Thomson price would have paid for the £95 annual cover for two including 17 days' life on the piste with Leeds & Holbeck: 0870-602-4816.

Elsewhere Holiday Which? is offering independent legal advice service for aggrieved travellers through Virgin Travelstore. It has produced a database of around 145 common problems arising from holidays; consumers can search for a solution for their specific complaint.

AIG on track for extra accuracy

AIG Life has added three trackers to its range, covering the Eurostoxx 50, the US S & P 500 and Japan's Nikkei 225.

The funds, constructed from a mix of futures and cash, claim to track more accurately than rivals. They are available for pension and life assurance plans.

webTitle: Weekend: Civil rights heroine Claudette Colvin

fields.headline: She would not be moved
fields.standfirst: Rosa Parks is a heroine to the US civil rights movement. Yet months before her arrest on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, a 15-year-old girl was charged with the same 'crime'. Why has Claudette Colvin been denied her place in history? Gary Younge investigates
fields.trailText: Rosa Parks is a heroine to the US civil rights movement. Yet months before her arrest on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, a 15-year-old girl was charged with the same 'crime'. Why has Claudette Colvin been denied her place in history? Gary Younge investigates.
fields.body:
This much we know. On Thursday, December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks, a 42-year-old black seamstress, boarded a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, after a hard day's work, took a seat and headed for home. The bus went three stops before several white passengers got on. The driver, James Blake, turned around and ordered the black passengers to go to the back of the bus, so that the whites could take their places. "Move y'all, I want those two seats," he yelled.

The bus froze. Blake persisted. "Y'all better make it light on yourselves and let me have those seats," he said.

The three black passengers sitting alongside Parks rose reluctantly. Parks stayed put. Blake approached her. "Are you going to stand up?" he asked.

"No," said Parks.

"Well, I'm going to have you arrested," he replied.

"You may do that," said Parks, who is now 87 and lives in Detroit.

It was an exchange later credited with changing the racial landscape of America. Parks's arrest sparked a chain reaction that started the bus boycott that launched the civil rights movement that transformed the apartheid of America's southern states from a local idiosyncrasy to an international scandal. It was her individual courage that triggered the collective display of defiance that turned a previously unknown 26-year-old preacher, Martin Luther King, into a household name.

It was a journey not only into history but also mythology. "She was a victim of both the forces of history and the forces of destiny," said King, in a quote now displayed in the civil rights museum in Atlanta. "She had been tracked down by the zeitgeist - the spirit of the times." And, from there, the short distance to sanctity: they called her "Saint Rosa", "an angel walking", "a heaven-sent messenger". "She gave me the feeling that I was the Moses that God had sent to Pharaoh," said Fred Gray, the lawyer who went on to represent her.

But somewhere en route they mislaid the truth. Rosa Parks was neither a victim nor a saint, but a long-standing political activist and feminist. Moreover, she was not the first person to take a stand by keeping her seat and challenging the system. Nine months before Parks's arrest, a 15-year-old girl, Claudette Colvin, was thrown off a bus in the same town and in almost identical circumstances.

Like Parks, she, too, pleaded not guilty to breaking the law. And, like Parks, the local black establishment started to rally support nationwide for her cause. But, unlike Parks, Colvin never made it into the civil rights hall of fame. Just as her case was beginning to catch the nation's imagination, she became pregnant. To the exclusively male and predominantly middle-class, church-dominated, local black leadership in Montgomery, she was a fallen woman. She fell out of history altogether.

King Hill, Montgomery, is the sepia South. In this small, elevated patch of town, black people sit out on wooden porches and watch an impoverished world go by. Broken-down cars sit outside tumble-down houses. The pace of life is so slow and the mood so mellow that local residents look as if they have been wading through molasses in a half-hearted attempt to catch up with the past 50 years.

"Middle-class blacks looked down on King Hill," says Colvin today. "We had unpaved streets and outside toilets. We used to have a lot of juke joints up there, and maybe men would drink too much and get into a fight. It wasn't a bad area, but it had a reputation." It is here, at 658 Dixie Drive, that Colvin, 61, was raised by a great aunt, who was a maid, and great uncle, who was a "yard boy", whom she grew up calling her parents.

Today, she sits in a diner in the Bronx, her pudding-basin haircut framing a soft face with a distant smile. Her voice is soft and high, almost shrill. The urban bustle surrounding her could not seem further away from King Hill. She now works as a nurses' aide at an old people's home in downtown Manhattan. She turns, watches, wipes, feeds and washes the elderly patients and offers them a gentle, consoling word when they become disoriented.

"I make up stories to convince them to stay in bed." Her rhythm is simple and lifestyle frugal. She works the night shift and sleeps "when the sleep falls on her" during the day. She shops with her workmates and watches action movies on video. Until recently, none of her workmates knew anything of her pioneering role in the civil rights movement.

But go to King Hill and mention her name, and the first thing they will tell you is that she was the first. They remember her as a confident, studious, young girl with a streak that was rebellious without being boisterous. "She was a bookworm," says Gloria Hardin, who went to school with Colvin and who still lives in King Hill. "Always studying and using long words."

"She was an A student, quiet, well-mannered, neat, clean, intelligent, pretty, and deeply religious," writes Jo Ann Robinson in her authoritative book, The Montgomery Bus Boycott And The Women Who Started It.

Colvin was also very dark-skinned, which put her at the bottom of the social pile within the black community - in the pigmentocracy of the South at the time, and even today, while whites discriminated against blacks on grounds of skin colour, the black community discriminated against each other in terms of skin shade. The lighter you were, it was generally thought, the better; the closer your skin tone was to caramel, the closer you were perceived to be to whatever power structure prevailed, and the more likely you were to attract suspicion from those of a darker hue.

From "high-yellas" to "coal-coloureds", it is a tension steeped not only in language but in the arts, from Harlem Renaissance novelist Nella Larsen's book, Passing, to Spike Lee's film, School Daze. "The light-skinned girls always thought they were better looking," says Colvin. "So did the teachers, too. That meant most of the dark complexion ones didn't like themselves."

Not so Colvin. They had threatened to throw her out of the Booker T Washington school for wearing her hair in plaits. As well as the predictable teenage fantasy of "marrying a baseball player", she also had strong political convictions. When Ms Nesbitt, her 10th grade teacher, asked the class to write down what they wanted to be, she unfolded a piece of paper with Colvin's handwriting on it that said: "President of the United States."

"I wanted to go north and liberate my people," explains Colvin. "They did think I was nutty and crazy."

One incident in particular preoccupied her at the time - the plight of her schoolmate, Jeremiah Reeves. Reeves was a teenage grocery delivery boy who was found having sex with a white woman. The woman alleged rape; Reeves insisted it was consensual. Either way, he had violated the South's deeply ingrained taboo on interracial sex - Alabama only voted to legalise interracial marriage last month (the state held a referendum at the same time as the ballot for the US presidency), and then only by a 60-40 majority. "When I was in the ninth grade, all the police cars came to get Jeremiah," says Colvin. "They put him on death row." Four years later, they executed him.

It was this dark, clever, angry young woman who boarded the Highland Avenue bus on Friday, March 2, 1955, opposite Martin Luther King's church on Dexter Avenue, Montgomery. Colvin took her seat near the emergency door next to one black girl; two others sat across the aisle from her. The law at the time designated seats for black passengers at the back and for whites at the front, but left the middle as a murky no man's land. Black people were allowed to occupy those seats so long as white people didn't need them. If one white person wanted to sit down there, then all the black people on that row were supposed to get up and either stand or move further to the back.

As more white passengers got on, the driver asked black people to give up their seats. The three other girls got up; Colvin stayed put. "If it had been for an old lady, I would have got up, but it wasn't. I was sitting on the last seat that they said you could sit in. I didn't get up, because I didn't feel like I was breaking the law."

To complicate matters, a pregnant black woman, Mrs Hamilton, got on and sat next to Colvin. The driver caught a glimpse of them through his mirror. "He asked us both to get up. [Mrs Hamilton] said she was not going to get up and that she had paid her fare and that she didn't feel like standing," recalls Colvin. "So I told him I was not going to get up, either. So he said, 'If you are not going to get up, I will get a policeman.'"

The atmosphere on the bus became very tense. "We just sat there and waited for it all to happen," says Gloria Hardin, who was on the bus, too. "We didn't know what was going to happen, but we knew something would happen."

Almost 50 years on, Colvin still talks about the incident with a mixture of shock and indignation - as though she still cannot believe that this could have happened to her. She says she expected some abuse from the driver, but nothing more. "I thought he would stop and shout and then drive on. That's what they usually did."

But while the driver went to get a policeman, it was the white students who started to make noise. "You got to get up," they shouted. "She ain't got to do nothing but stay black and die," retorted a black passenger.

The policeman arrived, displaying two of the characteristics for which white Southern men had become renowned: gentility and racism. He could not bring himself to chide Mrs Hamilton in her condition, but he could not allow her to stay where she was and flout the law as he understood it, either. So he turned on the black men sitting behind her. "If any of you are not gentlemen enough to give a lady a seat, you should be put in jail yourself," he said.

A sanitation worker, Mr Harris, got up, gave her his seat and got off the bus. That left Colvin. "Aren't you going to get up?" asked the policeman.

"No," said Colvin.

He asked again.

"No, sir," she said.

"Oh God," wailed one black woman at the back. One white woman defended Colvin to the police; another said that, if she got away with this, "they will take over".

"I will take you off," said the policeman, then he kicked her. Two more kicks soon followed.

I was very hurt, because I didn't know that white people would act like that and I ... I was crying," she says. The policeman grabbed her and took her to a patrolman's car in which his colleagues were waiting. "What's going on with these niggers?" asked one. Another cracked a joke about her bra size.

"I was really afraid, because you just didn't know what white people might do at that time," says Colvin. In August that year, a 14-year-old boy called Emmet Till had said, "Bye, baby", to a woman at a store in nearby Mississippi, and was fished out of the nearby Tallahatchie river a few days later, dead with a bullet in his skull, his eye gouged out and one side of his forehead crushed. They took her to City Hall, where she was charged with misconduct, resisting arrest and violating the city segregation laws. The full enormity of what she had done was only just beginning to dawn on her. "I went bipolar. I knew what was happening, but I just kept trying to shut it out."

She concentrated her mind on things she had been learning at school. "I recited Edgar Allan Poe, Annabel Lee, the characters in Midsummer Night's Dream, the Lord's Prayer and the 23rd Psalm." Anything to detach herself from the horror of reality. Her pastor was called and came to pick her up. By the time she got home, her parents already knew. Everybody knew.

Clubs called special meetings and discussed the event with some degree of alarm. Mothers expressed concern about permitting their children on the buses. Men instructed their wives to walk or to share rides in neighbour's autos."

It was going to be a long night on Dixie Drive. "Nobody slept at home because we thought there would be some retaliation," says Colvin. An ad hoc committee headed by the most prominent local black activist, ED Nixon, was set up to discuss the possibility of making Colvin's arrest a test case. They sent a delegation to see the commissioner, and after a few meetings they appeared to have reached an understanding that the harassment would stop and that Colvin would be allowed to clear her name.

When the trial was held, Colvin pleaded innocent but was found guilty and released on indefinite probation in her parents' care. "She had remained calm all during the days of her waiting period and during the trial," wrote Robinson. "But when she was found guilty, her agonised sobs penetrated the atmosphere of the courthouse."

Nonetheless, the shock waves of her defiance had reverberated throughout Montgomery and beyond. Letters of support came from as far afield as Oregon and California. She still has one - a handwritten note from William Harris in Sacramento. It reads: "The wonderful thing which you have just done makes me feel like a craven coward. How encouraging it would be if more adults had your courage, self-respect and integrity. Respectfully and faithfully yours."

But even as she inspired awe throughout the country, elders within Montgomery's black community began to doubt her suitability as a standard-bearer of the movement. "I told Mrs Parks, as I had told other leaders in Montgomery, that I thought the Claudette Colvin arrest was a good test case to end segregation on the buses," says Fred Gray, Parks's lawyer. "However, the black leadership in Montgomery at the time thought that we should wait."

Some in Montgomery, particularly in King Hill, think the decision was informed by snobbery. "It was partly because of her colour and because she was from the working poor," says Gwen Patton, who has been involved in civil rights work in Montgomery since the early 60s. "She lived in a little shack. It was a case of 'bourgey' blacks looking down on the working-class blacks."

"They never thought much of us, so there was no way they were going to run with us," says Hardin. Others say it is because she was a foul-mouthed tearaway. "It bothered some that there was an unruly, tomboy quality to Colvin, including a propensity for curse words and immature outbursts," writes Douglas Brinkly, who recently completed a biography of Parks. But people in King Hill do not remember Colvin as that type of girl, and the accusation irritates Colvin to this day. "I never swore when I was young," she says. "Never."

Everyone, including Colvin, agreed that it was news of her pregnancy that ultimately persuaded the local black hierarchy to abandon her as a cause célèbre. For Colvin, the entire episode was traumatic: "Nowadays, you'd call it statutory rape, but back then it was just the kind of thing that happened," she says, describing the conditions under which she conceived. She refused to name the father or have anything to do with him. "When I told my mother I was pregnant, I thought she was going to have a heart attack. If I had told my father who did it, he would have killed him."

A personal tragedy for her was seen as a political liability by the town's civil rights leaders. In his Pulitzer prize-winning account of the civil rights years, Parting The Waters, Taylor Branch wrote: "Even if Montgomery Negroes were willing to rally behind an unwed, pregnant teenager - which they were not - her circumstances would make her an extremely vulnerable standard bearer."

"If the white press got ahold of that information, they would have [had] a field day," said Rosa Parks. "They'd call her a bad girl, and her case wouldn't have a chance."

Montgomery's black establishment leaders decided they would have to wait for the right person. And that person, it transpired, would be Rosa Parks. "Mrs Parks was a married woman," said ED Nixon. "She was morally clean, and she had a fairly good academic training ... If there was ever a person we would've been able to [use to] break the situation that existed on the Montgomery city line, Rosa L Parks was the woman to use ... I probably would've examined a dozen more before I got there if Rosa Parks hadn't come along before I found the right one."

'Facts speak only when the historian calls on them," wrote the historian EH Carr in his landmark work, What Is History? "It is he who decides which facts to give the floor and in what order or context. It is the historian who has decided for his own reasons that Caesar's crossing of that petty stream, the Rubicon, is a fact of history, whereas the crossing of the Rubicon by millions of other people before or since interests nobody at all."

Montgomery was not home to the first bus boycott any more than Colvin was the first person to challenge segregation. Two years earlier, in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, African-Americans launched an effective bus boycott after drivers refused to honour an integrated seating policy, which was settled in an unsatisfactory fudge. And, like the pregnant Mrs Hamilton, many African-Americans refused to tolerate the indignity of the South's racist laws in silence.

Nor was Colvin the last to be passed over. In the nine months between her arrest and that of Parks, another young black woman, Mary Louise Smith, suffered a similar fate. Smith was arrested in October 1955, but was also not considered an appropriate candidate for a broader campaign - ED Nixon claimed that her father was a drunkard; Smith insists he was teetotal.

But there were two things about Colvin's stand on that March day that made it significant. First, it came less than a year after the US supreme court had outlawed the "separate but equal" policy that had provided the legal basis for racial segregation - what had been custom and practice in the South for generations was now against federal law and could be challenged in the courts.

Second, she was the first person, in Montgomery at least, to take up the challenge. Most Americans, even in Montgomery, have never heard of her. She has literally become a footnote in history.

For we like our history neat - an easy-to-follow, self-contained narrative with dates, characters and landmarks with which we can weave together otherwise unrelated events into one apparently seamless length of fabric held together by sequence and consequence. Complexity, with all its nuances and shaded realities, is a messy business. So we choose the facts to fit the narrative we want to hear.

While this does not happen by conspiracy, it is often facilitated by collusion. In this respect, the civil rights movement in Montgomery moved fast. Rosa Parks was thrown off the bus on a Thursday; by Friday, activists were distributing leaflets that highlighted her arrest as one of many, including those of Colvin and Mary Louise Smith: "Another Negro woman has been arrested and thrown in jail because she refused to get up out of her seat on the bus for a white person to sit down," they read. "It is the second time since the Claudette Colvin case that a Negro woman has been arrested for the same thing."

By Monday, the day the boycott began, Colvin had already been airbrushed from the official version of events. Meanwhile, Parks had been transformed from a politically-conscious activist to an upstanding, unfortunate Everywoman. But Colvin was not the only casualty of this distortion. Parks was, too. Her casting as the prim, ageing, guileless seamstress with her hair in a bun who just happened to be in the wrong place at the right time denied her track record of militancy and feminism. She appreciated, but never embraced, King's strategy of nonviolent resistance, remains a keen supporter of Malcolm X and was constantly frustrated by sexism in the movement. "I had almost a life history of being rebellious against being mistreated against my colour," she said.

But the very spirit and independence of mind that had inspired Parks to challenge segregation started to pose a threat to Montgomery's black male hierarchy, which had started to believe, and then resent, their own spin. Nixon referred to her as a "lovely, stupid woman"; ministers would greet her at church functions, with irony, "Well, if it isn't the superstar." Reverend Ralph Abernathy, who played a key role as King's right-hand man throughout the civil rights years, referred to her as a "tool" of the movement.

Those who are aware of these distortions in the civil rights story are few. Betty Shabbaz, the widow of Malcolm X, was one of them. In a letter published shortly before Shabbaz's death, she wrote to Parks with both praise and perspective: "'Standing up' was not even being the first to protest that indignity. Fifteen-year-old Claudette Colvin was the first to be arrested in protest of bus segregation in Montgomery.

"When ED Nixon and the Women's Political Council of Montgomery recognised that you could be that hero, you met the challenge and changed our lives forever. It was not your tired feet, but your strength of character and resolve that inspired us." It is a letter Colvin knew nothing about.

Colvin is not exactly bitter. But, as she recalls her teenage years after the arrest and the pregnancy, she hovers between resentment, sadness and bewilderment at the way she was treated. "They just dropped me. None of them spoke to me; they didn't see if I was okay. They never came and discussed it with my parents. They just didn't want to know me."

She believes that, if her pregnancy had been the only issue, they would have found a way to overcome it. "It would have been different if I hadn't been pregnant, but if I had lived in a different place or been light-skinned, it would have made a difference, too. They would have come and seen my parents and found me someone to marry."

When the boycott was over and the African-American community had emerged victorious, King, Nixon and Parks appeared for the cameras. "It's interesting that Claudette Colvin was not in the group, and rarely, if ever, rode a bus again in Montgomery," wrote Frank Sikora, an Alabama-based academic and author. After her arrest and late appearance in the court hearing, she was more or less forgotten. Later, she would tell a reporter that she would sometimes attend the rallies at the churches. "I would sit in the back and no one would even know I was there."

The upshot was that Colvin was left in an incredibly vulnerable position. A poor, single, pregnant, black, teenage mother who had both taken on the white establishment and fallen foul of the black one. It is this that incenses Patton. "I respect my elders, but I don't respect what they did to Colvin," she says. "For a while, there was a real distance between me and Mrs Parks over this. Colvin was a kid. She needed support."

If that were not enough, the son, Raymond, to whom she would give birth in December, emerged light-skinned: "He came out looking kind of yellow, and then I was ostracised because I wouldn't say who the father was and they thought it was a white man. He wasn't." She became quiet and withdrawn. "I wasn't with it at all. All I could do is cry."

She would not be moved (continued)

Blake approached her. "Are you going to stand up?" he asked. "No," said Parks. "Well, I'm going to have you arrested," he replied. "You may do that," said Parks, who is now 87 and lives in Detroit. Parks's arrest sparked a chain reaction that started the bus boycott that launched the civil rights movement that transformed the apartheid of America's southern states from a local idiosyncrasy to an international scandal. It was her individual courage that triggered the collective display of defiance that turned a previously unknown 26-year-old preacher, Martin Luther King, into a household name. It was a journey not only into history but also mythology. "She was a victim of both the forces of history and the forces of destiny," said King, in a quote now displayed in the civil rights museum in Atlanta. "She had been tracked down by the zeitgeist - the spirit of the times." And, from there, the short distance to sanctity: they called her "Saint Rosa", "an angel walking", "a heaven-sent messenger". "She gave me the feeling that I was the Moses that God had sent to Pharaoh," said Fred Gray, the lawyer who went on to represent her. But somewhere en route they mislaid the truth. Rosa Parks was neither a victim nor a saint, but a long-standing political activist and feminist. Moreover, she was not the first person to take a stand by keeping her seat and challenging the system. Nine months before Parks's arrest, a 15-year-old girl, Claudette Colvin, was thrown off a bus in the same town and in almost identical circumstances. Like Parks, she, too, pleaded not guilty to breaking the law. And, like Parks, the local black establishment started to rally support nationwide for her cause. Broken-down cars sit outside tumble-down houses. Though he didn't say it, nobody was going to say that about the then heavily pregnant Colvin. But Colvin was not the only casualty of this distortion. Parks was, too. Her casting as the prim, ageing, guileless seamstress with her hair in a bun who just happened to be in the wrong place at the right time denied her track record of militancy and feminism. She appreciated, but never embraced, King's strategy of nonviolent resistance, remains a keen supporter of Malcolm X and was constantly frustrated by sexism in the movement. "I had almost a life history of being rebellious against being mistreated against my colour," she said. But the very spirit and independence of mind that had inspired Parks to challenge segregation started to pose a threat to Montgomery's black male hierarchy, which had started to believe, and then resent, their own spin. Nixon referred to her as a "lovely, stupid woman"; ministers would greet her at church functions, with irony, "Well, if it isn't the superstar." Reverend Ralph Abernathy, who played a key role as King's right-hand man throughout the civil rights years, referred to her as a "tool" of the movement. Those who are aware of these distortions in the civil rights story are few. Betty Shabbaz, the widow of Malcolm X, was one of them. In a letter published shortly before Shabbaz's death, she wrote to Parks with both praise and perspective: "'Standing up' was not even being the first to protest that indignity. Fifteen-year-old Claudette Colvin was the first to be arrested in protest of bus segregation in Montgomery. "When ED Nixon and the Women's Political Council of Montgomery recognised that you could be that hero, you met the challenge and changed our lives forever. It was not your tired feet, but your strength of character and resolve that inspired us." It is a letter Colvin knew nothing about. Colvin is not exactly bitter. But, as she recalls her teenage years after the arrest and the pregnancy, she hovers between resentment, sadness and bewilderment at the way she was treated. "They just dropped me. None of them spoke to me; they didn't see if I was okay. They never came and discussed it with my parents. They just didn't want to know me." She believes that, if her pregnancy had been the only issue, they would have found a way to overcome it. "It would have been different if I hadn't been pregnant, but if I had lived in a different place or been light-skinned, it would have made a difference, too. They would have come and seen my parents and found me someone to marry." When the boycott was over and the African-American community had emerged victorious, King, Nixon and Parks appeared for the cameras. "It's interesting that Claudette Colvin was not in the group, and rarely, if ever, rode a bus again in Montgomery," wrote Frank Sikora, an Alabama-based academic and author. After her arrest and late appearance in the court hearing, she was more or less forgotten. Later, she would tell a reporter that she would sometimes attend the rallies at the churches. "I would sit in the back and no one would even know I was there." The upshot was that Colvin was left in an incredibly vulnerable position. A poor, single, pregnant, black, teenage mother who had both taken on the white establishment and fallen foul of the black one. It is this that incenses Patton. "I respect my elders, but I don't respect what they did to Colvin," she says. "For a while, there was a real distance between me and Mrs Parks over this. Colvin was a kid. She needed support." If that were not enough, the son, Raymond, to whom she would give birth in December, emerged light-skinned: "He came out looking kind of yellow, and then I was ostracised because I wouldn't say who the father was and they thought it was a white man. He wasn't." She became quiet and withdrawn. "I wasn't with it at all. All I could do is cry." She would not be moved (continued)

fields.headline: An irregular guy
fields.standfirst: Behind the all-American looks of furniture designer Harry Allen there lurks an experimental spirit. As he gets ready to launch a new collection in the UK, Peter Hall looks for surprises in his giant New York apartment
fields.trailText: Behind the all-American looks of furniture designer Harry Allen there lurks an experimental spirit. As he gets ready to launch a new collection in the UK, Peter Hall looks for surprises in his giant New York apartment
fields.body:
Just a few minutes with the garrulous Harry Allen in his capacious, light-flooded Manhattan apartment, and you begin to get the picture. Along walls the length of the building, prototypes of Allen's furniture designs are mingled with various mid-century classics and yard sale knock-offs of mid-century classics. With theatrical cynicism ("I'm schizoid about showing my apartment") and several digressions (his noisy former neighbours, his Europhile tendencies, his engineer father), Allen gives an entertaining guided tour of his work.

The centrepiece of the main room is a 14ft-long table, constructed in situ from an environmentally-friendly grade of plywood, created from compressed, glued chips of young trees. It's so strong, says Allen, that "you can walk on it".

A box-like, plywood chair with a seat resembling the surface of a waffle is work in progress, called Grid Chair - no relation to Grid Table, part of his first collection in 1993 and the forerunner of a new table he has designed for Habitat.

Since this first show, he quickly built a reputation as an experimentalist and now, aged 36, Allen is enjoying a taste of international success. His interiors work, which started with the hugely popular gallery-like design store Moss in 1993, is now spawning commissions from Japanese retailers and New York restaurants.

He has a ceramic foam light in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art (Moma), in New York. He recently received (along with Sir Terence Conran) a major design award from the Brooklyn Museum Of Art. And he is designing table-top products for Wireworks in London, lighting for George Kovacs in New York, and furniture for Habitat.

Tom Dixon, director of design at Habitat, is an admirer: "I think he's got something of that American aesthetic. He is fascinated with materials and likes the way they go together, and he's an intelligent guy who thinks things through."

In many ways, the emergence of Allen and his Modernist-minded peers marks a return to form for US design. The history of postwar American furniture went something like this: in the 40s and 50s, Charles and Ray Eames discovered moulded plywood and set out "to get the most of the best to the greatest number of people from the least", making simple, elegant, functional pieces. With the likes of George Nelson and Herman Miller, their playful utilitarianism found full-throated voice in plastics, wood and steel furniture.

Everything went along swimmingly until the early 80s, when postmodern designers such as Robert Venturi and Michael Graves began slapping Art Deco references on to furniture and turning out cartoon-like laminated chairs and kettles with birds on top. Suddenly, high design was mired in gaudy colours, high-lacquered finishes and faux-historical, cartoony references.

Allen studied industrial design at New York's Pratt Institute, becoming part of a generation of designers dubbed the "New Functionalists". Their work followed the same structurally derived clean lines of Nelson and the Eameses, and was similarly multi-functional and modular.

Allen first caught the attention of the public in 1993 with a free-standing storage system comprising an aluminum frame that could be fitted with drawers, shelves and storage cubes. He called it Living System. For Allen, it wasn't difficult to stand out: "Everything was horn shaped, because Philippe Starck was such a stud at the time."

A year later, Allen added a Living Lighting series, which emerged out of his discovery of ceramic foam at a friend's factory. To make ceramic foam, polyester is fired so that each strand becomes a hollow tube. Allen had a set of blocks made from it, which he illuminated from beneath with light bulbs. The idea caught the attention of Moma, which asked Allen to create a set for its 1995 exhibition, Mutant Materials In Contemporary Design.

Fearing that the humble, glowing blocks were a little too prosaic for the lofty museum, Allen redesigned the lights with supporting white towers to elevate the blocks. "I jooshed them up for Moma," he admits. "Now I look at the originals and I think they're better than the tower ones. They're fresher and less designed in a way."

This aptitude for self-criticism, coupled with a knack for self-promotion, has undoubtedly helped Allen charm some useful clients and propel his work forward. Like his contemporaries, he prizes freshness and irregularity over Machine Age perfection. He calls it "non-design": the spontaneous, unplanned aspects of a product that is turned out before the traditional revising, refining and polishing stage. His lamp collection, for example, includes a bare light bulb stuffed inside a crude transparent block of silicone rubber.

The tour ends in Allen's studio on the ground floor of his building, where a handful of designers sit at computers. At the centre is another table, square-shaped, with a grid surface. It is an early version of a project for Habitat, originally intended to complement the Living Systems unit (along with a metal-framed upholstered Chuck chair that folds out into a couch and a bed). The table surface is made up of nine laminated squares that can be replaced with other squares incorporating baskets, holes for glasses or, perhaps, fish bowls. Habitat plans to bring out a smaller version next year.

Ironically, it is UK companies such as Habitat and Wireworks that are most receptive to Allen's progressive designs. Tom Dixon, who is building up quite a roster of young, disaffected overseas designers, sums it up: "I do think there is a faintly American style that is all about the love of industry and generous proportions and high-quality materials, which Harry is tapping into. The sad thing is that American industry doesn't see fit to back these people."

 Harry Allen's work is featured in the new book, Contemporary American Furniture, by Marisa Bartolucci and Cathy Lang Ho (Laurence King, £25). To order a copy for £20 (plus 99p p&p), freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: Brief encounter
fields.standfirst: Living in a rented house is no excuse for letting the outdoors go to ruin. Christopher Lloyd suggests beautiful plants that bring quick results - and are easy to take with you when you move
fields.trailText: Living in a rented house is no excuse for letting the outdoors go to ruin. Christopher Lloyd suggests beautiful plants that bring quick results - and are easy to take with you when you move.
fields.body:
Moving into temporary accommodation is a common situation, but it does not, given the right property, preclude gardening. I have friends who do not as yet have sufficient funds to take out a mortgage. One of them is so passionate about gardening, however, that they have deliberately rented a semi-detached with a reasonably sized piece of garden, pending the time - perhaps in two or three years - when they can buy their own place.

Obviously, in these circumstances, you don't want to spend a great deal on input. Before taking on the lease, get the owners' permission to make any changes that you deem essential: will it, for instance, be permissible to straighten the edges of a horribly wiggly border? And what about a tree that makes everything parched and barren underneath - should the incomers take it upon themselves to remove it, always supposing there's no preservation order attached to the aforementioned roots? It may well be that the landlords dislike it themselves and would be only too glad to see it go without having to take on the responsibility.

You may want to create more or larger borders. Ensure they are within the sight lines that will be most used; from the kitchen or the living-room windows, for instance. Vegetables can be grown out of sight and at a greater distance, although a few herbs such as parsley, sorrel, chives, thyme and winter savoury, need to be within an easy distance so you can dart out in foul weather and pick them quickly.

Pots are a good idea, especially for succulents such as crassulas, echeverias, aloes, agaves and cacti which can get along without being watered for long spells. They can line the front path and be clustered either side of the front door. Being in pots, their position can be changed - and they can, of course, be packed away when you move.

Some will need housing in winter. Install a lean-to greenhouse against the garage; in fact, the garage itself may better lend itself to overwintering plants than as a shelter for the car, which won't suffer from frost. One has to get one's priorities right. Many evergreens need little or no light in winter if temperatures remain low. Some risks should be taken; the greenhouse effect should be taken advantage of, supposing it has reality in fact.

Your soil is sure to need improving, so find sources for bulky organic matter that will lastingly improve it in terms of both water-holding and texture, thereby providing plant roots with a congenial medium. Moss peat is entirely useless for this purpose, but it may have a role in your potting composts. Your flower and vegetable beds may also be thick with perennial weeds, and getting rid of them is quite a long-term business - not really worthwhile if you will only be there for a short time, although I should not rule out spot-treatments with glysophate, such as Roundup. Dandelions respond quickly and completely to its use.

You will want to grow plenty of annuals, biennials and quickly developing perennials. Some shrubs will be worth starting, with a view to transferring them in a couple of years or so to your new garden. Hydrangeas, for example, will move well, and will not be missed by whoever moves in after you.

Remember that you are not allowed to remove large and long-established trees or shrubs, but you can start to collect a range of plants that will be useful to you in your permanent garden. Direct sowing of annuals where they are to flower may sound an easy option, but the seedlings will run up against serious competition from weed seeds that germinate at the same time and have greater vigour. For this reason it is sometimes recommended that direct sowings should be in rows, allowing for easier weeding. But even when the rows run in different directions, they will always, in my experience, look like rows, which is not aesthetically pleasing.

It is generally far more satisfactory to sow in pots or modules, to thin out the seedlings or prick them out into seed trays or plugs or pots, and to plant them into newly cleaned ground when large enough to cope. They must, of course, be hardened off. This way they have a head start over any weed seedlings that subsequently appear, and it will be easy to see which are the plants you want and which are the weeds.

It will not be worth planting long-term shrubs that take years to settle down before making any significant contribution - eucryphias, for instance, or most magnolias. Neither, for similar reasons, would you plant a yew hedge. But don't be anti-social and plant a Leyland cypress hedge either, as its vigour will give a great deal of trouble in future years. Fencing may be the most satisfactory solution for making temporary divisions - it is amazing what glamorous results can be achieved in just a few months.

To many previously frustrated gardeners, even a temporary garden works as a lifeline. Naturally you'll have the usual moans - slugs, the neighbours' cats, the weather. That is inevitable when you are dealing with living things. We don't generally hear so much about the rewards, but they are very real.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort is something of a traditionalist where Italian food is concerned. Or at least, he was - until he went for lunch at Ibla
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort is something of a traditionalist where Italian food is concerned. Or at least, he was - until he went for lunch at Ibla
fields.body:
We can all make mistakes. I just seem to make more than my fair share of them. I made one with the wine. "Idem" said the wine list, and indicated that it was a blend of grapes used for Fiano di Avellino and Greco di Tufo. I have encountered these wines before, and found them austere, rather uncompromising fluids that cut across food with crisp authority - but what was this? A liquor that looked like a distillation of daffodils, soft and honeyed to the sniff, and smooth over the tongue, just this side of sweetness and with only a hint of the hoped for acidity to cut across a line-up that included warm octopus salad, tuna tartare, tagliatelle with duck sauce and pecorino, deep-fried fish Piedmontese-style with red cabbage and lemon sauce, and slow-cooked veal cheek in red wine with fennel and polenta. I apologised to Amaryllis, who was rather gracious about it.

We were lunching at Ibla, one of those new-wave Italian restaurants that had been quietly garnering a good deal of unqualified approval from various distinguished quarters. In spite of the rather infra dig roadworks outside the front door, its house style sits happily with the street chic of Marylebone High Street - sort of distinctive but unshowy, smart but casual. There's the Shaker shop up the road, with the Orrery restaurant above the Conran shop further up, and other smartieboots places tlike that to go shopping in beforehand. The rich, ox-blood-red walls and ceiling and the natural (ie unbleached) wooden floor of Ibla's back dining room combined to produce a warm, designer, womb effect.

Ibla is new-fashioned rather than trad Italian - it's neither trad London, with that oleaginous charm, giant pepper grinder and indifferent food, nor trad Roman or Bolognese, say, with their straightforward dishes prepared from great ingredients to time-honoured recipes. No, Ibla is in a new mould, which seems to have been specifically developed for the markets of London, New York and Michelin and which specialises in a sort of Frenchified Italian cooking, complete with French-style sauces and composed dishes that come complete with veg. If I am totally honest, I have to admit that I am not always in favour of this new style - every time I visit Italy, I am reminded of the excellence of simplicity, and that everything there is always based on the supreme quality of local ingredients - but I would hate to say that my mind is closed on the matter. I am a reasonable man. I am open to persuasion - and the food at Ibla is pretty persuasive at that.

The French influence was represented in the main by Amaryllis's fish dishes. The tuna tartare is straight out of the French modern haute cuisine handbook, although at Ibla it is cut in larger chunks than is usual, which means you get more of the texture of the tuna. The fish was topped with a poached quail's egg, which added a certain unctuous, sticky lubrication to the tumulus of tuna, and matched with juvenile veg.

The frittura mista di pesce e cavalo rosso in salsa di lemone was a pretty sophisticated take on fried goujons. As an item on the set- price lunch menu, it was generous to the point of extravagance, with large and small chunks of fish in a thistledown-light batter. The red cabbage was an interesting addition, cooked to within a millimetre of losing its crunch, with its natural, earthy sweetness making a rather interesting foil to the rest.

The octopus in my warm salad with cherry tomatoes and crispy aubergine was irreproachable, positive without being chewy and fresh enough to hold its delicate and all too fugitive flavour. But what was lollo rosso doing in the salad? God, I hate the stuff - it's like eating a ballerina's tutu. And the aubergine crisps had more or less lost their crispness.

The tagliatelle, on the other hand, was a perfectly splendid dish - deep-yellow pasta with small nuggets of muskily sweet duck given bounce by the salty punch of pecorino. My guanciale di vitello brasato con finocchio e polenta was even better. The meat gave out a kind of deep bass boom as it fell to bits between teeth and tongue. The juices of cheek and wine had been rendered to mellow harmony through long cooking, with the fennel bringing in a gently vegetable note. Only the hump of stodgy polenta seemed lumpenly at odds with this soul-comforting dish.

And all the while Amaryllis drank the Idem without a word of complaint. Maybe she has a saintly good nature. Maybe she even liked the stuff. It was, in fact, a fine wine and, oddly enough, didn't go badly with both the tagliatelle and veal cheek. I suspect that it went rather less well with the fish, but there you go.

And there we went, passing on pudding (perhaps not surprisingly), for £81.50 - which, on a food to non-food ratio of £44:£37.50, seems to me to be pretty good value for money given the range and quality of what we ate. If you forget for a moment that it is Italian, and just concentrate on flavours, skill, pleasure, style and stuff like that, then Ibla is pretty near top-drawer material, make no mistake

If I am totally honest, I have to admit that I am not always in favour of this new style - every time I visit Italy, I am reminded of the excellence of simplicity, and that everything there is always based on the supreme quality of local ingredients - but I would hate to say that my mind is closed on the matter. I am a reasonable man. I am open to persuasion - and the food at Ibla is pretty persuasive at that. The French influence was represented in the main by Amaryllis's fish dishes. The tuna tartare is straight out of the French modern haute cuisine handbook, although at Ibla it is cut in larger chunks than is usual, which means you get more of the texture of the tuna. The fish was topped with a poached quail's egg, which added a certain unctuous, sticky lubrication to the tumulus of tuna, and matched with juvenile veg. The frittura mista di pesce e cavalo rosso in salsa di lemone was a pretty sophisticated take on fried goujons. As an item on the set- price lunch menu, it was generous to the point of extravagance, with large and small chunks of fish in a thistledown-light batter. The red cabbage was an interesting addition, cooked to within a millimetre of losing its crunch, with its natural, earthy sweetness making a rather interesting foil to the rest. The octopus in my warm salad with cherry tomatoes and crispy aubergine was irreproachable, positive without being chewy and fresh enough to hold its delicate and all too fugitive flavour. But what was lollo rosso doing in the salad? God, I hate the stuff - it's like eating a ballerina's tutu. And the aubergine crisps had more or less lost their crispness. The tagliatelle, on the other hand, was a perfectly splendid dish - deep-yellow pasta with small nuggets of muskily sweet duck given bounce by the salty punch of pecorino. My guanciale di vitello brasato con finocchio e polenta was even better. The meat gave out a kind of deep bass boom as it fell to bits between teeth and tongue. The juices of cheek and wine had been rendered to mellow harmony through long cooking, with the fennel bringing in a gently vegetable note. Only the hump of stodgy polenta seemed lumpenly at odds with this soul-comforting dish. And all the while Amaryllis drank the Idem without a word of complaint. Maybe she has a saintly good nature. Maybe she even liked the stuff. It was, in fact, a fine wine and, oddly enough, didn't go badly with both the tagliatelle and veal cheek. I suspect that it went rather less well with the fish, but there you go. And there we went, passing on pudding (perhaps not surprisingly), for £81.50 - which, on a food to non-food ratio of £44:£37.50, seems to me to be pretty good value for money given the range and quality of what we ate. If you forget for a moment that it is Italian, and just concentrate on flavours, skill, pleasure, style and stuff like that, then Ibla is pretty near top-drawer material, make no mistake

webTitle: The knowledge: light my fire -  chestnuts

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Light my fire: chestnuts
fields.trailText: Light my fire: chestnuts
fields.body:
The subject They that roast on an open fire while Jack Frost's nipping at the air - and that brutalise the fingertips of any poor sod who gets the job of preparing them. Plus, on the sly, a brace of whizzo Christmas book recommendations.

The basics Chestnuts are funny old nuts (well, they're seeds, actually, of the Castanea sativa tree, which is native to Asia Minor.) While most nuts ooze oil (more than 50% calories), chestnuts are mainly carbohydrate. This explains their unique and varied cooking properties. (Bet you didn't know that the original polenta was made from chestnuts.) Our supplies usually begin their lives in Italy, France or Spain. Nomenclature: thick outer layer is husk, thin inner layer is skin.

The details Chestnuts should be hard, and heavy for their size; choose them individually. To do almost like the song says - that is, roast them on an open fire - buy a perforated roasting pan (around £20). To prepare for stuffing etc, here's the least painful procedure I know, from Christmas tip number one, The Cook's Encyclopaedia, by Tom Stobart (Grub Street, £20). First, cut a slit in the husk, then bake, boil or microwave until you can remove the husks easily. After husking, put the nuts in cold water with a little oil. Bring to the boil, then simmer. Within a few minutes, the skins will start coming off. Take out a few at a time (they're hot, sorry!) and rub between tea-towels to complete the flaying. Now you're set, and not solely for stuffing - think soups, purées, marrons glacés, braises, or the awesome chestnut sauce in Christmas prezzie two, Elizabeth David's Is There A Nutmeg In The House? (Michael Joseph, £20).

Where to buy Can't miss 'em.

The easy way out Heh, heh: your family peels, you provide plasters. Or buy Merchant Gourmet Chestnuts, £1.99/200g, from Sainsbury's, Tesco, Waitrose and Somerfield. Expensive, but your fingertips will love you.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Double Maxim
fields.trailText: Double Maxim
fields.body:
Double Maxim, a strong brown ale from the north-east, has been reborn - the beer disappeared in 1999 when the Vaux Brewery in Sunderland shut down, but two former Vaux executives, Doug Trotman and Mark Anderson, have relaunched it, and it is now brewed by Frederic Robinson of Stockport.

Maxim was first launched in 1901 to celebrate the return of Captain Ernest Vaux from the Boer war, in which he led a raid with a Maxim machine gun. Its strength was reduced after landlords began complaining that customers were falling asleep, but in 1938 it was raised again, to 4.7%, and renamed Double Maxim. It soon became a cult on Wearside, rivalling Newcastle Brown Ale.

Double Maxim is more characterful than Newcastle Brown, however, having a complex aroma and palate, with earthy, spicy hops and tart fruit with hints of caramel. The finish is bitter-sweet, with a good balance of fruit, malt and hops, and ending dry and bitter. It's available from Safeway for around £1.49 a bottle (further details available from Double Maxim.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya asks some pretty searching questions
fields.body:
There's always a time when we have to ask ourselves fundamental questions: Who am I? What am I here for? What's the meaning of life?

As you know, I've found the internet very helpful in my progress through this eventful year, but not always. Particularly not during the past few weeks. If I watched the news and saw Bush, Gore, Blair or Hague, my instinctive cry was, 'Oh, God!' The invocation would come to my lips as soon as I opened my credit-card statements,or put the phone down after speaking to my mother. I repeated it obsessively when I read Migraine Alan's letter last Tuesday: he said he's always known he was a lesbian, so has found a surgeon who specialises in sex changes through http://home.ici.net/~robbyn/Indigo/Sc, and suggested that we get in touch after he's had the operation.

Eventually, I realised that this constant invocation had to be a message from my inner self. Thanks to www.carmelite.org.uk/life.html, I discovered my true vocation, and I have decided to become a Carmelite nun. As explained on the site, I will be consecrated to God by Solemn Vows, and I'll promise to live, in the company of other sisters, a life that is poor, chaste, obedient and wholly dedicated to prayer in the service of the church.

Solitude and silence are essential to my new life, so this is my farewell to Guardian readers and surfers of the web who have been kind enough to read my botched accounts of a complicated modern life, or visit my website. Perhaps we'll meet again somewhere over the rainbow, as Mum's favourite song suggests, or wherever the ideal place is. Love to you all.
