webTitle: What to eat on Christmas Eve?

fields.headline: Scale models
fields.standfirst: We have no national fish dish, with the notable exception of the deep-fried affair with chips
fields.trailText: We have no national fish dish, with the notable exception of the deep-fried affair with chips,  says  chef Jeremy Lee
fields.body:
Why do we all rush through the weeks before Christmas, preparing like mad for the Big Day, and give so little thought to its Eve? While the great part of Europe, all the way from Scandinavia to Greece, celebrates Christmas Eve with rituals ranging from ancient and simple to elaborate and sumptuous, we Brits tend to ignore it altogether. We may, of course, be tired of the whole ghastly ritual by then, anyway; or perhaps it has something to do with old legends of witchcraft, of spirits being appeased and put to rest through revels, and of shaman-like rituals to banish evil beasties.

The great festive jollities of Europe are many, but my gut feeling is that such traditions do not travel well, and are therefore best enjoyed on their own turf. There is, however, no reason whatsoever to miss out on all of the fun - and as a great deal of that fun revolves around food, then setting forth a fine supper of fish on Christmas Eve seems eminently sensible rather than radical or revolutionary.

Indeed, traditionally, the meal before mass on Christmas Day has meat proscribed, which has given the devout on Christmas Eve a leaning towards a light meal - and that usually, although not necessarily, has consisted of fish.

It's a fine notion, to my mind, and it seems such a pity that we British have never developed a festive fish dish of our own - come to that, we have no national fish dish of any kind, with the notable exception of the deep-fried affair with chips. Even that former magnifico of the Christmas sideboard, smoked salmon, which was for so long a Yuletide staple because it is expensive and easy to serve, has become largely debased in recent years, and is now more the preserve of the hopelessly naff.

But I must stop: a harangue is really not what is required here. The point is to spread the great affair that is Christmas over a few days, not cram it all into a single, gut-busting meal. All that effort for just one day seems plain silly when diet and dignity are far better served by spreading it out over a longer period. It also expands the time available for pleasure - and there is no need to mention the digestive benefits of eating thus.

So, I can think of no better way to set such a remarkable change in our national habits in train than by serving up a great dish of fish cooked in a pie or a chowder or a stew on Christmas Eve.

All recipes serve six.

Fish Stew
Use as many or as few varieties of fish and shellfish as you want. Flatfish such as halibut, plaice and brill are particularly good cooked this way. I advocate making a simple stock in which the fish is later cooked on the bone.

For the stock

4 medium leeks

5 medium onions

3 small carrots

4 sticks celery

1 bulb fennel (if available)

1 whole bulb garlic

1 bayleaf

1 small sprig thyme

12 black peppercorns

bottle good white wine

Generous pinch saffron

For the stew

1.2kg white fish, on the bone

300g mussels, scraped and bearded

200-250g prawns in their shell

1 live crab (optional)

175ml double cream

1 handful flat-leaf parsley, chopped

Place the mussels in a colander and rinse under the cold tap for a half-hour. Meanwhile, place a large, heavy pot on the stove. Scrub clean all the vegetables, then cut into thumb-sized pieces and put in the pot, along with all the other stock ingredients except the saffron. Add a litre of water, bring to a gentle simmer and cook for 30 minutes.

Warm a large, handsome dish in the oven. Strain the stock through a sieve into another pot, saving the garlic but discarding all the other ingredients. With the back of a spoon, push the garlic through the sieve and into the strained liquid. Stir and return to the heat. Bring to the boil, add the saffron and simmer for five minutes.

Cut the larger pieces of fish into manageable pieces. If a crab is to figure, kill it just before plunging it into the broth. To do this, flip the crab over on its back, pull back the exposed flap and insert a spike, driving it home with a bold thrust, thereby executing instant death. Remove the claws from the crab and quarter the carapace. Drop into the stock, along with the larger fish. Add the rest of the fish according to size, so that all are cooked at the same time - the mussels and prawns will need to go in last of all. If necessary, transfer any cooked fish to the pre-heated dish. Once all the fish is done, place it in the dish.

Pour the cream into the stock, simmer for a minute or so, add salt and pepper as required, and stir in the parsley. Pour over the cooked fish, and serve with new potatoes or crusty bread.

Chowder
It is a puzzle why Britain has no national fish soup or stew, surrounded as we are by water populated with the finest fish and shellfish in the world. Chowders are splendid, cheap, easy and open to a great many variations, so it is similarly puzzling as to why their appearance is so rare.

300g large waxy potatoes

2 small onions

50g unsalted butter

160g coley or pollack fillet, cut into pieces

1 handful each mussels and clams (optional)

30g good streaky bacon, salt pork or pancetta

350ml milk

120ml double cream

1 bayleaf

1 handful flat-leaf parsley, chopped

Peel the potatoes and cut them into 1cm cubes. Chop the onion and bacon into small pieces. In a large pot, melt the butter, and fry the bacon and onion until the onion has softened and coloured lightly.

If using mussels and/or clams, add them to the pot now, along with a splash of water, and cover to steam the shellfish until they are all opened (discard any that do not do so). Tip the shellfish, onion and bacon into a colander over a bowl, to collect the juices, and return the empty pot to the stove.

Rinse the cut potato of any excess starch, and add to the pot, along with the milk and any liquor from the shellfish. Add the bayleaf and a little pepper, and simmer until the potato is cooked. Return the bacon, onion and shellfish to the pot, along with the fish, and simmer for 10 minutes, until the fish is just cooked. Stir in the cream and parsley, and season. The chowder looks its best when served in a tureen.

Fish Pie
Unlauded fish are great in a dish such as this. There are a few stages to this recipe, but the result is worth the effort.

2 large potatoes

1 small head celeriac

1kg mussels, scraped and bearded

1kg pollack or coley fillet

1 small onion

1 clove garlic

1 bayleaf

25g unsalted butter

1 glass white wine

1 litre milk

1 dssp Dijon mustard

1 handful flat-leaf parsley, chopped

lemon, juiced

Salt and pepper

For the crust

2 large potatoes

2 large handfuls fresh breadcrumbs

25g freshly grated Parmesan

25g unsalted butter

Scrub all the potatoes, place them in a pot of lightly salted water, and bring to the boil. Peel the celeriac and cut into pieces. Place the mussels in a colander and rinse under running cold water for half an hour. Remove any skin and bones from the fish and cut the flesh into chunks.

Pre-heat the oven to 190C/375F/ gas mark 5. Heat a large pot, and in it fry the onion and garlic in butter, along with the bayleaf. Tip in the mussels and wine, cover and steam gently until all the shells are opened (discard any that do not open). Strain through a colander held over a bowl. Return the pot to the stove, add the celeriac and milk, and simmer gently, stirring from time to time to prevent sticking, until the celeriac is cooked through. Drain and peel the potatoes, add half to the celeriac mixture and purée. Shell the mussels, discarding the shells. Keep the cooked onion.

Carefully pour the mussel liquor into the purée, leaving any grit behind. Stir in the mustard, parsley, cooked onion, mussels, seasoning and lemon juice. Put the fish in a handsome ovenproof dish and pour over the sauce. Break up the remaining potatoes into small pieces. Lay these over the top of the fish, then liberally strew with breadcrumbs. Melt the butter and pour over the crust and top with the Parmesan. Bake for 30-40 minutes until well coloured and crisp, with the fish just cooked through.

Brandade
There is many a brandade made with mashed potato - I suspect this is merely to bulk out the simple dish. This version omits the spud.

1.5kg dried salt cod

1 small sprig thyme

1 bayleaf

2 cloves garlic

1 lemon

200ml double cream

300ml good olive oil

Black pepper

It is essential that the cod be soaked for at least 24 hours and that the water be changed at least three times. Once the excess salt has been removed, place the fish in a pot along with the thyme and bayleaf. Cover with cold water, bring to a boil, then turn off the heat and leave the fish to cook within the liquor.

Peel the garlic, flatten with a knife, chop very fine and place in a bowl. When the fish is cool enough to handle, remove any skin and bones, and add to the garlic bowl. Beat the fish and garlic together, then slowly add the oil. Next, slowly add the cream, until the mixture is a thick paste. Add lemon juice to taste, along with lots of pepper, then heat gently over a low flame.

This is best spread on thinly sliced bread that has been dotted with olive oil and baked golden in the oven.

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Satan's Christmas tree
fields.standfirst: Harriet has inherited Gordon's ability to sulk. Now I get it in wraparound stereo
fields.trailText: Harriet has inherited Gordon's ability to sulk. Now I get it in wraparound stereo.
fields.body:
Ex-Spouse is sulking. He discovered that his Aunt Elspeth had given me £50,000. Conveniently forgetting my lurid fantasies about a hammock in Bali, I inform him that it's just a bit of money-laundering to thwart the government. Should Elspeth eventually need a nursing home, she wants one on the NHS. She still has a touching faith in the social ideals of 1947, when literacy, train travel, rural post offices and skylarks were so widely available as to be a nuisance, and when beef tea was a nourishing food for invalids, not a form of euthanasia.

"The thing is," I informed him, "if the money's not in her account, they can't sting her for it, can they?"

"But why wasn't I consulted?"

"Because Elspeth didn't want Elaine getting her hands on it, that's why! She's bled you white as it is. Look at you!" Ex-Spouse turned appropriately pale at the mention of his peccadillo. Although peccadillo seems rather a tame term for a full-blooded wife and kid on the warpath. Armadillo, perhaps. Anyway, he stalked off and has sulked ever since. Though sulking is so akin to his regular demeanour that nobody has really noticed.

"Mum? Can I be in charge of the Christmas decorations?" Harriet is developing an interest in decor beyond her own face. She's my only hope of help at the moment. Henry has acquired a posh girlfriend called Claudia who is taking him off skiing for Christmas - a thought that fills me with terror.

Agree readily to Harriet's decorating initiative. Next, aunt wants me to take her to the bank. I escort her everywhere now. It's a precaution. "I've just rrrealised they'rrre charrrging me £1.50 every time I use an alien cashpoint! I'm going to give that gairrrl a piece of my mind!" Poor aunt. Her mind is increasingly fractured these days. So is mine. I must get some of that stuff that improves the memory. I forget what it's called.

Perform minor banking ritual myself, and observe how chilly the clerks have become, now that I have £50,000 in my account. (Well, £49,340 and sinking, actually - you know how it is.) I bet they'd be all over me if I was Anne Robinson. Strange about Anne Robinson. She is increasingly acquiring the status of the Angel of Death.

Return home to find Harriet has decorated the tree in the front garden with fluorescent skulls, rubber tarantulas and plastic eyeballs complete with conjunctivitis. "Harriet! It's supposed to be Jesus' birthday, not Satan's!" I hiss, hurrying aunt up the path. Harriet is influenced at the moment by Marilyn Manson, the death-obsessed Gothic songster. His idea of decor is skeletons, skulls and taxidermy, but Harriet assures me that he's a thoroughly bloody nice bloke.

"Take that skull off the tree - it's like voodoo!" I insist none the less. Harriet stomps off scowling. She's inherited Gordon's ability to sulk. Now I can experience it in wraparound stereo.

While I am putting on the kettle, he comes in looking ominous. "As I seem not to be wanted in this family," he announces, "I thought I'd just let you know that I intend to find myself a bedsit after Christmas."

Stifling the impulse to say "Why wait until then?", I seize him briskly by the doleful, Eeyore-like cardigan. "Don't be so bloody silly!" I snap. "Not wanted, indeed! However could I manage Harriet without you? Don't you realise? We all love you to bits, you dummy!" Then, acting on some crisis-managing impulse, I embrace him energetically, rather in the manner that Al Gore once kissed his wife: not for pleasure, but out of necessity. Ex-Spouse, rather frighteningly, reciprocates and clings to me like a drowning man. Feel intense pang of something, probably a mixture of pity and terror. "We'll go out for a meal together tomorrow," I promise, "and talk over this money business and get it sorted."

I cannot help noticing that he still smells like the man I married, and it touches me, somehow. Is there going to be a miracle for Christmas? Despite the awful mess we've made of it, with him going off and marrying Elaine and having another kid, and then being chucked out - despite all the water that's gone under and, indeed, over the bridge - are we going to fall in love all over again?

I bloody well hope not.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: Choose a video
fields.trailText: Choose a video
fields.body:
More relationships go wrong in video shops than anywhere else on the planet. That's because there's only one video in the whole shop that you both want to see, and that one's out.

Women like videos whose title can best be summed up as The Bride's Having A Baby. These are only ever picked by men in a desperate attempt to escape from some deep trouble. In a typical woman's film, nothing happens from beginning to end, except for a huge amount of talking and sobbing. Men, on the other hand, like to watch action thrillers that combine cars, weapons and explosions. Dialogue will be limited to, 'Get that weapon out of the car before it blows up!' Men will pick anything that has an exploding fireball on the cover. This is a visual guarantee for men of a total absence of women bonding over a quilt. Sadly, these covers make it almost impossible to persuade women that the film is in reality a romantic comedy starring Julia Roberts.

There are, of course, other types of videos in the shop - the rude ones on the top shelf, which feature so many nurses that it's no wonder there's a shortage in the NHS; the art film with subtitles, which guarantees you three things: lots of interesting camera angles, a depressing ending in winter with piano music, and more sordid sex scenes than in the top-shelf ones. Then there are the specialist children's videos - or pacifiers, as they are called. These feature horrific scenes of violence and interspecies relationships that have somehow slipped past the censor because they're in cartoon form.

There's also a selection of horror/ slasher movies that are a bit spooky late at night. With these, it's best to take Dumbo out as well, just to calm your nerves before going to bed - although you run the risk of dreaming of grotesque and unspeakable things happening to Dumbo. And there are the new releases, which always seem much more attractive than the older new releases from three years ago that you haven't seen yet. Also, they're a quid more expensive, so they must be better.

People in long-term relationships keep a mental tally of what they've seen, and a complex form of bartering goes on: 'I sat through Patchwork Sisters for eight hours, so you can see Lethal Violence IV this time.' With mobile phones, it's possible to consult with your partner at home, but beware a man saying he has a film with Julia Roberts in it that is a kind of a cross between Four Weddings and Pretty Woman. Especially if it's called Extreme Explosion.

webTitle: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice: how critics assess a wine

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice: how critics assess a wine
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice: how critics assess a wine
fields.body:
One of the earliest complaints that was laid against the Superplonk column, and indeed the books, was the absence of romance. Reviewers (far more than readers) beefed that the hard-headed rating of wines by awarding them points out of 20 - and on a strict value-for-money basis, too - left no room for wine's soft side. I had no soft side, it was alleged.

Nor do I, as a wine writer. I leave the fluffy side to others. Wine writers, you see, are of two sorts. And what sort of wine writer you are depends on which end of the bottle you start from.

There are those - and they make up the great majority of people employed in my trade - who begin at the bottom; on the lees, if you will, among the microscopic bits and bobs of the grapes left over from the winemaking. Such writers focus on the minutiae of the wine, the vineyard, the terroir, the variety of the grapes, the philosophy - for them, the style or approach is quite insufficient to do justice to the depth of feeling that they consider appropriate here - of the wine grower. Such writers are social animals, above all else; they are fabulists with a great many friends in the world of wine.

These fabulists are almost invariably besotted by the legends that surround a wine, and they cannot divorce this from the reality of tasting the liquid itself. Once, in the cellar of Chteau Lafite (autumn 1978, I think it was), the cellar master, with great ceremony, extracted some young wine from a barrel and solemnly filled three glasses. He handed a glass to my French companion, one to me and one he took himself. What followed then, as the wine was reverentially sipped, was a neo-religious ritual from which only I dissented, since the wine was simply "quite nice" - it wasn't marvellous, nor would it have become so.

The writer who starts from the business end of the bottle, however, has far fewer friends. In a perfect world, as he knows in his heart, he would have no friends who grow and make wine - in much the same way as no film critic worthy of the status should boast of an abundance of friendships among directors and stars, because the critic will have cause regularly to see and to comment, perhaps unflatteringly, upon their performances.

As a result, it is much harder, and far lonelier work being a wine critic than being a mere wine commentator. You pour the wine. You regard its colour. You sniff it. You agitate the glass to release the perfume, and so better to appreciate the aromas and the nuances of the bouquet. Then you inhale these odiferous pleasantries - or unpleasantries, it must be said - through the chimney of taste. That is, the nostrils, which provide the brain's only access to the open air. And then, finally, you swig. You swill the liquid around the mouth and breathe in air, so that this liquid is aerated and all those thousands of tastebuds, each in differently oriented sectors (one is designed to recognise salinity, for example, another alkalinity, another sweetness, and so on), can provide the sensory data for the critic to examine what is called the mid-palate of the wine.

Some of the wine is permitted to make contact with the back of the throat, but only the very smallest amount is allowed to proceed from there and venture down the gullet - this is essential for the proper study of the finish of the wine. Then, the wine is ejected, the price tag noted, and several seconds left to elapse while all these various sensations are studied and written up as critic mulls over the impression the wine has left behind.

As part of a working day, a critic such as myself may taste more than a hundred wines (I rarely think it wise to venture, critically, over 170), and will write up copious notes describing each one, perhaps rating it, and also providing ideas as to how each one will perform with food and which dishes it is best suited for.

He or she (wine-writing favours use of "she", not least because women have finer noses) may take the price of each wine into consideration when passing judgment, or she may simply judge the wine as wine. For myself, I cannot judge a wine without knowing its price, which is an added incentive to concentrate solely upon it and nothing else. This inability to divorce the price of a bottle from its rating appals some romantics, and I seem to be alone among critics in that I have always rated wines in this way. It is extremely concentrated analysis, since it requires the taster, in arriving at a rating, rapidly to run through similar-performing wines at all price levels and thus arrive at a sensible, value-for-money judgment.

Such a critic pays no heed to the religion of the wine maker, or to the location of the grapes, or to the colour of the skins of the grapes, or to what fabulous stories may be attached to the vineyard's or the wine grower's reputation. These things may be taken in to account after the wine has hit the spittoon -and, indeed, they will have to be if the wine is a reputed colossus with an appropriate price tag, because such a wine will have had to have hit those thousands of tastebuds with some considerable impact and complexity if this reputation is a worthy one and not simply a fable as, sadly, is so often the case.

In splendid Lilliputian fashion, then, we wine writers are either top-enders or bottom-enders. So, take note from which end of the bottle your wine writer writes. Sensibly, of course, and not caring whether a wine writer is off her top or out of his bottom, you may simply decide to let the devil take the lot of us

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Wendy Richard
fields.trailText: Wendy Richard
fields.body:
Wendy Richard, 57, was born in Middlesbrough. Her parents worked in the licensed trade, and she was brought up in London, where she went to Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Arts. She had parts in Dixon of Dock Green and Dad's Army before landing her first big role, Shirley Brahms, in Are You Being Served? She is one of the original cast members of EastEnders, and has been playing Pauline Fowler for 15 years. She recently received the MBE and published her autobiography.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

A whole day at home on my own with no lines to learn and no washing to do.

What is your greatest fear?

Being late for work - they fine us!

Which living person do you most admire?

Mollie Sugden, for combining career and motherhood, being a splendid actress and baking wonderful cakes.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

Intolerance.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

Unprofessionalism.

What vehicles do you own?

I don't drive: I failed my test six times.

What is your greatest extravagance?

Clothes and bags.

What objects do you always carry with you?

My mobile phone, which plays The Archers' theme tune.

What makes you depressed?

The way this country is going.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

The bags under my eyes.

What is your most unappealing habit?

Smoking.

What is your favourite building?

Buckingham Palace.

How did you vote in the last election?

Conservative.

How will you vote in the next election?

Conservative.

Do you believe in capital punishment?

Yes.

Do you believe in monogamy?

Yes.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

It's a toss up between my partner John and my cairn terrier, Shirley Brahms II.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

'Can I have a cup of tea, please?'

What is your greatest regret?

Ever having got married.

How do you relax?

Listen to the radio and do my tapestry.

How would you like to be remembered?

She was alright.

webTitle: Weekend: Margaret Drabble's The Peppered Moth

fields.headline: Mothers and daughters
fields.standfirst: What do you do if you feel that, very likely, you never loved your own mother? In Margaret Drabble's case, she wrote a novel that is also partly a memoir about three generations of women in her family. She hoped that it would make the heart grow fonder. Did it work? Or was she just fooling herself all along? Suzie Mackenzie finds out
fields.trailText: What do you do if you feel that, very likely, you never loved your own mother? In Margaret Drabble's case, she wrote a novel that is also partly a memoir about three generations of women in her family. She hoped that it would make the heart grow fonder. Did it work? Or was she just fooling herself all along? Suzie Mackenzie finds out.
fields.body:
The first time I met Margaret Drabble, I was 14, she was 28, and I loathed her. Or, if not her precisely, then everything she represented. She had come to my school, the City of London - all girls, direct grant - to read from her latest novel, The Millstone, her third, and to lecture us on the novelist's life. Lecture - because in those days, it was 1968, no one "talked" to young women about their lives, their longing and their fear.

The object, of course, benign in its intent, was to fill us girls with the right kind of ambition. To inculcate in us the notion that, if you lived life like a novel, turning it over page by page, paying attention to its proper structure and chronology - school, university, career, marriage, kids - then somehow you could sidestep life's meanness.

There would have been teachers present in that lecture hall - Miss Woolley, Miss Church, the Misses B and M Nash - every one of them a spinster, and some of them so old, or so the rumour went, as to have lost fiancés in the first world war. I know now, though I neither understood nor could have appreciated it then, that we represented to these women their lost chance. "Their girls" - because we were all, always, "their girls", even the naughty ones - would in the phraseology of the day "have it all".

Did this make them resent us? Does resentment account for their sometime unkindnesses. Or did their thin-lipped strictness conceal some fear for us? Fear that the expectations they so assiduously filled us with would return to frustrate us. Probably a bit of both. Today, I can look with tenderness on the diligence with which they went about trying to prepare us for a world that their own lives could never comprehend. But God, how we mocked them then. The circumscribed narrowness of their lives and their ambition. Funny to think that, in fear and longing, we matched them, and so exactly. Even then.

Drabble, at that place and in that time, seemed to me one of them: ie, one of the ones sent to thwart us. Oh, we knew all about ambition. Hadn't Melinda Camber, only that year, achieved a scholarship to Oxford and Cambridge both - a feat so unparalleled in the school's history that we were all given a day off, a privilege normally reserved for the death of royalty?

Drabble couldn't know, as she stood before us, the Newnham scholarship girl with her starred first in Eng Lit, her husband, her three babies and her books - increasing, as it seemed, logarithmically year on year - that her shining example represented not limitless opportunity but our own imminent failure. Or was I the only one to go to bed that night consumed with despair?

It must have been some time not long after this that I helped myself to a bottle of pills, found at home, and had my stomach pumped in the local hospital. (Nothing to do with Ms Drabble; more, as I recollect, with a pretty boy named Bob.) I include this detail only because it seemed significant when the 14-year-old and 28-year-old met again, more than 25 years on. Very different people, anyone would suppose. But not me. I clung to my image of Ms Drabble as though it meant something.

It was 1995 when I met her again, and she was what? Still, in my mind, the successful author, with the unbroken trajectory, who made me fear for my future. I was on time. She was early. Making me feel, unreasonably I thought, as though I were late. So intractable these early impressions. ("And you never do catch up," she told me, a propos of her older sister, Antonia, much later on. "You are always behind. No matter how hard you try. She will always be older, cleverer, in higher heels.") Impressions can be as hard as fact, as solid as stone.

It was then that she told me about her own suicide attempt, more than 25 years earlier - and, indelibly now in my mind, the same year as my own. She wrote to her mother about it once, saying, "Don't do it. It's not fair."

But, if we are lucky, she says, we can break the repetition: "I don't think it can be done by willpower. Even the imagination can't release you. But sometimes an arbitrary factor can come crashing in and change the picture. I call that luck."

Her first bit of luck, she says, was marrying Clive. Because he was different from her. Volatile, emotional, noisy. "There was a lot of screaming." She had never known screaming. "Only nagging." It was a passionate love affair, and that's important, she says, for the children to know that they came from passion.

And then there was a passionate falling out of love, ending in divorce in 1975. "There was a long time when I didn't love him. But now I do." People don't say this, or not often. That love can shrink, shrivel up and regrow. They say "I love" or "I don't love", as if love exists only in the present, coming from nowhere, going nowhere, when, in fact, how we love is as rooted in our history as are our genes.

He took her DNA and she is still awaiting his call. "But I don't think I can be the Neanderthal link, or I would have heard from him, wouldn't I?"

It can't be done.

And in the novel Drabble doesn't attempt to do it, she moves freely across time and across the three generations of mothers and daughters who make up her story, subverting any idea of a linear structure whenever she sees fit. Life isn't threaded like a string of beads. It is more like the pile of marbles with which she and Antonia used to play as children in the attic of their unmarried aunt Phyll, baubles that crash and collide. "God," Drabble says, "marbles were so beautiful then." And sometimes, no doubt, she would pick one up, put it in her pocket, take it out of the game, and that would become hers, for keeps.

I have long considered Margaret Drabble subversive - based on that early impression, perhaps, but I prefer to think more rooted in fact. She has been described by some critics as suburban, domestic, preoccupied with middle-class mores - maternal, even in her writing. Whoever came up with the idea that this was safe? We forget that in the early 60s - when she was writing her first three novels, A Summer Bird-cage, The Garrick Year, The Millstone, all centred on the tensions in the lives of high-powered girls like her then self - it was unusual to scrutinise the solipsistic nature of young motherhood, that first generation of women who believed they could, by following their instincts, have it all.

The conflict between instinct and morality, the rough intrusion of accident into our lives, the weakness of human will - this most especially - has been her subject. And always rooted in time and place. In the 80s, she produced her disaffected trilogy, The Radiant Way, A Natural Curiosity and The Gates of Ivory, continuing the decision she had taken earlier to abandon heroines, which she has not reversed. She has also recently edited and revised what is probably the most scholarly and excellent work of reference to be produced in recent times, The Oxford Companion to English Literature.

The Peppered Moth is her most subversive book yet, though you don't realise until the end quite the extent of this. In an afterword, she tells the reader that it is, in fact, a book about her own mother, that she has drawn from letters and memoirs to produce her fiction. She has also "filled out with invention". She talks about her bias towards her father, "a good man". And the impossibility of loving an unlovable woman. She once said to me, "I don't know if I loved my mother."

And the deep sadness of the book is that, perhaps, she does know. She wrote the book, she says, in an effort to reclaim her mother. "I hoped that, by going back into her childhood, by reading her school reports, by revisiting the houses we lived in, perhaps I might understand what she was really like. And that some emotional blockage would be released. To tell you the truth, I innocently hoped that through it I would feel more love."

This could be read in different ways. As an act of compassion towards a woman now 16 years dead. And, indeed, towards herself - to forgive herself for not having loved this woman as, perhaps, we all feel we should love our mothers. It could be read, more harshly, as an act of appropriation - to secure this elusive woman, her mother, and the mother of Antonia, and of Helen and Richard, her siblings, once and all for herself.

I have tried to think myself into the position of her sisters and brother, reading the book, and have wondered if I would resent it. And I think I would. I have also wondered whether this is what Margaret has always done - possessively, jealously, drawn her mother to herself. It was Margaret who was there, at her mother's home in Suffolk, just hours after she died peacefully in her sleep. I listened to her describe it, with that kind of grim humour she has.

"She had just watched the last part of The Jewel In The Crown ... got to the end of the series and went to bed and died ... On her bedside table were her glasses and an open book, The Shogun, which she was reading. I don't think she would have wanted me to know that ... she hadn't got to the end of that." Did you kiss her, I asked her. "Yes," she said, "I did." I would have been jealous of that.

But, so many buts. There is real generosity in the book. She could have written it as a memoir, Drabble says, but she decided not to. One of the things about writing a novel rather than a memoir, she explains, is that you can generalise. "Say, this is the kind of thing mothers do to their daughters. And I could look at her as part of her generation." A generation of women, she says, "who grew up between the wars, who were educated into expectations, and who were then frustrated, sent back into the domestic world". So, a woman, a mother who was unique and not unique.

What do you select in a biography that is of significance - because it's all selection, isn't it, editing bits in, bits out, to suit our purposes? It seems to me, for example, of some importance that Drabble's mother, Kathleen Marie Bloor, always known as Marie, miscarried her first child. "I believe she was quite anxious to have a baby at this point." And so Antonia became that much-wanted, that longed for first baby.

"My mother meant to have my sister, she didn't mean to have me." Drabble relates how her mother used to say to her, "Who in their right mind would have had a baby in June 1939, with a war coming?" Who in their right mind would say this to their child? But then, Marie was the first of two sisters, Marie and Phyllis - this seems significant, too. In that family, the Bloor family, things divided neatly. Marie was the clever one. "I think my mother really was extraordinarily bright." Phyll the dunce. "Though not nearly as stupid as my mother used to like to say she was."

Imagine, then, being Margaret. Determined not to turn into her much derided aunt? "Not much chance of that." Or imagine being Marie. The girl who had grown up without an intellectual companion. Maybe even felt guilty about so easily outstripping her little sister. Now, with her own first two daughters, Marie could easily and consciously have set out to make her daughters intellectual equals - redress the perceived wrong. This might account for the fierce competition that the mother encouraged in her daughters. "I wish I understood," Drabble says.

It's not purely perverse to say that I like the sound of Marie Bloor. She talked to her daughters, "all the time". She told them stories about her life. "Endlessly." It's hard not to feel sympathy with this working-class Yorkshire girl, so clever that she got a scholarship to Newnham. Who arrived in Cambridge only to be put firmly in her place by Miss Strachey, principal of Newnham and Lytton Strachey's sister.

"My mother goes in all chirpy, she has been teacher's pet all her life ... and Ms Strachey says, 'A scholarship girl, I see. Will you be able to afford the fees?' And my mother, who thought that she had done so brilliantly well, suddenly realised that there was another standard by which she was being judged. And by which she felt she was being judged for the rest of her life." Her mother wanted vengeance, clearly - she was right to want it - and she got it in her brilliant daughters, all three at Newnham. She may also have wanted to protect her daughters. They were all taught to speak "proper English, not Yorkshire", though Marie spoke with a Yorkshire accent to the end of her life.

Her daughter, quite rightly, on the issue of class, wants to protect her. Don't you find, Margaret says, "that there's something about Bloomsbury that sets your teeth on edge - something to do with its unawareness of other people's hang-ups and vulnerabilities. That is Virginia Woolf's great weakness. She couldn't understand people's social difficulties. When she saw them, she didn't recognise them for what they were."

When she was researching this novel, Drabble went back to Newnham and looked through all the archival material relating to her mother's intake at Cambridge. "Her contemporaries were, as you'd expect, the children of mostly middle-class people - lawyers and the like. There were only a small handful like her from humble homes." Drabble's dad, the son of a Yorkshire sweet manufacturer, "from a slightly better home than hers", was a lawyer.

Did her parents love one another? This is the question that runs through the book. Maybe it is every child's question, or every unhappy child's question. Because, if we don't proceed from love, then ... what? She says there are no letters in existence between her parents. Odd, because her father was away for the war, and later in life he travelled a great deal on his own. So one has to assume either that they didn't write - though her father wrote to his friend frequently and Drabble has these letters - or that the correspondence was destroyed. Otherwise, her mother seems to have kept everything. Clearing out her grandparents' house, Drabble came across the thesis that her mother wrote on George Gissing. "Unfortunately, I think we left it in the garage." She never read it? "No."

Looking up the Gissing entry in The Oxford Companion, I learn that Gissing married "two proletarian girls". And, in the words of his friend HG Wells, "He felt that to make love to any woman he could regard as a social equal would be too elaborate, so he flung himself at a social inferior whom he expected to be grateful." Gissing, incidentally, was a Quaker, as was Drabble's father. And as was her mother later in life, when she renounced atheism. "She was quite unusual," Drabble says. "In certain things she was very bold."

Gratitude, a euphemism for resentment, as William Blake wrote. Is this enough to explain her mother's unkindness to her father? She was at least as bright as him; brighter, probably. "Possibly," Drabble says. "He was very bright." She married him at 25, then quite late in life. On the shelf? "I think," Drabble says, "she married him at a time when her career wasn't going as well as she had hoped."

After Newnham, unable to get a job - it was 1929, no one could get a job - she returned to her home town of Mexborough, which she hated, and was teaching at her old school. The ignominy of it: the golden girl ... And doing no better than Phyll, who was a primary school teacher. When their father became a circuit judge in Northumberland, she insisted she hated the north and made him move south. To Sevenoaks. A kind of purgatory, I would have thought.

With a dearth of documentary evidence, we have three things to fall back on her parents' love for each other. Drabble's own testimony: "She was horrible to him." Her mother's two university pals, who both wrote to Margaret saying, "They had a very happy early marriage." And something her father once said of her mother, late in life: "She is not the sweetheart she once was." That, Margaret says, "was the understatement of all time". The timing of this is impeccable. And she gets it from her mother, I am sure. To be funny and to be a sweetheart, even if a lapsed sweetheart, is pretty irresistible. You can love people like this.

Maybe, I said to her, none of us gets the mother we feel we deserve. She laughed. "Why would we deserve better than we get?" No, she said. No. "My mother was my mother, and I am undeniably a product of my mother. I would have liked my mother to have been happy. But whatever she was, she was my mother and there is no other mother I could have had. So I don't deserve a better mother. I feel intimately and closely connected to that woman who was my mother."

Maybe, I said, this is what we call love. "Could be. I suppose it could be." Then she rejects the idea. "But she drove me so mad - it's hard to give it that name." And then. "I think the sorrow I feel for her could be love." Sometimes, she says, she wonders, "What justifies writing fiction at all?" And answers her own question. "To find this common territory of loss."

It seems appropriate, somehow, that the last word in this should go to Margaret's only daughter, Becky. Becky, who loved her grandmother and who loves her mother. Amazing that she should be able to express this so simply. Margaret, of course, is exasperating. It is part of the maternal role. Becky has no children. "I said to her, 'Do you realise, after you my mitochondrial DNA will become extinct?' " (Her own mother, Marie, couldn't have expressed it better, by which I mean worse.) "So what?" she reports Becky as responding.

"The funny thing," Margaret says, "is that my mother was very nice to my children. She used to let them get into bed with her in the morning, which is more than she ever did with us." It strikes me that it's no coincidence that the novel spans three generations. You need this for some kind of understanding. The set-up, the tension and the forgiveness. Anyway, Becky wrote a poem: On Remembering Getting Into Bed With Grandparents. Though the object of the poem is singular - ie, her grandmother.

It's amazing that we got that far, loveless

As you were supposed to be ...

"Loveless," the daughters said ...

Yet ...

That's it really. The circularity of love. How it seems to abandon us and how it returns.

And my mother, who thought that she had done so brilliantly well, suddenly realised that there was another standard by which she was being judged. And by which she felt she was being judged for the rest of her life." Her mother wanted vengeance, clearly - she was right to want it - and she got it in her brilliant daughters, all three at Newnham. She may also have wanted to protect her daughters. They were all taught to speak "proper English, not Yorkshire", though Marie spoke with a Yorkshire accent to the end of her life. Her daughter, quite rightly, on the issue of class, wants to protect her. Don't you find, Margaret says, "that there's something about Bloomsbury that sets your teeth on edge - something to do with its unawareness of other people's hang-ups and vulnerabilities. That is Virginia Woolf's great weakness. She couldn't understand people's social difficulties. When she saw them, she didn't recognise them for what they were." When she was researching this novel, Drabble went back to Newnham and looked through all the archival material relating to her mother's intake at Cambridge. "Her contemporaries were, as you'd expect, the children of mostly middle-class people - lawyers and the like. There were only a small handful like her from humble homes." Drabble's dad, the son of a Yorkshire sweet manufacturer, "from a slightly better home than hers", was a lawyer. Did her parents love one another? This is the question that runs through the book. Maybe it is every child's question, or every unhappy child's question. Because, if we don't proceed from love, then ... what? She says there are no letters in existence between her parents. Odd, because her father was away for the war, and later in life he travelled a great deal on his own. So one has to assume either that they didn't write - though her father wrote to his friend frequently and Drabble has these letters - or that the correspondence was destroyed. Otherwise, her mother seems to have kept everything. Clearing out her grandparents' house, Drabble came across the thesis that her mother wrote on George Gissing. "Unfortunately, I think we left it in the garage." She never read it? "No." Looking up the Gissing entry in The Oxford Companion, I learn that Gissing married "two proletarian girls". And, in the words of his friend HG Wells, "He felt that to make love to any woman he could regard as a social equal would be too elaborate, so he flung himself at a social inferior whom he expected to be grateful." Gissing, incidentally, was a Quaker, as was Drabble's father. And as was her mother later in life, when she renounced atheism. "She was quite unusual," Drabble says. "In certain things she was very bold." Gratitude, a euphemism for resentment, as William Blake wrote. Is this enough to explain her mother's unkindness to her father? She was at least as bright as him; brighter, probably. "Possibly," Drabble says. "He was very bright." She married him at 25, then quite late in life. On the shelf? "I think," Drabble says, "she married him at a time when her career wasn't going as well as she had hoped." After Newnham, unable to get a job - it was 1929, no one could get a job - she returned to her home town of Mexborough, which she hated, and was teaching at her old school. The ignominy of it: the golden girl ... And doing no better than Phyll, who was a primary school teacher. When their father became a circuit judge in Northumberland, she insisted she hated the north and made him move south. To Sevenoaks. A kind of purgatory, I would have thought. With a dearth of documentary evidence, we have three things to fall back on her parents' love for each other. Drabble's own testimony: "She was horrible to him." Her mother's two university pals, who both wrote to Margaret saying, "They had a very happy early marriage." And something her father once said of her mother, late in life: "She is not the sweetheart she once was." That, Margaret says, "was the understatement of all time". The timing of this is impeccable. And she gets it from her mother, I am sure. To be funny and to be a sweetheart, even if a lapsed sweetheart, is pretty irresistible. You can love people like this. Maybe, I said to her, none of us gets the mother we feel we deserve. She laughed. "Why would we deserve better than we get?" No, she said. No. "My mother was my mother, and I am undeniably a product of my mother. I would have liked my mother to have been happy. But whatever she was, she was my mother and there is no other mother I could have had. So I don't deserve a better mother. I feel intimately and closely connected to that woman who was my mother." Maybe, I said, this is what we call love. "Could be. I suppose it could be." Then she rejects the idea. "But she drove me so mad - it's hard to give it that name." And then. "I think the sorrow I feel for her could be love." Sometimes, she says, she wonders, "What justifies writing fiction at all?" And answers her own question. "To find this common territory of loss." It seems appropriate, somehow, that the last word in this should go to Margaret's only daughter, Becky. Becky, who loved her grandmother and who loves her mother. Amazing that she should be able to express this so simply. Margaret, of course, is exasperating. It is part of the maternal role. Becky has no children. "I said to her, 'Do you realise, after you my mitochondrial DNA will become extinct?' " (Her own mother, Marie, couldn't have expressed it better, by which I mean worse.) "So what?" she reports Becky as responding. "The funny thing," Margaret says, "is that my mother was very nice to my children. She used to let them get into bed with her in the morning, which is more than she ever did with us." It strikes me that it's no coincidence that the novel spans three generations. You need this for some kind of understanding. The set-up, the tension and the forgiveness. Anyway, Becky wrote a poem: On Remembering Getting Into Bed With Grandparents. Though the object of the poem is singular - ie, her grandmother. It's amazing that we got that far, loveless As you were supposed to be ... "Loveless," the daughters said ... Yet ... That's it really. The circularity of love. How it seems to abandon us and how it returns.  The Peppered Moth is published by Viking on January 5 at £16.99. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck sniffs out the best cheap booze for Christmas
fields.body:
Booths, the bijou chain of northern supermarkets, has an approach that is difficult to define, but that springs from an ethos of old-fashioned grocery service - you could say it's a bit like Fortnum & Mason meets Asda. To celebrate the festivities, the store has a delightful alternative to cava or champagne: Prosecco Zonin (16 points out of 20, £4.99), a sparkling wine from Italy. One of the world's great unsung bubbly wine bargains, it is deliciously dry with a hint of strawberry. Also at Booths is Jordan Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £8.49), from South Africa, which can also be found at Waitrose, Unwins and Wine Cellar. It has melon-and-lime yoghurt fruit with a hint of walnut - quite yummy. The 99 vintage is not in the same class.

Majestic has an abundance of bubblies, notably the current blend of Yellowglen Pinot Noir Chardonnay, from Australia, which is superb. Rating 16 points and costing £8.49, this is a classy, subtly rich wine of some style - and if you buy six or more bottles, the price drops to £6.37. Also at Majestic, as well as Oddbins and Safeway, is Mamre Brook Cabernet Shiraz 1996 (16 points, £6.99), from Australia, which is at its peak of savoury smoothness and richness. Bulk purchase brings the price down to £5.99. Two further festive reds at Majestic are from the great Rhne house of Guigal. Its basic Ctes du Rhne 1998 (16 points, £6.99) is a rich and svelte performer on the tastebuds, offering character with finesse, which you can get for £5.99 if you buy two bottles or more. Unwins and Oddbins have it, too. Guigal's 1997 Gigondas, meanwhile, is a classic, parading hedgerow-sweet, dark, herby, subtly mineral-edged fruit of complexity and texture. It rates 16.5 points and is on offer at £11.99 until January 29.

At Oddbins there is Wirra Wirra RSW Shiraz 1997 (18 points, £14.99, Fine Wine Stores only), from Australia. It's a world-class specimen, elegant, huge, potent yet polite. Chteau de l'Engarran Quetton Saint-Georges Coteaux de Languedoc 1998 (17.5 points, £8.99) is rather exquisitely refined at first smell and sip, then a hint of a rugged, misspent youth appears to garnish the soft plummy fruit with bite, tannin and longevity of performance. Fabre Montmayor Merlot Lujan de Cuyo 1997 (17 points, £6.99), from Argentina, is beautifully complete in its harmony of fruit, acids and tannins and immediately seductive. Merryvale Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (17 points, £13.99), from California, is an alcoholic (14.5%) subterfuge, since there are merlot, cabernet franc and petit verdot grapes in there, too. All that said, this duplicitous blend lies gorgeously on the tastebuds with a polish recalling Lafite in a soft year.

At Safeway we have Knappstein Cabernet/Merlot 1998 (16.5 points, £7.99, selected branches), from Australia, which is brightly textured, replete with polished plummy flavours and with an elegant finish. Errazuriz Merlot Reserva Don Maximiano Estate 1998 (16.5 points, £9.99, Oddbins has it, too), from Chile, is like drinking, or perhaps chewing, a soft velvet glove suffused with essence of cassis. Jean Louis Denois Mourvedre/Grenache Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (17 points, £5.99) is stunningly well textured with potent fruit of complexity and minor grandeur, combining rich herbs and lovely warm tannins. Evans & Tate Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, £8.99, selected branches) is nutty and figgy with concentrated weight on the finish.

Sainsbury's has Danie de Wet 'Call of the African Eagle' Chardonnay Reserve 2000 (17 points, £6.99, 140 branches), a very delicate, subtle, stealthy artefact that is consummately delicious and nutty (with a very vague echo of peaches and cream), fresh yet textured and gently rich, and it finishes with aplomb. This is an assured, understated wine of great class. It also has Petaluma Bridgewater Mill Shiraz 1998 (16.5 points, £8.49, 180 branches), from Australia, with a chewy, coal-edged texture, deep and rich and softly spicy. It flaunts plums, blackcurrants and a touch of leather, along with delicious tannins.

Finally, an announcement (at last!): Superplonk.com has now gone live! All comments and suggestions gratefully received.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: How do you teach citizenship?

fields.headline: How do you teach citizenship?
fields.standfirst: Can you really imagine having to start each day at work by bestowing a lot of insincere compliments on the person at the next desk?
fields.trailText: Can you really imagine having to start each day at work by bestowing a lot of insincere compliments on the person at the next desk?
fields.body:
If, as a schoolboy, I had been asked to stand in a circle and declare to the boy on my left, "I'm glad you are here", and then describe to him his good points, I think I would have been paralysed by shame and embarrassment. Can you imagine doing it now? Can you imagine having to start each day at work by bestowing a lot of insincere compliments on the person at the next desk?

It would not merely be against nature, but against every competitive, go-getting, uncharitable instinct that drives us forward through life. Nevertheless, it is one of the many techniques by which the government intends to wage war on the yob culture and turn us all from an early age into "model citizens".

The government - with the best of intentions, of course - has decided to practise in British schools the philosophy of an American "educator" called Francine Britton, who has spent 10 years roaming the world with her message that "citizenship" is something that can and should be taught in schools. She has been extremely successful: her textbook on the subject has been widely used not only in the US, which one might expect, but even in countries as remote as Thailand and China.

It was to have been launched in London this week by the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the education secretary, David Blunkett, whose own method of teaching citizenship to his children has, by his own cheerful admission, been to smack them. "It worked at the time," he said last week.

Beating was widely practised as a punishment when I was at school, and I don't think that it did work, since it didn't usually seem to make the victim behave any better afterwards than he did before. There was even a certain kudos in being beaten often. But though I have yet to see Britton's book, it sounds from the reports that it may be even less effective in achieving its aim of a "spiritual, moral, social and cultural" renaissance among the nation's youth than the less subtle techniques practised by Mr Blunkett.

It may be quite fun for students to practise some of Britton's proposed exercises, such as pretending they are in a crippled submarine on the sea bed (it would be interesting to know what is regarded as model behaviour in such hopeless circumstances), but her general attitude to life and way of expressing herself are not of a kind that would appeal to the Just Williams of this world.

"The entanglements I experience in the classroom are often no more or less than the convolutions of my inner life," she has said. And she has written a number of "non-traditional children's stories that address conflict resolution, gender identity and global issues". If I were Violet Elizabeth Bott, the mere idea of these would make me want to scream and scream until I was sick.

I can see why Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools, is opposed to citizenship lessons of the kind proposed by Britton. He has worked hard and successfully to improve literacy and numeracy in primary schools, and doesn't want time wasted on anything else.

Even more to the point is a comment by Alan Smithers, professor of education at Liverpool University, that "citizenship is probably best learnt through the traditional subjects such as English and history ... One can learn plenty about citizenship from the plays of Shakespeare, the novels of Jane Austen and the study of, say, 19th century British history," he went on. "I think citizenship education could all become rather vacuous and take curriculum time away from important things like maths and science."

He is right. The problem is you can't teach "citizenship" in a cultural vacuum. Few British schoolchildren can name even a couple of Shakespeare's plays. Few know anything about British history, and assume that it is something they should be ashamed of. Hardly any of them realise that our history has been predominantly a long and successful battle for justice and freedom for the common man. Before learning to be "model citizens", our children should be given some idea about what kind of country they are citizens of. This is where the schools have failed them.

We have more lessons to learn from the US than the virtues of a republican system or Britton's views on civilising children. We should note the extent of the backlash there in recent years against the promotion of ethnic separatism as a way of building a sense of self-esteem among minority children. Several leading US commentators, such as the liberal historian Arthur Schlesinger, have argued that the effect of this has been to create an ever more divided society.

Even English Heritage, which has the task of preserving our historic monuments, wants to change its image because it is worried that older buildings lack "relevance" to black and Asian Britons. "It's frankly hard to get an Afro-Caribbean living here to get excited about, say, Blenheim Palace," said Sir Jocelyn Stevens, its former chairman. But why should that be so, unless they have been taught not to be?

fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.trailText: Your response
fields.body:
In Sally Vincent's profile of the extraordinary Eileen Atkins (A Class Act, December 9), she comments that Atkins 'has never allowed herself to be involved in anything vaguely resembling mediocrity ... picking one plum role after another like a scrumper with an in-built shit detector'. Vincent goes on: 'She doesn't seem to have ever bothered to open a script unless it emanated from Shakespeare or Shaw or ... Eliot, Tennessee Williams, DH Lawrence, Edward Albee, Robert Bolt or John Osborne.' Neatly observed, but inconveniently for this thesis Atkins has a major blot on that brilliant landscape: she starred in Jeffrey Archer's second play, Exclusive. Her 'in-built shit detector' was obviously not working that day, but at least she wasn't alone: her co-stars were Paul Scofield and Alec McCowen.

Mark Shenton
London SE1

How strange and wonderful to see my childhood friend sitting on the Brighton bench (A Glimpse Of The Deep, December 9) - 27 years ago, 'Amanda from Leeds' and I shared midnight feasts and hid pet mice in our bedrooms. But wait: could that really be 'my' Amanda, going out clubbing at the age of 36? I gave all that up at least a year ago!

L Warwick
London E9

The day I need someone to tell me that a DJ, a lot of booze, 'having-it' guests, and no psychotic gatecrashers makes for a good party, I'll just stop having them (Home, December 9). And can the person who filled the kettle with beer at Martin's last party please own up.

Coo Covill
coo@covill.demon.co.uk

Your cover picture and the cartoon inside (in which all the females had huge round breasts, half or fully exposed) suggest that, for a woman to be 'fabulously successful' at parties, she must show a considerable amount of naked flesh, rather than be intelligent, fun or witty.

Rachel Burgess
Sandhurst, Berks

In response to Jeff Williams and Paul Sharville (Dear Weekend, December 9), I'm sure there are many of us out here who find the adverts a mere page divider, irritating but necessary to keep our favourite magazine on the road. I'm sure your advertisers will be pleased to learn that the great (possibly socialist) unwashed can be diverted from Aids in Malawi to a car, perfume or some lifestyle statement by the mere juxtaposition of a brightly coloured page. These people are to be sympathised with. I expect they will write in to complain about Julie Burchill's objections to Mr Lennon. I personally have greater regret about the passing of Ian Dury.

Gerry Duffett
Hythe, Southampton

Well done Ms Burchill, an excellent piece on Lennon (December 9). But to suggest that McCartney wrote any decent songs? Now that is offensive.

Tim Davies
Wotton-Under-Edge, Glos

John Lennon was a deeply flawed individual who happened to be a wonderful singer and composed a considerable number of excellent, often moving songs, giving pleasure to many millions. Julie Burchill is a deeply flawed individual who once wrote in the Face that Stalin's victims 'deserved to die because they were not good communists'. I don't suppose she can sing, either.

Francis Mansell
London N16

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: The last word on   Sex
fields.standfirst: Love's mysteries in souls do grow; but yet the body is his book -   John Donne
fields.trailText: Love's mysteries in souls do grow; but yet the body is his book - John Donne
fields.body:
A common thread connects opposition to the morning-after pill and the photograph by Stephen Meisel in which the model Sophie Dahl, aided only by a pearl necklace and an ecstatic pose, advertises perfume. It also ran through recent endeavours to retain anomalies in legislation concerning the age of consent, and it is the unremitting theme of self-appointed watchdogs over broadcasting standards. The common thread is moral conservatism about sex and sexuality, long known as Mrs Grundyism.

Perhaps such conservatism should now take its name from Mary Whitehouse, Victoria Gillick, Baroness Young, or some other more recent heroine in the great cause of making people as sexually inactive, ignorant, and powerless as possible. What such warriors wish is to stop people having sex unless thoroughly married, knowing anything about it if unmarried and not much more if they are, and (anyway for the likes of Mrs Gillick, mother of 10) being completely at the mercy of reproductive chance, despite the availability of safe scientific means of controlling fertility. For this is what the anti-sex crusade desires: limitation, ignorance, enslavement to biology, and marginalisation of sex to hidden places in just one conventional kind of relationship.

If sexual relations are ever perfunctory and unimaginative, unsatisfying or downright frustrating, exploitative, furtive, sleazy or violent, it will have a great deal to do with the meddling hand of moralism. If there is a troubling level of sexually transmitted disease in society, it will again have much to do with moralism. If there are unwanted pregnancies, especially among girls and young women, and a high rate of abortions, it will yet again be because of moralism.

Why? Because of the counterproductive effect of moralism's utterly futile endeavour to limit and control sexuality by denial, by limiting knowledge and opportunity, by directing the sexual side of human nature into as anodyne and routine a channel as possible. Moralists think that if they expose people - and especially the young, those volcanoes of hormones - to as little stimulation as possible by censoring sexual images and references, and by keeping them as much in the dark and as much under a sense of prohibition as they can, they will thereby squeeze sex out of daily life, or at any rate keep it bottled.

But exactly there lies their mistake. Imprisoning sexual feelings is an invariable recipe for potentiating them. Ignorance about how to deal with them means that when they express themselves they might do so negatively, even harmfully - and with serious consequences: as when the combination of secrecy and shame with urgency results in couples not having contraception available when they need it.

Moralists think they get everything they want by cementing sex to fertility, because pregnancy and child-rearing are well-known antaphrodisiacs (not invariably, as Mrs Gillick herself cheeringly illustrates), so the moralists can be confident that in most cases sexual passion between marital partners will diminish - although no sooner have moralists breathed a sigh of relief on that score than they find themselves deprecating the adultery and resulting family breakdown that frequently follow, without accepting the leading part their repressive views play.

What is the source of the moralists' strange idea that sex is wrong, bad, dirty, and in need of control? One answer is: the consequences of just such control - for if you dam a river it will flood elsewhere in awkward and unexpected ways. A major source of hostility to sex is religion. "Christianity gave Eros poison to drink," Nietzsche observed, "but he did not die of it, he degenerated - into vice." The belief that soul is heavenly and body earthly, and that everything earthly interferes with the soul's aspiration to heaven, is the fountainhead of negative evaluations of bodily things. Yet as Mark Twain said, "Nature knows no indecencies; man invents them."

That case is proved by Meisel's perfume advertisement. It is beautiful and erotic; to the generous eye it adds delight and flavour to the world, while to the acidulated eye of prudery it is a lecherous and threatening affront. How sad, therefore, for the prude!

webTitle: A walk on the Wilde side brings its rewards

fields.headline: A walk on the Wilde side brings its rewards
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
January 19 2000

New York. Peter Shaffer talks vividly about Gielgud and Brecht and Oscar Wilde and the celebrated West End impresario, Binkie Beaumont: "I gave him [Beaumont]the manuscript of The Royal Hunt of the Sun, and I'd written a line that became slightly notorious, a stage direction about the Spanish army. The line was: 'They now climb the Andes.' I was staying the weekend at Binkie's and John Perry was there, the partner, and they had referred not at all to the manuscript, but I overheard John Perry describing it to Binkie: 'Well dear, they climb up the Andes, do they? And what do they do then? They climb down them, dear. Fancy.' And I thought, I don't think this is quite the management for this play."

He talks about the endurance of the power of theatre, of the reticent Chichester audience leaning forward, with their hands palms upwards willing Robert Stephens as Atahualpa to rise from the dead.

January 21

Coulsdon mental hospital for a piece about Antonin Artaud, the French actor, director, visionary - and madman. The hospital has been disused for two years; it must have housed hundreds of patients, now beneficiaries of the "care in the community" policy, which gave the mentally ill the franchise of the open streets. Mind you, if you weren't mad when you came here... This is a sick building, soaked in misery. Its infinitely long, tiled corridors have been made even more depressing by the addition of brown paint for a TV series called Psychos. Roger, the director, is anxious about using the word "magus" in my piece about Artaud. I fight for it on the grounds of dumbing up, but he's probably right on the grounds of pretentiousness. In Berlin I had the same argument over the word "dialectic".

January 24

It's the Irish episode, we're in the foyer of the Savoy hotel, it's 6.30 in the morning and I'm talking about Oscar Wilde, who ran up a large bill here - feasting with panthers in the bedrooms and dining with Bosie in the Grill Room. The hotel staff are wholly helpful, but we have to be out before 8.30 as they have a delegation from the MoD arriving for a meeting with a Slovenian military delegation. Or the other way round.

On to Blacks' club in Dean Street, then Lobb's the bootmaker. In Lobb's the clock has stopped in 1951, redecorated by the previous Mr Lobb for the Festival of Britain. It smells of age and leather and money, but is agreeably immune from marketing, management, advertising and postmodernism.

The present Mr Lobb shows me round: the shop is flanked on one side by display cases including two tiny pairs of shoes - one belonging to Queen Victoria, the other to Haile Selassie. On the other side, blue-aproned shoemakers rasp away at wooden lasts for new customers. A book displays the outlines of feet from many kings, maharajahs, film stars, thriller writers, and, infamously, Horatio Bottomley [the first world war jingoist, subsequently a fraudster] and Guy Burgess. No doubt Jeffrey Archer has his shoes made here, but the ever-courteous and ever-discreet Mr Lobb merely smiles gnomically when I suggest it.

He takes me below stairs, where thousands of lasts are stacked on shelves like scrolls in a catacomb. In corners of the basement sit more shoemakers working away with welt beaters, heel irons, waist irons, burnishing irons, lasting pincers, skiving knives, breasting knives, prick stitchers, scrapers, fudge wheels, crow wheels, channel openers, bones and last hooks, which draw the lasts from the finished shoes - which normally take about a year to make and cost £2,000. Next door is Lock's the hatter, equally revered, even if a little more prone to merchandising and modernising than Lobb's. They have a bill for Mr Wilde who had to leave the country in a hurry. [It was paid this month on the centenary of Wilde's death by Royston du Maurier, an artist from Worthing.] I end the day being filmed walking down Old Compton Street - not quite Wilde territory, this, but you get the idea.

January 25

Off to interview director Peter Gill about DH Lawrence's plays, which Peter directed definitively at the Royal Court in the late 60s. Peter is a Welsh working-class Catholic; he's like a highly intelligent, worldly and charming Jesuit priest. He talks in a maze of sub-clauses, which spiral round the subject, sparking observations about the romanticism of British theatre, the shapelessness of great plays, and the ineradicable presence of class in our culture.

Night. As the audience emerges from the National Theatre, I'm talking to the camera about the history of the campaign to establish it. A familiar face appears, accompanied by a week-old baby in a carry-cot: it's John Caird, director of Candide, which has just had its last night. John says he wondered who it was talking so knowledgeably about theatre history. I wish. I'm intrigued by a couple who stand looking at a leaflet for the Christmas show, Honk the Ugly Duckling. "Look, Sheryl," says the man. "It's got frogs in it. We must come to that."

January 26

Manchester, to do a piece about Miss Horniman, who was an Edwardian heiress to a tea fortune - a handsome woman with an artistic bent, who smoked in public, wore trousers to ride a bicycle and offered a large sum of money to an actress and fellow member of her occult group, Florence Farr, for the purpose of putting on plays. Farr commissioned WB Yeats - also a member of the occult group - which is how Miss Horniman ended up as the money behind the Abbey Theatre in Dublin. Florence Farr, incidentally, believed in daily sex as a health tonic. George Bernard Shaw was a beneficiary of this regime, as was Yeats, after years of petitioning.

Miss Horniman supported the Abbey for many years, but her enthusiasm was dampened by Yeats's scorn for her artistic ambitions and her disapproval of home rule. She didn't like the Irish and they didn't like her, so she withdrew her money and initiated the English Repertory Movement by buying the Manchester Gaiety theatre and endowing a group of playwrights, who wrote for the north about the north. They were called the "Manchester School", and included Harold Brighouse (Hobson's Choice) and Stanley Houghton (Hindle Wakes).

I'm 150 feet up on a cast-iron fire escape on the side of a factory in Ancoats that is as old in years as it's high. It's very cold, I have mild vertigo - a faint desire to plummet towards the ground - and have ample time to reflect on film-making. I've directed a dozen films for television and invariably found the process wildly invigorating: every minute of the day is crammed with interest - strategy, decisions, the picture, the sound, the logistics. Every day spent making a film produces a finished piece of the puzzle, a complete element, whereas rehearsals in the theatre stretch out forever like a snake of molecules. But acting for film is like being in the army: hours of waiting followed by a few minutes of action. And often feeling like a glove puppet. When you're directing film, the enemy is time; when you're acting, it's boredom.

Later I do a piece to camera under a railway bridge, arching above me in a film-noirish sweep. A spectator stops for a moment, fascinated by the film camera and lights. I start my piece with the words "George Bernard Shaw . . ." at which point the spectator scarpers as if his trousers were on fire.

January 27

I have a similar experience walking up a steep terraced street in Eastwood in Nottinghamshire. "What yer filming?" says a passing woman. "DH Lawrence." "Oh, him," she says with a vinegary face. Eastwood has been comprehensively heritaged: follow the blue line on the pavements and it will take you to all the principal sites of veneration. The afternoon brings me to one of my stations of the cross, the auditorium of Nottingham Playhouse. To remember a time in the 70s when a regional theatre did mostly new plays, as we did, with a permanent company in a changing repertoire, seems like recalling the roaring twenties.

 Richard Eyre's Changing Stages, the book of his recent television series, is published by Bloomsbury, price £30.
