fields.headline: When three become one
fields.standfirst: The entire Henry VI trilogy in one sitting?  Michael Billington  praises an awesome day-long event
fields.trailText: The entire Henry VI trilogy in one sitting? Michael Billington praises an awesome day-long event
fields.body:
The Royal Shakespeare Company makes its own contribution to the current monarchy debate with an exciting revival of the three parts of Henry VI at The Swan in Stratford-upon-Avon. Even if Shakespeare never ultimately questions the necessity of kingship, he shows the chaos that follows dynastic uncertainty. And, since the trilogy tours to America, you assume local audiences will see its relevance to their own constitutional crisis: that a lame-duck head of state opens the way to civil dissent.

Harold Bloom dismisses the trilogy as an exercise in Marlovian rhetoric that no longer lives. Absolutely untrue. The three plays work theatrically and appeal to audiences increasingly fatigued by the narrowing down of the Shakespeare canon. If you are going to do the plays, you should also do them as a complete set finally incorporating Richard III.

In 1963 and 1988, the RSC chopped the tetralogy into three plays dubbing them, respectively, The Wars of the Roses and The Plantaganets. Here Michael Boyd rightly follows the far better example of Terry Hands in 1978 - by presenting the Henry VI plays virtually uncut: the result is an awesome day-long event in which the actors' commitment is matched by that of the audience. Boyd and his designer, Tom Piper, have also taken radical steps to unify the stylistically variable plays. For a start they have re-aligned The Swan so that the stage-floor is an irregular oblong. Above all, they have realised the virtue of the building lies in its height. Actors are constantly scaling ladders and ropes to remind us of the vertical nature of siege-warfare. Characters descend from the flies encased in picture frames. Red and white feathers fall from on high symbolising both fluctuating fortunes, fickleness and human transience.

What is striking is how these plays change their meaning with the years. In the Hall-Barton Wars of the Roses they expressed a 1960s scepticism about the political process itself - the dominant image was of a diamond-shaped council table around which the embattled lords argued. Obviously, the plays remain acute studies in the nature of power. But Boyd treats the trilogy as, above all, an extended essay on time.

The young, callow Henry VI is haunted by his grandfather's usurpation of the throne. But the characters also exist in a nightmare present. And death is seen as an entrance as well as an exit: corpses rise up to be guided offstage by a mysterious gatekeeper only to re-appear, like the Duke of York, in the thick of battle. It's a very Eliotesque idea, that time present and time past are both present in time future.

But, however much Boyd unifies the plays visually, there's no getting away from the simple fact that Part Two is the trilogy's undisputed high point. The first Part, dealing with French wars and domestic factions, is vivid enough. But in Part Two Shakespeare displays that ability to embrace court and commoners that he was later to deploy, with even greater genius, in the Henry IV plays. At court the nobles conspire against the Duke of Gloucester; their disputes are mirrored by battles between Horner, an armourer, and his servant (delightfully named Peter Thump). We also get the Kentish rebellion of Jack Cade: as Jake Nightingale's Cade here swings on a trapeze above his followers, we are reminded that - far from being a republican - he sees himself as a legitimate claimant to the throne pre-emptively dubbing himself Sir John Mortimer.

Everyone in these plays is reaching for what they call "the glorious gold". The only person who understands the hollowness of power is the throne's occupant, Henry VI. Much has been made of the casting of David Oyelowo in the role, the first black actor to play a Shakespearean king at Stratford. Far more important is the moral strength Oyelowo brings to the part. His king may be militarily weak and politically fallible but he has the inner certainty of the believer; and when he rounds on his wife for defending her lover - "Ungentle Queen to call him gentle Suffolk" - it is with fearsome wrath. In the midst of the carnage, Oyelowo exudes a specific gravity.

I heard mumbles in some quarters that the casting could not match the great days of The Wars of the Roses. But this is, on average, a much younger company and one whose strength resides in its collective purpose. Fiona Bell, significantly doubling as Joan la Pucelle and Margaret of Anjou, moves from trull to termagant with crop-haired, iron-souled determination. Clive Wood's Duke of York watches over the action like a still, animalistic predator. Aidan McArdle as his son, Richard, whose disabilities are constantly mocked, malevolently implies the smiler with the knife under the cloak. And Richard Cordery, plumply complacent as the Lancastrian Gloucester who is Henry's protector, suggests an apple tree waiting to be axed.

Inevitably there are niggles: the emblematic scene of the father who has killed his son and the son who has killed his father is undercut by having two actors instead of four. And there are moments, particularly in Part Three, when the head spins with fatigue as the realm descends into chaos.

But, for the most part, Boyd and his team have staged the plays superbly. What they bring out is not merely the epidemic nature of throne-lust but the notion that history is a continuous inter-twining of past, present and future. It is as if Shakespeare's blood-boltered trilogy has been memorably permeated by the spirit of Eliot's Four Quartets.

 At The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon, until February 10. Box office: 01789-403403.

His king may be militarily weak and politically fallible but he has the inner certainty of the believer; and when he rounds on his wife for defending her lover - "Ungentle Queen to call him gentle Suffolk" - it is with fearsome wrath. In the midst of the carnage, Oyelowo exudes a specific gravity. I heard mumbles in some quarters that the casting could not match the great days of The Wars of the Roses. But this is, on average, a much younger company and one whose strength resides in its collective purpose. Fiona Bell, significantly doubling as Joan la Pucelle and Margaret of Anjou, moves from trull to termagant with crop-haired, iron-souled determination. Clive Wood's Duke of York watches over the action like a still, animalistic predator. Aidan McArdle as his son, Richard, whose disabilities are constantly mocked, malevolently implies the smiler with the knife under the cloak. And Richard Cordery, plumply complacent as the Lancastrian Gloucester who is Henry's protector, suggests an apple tree waiting to be axed. Inevitably there are niggles: the emblematic scene of the father who has killed his son and the son who has killed his father is undercut by having two actors instead of four. And there are moments, particularly in Part Three, when the head spins with fatigue as the realm descends into chaos. But, for the most part, Boyd and his team have staged the plays superbly. What they bring out is not merely the epidemic nature of throne-lust but the notion that history is a continuous inter-twining of past, present and future. It is as if Shakespeare's blood-boltered trilogy has been memorably permeated by the spirit of Eliot's Four Quartets.  At The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon, until February 10. Box office: 01789-403403.

fields.headline: Misanthrope and whine
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: William still believes in Santa Claus, and he nagged me to take him to see "Santa" abseil down the side of Debenhams last night before ceremonially entering his grotto on the third floor
fields.body:
Wednesday, December 6, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

William still believes in Santa Claus, and he nagged me to take him to see "Santa" abseil down the side of Debenhams last night before ceremonially entering his grotto on the third floor. We stood at the front of the crowd and when Santa landed with his beard askew and his red suit in disarray from the harness, William shouted, "Santa, will you bring me a PlayStation 2 for Christmas." Santa replied, "Of course I will, lad." I could have killed the old git: How am I going to get the money together to buy a PlayStation; they are £200. And, anyway, there are none to be had in the land. Shall I tell the truth to William and inform him that the abseiling Santa was in fact a grizzled member of The Rockettes, the Leicestershire Rock Climbing Club (a person who has no authority to make promises about Christmas presents), or do I wait until December 25 to see the disappointment on the kid's face?

My extended family is in turmoil about Christmas arrangements. Nobody knows where to go on Christmas Day, Boxing Day, or New Year's Eve. Only one thing is certain; I will not be entertaining anybody in this house. I can't even afford the Barbie Advent calendar that William has set his heart on. I asked Mohammed in the garage if I could buy one for half price, being, as we are, half way through the month. But he refused! How mean can you get? He said he would put the Barbie Advent away until next year and get the full price. So much for good will to all men.

Thursday, December 7

Tania Braithwaite gave out a grudging invitation to us to join her at The Lawn on Christmas Day as we stood in adjoining queues in Safeway. She said, "Come round if you've nowhere else to go." A quick glance into her trolley reminded me of her turkeyless and chocolateless attitude to the festivities. Soya products predominated, and there were a dozen bottles of elderflower cordial. No wonder my father refuses to get better and shake off his hospital-borne infection. He planned to spend Christmas Day with Tracy Lintel, his barrier nurse. The balloons, crackers and party-poppers are in the hospital steriliser even as I write.

Friday, December 8

Pamela Pigg rang today? She said, "I can't get you out of my mind, Aidey." Glenn overheard (her voice is rather shrill). He said darkly, "You'd 'ave to be outta your mind to go out with her again, Dad." Pamela has got a new job working with tramps, although she calls them the single homeless. She told me that there are several vacancies in the night shelter. She added that she thought I had all the qualities needed to work with such unfortunates. "Yeah, you ain't got no sense of smell," said Glenn. He was alluding to my recent failure to detect a packet of five-week-old prawns which I'd inadvertently left in the car next to the heater. Others were gagging as I drove, to my considerable bewilderment. Perhaps I should go to the Leicester Royal Infirmary and ask for a nasal efficiency test.

Saturday, December 9

My mother has covered the front of her house in a life-sized flashing bulb depiction of Santa on his sleigh. It is vulgar beyond belief. Her front garden is dominated by cardboard cut-outs of Posh, Becks and Baby Brooklyn. Each has a wire coat hanger and tinsel halo about their heads. "They are the holy family of the year 2000," she said. However, I predict that she will soon tire of the crowds who collect after dark every night. Somebody has already stolen Brooklyn's manger.

Monday, December 11

Brick Eagleburger is suing Peter Elf, his solicitor, for failing to protect his rights as an American Postal Voter, after Elf refused to act for Brick, saying he was "a bit rusty" on the intricacies of US constitutional law.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Thesps are sex workers

fields.headline: Thesps are sex workers
fields.standfirst: Being an actor is more like being a prostitute than being a soldier: you're hired for the way you look, and you show your body to strangers
fields.trailText: Being an actor is more like being a prostitute than being a soldier: you're hired for the way you look, and you show your body to strangers.
fields.body:
My friend Joanne Good drives what I sometimes think must be the best morning radio show in the country. Broadcasting as Breakfast Live In Brighton, six days a week from 6-9am, on BBC Southern Counties Radio ("serving Surrey, Sussex and northeast Hampshire" - I don't know why, but the specificness of that "northeast Hampshire" always makes me laugh), she is tireless and shameless, with the personality of a hydraulic pump crossed with a go-go girl, even at that time of morning.

She jumps from topic to totally unrelated topic - from the Panzer Mansion, the Brighton mansion that was full of midgets between the wars, to the girly 70s habit of writing pop stars' names on one's rough book at school - with all the enthusiasm of a nine-year-old let loose in Claire's Accessories.

To make things bittersweet, Joanne has an enemy, one "E Thompson", who despises her so much that she will not even do her the courtesy of writing to her on a nice piece of notepaper, and instead sends her harsh missives on the back of cancelled cheques and various other paper waste. Rose Red to Joanne's Snow White, "E Thompson" is like Anne Robinson with PMT, and seems obsessed with raining on Joanne's parade by correcting her grammar, picking on her pronunciation and generally letting her know what a silly girl she is.

Because Joanne is so used to being popular, she reads these letters with a voice full of disbelief and doubt, almost as if she thinks it is one of her friends having a laugh. And then, never missing a beat, she is immediately back to her old bouncy self, uninhibitedly scampering up and down the keyboard of her mind like a cartoon kitten trying to play the piano. Forget the endless sea, sodomy and members of Supergrass that make Brighton such a joy; Joanne's radio show alone is all the reason you need to move here.

But there is a downside to Joanne. Not one, but two people inhabit her body. She was, and still is, an actress - if you watched Crossroads in the early 80s, you'll remember her as Carole Sands, the waifish blonde beauty who worked as a mechanic at the motel garage, predating Kylie Minogue's Charlene by at least half a decade. These days, it's Casualty and panto, but to hear her go on you'd think it was Chekhov and Pinter.

Alongside Joanne the Broadcaster, who is down to earth, vivid and witty as you could wish, there lives Joanne the Luvvie, who is frankly unbearable. Last week, discussing her forthcoming appearance in Cinderella alongside Julian Clary and a huge pumpkin, she compared acting to "being in the trenches during the first world war, and about to go over the top". For once, she wasn't joking.

Actors have always been preposterous people, but such military metaphors take their folly to new heights of deliciousness. Who can forget Liz Hurley stating that she would never date "a civilian" (ie, a non actor), because they wouldn't be able to deal with the pressure? (The pressure of being caked in make-up and having their photo taken, this must be.)

Then there are people who should know better encouraging thesps to think of themselves as warriors - Richard Eyre, talking about Jason Robards in the Guardian last week, gushed that, "like a campaign veteran, he speaks of the music of Long Day's Journey in the tones of a man who loves the smell of napalm in the morning". Ew!

Surely the word "punter" would be a better choice than civilian? Being an actor is far more like being a prostitute than a soldier: you get hired for the way you look, and you show private parts of your body to strangers, which I've never heard was the way to make it big in the SAS - the Navy, maybe. I've never got an answer from even the most know-all of my regular detractors/correspondents, so I'll ask the question again - when Demi Moore shows her breasts on film or Sharon Stone her vagina, what, exactly, makes them artists and not sex industry workers, albeit highly astute, excellently paid sex industry workers? I'm not being snotty; I'm genuinely interested.

As with prostitutes, the money actors get for their goods goes down as they age past their peak of physical perfection. Just look at Arnie, down from $20m to $15m a picture, with a promise of only $8m if the next one lays an egg. Also, one feels a good deal more contempt for well-bred and educated types - your Vanessas and Emmas, who lower themselves to it - than for the cheap and cheerful Martines and Patsys, who might otherwise be wasting their beauty in Woolworths. Of course, some men go to prostitutes not for sex but to hear them tell their sad story - take a bow, Melanie Griffith, whose films no one has been to see for a decade but whose tale of woe, broadcast daily on the internet, has made her hot once more.

There are exceptions to every rule - Kathy Burke, Rachel Weisz and Jude Law, for example, are the very models of dignity, restraint and perception, both as people and as artists - but, generally, actors are horrifically silly. So, are they actors because they're silly, or silly because they're actors? Whatever, "stress" - that great mantra alibi of the silly at work - has been adopted by actors as by no other group of workers; not nurses, not teachers, not people who work for Marco Pierre White.

Remember Stephen Fry running out on his colleagues on that first night and sending a bleating letter to the papers about the stress and strain he was under? Yeah, like the secret police came in the middle of the night, forced him out of bed at gunpoint and made him do all those acting jobs and commercials that earned him so many millions of pounds. Just what is so stressful about a prolonged, incredibly well-paying game of Let's Pretend? They're still at it. "It was a nightmare," says Cold Feet's John Thompson of filming three TV shows. "I was becoming a multiple personality!" As Larry Olivier said to Dustin Hoffman after the latter had been agonising over how to play a scene, "Ever thought of acting, dear boy?"

Lots of actors like to play up their social conscience; many even claim to be socialists ("socialist actor" must rate with "friendly fire" as one of the best oxymorons of all time). Without fail, they talk about what hard work play-acting is, with not a thought to what an insult such jabber is to miners, fire fighters and the like, or even to people with profoundly boring jobs.

The fact is that being an actor, or a writer, or a footballer, or anything you enjoy, is not a pain, it's a privilege. If it does cause you so much stress, maybe that's because you're not very good at it. (It is interesting that those, such as Hurley and Fry, who moan the most about how hard acting is are indeed spectacularly bad at it.) Perhaps stress is just Mother Nature's way of telling us that we're crap at our jobs and should try something new.

fields.headline: Sleaze factors
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the need for journalists to declare their interests
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the need for journalists to declare their interests
fields.body:
Christmas is coming. One of the sure signs in the Guardian offices in Farringdon Road is the sale of tickets for the seasonal sleaze draw. This takes place just before Christmas to allot to the lucky winners the "gifts" that have been sent to individual journalists. The money goes to the charities nominated in the Guardian's Christmas appeal. Last year these received about £700. This year it may be more.

The gifts this year - more than 150 of them, as I write - include £100-worth of vouchers for a women's clothing store, a surfboard, two scooters, encyclopedias, dictionaries, cocktail shakers and lots of wine. I am coming round again to the subject begun in last week's column, the need for journalists to avoid inappropriate connections and to declare all interests relevant to their work.

The sleaze raffle, possibly (and possibly not) a title that travesties the intentions behind many friendly gestures, has only been running for three or four years, at least in its present well-organised form. Donating to the draw a gift that arrives at the Guardian is still a matter for the individual journalist. The choice is: keep it, send it back or donate it to the draw. The size of the draw has grown as we have all become more sensible, I think you would say, about these things.

The rule that many editors apply to the receipt of gifts, and to declarations of potentially compromising or embarrassing interests, is what they call "the Private Eye test". This was specifically mentioned in a note to staff posted by the previous editor of the Guardian and it or something similar is certain to be included in the revised guidelines the paper will circulate to staff in the new year.

It goes like this: before you enter into any outside arrangement, imagine how you would feel if you read about it in the pages of Private Eye. We failed the test this week, in the matter of a commercial interest - now abandoned in favour of a charity to be nominated - of our wine critic. It does not feel good.

Journalists need to protect their integrity, and the Guardian, not least since in assuming the high moral ground it has rendered itself a particularly attractive target for attack, has to protect the trust in which it is held by its readers.

The preamble to the press complaints commission's code of practice opens with the words: "All members of the press have a duty to maintain the highest professional and ethical standards." In an ideal world, perhaps, that would be enough.

There are specific requirements of journalists working in certain areas, for example in financial journalism. The rules for the latter are incorporated in clause 14 of the PCC code and broadly forbid them to use for their own advantage information gained in advance of publication; to write about shares in which they have undisclosed holdings; or to buy or sell shares about which they have written or intend to write. All these rules are soon to be joined by additional PCC guidelines which are likely to include advice to editors about the courses they might follow when lapses occur among their staff.

The Guardian has had a personal shares register for its financial journalists for many years. It is simply a book kept by the editor in charge of the department. His predecessor, in 1991, put in the following note: "All staff are expected to list all shares that they own, any transactions in those shares and any other investments which they believe ought to be properly disclosed because of a possible conflict of interest. I should add that it is company policy that while it is acceptable for financial staff members to own shares, it is not acceptable for them to be market traders on a regular basis."

The present editor of the Guardian circulated this note again and endorsed the policy at the beginning of this year. The original note concluded: "We must satisfy the standards of transparency in our affairs which we demand of others."

Some areas are more transparent than others. Parliamentary journalists, for example, have, since 1985, had to make a simple declaration of all outside interests relevant to their work at Westminster. Most interests are declared as "none", or occasional freelance broadcasting and journalism.

You may inspect this register for yourself on the internet. Go to www.parliament.uk then select "index", then the letter "R", and then "Register of Journalists' Interests." This register is kept on behalf of the parliamentary commissioner for standards. Not all parliamentary journalists appear to be aware that it is available for open inspection.

Until the publication of fuller guidelines next year, the Guardian's journalists are invited to register any relevant interests with the managing editor of the paper. Freelances should declare relevant interests to their commissioning editors.

I shall try to keep you up to date on developments. By the way, I have bought tickets in the sleaze raffle. Do you think that is all right?

 Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Take me to your black Madonna

fields.headline: Take me to your black Madonna
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
While the rest of the world was trying to blag tickets to see Madonna in Brixton, writer Bonnie Greer was on a different type of Madge-quest. The first installment of a two-parter, In Search of the Black Madonna (Radio 4), broadcast yesterday, was a revelation of how to do a personal pilgrimage in a secular, uncaring world.

Greer grew up a Catholic in Chicago, leaving the church after her first communion. "Why are there no black saints?" she had asked herself, quite reasonably, in a church stuffed to the gills with colour-blind religious icono- graphy. (This is so much more impressive a question to ask than my own during first communion - whether David King and I could get into Saturday Night Fever at the ABC down the road afterwards, despite the fact we were years too young and I was wearing a small wedding dress.)

Later, as an adult, a chance encounter in an Athens church with a statue of a black Madonna prompted Greer to ask whether she would have stayed with her faith if, as a child, she had seen symbols that related to her world. Then, taking a short cut through the All Saints Church in London's Notting Hill one day, she spied a statue of Our Lady of Walsingham, patron saint of English Catholics. "And she's the colour of my mom, she's brown skin," thrills Greer.

These are the facts with which she begins her quest. More murder mystery than religious sermon, Greer challenges experts and men of the church to explain the concealment of this black figure. The Notting Hill statue has been replaced with a smaller, lighter-skinned version and the priest there tells Greer the other never existed; many black Madonnas, like the one at Walsingham, have been anglicised, painted white, given blonde hair. Some priests take them from public view and "keep them in their bedrooms". Yes, I know.

What made this an extraordinary programme was Greer's personal - and clearly political - investment in the subject. Her account was both elegant and jumpy ("Am I imagining this? Am I going crazy?" she says at one point), and she switched between intellectual reflection and instinctive, unscripted moments. "Oh wow, mao, well, well, well," she blurts out on realising the original Notting Hill statue is missing. Best of all were the twee, otherworldly types having to talk about blackness with a fiercely sharp black woman, not afraid to ask why and how colour had been drained from her early faith.

The third and final part of A Short History of Darkness (Radio 4) - poetic reflections on our fear of the dark - made spooky listening. It featured poems about darkness, recollections of being too frightened to go up to bed at night, and a theoretical astronomer muttering darkly on about "dark matter". A woman confessed to being frightened of foghorns, and sounded irrevocably wounded by the fear. A quirky, small joy, it left me pondering whether people in bungalows have an equivalent of "going up to bed" terror.

They would have if any members of The Moral Maze (Radio 4) team were waiting for them. This week's thing-to-be-extreme-about was the over- the-counter availability of the morning after pill. The problem wasn't so much their ludicrous takes on the subject, though being told that anything other than "trothful intercourse" is "evil" did have me groaning, head in hands.

Nor was the problem having countless old men (none of whom I presume have sampled the delights of the drug) talking about what women should and shouldn't do. No, the problem was that the subject matter couldn't help but make you think about getting evilly jiggy with the panel members, especially with David Starkey going on about "positions we might adopt". Eugh! Hand tapes of The Moral Maze out in playgrounds and watch those pregnancy rates tumble.

fields.headline: Giorgio's new emporium
fields.standfirst: The Guggenheim has given itself over to Armani.  Michael Ellison  despairs
fields.trailText: The Guggenheim has given itself over to Armani. Michael Ellison despairs
fields.body:
The Kandinskys are shown to perfect effect in the discreet lighting, likewise the Picassos, Van Goghs and Monets. So all is well in the gift shop at Frank Lloyd Wright's Guggenheim museum in New York. All is well, too, at the box office of the institution that showed how to get them through the door when it gave the world The Art of the Motorcycle two and a half years ago. Now it has moved on - from oily rags to glad rags. Specifically, the main galleries at the Guggenheim, once home to 20th-century painting, are the latest franchise in the Giorgio Armani chain.

The Guggenheim is becoming something of a franchise itself, with its flagship on Fifth Avenue, another in SoHo, one more Frank Gehry job going through the planning hoops on the Lower East Side, Gehry's much-admired previous work in Bilbao, satellites in Berlin and Venice, a new gallery being built in Las Vegas, and the prospect of museums in Rio de Janeiro and a second Brazilian city. Impressive, even if the latest artist to show on Fifth Avenue has this many shops in the US alone.

"The Guggenheim is no longer a serious art institution," argues Hilton Kramer, art critic of the New York Observer. "It has no aesthetic standards and no aesthetic agenda. It has completely sold out to a mass-market mentality that regards the museum's own art collection as an asset to be exploited for commercial purposes." By these standards, the Guggenheim is not alone. The Brooklyn Museum of Art is running a hip hop exhibition, Boston has one on guitar design, and even the august Metropolitan Museum of New York had a show last year that venerated rock stars' stage kit.

No one suggests that Sean "Puffy" Coombes, the estate of Leo Fender or the designer of Tina Turner's miniskirts resorted to supra-artistic techniques to help their works find a platform in unaccustomed surroundings. But Armani, whose exhibition of 400 outfits runs until January 17, is different. Thomas Krens, the museum's director, says he approached the designer about the enterprise, but agrees that word of an Armani pledge of $15m is not far off the mark. "A friendship has grown between us and Mr Armani, and he and his Italian corporation have indicated significant interest in aiding the museum in some of its projects," says Krens. "It's a non-story. Who do you get to support an institution? People who have relationships with it."

Armani's relationship with the people who wear his clothes is a big part of the Guggenheim show - how he makes them feel powerful, casual, loose and structured, all at the same time. Never mind if you start thinking after a while that when you've seen one suit, you've seen them all. This is like an Oscars award ceremony where the stars sent along their outfits while they stayed at home and watched it on television. Armani's connection with the movies is strong, as we are often reminded, starting with American Gigolo, starring Richard Gere. "The seductive elegance of the anti-hero's clothing became legend," are the words chosen to explain the significance of a crumpled jacket. The exhibition guide reiterates: "The film... marked the beginning of a long and fruitful history of collaboration on films, most recently John Singleton's remake of Shaft."

The fact that neither of these exactly rivals Citizen Kane passes without mention, submerged in the lustre of the garments and their peripherals. There are pictures by 25 photographers, film of models on the catwalk, advertising campaigns through the years and descriptions of collections couched in language that makes you wonder whether one might be described as a cheeky little number. But all these are outdone by the room given over to the stars, where, for example, the 1988 number run up for Eric Clapton is presented with the kind of reverence the man himself reserves for his guitar.

Robbed of their contents, these clothes do reveal something about the stars for whom they were created: the size of their celebrity is often in inverse proportion to their physique. Matt Damon appears to be one of the few fully-grown men in the movies. The suits are mounted on a plinth several inches off the ground, and still Russell Crowe barely makes it to the height of the average shoulder. Robert De Niro is granted a couple of inches more than the rest between the platform and the bottom of his trouser legs, to give the impression that he is merely small. That, perhaps, is the height of fashion.

fields.headline: The one with the squealing
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
All the girls in the studio audience squealed when Monica finally accepted Chandler's proposal at the end of the Friends double bill (Channel 4).

Brought to fever pitch by the preceding shenanigans (boy nearly lost girl in an ill-advised practical joke), they let it all out in one collective falsetto shriek, possibly provoked by surprise as much as relief. Why would Monica (Courteney Cox Arquette) choose Chandler (Matthew Perry) over Richard (Tom Selleck), who had so unexpectedly come back into her life with an offer of marriage on a plate? Financial and aesthetic reasons can't have come into it: Selleck may be twice Perry's age, but he is almost indecently well-preserved, which is more than can be said for his junior love rival. And you only had to take one look around his luxurious pad to see that this was a man who could provide for a girl. Richard offered shelter from the storms of life against his barrel chest, which we know from all those episodes of Magnum to be lavishly forested. Chandler, meanwhile, discoursed disagreeably on the sex life of pigs, leaving the audience to supply its own cruel, weight-related jokes.

This being telly, of course, Monica chose Chandler - "I can't believe I was so lucky to fall in love with my best friend," she explained, while the rest of the gang looked on dewy-eyed. So knowing is Friends that they even slipped in a couple of sly references to Chandler's dubious sexuality ("he is one who is unlikely to take a wife," stammered Joey). Mind you, nobody seeing Chandler in his jock wardrobe, with "longish" slicked-back hair, could ever imagine that he was anything other than 100% heterosexual.

After that embarrassing phase in the third or fourth series when famous guest stars outnumbered the core cast, Friends has returned to its original business of daft one-liners and underplayed erotic frisson. The cast is still as adorable as ever and, in David Schwimmer's case, so over-adorable one can only meditate violence. It is awesome to behold people that famous actually bothering to walk, talk, learn lines and turn up at the studio on time. There is yet to be an episode where Phoebe slurs her words or Joey is inexplicably absent. A scene in which Rachel complained about her lack of a husband gained immeasurably from the knowledge that Jennifer Aniston possesses the trophy husband of all time in the chiselled form of Brad Pitt. She didn't exactly wink at the camera; she didn't have to.

If you find yourself temporarily unpartnered, you could do a lot worse than head off to your nearest ceroc club, where you can dance with 20 different partners a night and yet maintain a spotless reputation. Ceroc is a user-friendly form of jiving attempted by ballerina Deborah Bull in Travels with My Tutu (BBC2), a pleasant new series in which the bouncing Bull gives up the day job at the Royal Ballet to move to some different beats. Jive kicked off the series and, during her excursion into the world of partnered dancing, Bull rubbed shoulders with a selection of greasy rockers, ageing Betty Grables and wannabe hair hoppers. At the Leopard Lounge in London she cerocked the night away with a succession of highly eligible young men; at the 100 Club she mastered the more complex moves of the lindyhop with sickening ease and seemed, by the end of the show, to have developed the ability to fly. "The principle is to keep your legs under your body," explained Simon, her lindyhop instructor, but Bull's limbs seemed determined to describe elegant arcs at points well above her head.

Veteran jivers reminisced about the rituals of preparation - four hours in the bathroom perfecting the Betty Grable hairstyle, soaking their petticoats in sugar water for extra stiffness - but it was all worth it when a boy called Lenny Rubberlegs flung you over his head and showed your knickers to the world. Rockabilly dance teacher Kav Kavanagh sported the greatest quiff this side of Chris Isaak, and had the muscles and tattoos to match it; he was also a demon on the floor, flinging his partner through the air like a rag doll. "That's straight out of Giselle!" gasped Deborah Bull, seeing a chance to score a few rock chick points, only to end up with her gusset indecently entangled in Kav's crowning glory. Next week she's going to try belly dancing, which will be difficult for a woman with no discernible belly.

fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The village we live in is built on rock with two main streams flowing through it. They start as springs on the Preseli hills gathering more water as they tumble down to the river Brynberian, which joins the Nevern to enter the sea at Newport. The chapel stands on the highest point. The houses are nearly all old. Our garden has one of the streams as a boundary. It runs in a deep channel down to the road, where a bridge has been replaced by a culvert under the tarmacadam.

There's been one flood in living memory: we hadn't kept the culvert clear. But this year we've had another surprise. There were village wells before the water was piped here. Long ago, a footbridge was built over one of the streams for easy access to a well. It was made of two boulders with pieces of thick slate taking it from bank to boulders to bank. This autumn the bridge has been swept away by the water, the stones carried down stream. And still the weather is wet and windy. However, some birds are using it for fun. The correspondence columns of British Birds have reported both carrion crows and rooks hanging down or somersaulting on electricity wires. They're enjoying themselves.

This autumn we've seen flocks of rooks rocketing into the air, like humans into a rough sea, to play with the air waves. One bird was flying backwards. It knew where it wanted to land and was able to dance with the wind to get there. Rooks gather on the chapel green to use the great wetness for more practical pursuits. This land is a kind of rough pasture although it is cut in the summer. There are wild flowers like bulbous and meadow buttercups.

Following research done at Denmark Farm Conservation Centre near Lampeter, I would guess that if you stood on the green wearing size 10 shoes you could have 1,106 invertebrates below you. On a rye grass field the equivalent number would be 86. The rooks peck and munch, joined by magpies and jackdaws. It's the time for cornucopia.

fields.headline: Belligerent romantic
fields.standfirst: Fifty years after his death at 94, George Bernard Shaw is the least fashionable of playwrights and is vilified for his politics. But Michael Holroyd, his biographer, argues that he has been unfairly demonised and calls for a Shavian revival
fields.trailText: Fifty years after his death at 94, George Bernard Shaw is the least fashionable of playwrights and is vilified for his politics. But Michael Holroyd, his biographer, argues that he has been unfairly demonised and calls for a Shavian revival
fields.body:
This year Bernard Shaw is 144. It is of course, no age at all for the author of Back to Methuselah. That cycle of plays, searching like a Hubble telescope for some distant gleam of optimism, reaches forward to the year 31920, when human beings regularly live for several hundred years. But if GBS (he hated the name George and never used it) is nowhere near that Shavian prime yet, he is nevertheless in his element as the most unfashionable playwright and political thinker of today.

For he was, like Ibsen, a sort of devil's advocate who, in the words of William Archer, Ibsen's English translator and Shaw's friend, "goes about picking holes in every 'well-known fact'". He will not allow complacency; he hates secondhand opinions; he attacks fashion; he continually challenges and unsettles, questioning and provoking us even when he is making us laugh. And he is still at it. No cliché or truism of contemporary life is entirely safe from him.

Shaw began this work soon after arriving in England at 20 - in the words of the Irish poet AE, "as the last saint sent out from Ireland to save the world". Apparently rising above his first 20 years of unhappiness and neglect in Dublin, and soldiering through the next 20 years of failure as a novelist and playwright in London, he set himself up in the last quarter of the 19th century as a professional man of genius. "England had conquered Ireland," he explained, "so there was nothing for it but to come over and conquer England."

By the time Shaw and his wife Charlotte came to live in the Hert fordshire village of Ayot St Lawrence in 1906, GBS was 50 and gained a good deal of notoriety as an experimental dramatist and political pamphleteer. Whatever his subject, he advocated change.

His arrival at the rectory was like the landing of a meteor. What on earth did this hitherto undisturbed agricultural community make of him? Those who had the vote were, in the main, Tory voters and they did not hold much with going to frivolous places like theatres. So they would have known GBS during those years before the first world war mainly through the newspapers.

In his charming play, Village Wooing, partly inspired by Ayot St Lawrence, Shaw wrote: "You must always let yourself think about everything. And you must think about everything as it is, not as it is talked about... We should never accept anything reverently without asking it a great many very searching questions." But this is what the villagers objected to. Surely there were some things best left alone, some things that did not bear thinking of, and a whole lot of things that, even in a democracy, you could never affect. The trouble about GBS was that he turned up every stone until there was no place on which you could safely place your foot. Think of everything in this searching and critical way and you would go mad.And certainly there were some people who thought GBS was mad.

His views on education, for example, like his views on punishment - on all discipline apparently short of capital punishment itself, which he seemed to advocate as a sort of merciful euthanasia - would surely lead to chaos and anarchy if they were ever put into practice. He thought England's public schools for rich private people so socially divisive that he would like to see them all razed to the ground and the ground itself sown with salt. He thought the arts more important than the teaching of Latin, a thoroughly dead language that could surely be advocated only by those with a "vested interest in torture". Children, he concluded, "should be compelled to do without adult guidance, and depend on themselves to the full limit of their resourcefulness".

Herbert Gladstone, secretary of state for home affairs, gave him the opportunity of a gloriously Shavian rejoinder when Gladstone claimed that this intake of nourishment was not unpleasant. In a letter to the Times Shaw invited Gladstone to dinner. The Fabian Society, he promised, would give him a banquet. "The rarest wines and delicacies shall be provided absolutely regardless of expense," he wrote.

"The only condition we shall make is that Mr Herbert Gladstone shall partake through the nose; and that a cinematograph machine be at work at the time registering for the public satisfaction the waterings of his mouth, the smackings of his lips, and other unmistakable symptoms of luxurious delight."

Money should never be allowed to buy better health, longer life.

That, quintessentially, was Shaw's socialist programme. And he was continually going round the country proclaiming it in public speeches. In May 1906, he spoke in Manchester. He vigorously attacked vivisection, Shakespeare and charity (Can the Poor be Saved by the Pity of the Rich?). He championed photography and the value of swearing. He expounded the mysteries of "socialism for millionaires" - what would later be called "champagne socialism" - and he extolled the hygienic advantages of cremation over earth burial.

He also attacked Christmas, representing himself as an admirer of Scrooge and the enemy of Santa Claus. The running battle between Shaw and Christmas lasted some 60 years, GBS having declared war on this "orgy" and "nuisance" in the 1880s. But the Court theatre was never a commercial success and Shaw himself was hardly recognised as a playwright by the critics.

After he had written half a dozen plays, Max Beerbohm concluded that to produce even one of them "would be almost impossible at any ordinary theatre". And yet, in some perverse way, Shaw appeared to prosper. It was as if he got nourishment from all this invective and abuse. The public loved it and it ran from 1911 to 1913 - that is, for more than 600 performances. The next year, following its premiere in Vienna, Pygmalion opened in London. So, to the confusion of his critics, Shaw in his 60s became the most famous and successful playwright in the world. Before the war, he had been "one of the leaders in the revolutionary movement of our youth", Leonard Woolf wrote in his autobiography. By the mid-30s, Woolf was writing in the New Statesman "There is no living man to whom the generations which came to maturity between 1900 and 1914 owed so much as to Mr Shaw... Who are these barbarians? Are they the theatre critics themselves? What they are claiming in their newspaper columns is that GBS is the barbarian.

When Sam Walters staged The Simpleton of the Unexpected Isles in the mid-1990s, the critics, realising that they were on unfamiliar territory, panicked. What were they to do? What they did was to read Shaw's preface, though not his warning that these prefaces had nothing to do with his plays. "It is all more harmless Shavian fun you might think," objected Charles Spencer in the Daily Telegraph, until he added darkly, "you read the preface." Once you read that you had the benefit of becoming (I use his word) "nauseated". He didn't review the preface, he reviewed the play.

Benedict Nightingale had also read the preface. Writing in the Times, he drew his trusty sword of truth and struck a high moral note. Though Shaw's play was witty and diverting, GBS was actually doling out "intellectual poison and death", he wrote. He, and John Peter in the Sunday Times, reminded readers that Shaw had visited Soviet Russia in 1931. They did not mention his visits to India and Ceylon or his romance with Molly Tompkins on the Italian lakes where the real provenance of the play lies. They did not mention the literary parallels with Gilbert and Sullivan's Mikado or Shakespeare's The Tempest.

They seized instead on two non-playwrights, Hitler and Stalin. "No wonder the play went down well in Nazi Germany," wrote Michael Coveney, the Observer critic. But The Simpleton did not do well in Germany - it was never shown in Berlin. In fact a number of Shaw's plays were banned in Nazi Germany. His translator was Jewish and the Nazi theoretician Alfred Rosenberg placed Shaw among "the army of half-bred artists" that opposed the "revived racial spirit".

In the late 19th and 20th centuries, eugenics was debated as heatedly as Darwinism itself. If you take some statements out of their historical context they can sound quite sinister. Let me give you one quote, from 1906, the year Shaw went to Ayot:

"The unnatural and increasingly rapid growth of the feeble-minded and insane classes, coupled as it is with steady restriction among all the thrifty, energetic and superior stocks, constitutes a national and race danger which it is impossible to exaggerate... the source from which the stream of madness is fed should be cut off and sealed off...."

This does sound unacceptable today. In fact it was written by Hitler's and Stalin's arch-enemy, Winston Churchill. What Shaw actually believed was that we must rely on sexual attraction to guide us, and that the procreation of children should not be confined within classes or religions or races. In other words he believed in the benefits of mixed marriages. But we feel the need to demonise him, as a previous generation felt the need to criminalise Oscar Wilde. It is not that he didn't say stupid or insensitive things. He knew this as well as anyone, but believed in the right of the intellectual to test any idea to destruction and pleaded with critics not to judge him by what he called his "imbecilities".

But some academic authors cannot resist imbecilities. Like blind pedestrians, they follow, as if believing that Shaw himself was guilty of the same deeds as Hitler and Stalin, or that these dictators were acting on his orders. In fact, Shaw made clear that it would have been better for the world if such people had never existed. But it was foolish, he added, to believe that history had not been dominated by them or that "we were somehow living beyond history now in a land ruled by our private moralities". What Shaw wrote about Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany was part of his tactical foreign policy, a political treatment for national paranoia and aggressive inferiority. But his language was darkened by the awful metaphors of his imagination.

That imagination was undoubtedly affected by those first 20 years of neglect and unhappiness in Dublin, and the next 20 years of failure and poverty in London over all of which he appeared to rise on the wings of comedy. His prefaces are sometimes comparable to the horrific satires of Jonathan Swift and, fuelled by the same disgust with human beings, the concentrated pessimism of Samuel Beckett.

It has been Shaw's fate to be assailed by literal-minded academics, championed by humourless scholars and presented on stage by timid matinee directors. But there are at last signs of a change. Writing of Heartbreak House in 1997, Susannah Clapp wrote in the Observer: "The main strength of David Hare's production is an unexpected one: it transmits what Shaw is always accused of lacking - force of feeling." The following year, reviewing The Doctor's Dilemma at the Almeida, Michael Billington wrote: "We have, I suspect , done Shaw a grave injustice. We have always treated him as a cerebral comedian or didactic dramatist. But... Shaw was a passionate writer obsessed by the power of romance over realism." If we can follow that romance and discard the didacticism we will have recovered a major dramatist for this new century.

fields.headline: This grim old century
fields.trailText: And so we enter the final days of this grim old century. By which, of course, I mean the 20th century, in which Smallweed, along with everyone else who is literate and numerate, has been living all this year. Few serious people - not even the Tory ministers who set up the celebrations - still cling to the foolish notion that the 21st century and third millennium began on January 1 this year.
fields.body:
And so we enter the final days of this grim old century. By which, of course, I mean the 20th century, in which Smallweed, along with everyone else who is literate and numerate, has been living all this year. Few serious people - not even the Tory ministers who set up the celebrations - still cling to the foolish notion that the 21st century and third millennium began on January 1 this year.

Only this week I opened a book, called Marking Time - The Epic Quest To Invent the Perfect Calendar, by Duncan Steel of Salford University, which has this to say on the subject: "Let us mention a point which relates to people's misconceptions about when the new millennium begins. That is, strictly, with the start of the year 2001, because until then the full 2,000 years have not elapsed since the zero point of the dating system (the instant of midnight between December 31 1BC, and January 1 AD1), arbitrary though that may be."

Exactly. Even Pope John Paul II, it seems, is fallible in this instance, having fixed the year of jubilee 12 months too early. Steel also notes, by the way, that Russia's October revolution took place in November, and - by implication - that the Act of Settlement 1701, which has taken such a drubbing in this newspaper recently, is really the Act of Settlement 1700. This is because in those days our year began on March 25, and the act became law in the bit of 1701 which belonged under that system to 1700.

This has been a great week for small weeds: or to be more particular for the Arabidopsis thaliana, the mild uncelebrated weed which has given the world such a breakthrough in the understanding of plants. I hope that readers, in toasting the new millennium two weeks from now, will couple with it the name of this new benefactor of humankind; and that those who are pregnant in the year 2001 will consider giving their daughters the name Thaliana. Arabidopsis might just about do for their sons.

And now, cricket. (Those readers who sometimes complain when I write about sport should look away now.) The failure of the Surrey leg spinner Ian Salisbury to make any impact in the test series just concluded against Pakistan came as no surprise to Smallweed. As I have noted before, it is almost always a mistake for selectors to pick players named after cathedral cities.

The one exception was Arthur Shrewsbury, who played 23 tests for England in the closing years of the last (ie 19th) century. Asked to name the batsman he most admired among those he had played with (apart, of course, from himself), WG Grace is said to have responded: "Give me Arthur".

But the Hon CJ Coventry (Worcestershire) lasted only two tests - against South Africa in 1882 - while AP Wells (Sussex) played only one. One would like to believe that those at the Oval would never forget what happened to Wells in 1995, when at 33, with 15 summers of country cricket behind him, he was at last given a chance to bat for his country, only to be caught off his very first ball. But in fact great swaths of the crowd were far too busy chomping and slurping to take any notice. There was no England second innings and Wells was not picked again.

I'm sure I am not alone in finding William Hague's assault on the Macpherson report curiously incomplete. Why does he fail to mention, as evidence of the depression of police morale, the fate in the past two seasons of the Metropolitan police rugby XV? In 1999-2000, their first full season after Macpherson pronounced, they lost every one of their 26 games in division 4 south, scoring only 223 points while conceding 1,308 (an average of 50 per match) and were relegated. "They struggled on some days to field a decent side," the official RFU directory observes with just a touch of the otiose. And even now that they are down in London division one they continue to struggle. They have lost every one of their 11 games so far this season, scoring 82 points and conceding 355. As the ancients used so wisely to say: "Post hoc propter hoc."

A writer to the Times says he is baffled by the domination of contralto solos in oratorio by counter-tenors. In concerts and recordings of all kinds, he says, the contralto voice is being replaced by the peculiar sound of males singing falsetto. "Have contralto singers," he asks, "been sent into exile?"

An old musicologist writes: These words strike a chill in the hearts of old musicologists such as myself, recalling as they do the dreadful events of the year 1927, when one by one basset horn players went missing from most of our principal orchestras. The rest of a band would turn up for a concert to find the desk assigned to the basset horn empty, and subsequent calls to his home would reveal that the player had disappeared.

Only strenuous representations by the prime minister, Stanley Baldwin - no mean performer himself, by the way, upon the bassoon - pleading the need to avert a panic, kept this scandal out of the press. The crisis grew worse when amateur orchestras in places as far apart as Blackburn and Lostwithiel, normally equipped with such players, began to report them missing.

Fortunately, a Scotland Yard detective, whiling away an evening in Bavaria eavesdropping on the gossip in a local bierkeller, picked up a conversation which led the force to resolve the mystery. After months of assiduous probing by detectives in lederhosen, the missing musicians were traced to the dungeon of a high-steepled castle on the shining, sinuous road between Rosenheim and Garmisch-Partenkirchen, from which, sobbing and shaking but tootling bravely away on their precious instruments, they were brought back to liberty.

A rich and eccentric count called von Schnauffenhausen had, it transpired, composed a concerto for 83 basset horns which no orchestra in the region could play. He had therefore resorted to kidnapping potential soloists, both from Britain and from countries such as Liechtenstein and Andorra, where, as he supposed, their absence would hardly be noticed. Could it be that a similar fiendish plot has now been laid to seize and incarcerate British contraltos?

A pedant writes: I mistrust this story. It does not appear in Grove.

An old musicologist wearily comments: That is the trouble with Grove. "Insufficiently eclectic" is the term I think I would use.

Few serious people - not even the Tory ministers who set up the celebrations - still cling to the foolish notion that the 21st century and third millennium began on January 1 this year. Only this week I opened a book, called Marking Time - The Epic Quest To Invent the Perfect Calendar, by Duncan Steel of Salford University, which has this to say on the subject: "Let us mention a point which relates to people's misconceptions about when the new millennium begins. That is, strictly, with the start of the year 2001, because until then the full 2,000 years have not elapsed since the zero point of the dating system (the instant of midnight between December 31 1BC, and January 1 AD1), arbitrary though that may be." Exactly. Even Pope John Paul II, it seems, is fallible in this instance, having fixed the year of jubilee 12 months too early. Steel also notes, by the way, that Russia's October revolution took place in November, and - by implication - that the Act of Settlement 1701, which has taken such a drubbing in this newspaper recently, is really the Act of Settlement 1700. This is because in those days our year began on March 25, and the act became law in the bit of 1701 which belonged under that system to 1700. This has been a great week for small weeds: or to be more particular for the Arabidopsis thaliana, the mild uncelebrated weed which has given the world such a breakthrough in the understanding of plants. I hope that readers, in toasting the new millennium two weeks from now, will couple with it the name of this new benefactor of humankind; and that those who are pregnant in the year 2001 will consider giving their daughters the name Thaliana. Arabidopsis might just about do for their sons. And now, cricket. (Those readers who sometimes complain when I write about sport should look away now.) The failure of the Surrey leg spinner Ian Salisbury to make any impact in the test series just concluded against Pakistan came as no surprise to Smallweed. As I have noted before, it is almost always a mistake for selectors to pick players named after cathedral cities. The one exception was Arthur Shrewsbury, who played 23 tests for England in the closing years of the last (ie 19th) century. Asked to name the batsman he most admired among those he had played with (apart, of course, from himself), WG Grace is said to have responded: "Give me Arthur". But the Hon CJ Coventry (Worcestershire) lasted only two tests - against South Africa in 1882 - while AP Wells (Sussex) played only one. One would like to believe that those at the Oval would never forget what happened to Wells in 1995, when at 33, with 15 summers of country cricket behind him, he was at last given a chance to bat for his country, only to be caught off his very first ball. But in fact great swaths of the crowd were far too busy chomping and slurping to take any notice. There was no England second innings and Wells was not picked again. I'm sure I am not alone in finding William Hague's assault on the Macpherson report curiously incomplete. Why does he fail to mention, as evidence of the depression of police morale, the fate in the past two seasons of the Metropolitan police rugby XV? In 1999-2000, their first full season after Macpherson pronounced, they lost every one of their 26 games in division 4 south, scoring only 223 points while conceding 1,308 (an average of 50 per match) and were relegated. "They struggled on some days to field a decent side," the official RFU directory observes with just a touch of the otiose. And even now that they are down in London division one they continue to struggle. They have lost every one of their 11 games so far this season, scoring 82 points and conceding 355. As the ancients used so wisely to say: "Post hoc propter hoc." A writer to the Times says he is baffled by the domination of contralto solos in oratorio by counter-tenors. In concerts and recordings of all kinds, he says, the contralto voice is being replaced by the peculiar sound of males singing falsetto. "Have contralto singers," he asks, "been sent into exile?" An old musicologist writes: These words strike a chill in the hearts of old musicologists such as myself, recalling as they do the dreadful events of the year 1927, when one by one basset horn players went missing from most of our principal orchestras. The rest of a band would turn up for a concert to find the desk assigned to the basset horn empty, and subsequent calls to his home would reveal that the player had disappeared. Only strenuous representations by the prime minister, Stanley Baldwin - no mean performer himself, by the way, upon the bassoon - pleading the need to avert a panic, kept this scandal out of the press. The crisis grew worse when amateur orchestras in places as far apart as Blackburn and Lostwithiel, normally equipped with such players, began to report them missing. Fortunately, a Scotland Yard detective, whiling away an evening in Bavaria eavesdropping on the gossip in a local bierkeller, picked up a conversation which led the force to resolve the mystery. After months of assiduous probing by detectives in lederhosen, the missing musicians were traced to the dungeon of a high-steepled castle on the shining, sinuous road between Rosenheim and Garmisch-Partenkirchen, from which, sobbing and shaking but tootling bravely away on their precious instruments, they were brought back to liberty. A rich and eccentric count called von Schnauffenhausen had, it transpired, composed a concerto for 83 basset horns which no orchestra in the region could play. He had therefore resorted to kidnapping potential soloists, both from Britain and from countries such as Liechtenstein and Andorra, where, as he supposed, their absence would hardly be noticed. Could it be that a similar fiendish plot has now been laid to seize and incarcerate British contraltos? A pedant writes: I mistrust this story. It does not appear in Grove. An old musicologist wearily comments: That is the trouble with Grove. "Insufficiently eclectic" is the term I think I would use.

fields.headline: Why can't Peter come out with an open secret?
fields.trailText: This week we transmitted the last in the present  series of It's A Funny Old World, which is a jokey  political diary on Radio 4. One of the sequences took  place at a meeting of the Tories' Centre for Policy  Studies, in which they debated whether the party  should be more inclusive or should hold to its ancient  verities.
fields.body:
This week we transmitted the last in the present series of It's A Funny Old World, which is a jokey political diary on Radio 4. One of the sequences took place at a meeting of the Tories' Centre for Policy Studies, in which they debated whether the party should be more inclusive or should hold to its ancient verities.

In practice, it turned into a long discussion of gay rights, and I must say that these, by now somewhat elderly, young fogies repeatedly rolling the word "homo-sex-ual" round their mouths was very funny. That, and their obsessional hatred for Steve Norris.

However, we couldn't use the extracts because someone at the meeting denounced the cabinet for containing "three sodomites". Since only Chris Smith and Nick Brown are officially "out", the third had by implication to be Peter Mandelson. Astonishingly, the BBC ban on any reference to his sexuality is still in place even though he openly lives with and escorts in public his partner, Reinaldo da Silva.

So in other words, Mr Mandelson is overt, but not out. We couldn't use the item.

Is it any of our business? Perhaps not, though there is no question of hypocrisy here, since Mr Mandelson has never pretended to be heterosexual. Possibly sexual orientation should never be mentioned, under any circumstances.

On the other hand, why should he persist in pretending that something he is perfectly open about is a secret? As usual Mr Mandelson - who won a lengthy apology from the Today programme over his alleged remarks about George W Bush this week - has the best of all possible worlds.

He is, for some unfathomable reason, able to bend the BBC to his will almost any time.

Just when you think nothing more can go wrong for the Tories, their biggest celebrity fan, the comedian Jim Davidson, has confessed to going back on the bottle.

 An alcoholic, Davidson had managed to stop drinking since 1994. However, he was so smitten by a TV presenter called Suzi Perry that he started drinking again, in the - as it turned out, vain - hope that alcohol might lure her into bed. "I started cracking open the champagne, fell into a bottle and stayed there. I was absolutely smashed. I woke up the next morning with my first hangover since 1994," he said.

Wonderfully, the same issue of the Sun which contains Mr Davidson's confession also includes an ad for used cars in which he enjoins readers: "Park your eyes on all these lovely cars. There's over 1,300 for you to choose from!" But it looks as if he can't drive them.

Mr Davidson did the fund-raising speech at the party conference in Bournemouth this year, and is proud of the number of similar events at which he appears round the country. Of course, since he is no longer married to his fourth wife, his failed attempt to bed curvy Suzi is in no way an assault on William Hague's policy of family values. What a splendid role model for the party he is!

 I popped for a takeaway at our local Thai restaurant this week, and saw a new sign: "We proudly accept Visa cards". I wasn't sure what that meant until I offered my Visa card to pay for the meal.

The owner gazed at it for a long time. He handed me the chit to sign, I noticed a manly tear in the fellow's eye.

"When I came to this country," he said, "I had nothing. Nothing, but the burning desire to do better for myself and my family. For years I worked round the clock, taking two, sometimes three jobs, scarcely seeing my children. And now ... and now, it is all worthwhile. I have been handed a Visa card!" His voice tailed away as he choked back the sobs.

No, of course he didn't. But what kind of idiots do the Visa people take us for?

 The same kind of idiots who are supposed to respond to the sexy ad for Bordeaux wines, I suppose. This is the one that shows a woman in red underwear leaning erotically over her man, while they both glug claret, getting in the mood for something which may or may not be a game of ludo. The poster appeared earlier this year and has just been revived. The Bordelais, possibly the most snobbish people left in France, must be at their wits' end if they're resorting to that ancient standby of the desperate adman: our product will get you laid.

I was reminded of this by a fascinating article in the new edition of the American magazine Atlantic Monthly. It's about Robert Parker, the Maryland writer who is overwhelmingly the most influential wine critic in the world. A two-point rise in Parker's ratings, marks out of 100, can make a modest wine pro ducer into a millionaire. Parker has no truck with the mumbo-jumbo many French vignerons use to disguise the fact that a lot of their wines are thin, tasteless and overpriced.

A lot of French winemakers consequently loathe Parker. They've tried abusing him in the press, suing him, and on one occasion a chateau-owner stood by while a dog chewed at his leg. But there's little they can do. Consumers now trust Parker more than the winemakers, and with 25% worldwide overproduction of wine they'll need more than a few posters of young women in their smalls.

 At this time of year, some shops have Father Christmas in the window, his sleigh full of goodies. Some show Dickensian domestic scenes. Others are full of polystyrene snowmen in cotton wool blizzards. Selfridge's in Oxford Street has, for some unimaginable reason, filled its window with models of Michael Fabricant MP. And ho, ho, ho to all of you.

webTitle: Healing young minds scarred by violence

fields.headline: Healing young minds scarred by violence
fields.standfirst:
This month we are highlighting the work of the four charities chosen for our Christmas appeal. Today we look at Refuge and the effects of domestic violence

Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: The gnawing fear in the pit of her stomach was so overwhelming it made her gasp for breath as soon as the school bell rang to signal home time.
fields.body:
The gnawing fear in the pit of her stomach was so overwhelming it made her gasp for breath as soon as the school bell rang to signal home time.

For seven-year-old Molly this was the terrifying hour of reckoning she faced daily, when she would discover whether her mother had survived without her.

"I didn't cope much at school. I didn't use to get on with my work. I used to daydream all the time about what sort of stuff my dad could be doing to my mum. I was frightened, thinking that he could be beating her and hitting her with stuff right now. I was afraid he could kill her."

Sitting in her bedroom four years later, at the women's refuge she and her mother now call home, Molly describes the torment she silently endured as a child witnessing domestic violence.

The dread would usually subside when she saw the familiar blue coat hovering near the school gates but as she crossed the playground Molly would try to gauge just how bad the damage had been that day.

"When my dad stabbed my mum with a fork and when he used to punch her a lot, the next day her face would be all swollen, and when we came to the refuge he'd punched her in the eye and she couldn't see properly. That's why she couldn't put her lenses in because it was all big and she had to wear sunglasses and a hat," she murmured.

Molly and her mother Claire arrived at one of Refuge's safe houses a year ago, after fleeing in the middle of the night with few belongings and little money.

With the national charity's help they have built a new life free from abuse and fear, but the emotional scars they bear are not so easy to erase.

Molly, now 11, is among hundreds of thousands of children in Britain who have experienced their father or step- father stabbing, beating, burning, raping or threatening their mother.

Recent figures have shown one in four women will be physically abused by a partner or ex-partner and in nine out of 10 cases of domestic violence, children are in the same or an adjacent room.

Seeing or hearing a life- threatening assault can cause intense fear in a child.

"It made me feel frightened, scared and angry when I used to see mum cry and when I saw her blood and my dad hitting her with weapons and hitting her with his hands. The worst thing was when my dad hit my mum with a gun," Molly said.

In some cases the psychological damage such experiences can cause is long lasting and may lead to post-traumatic stress disorder.

The establishment of a unique children's service at Refuge has begun to address this problem and help children to overcome the trauma of what they have experienced at home.

Since 1995 the refuge-based programme, headed by an educational psychologist, Ruth Aitken, has focused on the psychological effects of violence on children and finding the best means of help and support for each individual. This is the first time child psychologists have worked in refuges anywhere in the world.

Many children like Molly suppress their own feelings and are fearful of telling anyone what is happening.

Refuge's research has found that children react in different ways to their experiences with some presenting an image of coping well and others displaying a range of emotions from anger, irritability, panic and regression to withdrawal, depression, underachievement, self-blame and guilt.

Most children entering the programme, which costs £360,000 a year to run, feel hopeless and sad. Many believe they will never be free of violence and fear. Others are so traumatised that they can only talk about their experiences in the third person.

The children are offered the opportunity to reflect on and make sense of what has happened to them in a safe environ-ment with psychologists and play workers in individual and group settings.

The project also provides nursery care and after school clubs as well as pioneering research into the little known effects of violence on pre-school children. The charity aims to provide the specialist service to every child who is living in a refuge but an acute shortage of funds prevents this from becoming a reality.

As Sandra Horley, chief executive of Refuge, pointed out: "The support we provide is just the beginning. Our services are crucial for the children in our refuges but if we really want to make a difference we have to reach more of them. We also have to get into the school, educate children and emphasise that violent behaviour is not acceptable."

Molly no longer daydreams at school. She was one of the luckier ones. The nightmares and panic attacks she frequently suffered a year ago no longer haunt her.

It is a slow process but, with the help of the children's service, she is gradually beginning to believe that the past is firmly left behind.

"I used to dream my dad was chasing me and my mum down the road. He wanted to kill her. He had a gun, he shot her in the belly and then he turned round and looked at me in a bad way, in an angry and horrible way.

"I'm not frightened any more and the nightmares have stopped. I know he isn't going to be coming here. I'm in the refuge. He won't be able to find us because it's a long way from him or any of my mum's friends or family and they won't tell him where we are."

Molly and Claire are not their real names.

 Refuge 24-hour national domestic violence helpline: 0870 5995443

The Christmas appeal charities: How they help

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.

Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford the fees of commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.
