webTitle: MPs agonise over matters of life and death

fields.headline: MPs agonise over matters of life and death
fields.standfirst:
Pleas from the disabled and ill, charges of Nazism - and then a free vote

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Pleas from the disabled and ill, charges of Nazism - and then a free vote
fields.body:
When an MP who uses a wheelchair because she has an incurable bone disease expresses the hope that a new line of research could help her, another offers to sacrifice two of her embryos, and a third accuses supporters of such research of thinking like Nazis, it is clear that something more than usually fundamental is happening in the Commons.

The question, debated in parliament yesterday and up for a vote on Tuesday, is whether scientists should be able to carry out experiments on a particular kind of human cell in the hope of treating serious degenerative illnesses such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's.

Given that there are trillions of cells in the human body, and we slough off millions of them every day as we shed dead skin, that does not seem so controversial. And it might not be, but for two words intimately linked to the debate: "embryo" and "clone".

The cells in question are human embryonic stem cells, between two and 100 of which make up the human embryo in its first days after conception. Scientists want to see if they can persuade them to grow into replacement components for people whose original cells have failed: to replace nerve cells, for instance, in the brains of Parkinson's sufferers.

The embryos in question are human in potential only. They cannot think or feel. They have no distinct organs. They are trillionths of the size of babies, and are far below the time threshold for abortion. They are surplus to requirements for couples having IVF treatment for infertility; they are already fertilised, and would be destroyed if couples did not give their consent for them to be used for research.

Despite all this, they are still human embryos, and for this reason the Catholic church and the broader anti-abortion lobby is opposed to the rules being changed next week to allow stem-cell research to be widened.

Anne Begg, the Aberdeen South Labour MP who has the bone-softening disease osteoporosis and gets around the Commons in a wheelchair, said it was too late for her to hope for a cure. But "perhaps there may be something in the stem cell research which could help".

Fiona MacTaggart, Labour MP for Slough, suffers from multiple sclerosis, and has been unable to have children. Her speech in the Commons could not have been more personal and poignant.

"At the moment there are two fertilised embryos of mine in a medical facility, which are available for research," she said.

"It is ironic that they could be used in research that could help to deal with my infertility, and not be used in research which could be of help to deal with the thing about which I am more anxious, my multiple sclerosis. Unless we pass these regulations that will be the case for everybody."

The Catholic and anti-abortion movement's insistence that not one human embryonic cell should be sacrificed was put by Edward Leigh, Tory MP for Gainsborough, who described the research as "the killing of innocents".

"The Nazis surely were saying that some humans are sub-human, therefore they are expendable ... it is the same argument. People are arguing that these embryos are sub-human. That is a point of view I reject."

The government is backing the change in the rules, and the human fertilisation and embryology authority, the HFEA, will still have the last word on whether scientists get a research licence.

The parties have given MPs a free vote on the issue, treating it as a matter of individual conscience. The government is likely to get its way, but an energetic constituency-based letter-writing campaign by the anti-abortion movement has alarmed its opponents, who find it harder to rally their foot soldiers.

"It's difficult for a family or an individual to say 'This is a matter of life or death for me,' because at the moment, it's not," said Alastair Kent, head of the Genetic Interest Group, an organisation for genetic disease charities.

"It's a promising avenue of research. It may well lead to treatments which become a matter of life and death, and at that point you'll watch people queuing up to get hold of them."

The "pro-lifers" have some curious allies in their campaign - an offshoot of the environmentalist movement, not normally standing shoulder to shoulder with Catholics and opponents of the right to abortion, is against the change because it sees it as a step towards human cloning.

Dave King, who runs a campaign against genetic engineering, does not object to experiment on stem cells but does not want to see the rules changed until a worldwide ban on human reproductive cloning is in place: something which will be extremely difficult to negotiate and may never happen.

But the rule change as drafted makes no mention of cloning. What's the connection?

Stem cells are so called because they have the potential to grow into any kind of specialised human tissue. As leaves grow off the stem of a plant, chemical messages inside stem cells instruct them to divide into ever more specialised cells, until they have formed cells for the liver, heart, skin, nerve, blood and scores of other tissue types.

If scientists succeed in unravelling the mysteries of those chemical messages they will be able to grow replacement cells for people whose own supply has been destroyed by degenerative disease.

That achievement is still a long way off. But even if researchers get that far, there is another barrier to successful treatment. Cellular spare parts grown from alien cells are likely to be rejected by the immune system.

One way to get around this would be the cloning technique used to create Dolly the sheep: take a human egg, remove its own DNA, insert the nucleus from an adult patient's cell, apply a jolt of electricity, and create a cloned human stem cell. This could then be used to grow replacement cells which would be 100% compatible with the patient's own.

The government points out that, surprisingly, doing this for humans is not actually illegal at the moment, subject to HFEA approval, although no-one has yet applied for a licence. In other words, they say, there is no need to vote on it. But campaigners for a no vote next week maintain that the change in the rules on embryo research would create a huge incentive for scientists to begin this kind of limited human cloning.

The question, debated in parliament yesterday and up for a vote on Tuesday, is whether scientists should be able to carry out experiments on a particular kind of human cell in the hope of treating serious degenerative illnesses such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. Given that there are trillions of cells in the human body, and we slough off millions of them every day as we shed dead skin, that does not seem so controversial. They are trillionths of the size of babies, and are far below the time threshold for abortion. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Lamplugh search fails
fields.body:
Lamplugh search fails

Detectives investigating the abduction and murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh 14 years ago yesterday called off a search of countryside close to a former army barracks and the M5 near Worcester. Police said they were optimistic about finding her body and searches of new sites would begin next month.

Journalist to be questioned

News of the World journalist Paul Lewis is to be questioned by police after apparently trying to breach security surrounding the US presidential jet at Birmingham international airport on Thursday.

Airport sources said he was stopped with an "aviation style" pass.

Police 'chase deaths' up 300%

Deaths during police chases rose by 300% in the year to last March, according to Home Office figures yesterday. Twenty-four people died trying to escape in cars or on motorcycles.

Thirty people intoxicated by alcohol or drugs died as police attended and 14 died from deliberate self-harm. Seven deaths occurred in police stations, compared with 16 the previous year.

Vicar nailed by cross parents

A vicar who upset pupils by saying Father Christmas did not exist said yesterday that he found it hard to believe it was news to anyone. The Rev Clive Evans was criticised by parents of children at Long Buckby junior school, in Northampton.

webTitle: London casino operator facing financial crisis

fields.headline: US pantomime for casino
fields.standfirst: Profits slump at London Clubs as Aladdin proves no treasure trove
fields.trailText: A top London casino operator is facing a financial crisis after running into problems with a big investment in Las Vegas.
fields.body:
A top London casino operator is facing a financial crisis after running into problems with a big investment in Las Vegas.

London Clubs International, which owns the capital's Les Ambassadeurs and St James's clubs, as well as the Sportsman and the Golden Nugget, said the "early under-performance" of its Aladdin resort and casino complex on The Strip in Las Vegas "has led to a significant deferral of cash inflows to the company".

As a result its half-year profits plunged to £800,000 from £8.7m last year and its shares dived 43% to a low of 57.5p. Three years ago the shares were changing hands at 420p.

London Clubs would have breached its banking covenants and has been forced to ask its lenders for a breathing space. Bankers have agreed to relax the covenants until its full-year results next spring.

Yesterday chairman Alan Goodenough said London Clubs would now be exploring financing options, including a rescue rights issue or bringing in a partner. He said the group still had the support of its shareholders, which include Schroders and the Prudential, but "that will be tested severely if we go for a rights issue".

London Clubs had originally planned to put up some $50m for a 25% stake in the 2,600 room Aladdin Hotel and casino. It was the first venture into Las Vegas by a European firm. But costs overran budgets and London Clubs was forced to up its investment to $194m when its partner, a private US property group called Sommer Trust, refused to come up with more cash. London Clubs now has 40% of the project.

"Aladdin was too big a risk for too small a company - it's as simple as that," said Andrew Burnett, leisure analyst at Merrill Lynch. "They should never have got into the project in the first place."

The company could now be a takeover target, but casino takeovers are fraught with difficulties, due to the tough UK gaming laws which regulate who can own casinos.

Mr Burnett added: "They will just have to hope they can stay in business and resist any predatory activity that may start circling them down at these levels because acquiring the company could be an attractive route into Vegas."

Mr Goodenough insists that Aladdin is still an "exciting and important project" with significant long-term value. But he admitted London Clubs had got far deeper into Aladdin than it ever envisaged. "It wasn't what we intended to do," he said. "We would never have done it".

Apart from the development problems, the resort has got off to a slow start, as some of the facilities failed to open on time. Pre-opening expenses were an additional £3.5m and the company's shares of losses since opening totalled £2.5m.

Elsewhere London Clubs' business is performing soundly. Turnover in the last six months was £74.7m, compared to £75.3m last year and operating profit excluding Aladdin was up marginally at £9.43m. Win levels in London were ahead of last year, even though the company sold off one casino - the London Park Tower - in May this year.

The group said that one of its Egyptian casinos in Taba has been affected by unrest in the region, but its operations in Cairo and Beirut are holding up well. It also has developments underway in South Africa and the Bahamas.

fields.headline: A3XX hits orders target
fields.trailText: The formal go-ahead for the Airbus A3XX super-jumbo could come as early as next week after Virgin Atlantic signed a £2.6bn deal to buy six aircraft with an option on another six.
fields.body:
The formal go-ahead for the Airbus A3XX super-jumbo could come as early as next week after Virgin Atlantic signed a £2.6bn deal to buy six aircraft with an option on another six.

The agreement takes the number of firm orders for the aircraft to 50, the target Airbus set for giving the project the green light.

The Airbus supervisory board is due to meet before the end of the year and the question of launch authorisation is expected to be high on the agenda.

Yesterday Airbus chief executive Noël Forgeard dropped a strong hint which way he expected a decision to go: "With 50 orders and many more options from quality customers around the world, Airbus is now in a strong position to launch production of the A3XX."

Virgin chairman Sir Richard Branson said the new aircraft would allow his airline to continue growing despite slot limitations at Heathrow.

"As other carriers are shrinking in size and cutting their network, Virgin Atlantic will be offering passengers more seats on more services to more destinations," he said.

The extra space provided by the A3XX - it has 49% more floor space and 35% more seats than the largest competitor flying today - would be used to provide facilities such as shops, gyms, business centres, beauty parlours and playrooms for children.

Sir Richard said that double beds would be installed for business class passengers. "You can do it on cruise ships, you can do it at home, so why shouldn't you be able to have relationships on planes?" he was quoted as saying yesterday.

Go-ahead for the A3XX would provide a boost for Britain's aircraft industry. Airbus is owned by a combination of the Franco-German-Spanish concern EADS and British Aerospace, with the UK company making the wings for previous Airbus aircraft.

fields.headline: Banks head for Byers showdown
fields.trailText: High street banks were heading for a showdown with the government last night after refusing its final demand to meet the costs of the post office-based universal bank.
fields.body:
High street banks were heading for a showdown with the government last night after refusing its final demand to meet the costs of the post office-based universal bank.

A day of talks between the banks, the Department of Trade and Industry and the Treasury ended without a deal, although the government remains confident of securing agreement before Christmas.

Creation of the bank, which was in the balance last night, is crucial to plans laid out by Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to provide a long-term future for the Post Office.

Whitehall officials said negotiations, some conducted through the British Bankers' Association and some with individual banks, were proving constructive. The tough public stance adopted by the banks was only to be expected at such a delicate stage in negotiations and there was no suggestion of the government threatening punitive action should the plan collapse.

A number of the banks believe they could be faced with the threat of an American-style community investment act in a second Labour term, setting out social responsibili ties, should they continue to refuse to support the project. A windfall tax on the banks is not on the government's agenda.

It is understood that if the DTI decides to press on with the creation of the universal bank, the government could be left with a bill of as much as £350m a year to keep it running.

The universal bank is designed to offer accounts for the 7m or so people who do not have an account but will need one when social security payments are paid directly into banks by 2004.

After months of negotiations and horse trading the govern ment had hoped to clinch a deal by Wednesday, when the heads of the banks are due to meet Mr Byers. The government has promised to cap the annual charge to the banks at £125m and pick up the remaining bill itself.

The banks earlier this week refused to pay any more than £75m a year for five years. This is understood to have infuriated DTI ministers, who asked the banks to find a way to pay more. This led to a meeting at the BBA yesterday at which the banks decided to stick to their original offer.

The banks have agreed to support the principle of the universal bank, in contrast to their initial outright opposition. It is understood that the banks will tell Alan Johnson, the post office minister, early next week that they would prefer to provide the financially excluded with their own specially-designed accounts, offered at post offices, which do not allow customers to overdraw.

The BBA declined to comment last night but Mr Johnson said: "The government remains strongly committed to the concept of universal banking services and pursuing this with the high street banks."

The Post Office remained "optimistic of a satisfactory outcome".

webTitle: Durlacher admits big losses lie ahead

fields.headline: Durlacher admits big losses lie ahead
fields.standfirst:
Former high flyer to write off £13m from investments

More net news
fields.trailText: Former high flyer to write off £13m from investments
fields.body:
Durlacher, the once high-flying internet investment bank, yesterday said it would write down £13m of its investments and warned of "substantial losses" in the pipeline, sending the firm's share price tumbling.

The move underlies the severity of the downturn in the dot.com sector, where Durlacher was seen as a prime example of a good new-economy investment.

"We believe the action taken provides clarity for shareholders on our investments and trading," insisted chairman and chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain, "and we remain committed to using our knowledge-led investment approach to identify and realise value in the telecoms, media and technologies sectors."

But the market sent Durlacher's share price down 7p to 22p on the back of the announcement.

Mr Chamberlain said the company expected to write down £13m invested in a number of unnamed companies, adding that the figure included write-offs on two dot.com investments which have folded - Wowgo, a website for teenage girls, and Unit 26, an online contemporary art dealership.

He said the past six weeks of turbulence in the hi-tech sector had brought about a "small loss" in Durlacher's stockbroking business, but the bulk of anticipated losses for the half-year to the end of December were the result of venture capital investments. "Valuing technology stocks at the earliest stages is the most difficult thing to do."

Mr Chamberlain also warned that the investment write-downs might have appeared overly negative to the market because Durlacher had not yet balanced them against potential write-ups. He said that a provisional study of stakes in just four companies showed a write-up of £25m, though he would not reveal which companies had been reviewed.

However, one investment understood to be undervalued is the company's stake in kVault Software, the email archiving operator, which was thought to be worth up to 20 times its £1m Durlacher book value in September.

Durlacher was once the darling of the stock market, coming within 12 places of a FTSE 100 ranking. But its share price has been falling since a Febuary high of 441p and the company has been dogged by reports of directors exercising their share options.

However, Mr Chamberlain insisted staff with share options were unlikely to be jumping ship in large numbers. "We attract creative people who want to get involved in building companies up. They don't just come to Durlacher for the share options."

But observers said staff retention was likely to become a serious problem for the investment bank, where many employees hold options, if the the share price continued to slide.

They also suggested that the write-downs by Durlacher might make it difficult for the companies involved if they needed to seek further rounds of funding from other investors.

Mr Chamberlain's 14% personal stake in the company has fallen in value from £314m to £15.7m since Febuary.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 'Orphan funds' dispute for Pru
fields.body:
'Orphan funds' dispute for Pru

The Prudential is "considering" a legal challenge put forward by a group of policyholders over the ownership of its £6bn-£8bn of "orphan assets" - money built up from surpluses and unclaimed policy bonuses. London solicitors Class Law have issued a claim in the high court on behalf of Prudential policyholder Richard Ashken which asks the court to rule on who owns the orphan assets.

The challenge is being backed by the Consumers' Association, which said yesterday that it objected to the company discussing the issue with the financial services authority "behind closed doors".

The Prudential is one of several insurance companies sitting on billions of pounds of orphan assets.

Tesco to open in Malaysia

Tesco plans to open about 15 hypermarkets in Malaysia at a cost of £215m. The British supermarkets group has entered an agreement with the Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby Berhad, which will have a 30% share of the joint venture.

Tesco already has 32 stores in Thailand, Taiwan and South Korea. France's Carrefour is the only other European operator in Malaysia.

EBRD admits Yugoslavia

Yugoslavia 's rehabilitation within the global financial community advanced yesterday when it was admitted to membership of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The EBRD said the decision to make Yugoslavia the 27th member had been unanimous. It is the first of the big international financial institutions to open its doors to a country that was largely isolated under former president Slobodan Milosevic.

Yugoslavia will still have to come up with a £10m entry fee but is expected to receive help from one of several potential sponsors.

GB Railways' loss to be met

GB Railways, owner of the Anglia rail franchise, expects the compensation agreed after the Hatfield accident to cover its subsequent revenue loss.

In the short term the group has reached an agreement in principle with the shadow strategic rail authority to bring forward £1m of its grant. GB Railways has submitted initial proposals for the Thameslink and Wales & Borders franchises and will continue to bid for franchises that it views as attractive. It announced half-year results showing a £2.1m loss, compared to a £500,000 profit last time.

Surfers are up for BTinternet

BT's unmetered internet access service provided by its BTinternet unit has 500,000 customers, with another 20,000 joining each week, the company said yesterday.

BTinternet plans to introduce what it calls the UK's first multi-access portal in January. POP, the personalised BTopenworld portal, would let customers create their own portals using personal computers or Wap mobile phones.

London solicitors Class Law have issued a claim in the high court on behalf of Prudential policyholder Richard Ashken which asks the court to rule on who owns the orphan assets. The challenge is being backed by the Consumers' Association, which said yesterday that it objected to the company discussing the issue with the financial services authority "behind closed doors". The Prudential is one of several insurance companies sitting on billions of pounds of orphan assets. Tesco to open in Malaysia Tesco plans to open about 15 hypermarkets in Malaysia at a cost of £215m. The British supermarkets group has entered an agreement with the Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby Berhad, which will have a 30% share of the joint venture. Tesco already has 32 stores in Thailand, Taiwan and South Korea. France's Carrefour is the only other European operator in Malaysia. EBRD admits Yugoslavia Yugoslavia 's rehabilitation within the global financial community advanced yesterday when it was admitted to membership of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The EBRD said the decision to make Yugoslavia the 27th member had been unanimous. It is the first of the big international financial institutions to open its doors to a country that was largely isolated under former president Slobodan Milosevic. Yugoslavia will still have to come up with a £10m entry fee but is expected to receive help from one of several potential sponsors. GB Railways' loss to be met GB Railways, owner of the Anglia rail franchise, expects the compensation agreed after the Hatfield accident to cover its subsequent revenue loss. In the short term the group has reached an agreement in principle with the shadow strategic rail authority to bring forward £1m of its grant. GB Railways has submitted initial proposals for the Thameslink and Wales & Borders franchises and will continue to bid for franchises that it views as attractive. It announced half-year results showing a £2.1m loss, compared to a £500,000 profit last time. Surfers are up for BTinternet BT's unmetered internet access service provided by its BTinternet unit has 500,000 customers, with another 20,000 joining each week, the company said yesterday. BTinternet plans to introduce what it calls the UK's first multi-access portal in January. POP, the personalised BTopenworld portal, would let customers create their own portals using personal computers or Wap mobile phones.

webTitle: Zimbabwe opposition calls off street action

fields.headline: Zimbabwe opposition calls off street action
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText:
Zimbabwe's main opposition party has called off plans
for popular protests to force Robert Mugabe from office
because it fears a confrontation could provoke
considerable bloodshed and provide a pretext for
cancelling presidential elections in 2002.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's main opposition party has called off plans for popular protests to force Robert Mugabe from office because it fears a confrontation could provoke considerable bloodshed and provide a pretext for cancelling presidential elections in 2002.

But the reluctance of the Movement for Democratic Change to challenge the president on the streets has angered some of the government's more fiery opponents who argue that Mr Mugabe will never allow himself to be voted out of power.

Yesterday, a special congress of the ruling Zanu-PF reaffirmed support for its leader after he declared that the party was at war with Zimbabwe's whites and their political "accomplices", the MDC.

Six weeks ago, the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, said the opposition was planning a series of strikes and demonstrations that would topple Mr Mugabe within months.

Mr Tsvangirai derided Zimbabwe's president as the "Milosevic of Africa" and said he should go immediately because had "committed genocide against a minority, rigged elections, ignored the rule of law and created a state which is internationally isolated".

But not unsympathetic senior officials in the Central Intelligence Organisation, the government's principal security organ, warned MDC leaders that they were playing into Mr Mugabe's hands.

They said the president intended to meet popular protests with force, and that violence would then be used as an excuse to detain opposition leaders, shut down parliament and impose a state of emergency. In time, Mr Mugabe would cancel the 2002 presidential election because he was almost certain to lose.

"We decided to make a tactical withdrawal when we realised he in fact wanted that protest to go ahead," said Tendai Biti, the opposition's chief legal strategist. "There was going to be bloodshed, really going to be bloodshed. We realised that the state saw this intended protest not as a democratic right, the state saw this as war."

He added: "The majority opinion in the party was, no, we can't do this, we'll be playing into the hands of a madman, because once 10 or so people are killed, he declares a state of emergency, bans all civic organisations, he dissolves parliament and the law then allows him to rule alone for a year." he said.

Mr Tsvangirai said the party would now concentrate on winning the election in 2002 but with Mr Mugabe so unpopular, and the economy facing further collapse, some in the MDC doubt the president will ever permit such a vote.

They argue that he has clearly demonstrated his contempt for the rule of law by defying court orders, barring legal action to contest June's parliamentary results and granting amnesty to people who murdered more than 30 of his political opponents.

Even if there is an election, the MDC is facing a new challenge. The party has lost the important backing of the country's main trade union confederation, which Mr Tsvangirai used to head and which was an important springboard for launching the opposition into parliament in June.

Zanu-PF has tried to regain control of the confederation, but the unions are also being wooed by a prominent ruling party dissident and former cabinet minister, Eddison Zvobgo. Although Mr Zvobgo remains a member of Zanu-PF, he has been sounding out other dissidents about the creation of a third party to challenge Mr Mugabe and the existing opposition.

Mr Tsvangirai admits that popular pressure is growing for his party to retake the initiative and launch its strikes and street protests against Mr Mugabe.

Mr Biti says the MDC is walking a tightrope. "If we fall too behind the people we become irrelevant, we become history. At the same time if we pull too far forward we expose the people we are trying to lead. That is the bare issue here - maintaining a balance between a vampire state and expectations of an increasingly radicalised population."

webTitle: Abbey pushes on with BoS merger

fields.headline: Abbey pushes on with BoS merger
fields.trailText: Abbey National threw down the gauntlet to its predator, Lloyds TSB, yesterday by insisting it was making progress on a merger with its preferred partner, Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Abbey National threw down the gauntlet to its predator, Lloyds TSB, yesterday by insisting it was making progress on a merger with its preferred partner, Bank of Scotland.

The latest manoeuvring in the three-way tussle saw Abbey ask the competition authorities to begin formal examination of a merger with BoS. One City source said this was like a "red rag to a bull".

The bull in this instance is Lloyds TSB, which told the City it was prepared to pay £18bn for Abbey in the form of 1.5 of its shares and 260p in cash for each Abbey share.

However, Lloyds TSB has not yet made a formal bid for Abbey, which had hoped to have announced its merger with BoS by now. Abbey is trying to force Lloyds TSB to make its bid official.

Rather than issue a hostile bid, Lloyds TSB is thought to be hoping to lure Abbey back to the negotiating table, a tactic endorsed last night by some major shareholders.

One investor said: "We would like Lloyds TSB and Abbey to talk to each other. We are pushing Abbey to try to be more open and stop closing the door in Lloyds' face."

So far, Abbey chief executive Ian Harley has resisted pressure to engage in takeover talks with his counterpart at Lloyds TSB, Peter Ellwood.

The investor said, however, that the City felt Lloyds TSB's offer was too low at just under £13 per share and many investors would hold out for at least £13.50. Abbey's shares touched their highest level of the year at £11.99 yesterday before ending at £11.75.

Abbey appeared to try to call Lloyds' bluff by telling that the City that it and BoS felt the time was right to begin the process of receiving clearance for their deal from competition authorities.

"Consequently, Abbey has today submitted a draft merger notice to the office of fair trading and intends to file a formal merger notice at the beginning of next week," Abbey said.

webTitle: Whale of a time for high-rollers

fields.headline: Whale of a time for high-rollers
fields.standfirst: The Aladdin offers the US gambler a little bit of English casino elegance,  writes Julia Finch
fields.trailText: The Aladdin offers the US gambler a little bit of English casino elegance, writes Julia Finch
fields.body:
Behind the flashy neon of the Vegas Strip is the St James's Room of The London Club, where high rollers are welcome and "whales" - some of the world's richest businessmen play for high stakes and are good for losses of tens of million pounds a year. In fact, whales make your average high roller look like a minnow.

Aladdin, says London Clubs, is already starting to attract some of the world's high rollers - defined in the gaming business as those who can sit down and lose £500,000.

So far, however, there have been no sightings of whales. "We know when they are in town," said a London Clubs spokesman. "They usually travel with an entourage, and someone lets you know they are coming."

In the UK there are strict rules about how clubs can woo the whales and rollers. But in the US they can push the boat out. They can pay airfares for an entire entourage, cover the bills for the most luxurious hotels and even offer discounts on losses - so the unlucky losers only have to stump up £400,000 if they happen to drop half a million.

The biggest gamblers come from the Far East, Middle East and Asia, but London Clubs says a new breed is emerging, which includes a younger generation of US multi-millionaires, many of whom have made dot.com fortunes in Silicon Valley.

Casinos make it their business to know their customers before they take to the tables, but one unknown US punter at Aladdin recently came in and dropped a million dollars in a matter of hours. Concerned that they did not know the unlucky young man, the club did some instant credit checks and was told not to worry-he was good for $80m.

webTitle: BA hopes Concorde will be airborne again next spring

fields.headline: BA hopes Concorde will be airborne again next spring
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: It has been branded cramped, thirsty and  environmentally unfriendly and was involved in one of  the most catastrophic aviation disasters of recent  history.
fields.body:
It has been branded cramped, thirsty and environmentally unfriendly and was involved in one of the most catastrophic aviation disasters of recent history. But yesterday British Airways remained confident that its Concorde fleet would carry passengers again, possibly as early as next spring.

The airline is also confident that its passengers, 80% of whom are business travellers, are desperate to fly supersonic once more, lured by the prospect of crossing the Atlantic in just over under three hours in the world's most graceful - and expensive - aircraft.

Concorde's chief pilot, Mike Bannister, said the latest indications from safety regulators were promising. He is relying on the hope that by next year passengers will have all but forgotten the flaming descent of flight AF4590 into the Hotelissimo outside Gonesse, in what some said was the final act of a plane that had already flown too far.

BA's plan to tempt nervous passengers back into Concorde's seats includes an ambitious series of safety modifications, which involves fitting Concorde's fuel tanks with Kevlar linings similar to those used in formula one racing cars and replacing wiring on the undercarriage with a reinforced system.

The new linings, due to arrive in the Heathrow hangars next week, are intended to protect the engine and fuel tanks from tyre bursts, which caused the Air France crash in Paris that killed 113 people. One of the criticisms has been that the design of the aircraft, with its undercarriage more or less parallel to its engine pods, means that the plane is more at risk from debris entering the engines.

Yesterday, an Anglo-French safety review of Concorde, which included BA and Air France representatives, manufacturers, aviation regulators, crash investigators and government officials heard how BA's engineers have been keeping the aircraft in working order during tests. A multimillion pound refit is aleady under way in anticipation that the safety regulators will give the green light. The planes have also been repainted.

Capt Bannister insisted this refit would not have gone ahead unless BA had received very positive noises about the likelihood of winning back its air safety certificate, withdrawn after the Paris crash. Following the meeting it also emerged that the engine modification kits have already been ordered and built and are expected to arrive at Concorde's hangar next week.

BA is also understood to be working on a life extension programme to give an extra 15 years to the 25-year-old aircraft. While the airline said there was no certain date for the plane to return to service, it is thought that all involved are working towards a possible April 2001 timescale.

Capt Bannister said: "We are keeping our aircraft in tip-top condition. A team of engineers has been keeping the aircraft ready to fly, checking them out every day, running the engines and looking after all the computers. This underlines our determination to fly once more.

"A huge amount of effort is taking place on both sides of the Channel and we are beginning to see some really encouraging signs of progress."

But not everyone shares BA's optimism that a return to the skies is inevitable. After a memorial service outside the Church of Madeleine in central Paris, one French pilot said: "One of the main problems with Concorde is the state of its Olympus engines. This is a plane that is well maintained but its engines are fragile and old. They are the product of the 1960s and unfortunately there is no modern equivalent. Maintenance and repairs must be carried out with specially created parts or old substitutes. This is reflected in the number of technical problems affecting the engines."

Every month last year, according to an internal report at Air France, at least one of the six Paris Concordes had an engine problem of some kind, despite flying for six hours a day. This means the problem is 20 times more likely to occur in a French Concorde engine than in a Boeing 747, which gets one tenth of the maintenance time of a Concorde jet.

Last night the expert group looking into restoring the supersonic jet to the skies said initial tests on modifications carried out on Concorde could take place as early as February.

The Anglo-French Concorde working group set out an engineering programme it believes is "sensible and achievable provided there are no unforeseen difficulties during the tests". The group includes the CAA and its French equivalent.

This would involve carrying out test flights and even recreating the fatal crash at Charles de Gaulle airport to ensure the new modifications were effective and did not adversely affect the plane's performance, making it more dangerous.

David Learmount of Flight International magazine said: "The significant thing is that they will have some new test flights by February with new systems embodied which are tested airborne. They are going to have to replicate a similar tyre burst to see if the new system is effective but also to make sure they have not created a new problem which might affect the plane's performance such as creating extra drag."

fields.headline: Nursery nation
fields.standfirst:
The republic

Join the debate online
fields.trailText: On one side of the Channel, order and liberty, peace and prosperity; on the other, the barking dogs of ideology and reaction, upheaval and revolution. But for us, beneficent evolution, wisdom slowly maturing in the sunny landscape of an ancestral constitution, and the glories of the common law
fields.body:
On one side of the Channel, order and liberty, peace and prosperity; on the other, the barking dogs of ideology and reaction, upheaval and revolution. But for us, beneficent evolution, wisdom slowly maturing in the sunny landscape of an ancestral constitution, and the glories of the common law. Feed on these precedents and be grateful. Shudder at the juxtaposed reality just 20 miles away.

"Scepticism" about Europe is now firmly wrapped in the shroud of contemporary Toryism. But for most of English history it is liberalism which has opposed the European political tradition, and the wildness of its mood swings between left and right, between commissars and kings, Jacobins and priests.

The story is a familiar one, told by England, mother of parliaments, to the subject-children at her knee. Over there, power was centralised, and in two stages. First, the despotism, sometimes enlightened, of monarchs. Theirs was a true modernity of efficient bureaucracy impatient of ancient aristocratic rights. Its monument is Versailles. Second came the despots' heirs - the totalitarians scornful of individual democratic rights. And their mausoleum is the Kremlin.

But England is meant to be incorrigibly exceptional. Limits on monarchy combine with property rights to protect us against arbitrary rule. Parliamentary representation gradually extends down the social scale. Beneath it all, a constitution not so much unwritten as written at different times and found in different places - yet somehow all hanging together.

All countries need their founding myths - and there is enough truth or truism in this story to explain its appeal. Much of English history has been written by English liberals and Whigs in order to demonstrate its truth. Europe's collapse in a prolonged civil war from 1914 to 1945 arrived on cue as if to confirm the happiness of the island condition. But distance is needed now to lend any enchantment to this constitutional view. Closer inspection dissolves the visionary fabric

Monarchy is central to the tale. Oceans of ink have been drained in the Whig-liberal celebration of 1688-89's gloriously smooth revolution and its 1701 post-script, the Act of Settlement. Recovery from the Stuart disaster seemed complete. Both Charles I and II had been genuinely Europhile monarchs. They pined for continental methods of absolute, non-parliamentary rule - the smartest and most dynamic model of government available in the 17th century. The first Charles tried to introduce it with armies; the second attempted it by secret treaties with Louis XIV. But Whiggery triumphant sealed the experiment's fate.

That year of 1701 was also when Louis recognised the Stuart James III, the Old Pretender, as lawful king of England. That now seems like a silly spit in the face of history. But the Act of Settlement, like much of our constitutional history, was a panicky measure, a quick fix which only retrospectively came to embody a deliberative wisdom.

The defence of the Hanoverian settlement is that it saved Britain from the continental nonsense of the confessional state - that reactionary alliance between throne and altar. And yet, the Act of Settlement merely provided the Anglican version of the same obscurantism. The Church of England was as firm-wristed a sprinkler of holy oils on monarchic heads as the Church of Rome. When the confessional state retreated in 19th-century Europe, the English followed suit. Eurosceptics -whether in 1701 or 2000 - bent on turning the Channel into an ocean, always miss the common currents.

Monarchy's other key 18th-century date is 1789 - the event which made the modern European state possible. English liberalism celebrates it as the date which the English avoided: no year of terror, no tumbrils, no guillotines in Whitehall. For this we should again incline our heads to the Hanoverian wisdom of moderation.

But this is the sleep of constitutional reason which brings forth myths. The paradox of English liberty is that it's not very good on freedom. The England ushered in by 1701 was a thoroughly ancien-regime affair. Certainly, it was hostile to despotic kings but it was in no sense proto-democratic. It was, on the contrary, tender towards the liberties of aristocratic groups - especially oligarchic Whig ones. Tories who opposed English involvement in continental European wars were the losers. But big gun Whigs like Marlborough (the original subject of For He's a Jolly Good Fellow after his Malplaquet victory of 1709) made fortunes out of killing European Catholics.

England today remains an ancien-regime society because it had no 1789 experience: 1701 worked all too well, helped by the zeal of generals such as the Duke of Cumberland, who shared with Marlborough the epithet of "butcher" after his work at Culloden. Sanctified by time's passage and Anglicanism's power, England ossified as a network of associations, of clubs and regiments, of schools and colleges, of JPs, high sheriffs and lord lieutenants, of Jane Austen-ish county society. It remains a place where loyalties are local and particular and are owed to the dynastic power which originally underwrote these loyalties. The state, that progressivist dissolver of prejudice, has had no English home.

But continental Europeans have been forced by 1789 and the collapse of dynasticism to turn themselves into citizens. Which is why their states work in a way that our congenitally tatty series of governments do not - and cannot, for as long as we remain a monarchy. Though very old in one sense, in another England remains a barely adolescent country - one which is only just beginning to question its own identity and probe its existence. Monarchs have kept us in the nursery.

Karl Marx once lamented "the deep idiocy of rural life". Marx used "idiot" in its ancient Greek sense of someone who lives apart. Peasants are technically "idiots" because they have not been socialised into true forms of engagement and community. It is in this sense that monarchy in England makes idiots as well as children of us all. For it proposes bogus models of community invented from above rather than ones of our own devising: princes, for example, mopping up loos and downing pints. Monarchy has stopped the English from inventing themselves as a nation.

Not for nothing did more sophisticated societies than ours, those of early Rome and ancient Athens, regard monarchy as a primitive stage in humanity's progress. For our arrested development we have to thank the sorry new world ushered in by 1701 and all that.

Britain's abiding European condition now propels it forward to catch up with 1789 over 200 years later than our neighbours. We are moving from being an early 18th-century European country into an early 21st-century European state. And in that rapid jolt we all discover that sovereignty is divisible and our loyalties are layered. After all our queen is, like the rest of us, a subject of the European Union - whose highest court must now rule on the legitimacy of English confessional dynasticism.

fields.bodyText: On one side of the Channel, order and liberty, peace and prosperity; on the other, the barking dogs of ideology and reaction, upheaval and revolution. But for us, beneficent evolution, wisdom slowly maturing in the sunny landscape of an ancestral constitution, and the glories of the common law. Feed on these precedents and be grateful. Shudder at the juxtaposed reality just 20 miles away. "Scepticism" about Europe is now firmly wrapped in the shroud of contemporary Toryism. But for most of English history it is liberalism which has opposed the European political tradition, and the wildness of its mood swings between left and right, between commissars and kings, Jacobins and priests. The story is a familiar one, told by England, mother of parliaments, to the subject-children at her knee. Over there, power was centralised, and in two stages. First, the despotism, sometimes enlightened, of monarchs. Theirs was a true modernity of efficient bureaucracy impatient of ancient aristocratic rights. Its monument is Versailles. Second came the despots' heirs - the totalitarians scornful of individual democratic rights. And their mausoleum is the Kremlin. But England is meant to be incorrigibly exceptional. Limits on monarchy combine with property rights to protect us against arbitrary rule. Parliamentary representation gradually extends down the social scale. Beneath it all, a constitution not so much unwritten as written at different times and found in different places - yet somehow all hanging together. All countries need their founding myths - and there is enough truth or truism in this story to explain its appeal. Much of English history has been written by English liberals and Whigs in order to demonstrate its truth. Europe's collapse in a prolonged civil war from 1914 to 1945 arrived on cue as if to confirm the happiness of the island condition. But distance is needed now to lend any enchantment to this constitutional view. Closer inspection dissolves the visionary fabric Monarchy is central to the tale. Oceans of ink have been drained in the Whig-liberal celebration of 1688-89's gloriously smooth revolution and its 1701 post-script, the Act of Settlement. Recovery from the Stuart disaster seemed complete. Both Charles I and II had been genuinely Europhile monarchs. They pined for continental methods of absolute, non-parliamentary rule - the smartest and most dynamic model of government available in the 17th century. The first Charles tried to introduce it with armies; the second attempted it by secret treaties with Louis XIV. But Whiggery triumphant sealed the experiment's fate. That year of 1701 was also when Louis recognised the Stuart James III, the Old Pretender, as lawful king of England. That now seems like a silly spit in the face of history. But the Act of Settlement, like much of our constitutional history, was a panicky measure, a quick fix which only retrospectively came to embody a deliberative wisdom. The defence of the Hanoverian settlement is that it saved Britain from the continental nonsense of the confessional state - that reactionary alliance between throne and altar. And yet, the Act of Settlement merely provided the Anglican version of the same obscurantism. The Church of England was as firm-wristed a sprinkler of holy oils on monarchic heads as the Church of Rome. When the confessional state retreated in 19th-century Europe, the English followed suit. Eurosceptics -whether in 1701 or 2000 - bent on turning the Channel into an ocean, always miss the common currents. Monarchy's other key 18th-century date is 1789 - the event which made the modern European state possible. English liberalism celebrates it as the date which the English avoided: no year of terror, no tumbrils, no guillotines in Whitehall. For this we should again incline our heads to the Hanoverian wisdom of moderation. But this is the sleep of constitutional reason which brings forth myths. The paradox of English liberty is that it's not very good on freedom. The England ushered in by 1701 was a thoroughly ancien-regime affair. Certainly, it was hostile to despotic kings but it was in no sense proto-democratic. It was, on the contrary, tender towards the liberties of aristocratic groups - especially oligarchic Whig ones. Tories who opposed English involvement in continental European wars were the losers. But big gun Whigs like Marlborough (the original subject of For He's a Jolly Good Fellow after his Malplaquet victory of 1709) made fortunes out of killing European Catholics. England today remains an ancien-regime society because it had no 1789 experience: 1701 worked all too well, helped by the zeal of generals such as the Duke of Cumberland, who shared with Marlborough the epithet of "butcher" after his work at Culloden. Sanctified by time's passage and Anglicanism's power, England ossified as a network of associations, of clubs and regiments, of schools and colleges, of JPs, high sheriffs and lord lieutenants, of Jane Austen-ish county society. It remains a place where loyalties are local and particular and are owed to the dynastic power which originally underwrote these loyalties. The state, that progressivist dissolver of prejudice, has had no English home. But continental Europeans have been forced by 1789 and the collapse of dynasticism to turn themselves into citizens. Which is why their states work in a way that our congenitally tatty series of governments do not - and cannot, for as long as we remain a monarchy. Though very old in one sense, in another England remains a barely adolescent country - one which is only just beginning to question its own identity and probe its existence. Monarchs have kept us in the nursery. Karl Marx once lamented "the deep idiocy of rural life". Marx used "idiot" in its ancient Greek sense of someone who lives apart. Peasants are technically "idiots" because they have not been socialised into true forms of engagement and community. It is in this sense that monarchy in England makes idiots as well as children of us all. For it proposes bogus models of community invented from above rather than ones of our own devising: princes, for example, mopping up loos and downing pints. Monarchy has stopped the English from inventing themselves as a nation. Not for nothing did more sophisticated societies than ours, those of early Rome and ancient Athens, regard monarchy as a primitive stage in humanity's progress. For our arrested development we have to thank the sorry new world ushered in by 1701 and all that. Britain's abiding European condition now propels it forward to catch up with 1789 over 200 years later than our neighbours. We are moving from being an early 18th-century European country into an early 21st-century European state. And in that rapid jolt we all discover that sovereignty is divisible and our loyalties are layered. After all our queen is, like the rest of us, a subject of the European Union - whose highest court must now rule on the legitimacy of English confessional dynasticism. fields.headline: Laporte agrees £1.4bn German bid
fields.trailText: Germany's Degussa-Huls yesterday launched an agreed £1.36bn bid for Britain's Laporte as the concept that big-is-beautiful continued to drive the restructuring of the global chemical and pharmaceuticals industries.
fields.body:
Germany's Degussa-Huls yesterday launched an agreed £1.36bn bid for Britain's Laporte as the concept that big-is-beautiful continued to drive the restructuring of the global chemical and pharmaceuticals industries.

News of the Anglo-German deal came as one of the biggest names in the chemical industry, BASF, announced that it was pulling out of the pharmaceuticals business through the sale of its Knoll subsidiary to America's Abbott Laborato ries for $6.9bn. Laporte said it had decided to surrender its 112-year independence because medium-sized players need more scale to survive.

Chief executive Jim Leng said chemicals companies needed to serve global customers "You either have to choose to be a delicatessen or a supermarket," he said.

The 697p-a-share cash deal was agreed after a month of talks between Mr Leng and Degussa's boss Utz Felcht. The pair held key meetings in Gibraltar, because Mr Felcht was on holiday in nearby Spain.

Laporte, which has 2,200 employees, is involved mainly in supplying bespoke ingredients for pharmaceuticals.

The company has been through a five-year transformation under Mr Leng, with the sale of activities in electronics, plastics, absorbents and pigments, culminating in an £810m clear-out of businesses to US financiers Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in September.

Other bidders could upset the takeover - Swiss firm Clariant discussed an 800p-a-share bid with Laporte 18 months ago. Mr Leng insisted he was not disappointed at achieving a lower price than this: "I'm looking forward in this deal, I'm not looking back - that's why I'm pleased to recommend it to shareholders."

Degussa's activities include making chemicals to stop ice cream melting, producing bleach for hairstyling and absorbents for nappies. Degussa offered assurances that the number of redundancies would be insignificant.

Mr Leng and Laporte's finance director, Michael Kayser, will, however, be leaving.

fields.headline: Phones billionaire reunited with Mitel
fields.standfirst: Terry Matthews, Wales' only billionaire, is being reunited with the company that helped make his fortune, writes Nick Fletcher.
fields.trailText: Terry Matthews, Wales' only billionaire, is being reunited with the company that helped make his fortune, writes Nick Fletcher.
fields.body:
He is paying $230m (£165m) for the office phone business and brand name rights of Mitel - which he co-founded in 1972 with Michael Cowpland, backed by a $4,000 loan. The name came from a combination of the entrepreneurs' christian names and at one point the company was sold to BT, which later disposed of the business.

Born in south-east Wales but now splitting his time between north London and Ottawa, Mr Matthews plans to increase research and development spending and revive the struggling phone business.

Mitel's chip business will not form part of the deal, and will be renamed.

Ottawa-based Mitel will keep a 10% stake in the phone business, which has around 3,300 staff.

Mitel talked to several parties interested in buying the phone unit but said that Mr Matthews' bid was the most attractive.

After Mitel, Mr Matthews founded Newbridge Networks, which was sold to Alcatel for $7.1bn earlier this year. This summer he became head of a small video firm, March Networks. He was also involved in putting together a bid to stage the 2009 Ryder Cup at his Celtic Manor resort in Newport, Gwent.

Mitel's chip business has long outperformed the sluggish phone system unit, but the company warned yesterday that market uncertainty has resulted in the cancellation or rescheduling of some semiconductor orders.

fields.headline: Narcotics on a high
fields.trailText: Meconic, the pharmaceuticals company which is Britain's only licensed narcotics producer, saw its shares rise 16p to 176p after it reported first-half profits up 20%.
fields.body:
Meconic, the pharmaceuticals company which is Britain's only licensed narcotics producer, saw its shares rise 16p to 176p after it reported first-half profits up 20%.

The company expected a "significantly stronger" second half with operating profit £4.2m for the six months to the end of October, compared to £3.5m for the same period a year ago.

The company put its success down to its decision last year to refocus its core pharmaceutical ingredients and fine chemicals businesses.

"The focus on higher-margin products has been particularly effective in delivering operating profit growth of 20%," said Peter Savage, Meconic's chairman.

The company was formed after a management buy-out from Glaxo in 1990. It is a worldwide supplier of bulk opiates used in pain killers.

webTitle: Toyota plays down talks with Ford

fields.headline: Toyota plays down talks with Ford
fields.trailText: Japanese car maker Toyota yesterday sought to shrug off speculation that it was considering an alliance with Ford.
fields.body:
Japanese car maker Toyota yesterday sought to shrug off speculation that it was considering an alliance with Ford.

Ford admitted earlier in the week that its chief executive, Jacques Nasser had met Toyota chairman Hiroshi Okuda.

"Everyone is talking these days as companies continue to seek partnerships to cut costs and explore possible strategic alliances," a Ford spokesman said.

Yesterday, however, Japan's Jiji news agency reported Toyota's president, Fujio Cho, as denying the two companies were discussing an alliance, though Toyota had acknowledged that Mr Okuda was meeting top executives from a number of car makers.

Alliances and joint ventures are an increasing feature of the automotive industry as manufacturers seek to build a global presence while addressing the problems of overcapacity in key markets such as the US and Europe.

This week General Motors announced it was cutting 10,000 jobs in North America and Europe, including more than 2,000 at Luton where the Vauxhall plant is being closed.

Vauxhall plants in Luton and Ellesmere Port began their Christmas shutdown periods yesterday but union sources said they intended to keep up the pressure on the group's management to reverse the Luton closure decision.

Measures to recruit support for the save-the-plant campaign will be announced in the coming week and trade union leaders will meet GM's top European management, probably not until the new year.

Early January is also expected to be a crucial time for the Nissan plant in Sunderland. The company is considering the choice of manufacturing base for the new Micra model.

webTitle: Turkey resists demands for EU deal with Nato

fields.headline: Turkey resists demands for EU deal with Nato
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText:
Turkey refused point blank last night to accept Nato
plans for cooperation with the EU's new rapid reaction
force, after resisting massive diplomatic pressure to
cave in.
fields.body:
Turkey refused point blank last night to accept Nato plans for cooperation with the EU's new rapid reaction force, after resisting massive diplomatic pressure to cave in.

As the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, insisted he could not compromise on the EU force, Nato ministers meeting in Brussels were unable to crack stiff Turkish resistance.

Despite an appeal from President Bill Clinton, Mr Ecevit said he would not give fledgling EU defence bodies automatic access to the resources of the 19-member alliance - which operates by consensus - without being given a full role in decision-making.

Turkey - which has a prickly relationship with the EU and little chance of joining for years - fears that if it has no decisive say, such resources could be used against its interests, possibly in disputes with Greece over the Aegean or Cyprus.

"We are standing firm on our position because we may face serious dangers if we are excluded from the European Defence and Security Identity," Mr Ecevit insisted. "We feel obliged to pursue our position without compromise."

Talks ended after Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, led feverish efforts by alliance foreign ministers to find a way out of the impasse. Turkey's foreign minister, Ismail Cem, was offered what Nato diplomats described as "special guarantees".

The crisis threatens to delay controversial plans for a deal which would give the EU "assured access" to Nato planning resources for missions that the alliance chooses not to undertake. Diplomats said the guarantee of access was the "keystone" of the agreement. Some sources believe Turkey is holding out for a better deal from the new administration of George W Bush.

In a separate development, Abdullah Ocalan, the Kurdish rebel leader sentenced to hang by Turkey, was yesterday granted leave to appeal by the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.

In a case with profound implications for Turkey's relations with the EU, Ocalan can now challenge the death sentence passed last year.

Ocalan's complaints arose from the death penalty itself, allegations of ill treatment and violations of the European Convention on Human Rights, to which Turkey is a signatory.

Ocalan, the founder of the outlawed Kurdish Workers Party or PKK, was kidnapped by secret agents in Kenya in 1998. At a trial in Turkey he was condemned to hang for hundreds of killings in the PKK's 16-year war.

A ruling from the Strasbourg court - which is not connected to the EU - could take several months.

"This is a very positive development," Ocalan's lawyer Irfan Dundar said in Istanbul. "They have accepted all the points where we believe there was a violation of rights."

Mark Muller, chairman of the Kurdish Human Rights Project, said it was "the most significant case on the death penalty" ever to come before the court. He also argued that the death penalty per se violates the convention's guarantees of the right to life and the prohibition of degrading treatment.

webTitle: Comment: Making Bush and Gore - the movie

fields.headline: Making Bush and Gore - the movie
fields.standfirst:
If only one could buy the film rights to the presidential stand-off

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: If only one could buy the film rights to the presidential stand-off
fields.body:
When I interviewed him last year, the director Oliver Stone complained that, after Nixon and JFK, people kept asking him when he was going to make the movie, Clinton. He insisted that he never would; the material had been so dramatised already by the media that there was no hold left for a director.

This week, though, Stone announced that his filmography will now include a trilogy of presidential films. His next project is The Day Reagan Was Shot, concentrating on only the second bullet of modern times to penetrate a president. (The third or fourth or fifth, in fact, Stone would say, one of the aims of JFK being to disprove the single bullet theory of the Dallas assassination.) Richard Crenna will play Reagan in what will surely be a fascinating exercise for a performer: acting an actor who is playing the role of the president.

It's fitting that the first movie star president should become the star of a movie. And it's not hard to predict the shape the film might take. Stone, genius of the conspiracy theory, will surely be drawn to subsequent admissions that Reagan was more seriously injured than was admitted at the time. Another key scene will surely be General Alexander Haig's sweaty (and constitutionally false) assumption of power at the White House: "I'm in charge." Stone may also find it impossible to leave out a scene in which Reagan, later found to have Alzheimer's, mislays his spectacles or forgets an appointment.

There is, however, a serious aspect to this speculation, which is the unlikeliness of a film-maker getting three major movies from the White House in the last 40 years, a period in which it has become commonplace to lament that politics is boring.

The American presidency does seem, in recent decades, to have become more dramatic, rather as if there were a secret plan to play down the federal deficit by selling the movie rights of the US government to Hollywood. It's hard to imagine an Oliver Stone movie about most of the presidents in the first two thirds of the 20th century: Eisenhower's military career is filmable (and has been) but little of what happened at the desk would grip a Multiplex.

Then, in Kennedy, Nixon, Reagan and Clinton, America began to throw up leaders demanding memorialisation by a Shakespeare or at least an Arthur Miller. Whatever their achievements as politicians, they were all massively dramatic characters. The likeliest explanation for this is that the mass-media exposure to which presidents became subjected not only demanded bigger figures but revealed their characters in greater detail. But this trend in US politics seemed to have come to an end with a year 2000 election race between two of the least charismatic candidates ever to wear a rosette.

The last five weeks, how ever, put even these two dull men into potential pre- production for Mr Stone, even though a movie called Bush would run the risk of accidentally bringing in a porn audience. Both the governor and the vice president are now compelling dramatic figures, Bush illustrating the tragedy of gaining power while unprepared for it and Gore the equally deranging fate of craving leadership for 30 years without achieving it.

There are certain creative talents so distinctive that they come to seem to be scripting the world. The visitor to Yorkshire now finds it full of Alan Bennett characters. In the same way, American presidencies now seem to be directed by Oliver Stone. While two of the last three administrations (Reagan and Clinton) felt occasionally like perfect scenarios for him, the Florida hiatus had his fingerprints all over it and the administration due to begin on January 20 would be well advised to eliminate the middleman and simply admit Stone's cameras to the Oval Office.

Watching the events of the last few weeks, television viewers frequently felt desperate to buy the movie rights. Moment after moment called for the attentions of a screenwriter. Imagine - with James Cromwell as former President Bush, James Woods as Governor Bush and Angela Lansbury as Barbara Bush - the scene in which, for 30 minutes on the night of November 7, the pseudo-Kennedys from Kennebunkport believe that they have won the White House. Then comes the phone call retracting the concession and Gore (Oliver Platt) delivers the celebrated line: "Now don't get snippy with me." Jeb Bush, played by the one who was the pervert in Happiness, reassures the family: "They ain't ever gonna find those other votes, Big Bro." Five weeks later, the deeply religious Gore and his running-mate Joe Lieberman (Woody Allen) are forced to accept that their God has denied them the prize.

I hope we get to see it. But the problem with this film-maker is that he exaggerates. Oliver Stone's Bush And Gore (a working title only) would feature Richard Nixon returning as a ghost to preside over a huge bonfire of Democrat ballots lit by Jeb and Barbara Bush. But Stone should simply film life. It's only fair to return the compliment because life has started imitating him. Whether or not he ever commits it to celluloid, Oliver Stone's Bush Administration starts shooting - or electrocuting, as Dubya prefers - next January 20.

Imagine - with James Cromwell as former President Bush, James Woods as Governor Bush and Angela Lansbury as Barbara Bush - the scene in which, for 30 minutes on the night of November 7, the pseudo-Kennedys from Kennebunkport believe that they have won the White House. Then comes the phone call retracting the concession and Gore (Oliver Platt) delivers the celebrated line: "Now don't get snippy with me." Jeb Bush, played by the one who was the pervert in Happiness, reassures the family: "They ain't ever gonna find those other votes, Big Bro." Five weeks later, the deeply religious Gore and his running-mate Joe Lieberman (Woody Allen) are forced to accept that their God has denied them the prize. I hope we get to see it. But the problem with this film-maker is that he exaggerates. Oliver Stone's Bush And Gore (a working title only) would feature Richard Nixon returning as a ghost to preside over a huge bonfire of Democrat ballots lit by Jeb and Barbara Bush. But Stone should simply film life. It's only fair to return the compliment because life has started imitating him. Whether or not he ever commits it to celluloid, Oliver Stone's Bush Administration starts shooting - or electrocuting, as Dubya prefers - next January 20. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: At this price?  Nycomed Amersham
fields.trailText: Nycomed Amersham, the Anglo-Norwegian health care combine, had softened us up in October with a warning that the eagerly awaited plan to partially float its APBiotech joint venture on Nasdaq could slip back to next year.
fields.body:
Nycomed Amersham, the Anglo-Norwegian health care combine, had softened us up in October with a warning that the eagerly awaited plan to partially float its APBiotech joint venture on Nasdaq could slip back to next year.

Yesterday it confirmed the inevitable in a trading statement which said followers should not expect a move to sell about 10% of the business, which specialises in gene-sequencing machines and other cutting-edge technology, before the end of February.

The move is likely to put a value on APBiotech of something upwards of $4bn, with Nycomed owning 55% and the balance belonging to America's Pharmacia. What is more, Nycomed has an option to by up to 20% of the business from Pharmacia during the second half of 2002 and can demand full control after 2004.

In the meantime, it is getting on with the little matter of "understanding the impact of genetic predisposition on the practice of medicine".

Spending in this area has been increased by £4m, but at the same time revenue flows have been held back by delays in launching certain technical platforms.

The net result yesterday was to leave shareholders twitchy ahead of the group's full-year figures, due at the end of February. There was a vague suspicion that the numbers were just not looking good enough for the management to go out on the road selling APBiotech.

In March, when investors were steaming into companies such as Nycomed, excited that genomic research might discover the key to life, the shares hit a peak of 745p.

They have been drifting lower ever since and yesterday's trading statement presented an irresistible opportunity to slice another 30p off the price to 525.5p.

Nycomed is an exciting, professionally run company, promising us everything from diagnostic tests for Parkinson's disease to new ways of screening lungs. The shares are only likely to travel sideways over the next couple of months. Hold.

webTitle: Leader: Should we follow the rabbi's lead?

fields.headline: The return of shame
fields.standfirst: Should we follow the rabbi's lead?
fields.trailText: Readers of the Jewish Chronicle may well have begun their weekend with a jolt. While idly flicking past the photos of Vanessa Feltz or a feature on  latkes , they would have found - opposite the "Faces & Places" photo-gallery of newly weds and bar mitzvah boys - a most striking advertisement.
fields.body:
Readers of the Jewish Chronicle may well have begun their weekend with a jolt. While idly flicking past the photos of Vanessa Feltz or a feature on latkes , they would have found - opposite the "Faces & Places" photo-gallery of newly weds and bar mitzvah boys - a most striking advertisement. Under the words, "Important Announcement" a London rabbi named an individual who has refused to grant his wife a religious divorce, or get , leaving her unable to marry a new partner in a synagogue.

"I wish to inform readers of this newspaper that Mr Yiki (Nick) Loewenstein of Hampstead Garden Suburb ..." it begins, going on to detail Mr Loewenstein's refusal to add a get to the civil divorce he and his wife sealed in 1991. The ad asks readers to help resolve "this impasse and thereby do our duty as a community".

For Chronicle readers this will be but the latest twist in what has been a long debate over how best to compel recalcitrant husbands to free their ex-wives. The plight of these "chained women" has become a civil liberties issue in Anglo-Jewry, which is anxious to find a way to prevent men being able to maintain a religious stranglehold over former wives.

But the latest tactic has a resonance beyond British Jewry. For what Rabbi Pini Dunner has done, by placing this ad, is to deploy the age-old weapon of shame. He is transparently seeking to shame Mr Loewenstein in public, a practice which is wholly sanctioned by Jewish tradition but which has fallen into disuse in wider British society.

Could it work for others? Government ministers often "name and shame" public services, but what about individuals? Perhaps shame might be a new remedy for anti-social behaviour: local papers might show the names and faces of those who had allowed their dogs to foul the pavement. But one thing is missing. The rabbi's appeal to shame works because Anglo-Jewry is still a community. How many of the rest of us can say the same?

webTitle: Letters: The vote on George W

fields.headline: The vote on George W
fields.trailText: A president elected by (some of) the people, for (some of) the people (Finally it's President Bush, December 14)? Justices stooping to act as political stooges? Uncounted votes? Hollow laughter.
fields.body:
A president elected by (some of) the people, for (some of) the people (Finally it's President Bush, December 14)? Justices stooping to act as political stooges? Uncounted votes? Hollow laughter. But the self-inflicted wound not only trivialises the US election process, it reinforces the cynical notion that all politicians are "in it for themselves". Our very concepts of the rule of law and the impartiality of officials are questioned. America is suddenly like the emperor in the story, left shivering, stripped of the very virtues we supposed were imbedded in its constitution.

Joyce Donoghue
Haywards Heath,
W Sussex

Harder to understand than the constitutional coup that has handed Bush the presidency is the apparent supine preference for "closure" at the expense of pursuing the cause of democracy shown by much of the US electorate and by Gore. Why should one be "gracious" in the face of such a travesty?

Keith O'Sullivan
Oxford

Surely the real tragedy of the supreme court decision is that we will now have to endure a vindicated Al Gore reapplying for the post in 2004? This will ensure a repeat of the most tedious election in history with a renewed fundamentalist fervour and even less discussion of the issues. The real losers are American liberals who will not get the chance to replace Gore with a more challenging candidate.

Max Benjamin
London

Let the American presidential election farrago be a lesson to those who think that a written constitution would solve all our problems.

Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University

It is ironic the Guardian is running its republican campaign while the greatest republic ever is tearing itself apart for lack of any authority above partisan politics. In this country, judges and civil servants still see themselves as non-political crown appointees, required to uphold the law regardless of party. Even in politics, "the public interest" is still addressed rather than naked party advantage (ask Shirley Porter). That is the strength of our historic, monarchical system.

Sir Alan Bailey
London

How ironic that the country that was the first role model for republicanism will now spend four years suffering from both the worst defects of the hereditary system and of the republican system. Our system has its absurdities, but at least Euan Blair will never be prime minister and the Queen is not split between Labour and Conservative.

Julian Bell London

Now that the US is celebrating its return to the hereditary principle, should the new president be known as George II or George V?

Tim Johnson
London

Will the Americans be able to figure out an election system so that next time the winner does not lose?

Steve Garnsey
Santiago, Chile

So, 200m citizens, nine voters. Is this the lowest turnout in electoral history?

Josh Winfield
London

It's Tweedledumb, then.

John Richards
St Ives, Cornwall

fields.headline: Gran abuse
fields.trailText: The new monthly grandparents' page is a great idea. But your first article about the increasing use/abuse of grandparents as childcarers  misses the point.
fields.body:
 The new monthly grandparents' page is a great idea. But your first article about the increasing use/abuse of grandparents as childcarers (Here we go again, December 14) misses the point. What we need is a coordinated, affordable system of childcare. Then, all the desperate scrabbling around with childminders, au pairs, grannies can stop. And a workplace culture that recognises that children sometimes get sick might be helpful too.

Heidi Bradshaw
Cambridge
heidi.bradshaw@talk21.com

Your opening article on grandparents only mentions grandmothers. Since it is they who are providing childcare (grandfathers are presumably pursuing their careers/hobbies) perhaps it should be a monthly grandmothers page.

Ruth Armitage
Leicester
Rutharm@btinternet.com
