webTitle: Letters: Viewers once again left in the dark

fields.headline: Viewers once again left in the dark
fields.trailText: The communications white paper does indeed leave us in the dark about the programming obligations of any future ITV contractor.
fields.body:
The communications white paper does indeed leave us in the dark about the programming obligations of any future ITV contractor. (Leader, December 13). In addition, it effectively leaves the public out in the cold where consultation is concerned.

This massive document, covering regulation, ownership, access, is loaded with proposals that will radically influence the nature of the programming and services available to the public. Yet the closing date for consultation is February 12 2001. How many members of the public will even know about this document and its implications, let alone have time to read, digest and respond to it?

This has the hallmarks of an attempt to stifle rather than promote debate on communications policy. If the government does not radically extend the deadline for consultation, and widen its methods of consultation on this vital issue, then it will be the public who are left in the dark, unable to see their way to having an input into this debate.

As we and others have argued for a number of years, there needs to be a full-scale public inquiry into these issues, not a hurried and inadequate consultation period which can only favour the media industry and their lobbyists.
Barry White
Campaign for Press and Broadcasting Freedom
freepress@cpbf.org.uk

 Voice of the Listener and Viewer welcomes the government's recognition that competition in a free market alone will not provide the range and quality of services that viewers and listeners have come to expect. We are pleased that for the first time there will be an independent advisory consumer panel for what will be a single, all-powerful regulator, overseeing every aspect of content and carriage in the digital age.

The obligations placed on Ofcom to promote greater media literacy are also welcome. But much work has to be done before viewers and listeners will truly become the "empowered digital citizens" the government desires.
Jocelyn Hay
Voice of the Listener and Viewer

webTitle: Letters: Men's take on Sophie Dahl's Opium

fields.headline: Men's take on Opium
fields.trailText: I was one of the road safety officers who were concerned with the Sophie Dahl Opium advert. It is one I believe would cause great distraction to drivers.
fields.body:
I was one of the road safety officers who were concerned with the Sophie Dahl Opium advert (Letters, Guardian, December 13). It is one I believe would cause great distraction to drivers. In Sheffield one was placed about 25m prior to a Pelican crossing, putting pedestrians at risk as well as car users.

I hope that this advert will be withdrawn and that the Advertising Standards Association takes into account the possible effect on road safety in vetting roadside adverts. There are many different ways of working towards the government's target of reducing road accidents. Highlighting distractions such as the above is one way.
John Wright
Sheffield city council

 When I first read about the fuss over the Sophie Dahl poster, I began to wonder what it could possibly look like to be so offensive. It was only when you printed an illustration of it I became aware that I had driven past it many times without it even registering. Does this suggest that I am a paid-up member of a more liberal society, or am I just getting old?
Jack Babrovskie
Stockport

 To the correspondent who asks what she should tell her two-year-old (Letters, December 14), I would suggest that all she needs to say is that "the lady has just had a bath and is getting ready to do some exercises".
David H Wild
Hemel Hempstead, Herts

 Surely if Vauxhall were to drop their offensively childish television ad campaign and take a leaf out of Opium's book, they'd have the macho men flooding back to the Vectra in no time.
Richard Booth
Bath

fields.headline: Politics of the street
fields.trailText: Mr Hague rightly worries about falling police numbers since 1993 (Anger as Hague is accused of playing the race card, December 15). But it is hardly a coincidence that in 1993 the last Conservative government launched a package of free-market reforms derived from the Sheehy Report, including substantial reductions in police pay and conditions of service.
fields.body:
Mr Hague rightly worries about falling police numbers since 1993 (Anger as Hague is accused of playing the race card, December 15). But it is hardly a coincidence that in 1993 the last Conservative government launched a package of free-market reforms derived from the Sheehy Report, including substantial reductions in police pay and conditions of service. The particularly sharp problems for London police are primarily a reflection of the same economic conditions in the capital that make recruitment acutely difficult for all public services there, notably the determination of housing and other costs by salary levels led by the City.

Mr Hague is also right to be concerned about the rise in crime figures over the last four decades. However, Conservative governments were in office for nearly three-quarters of that period. For most of the last 20 years they were in the thrall of a leader dedicated to the restoration of Victorian values. Well, she certainly succeeded in restoring Victorian levels of crime and social divisiveness. However, diverting genuine popular distress and anxiety on to scapegoats such as ethnic minorities or a supposed "liberal elite" has proved in the past to be a dangerously effective political tool, as another politician whose name begins with H showed 70 years ago.
Prof Robert Reiner
Professor of criminology
London School of Economics
R.Reiner@lse.ac.uk

fields.trailText: If all those fishermen who have been exploiting nature over the years had shown a modicum of concern for the consequences of this systematic killing off in the seas, unemployment would not have become a reality. If you take from nature, you have to give back to her.
fields.body:
As usual, codswallop (Cod quotas cut to all-time low, December 15). If all those fishermen who have been exploiting nature over the years had shown a modicum of concern for the consequences of this systematic killing off in the seas, unemployment would not have become a reality. If you take from nature, you have to give back to her.
Marion Dill
London

 Will David Blunkett (Tackle bullies outside school, teachers told, December 14) now start to tackle the massive problem of bullying of teachers (usually by headteachers) within schools, or don't the increasing numbers of stress-related teacher suicides matter?
Michael Ryan
Shrewsbury

 I am 21 and completed my first Quick Crossword on Monday after three years of trying. Is my poor record, when compared with older readers (Letters, December 14), yet another example of falling education standards?
Jessica Wright
Ware, Herts

 We in the public service have become familiar with the solution to inefficiency, chaos, overspending etc - privatisation. Has anyone thought of this as the answer to Railtrack (Comment, December 15)?
Ruth Knox
Secretary, Liverpool NUT

 The directors of Railtrack have to start somewhere in learning to run a railway. I thought therefore that it might help if I sent them a model railway for Christmas.

fields.headline: Chrystabel Leighton-Porter
fields.standfirst: Model for the Daily Mirror's Jane cartoon, whose saucy antics won the war for Britain
fields.trailText: Model for the Daily Mirror's Jane cartoon, whose saucy antics won the war for Britain
fields.body:
The former telephonist and beauty queen Chrystabel Leighton-Porter, who has died aged 87, was the model for the girl who put the strip into the Daily Mirror's comic strip cartoon, Jane, during the second world war. Light-hearted and usually lightly-clad, she boosted the morale of allied forces around the world; even Winston Churchill admitted that Jane was Britain's secret weapon.

When Jane appeared naked in 1944, the American service newspaper, Roundup, made it a headline story: "Jane gives all ... Right smack out of the blue, and with no one even threatening her, Jane peeled a week ago. The British 36th Division immediately gained six miles and the British attacked in the Arakan. Maybe we Americans ought to have Jane, too."

Created by artist Norman Pett in December 1932, the Jane character was originally posed for by his wife, Mary, but as the strip became more revealing, Pett sought out a professional model. He discovered blonde Chrystabel posing for life classes when he revisited his former art school in Birmingham in 1939.

Jane became noticeably more daring and accident-prone as the war grew darker, whether dancing a revealing can-can for a concert party, or losing her skirt climbing through a window chasing a fifth columnist. The continuity of the stories was fun but not important; stocking tops, cami-knickers, or an infrequent flash of nudity, as she bathed or changed clothes, was what her fans looked for every day.

In real life, the cartoon strip opened up other opportunities for its model, Leighton-Porter. Born in Eastleigh, near Southampton, she was the youngest of 11 children, and educated locally before becoming an artists' model in her late teens, and entering beauty contests, including one that crowned her "Venus of Kent".

Her success as Jane led to a contract with the theatrical impresario Leslie Grade and soon she was touring music halls in the stage show, Jane Out Of The Daily Mirror, mostly performed in areas with a high population of servicemen. For its time, it was a highly suggestive burlesque - popular with the audience (especially in bomb-torn London, where many artists refused to appear) but not with the Lord Chamberlain, who forbade Jane's nudity, except on paper.

The Jane character was the favourite of 90% of Daily Mirror readers in a survey carried out in 1946. In real life, Chrystabel's popularity kept her partying for a week in Trafalgar Square, Leicester Square and Piccadilly Circus when victory was declared in 1945. She received thousands of love letters from around the world, and, in one week alone, had 62 proposals of marriage. During her theatre tours as Jane, she met her future husband, RAF pilot Arthur Leighton-Porter; they married in 1946, a fact kept quiet at the time.

In 1948, artist Norman Pett moved to the Sunday Dispatch to create another blonde bombshell, Susie, although she never caught the public imagination as his earlier creation had done. Back at the Mirror, the task of portraying Jane fell to Pett's assistant, Michael Hubbard, who kept her postwar antics as saucy as ever, while giving the strip the more realistic look demanded in the era of classic girl-adventurer strips in the 1950s. In the face of the competition, Jane was eventually married off to her longtime boyfriend, Georgie Porgie, and the two sailed off into the sunset in October 1959.

All her life, Leighton-Porter continued to be identified with the character she had helped create. In 1949, she had starred in The Adventures Of Jane, a 55-minute black and white movie, in which a phoney, gem-smuggling sea captain had used her as an unwitting carrier for stolen diamonds. She made her last variety appearances in the early 1960s, and retired to Horsham, West Sussex, where she and her husband had lived since 1950.

There, she opened fetes, organised teas for the Horsham cricket club and gave after-dinner speeches. She was also often drawn out of retirement to help celebrate Jane, and attend reunions and wartime anniversary functions.

A television show, starring Glynis Barber as Jane, helped to revive the character in 1982, and her strip adventures reappeared in the Daily Mirror between 1985-90. In 1988, Chrystabel attended the premiere of a new Jane movie, Jane And The Lost City. During the anniversary of the D-Day landings, she was told by Major John Howard, who led the successful parachute drop at Pegasus Bridge, that, after the paratroopers, the second drop consisted of bundles of the Daily Mirror.

She is survived by her husband and her son, Simon.

 Chrystabel Jane Leighton-Porter, actress and model, born April 11 1913; died December 6 2000

fields.headline: Silly moo
fields.standfirst:
Hague's speech reminded me of another bald-headed bigot who got his facts wrong

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Hague's speech reminded me of another bald-headed bigot who got his facts wrong
fields.body:
These days, you can't even burn down a mosque without someone saying you're racist. You can't put on a pointy white hood, set fire to a cross and hold a rally for the Aryan master race without the liberal elite suddenly deciding that this would somehow be "politically incorrect". Try and kidnap young black people from West Africa and sell them as slaves to plantation owners in the deep South, and suddenly you'll find yourself being accused of "racial discrimination" by the PC police of Tony Blair's nanny state.

This was the essence of William Hague's speech on the Macpherson report. That yer anti-racism is all very well, but things have gone too far the other way. I'm sure I've seen that bald-headed bigot mouthing off about the blacks somewhere before? Of course, William Hague has turned into Alf Garnett. He sits in his armchair under portraits of the Queen and Churchill, ranting and raving and getting all his facts wrong. "Yer crime is going up, right?"

"No, it's going down."

"Shut up Ffion, you silly moo! Yer crime is going up because yer police numbers is falling under Labour."

"But police numbers have been falling since 1993."

"Exactly, cos yer bloody Macpherson says every one of 'em is racist."

"But the report was only last year and it never said that anyway."

"Look - shut up! And stop making out I'm racialist, you silly Welsh cow!"

What Hague was doing in his speech this week was shooting the messenger. What's more, Sir William Macpherson was an unarmed messenger, shot without provocation or warning and no doubt Hague will be cleared of all blame when they hold an internal inquiry. Macpherson had only confirmed what we all knew anyway, that racism was rife in the police force and that the constant harassment of black people was counter-productive to the fight against crime.

After an IRA bomb destroyed the Baltic Exchange in the City of London, a "ring of steel" was placed around the City, and armed police were stationed at checkpoints where they stopped any car suspected of containing Irish terrorists. I had never realised that there were so many black people in the IRA. Every week I would drive over Blackfriars Bridge and see armed police searching the car of yet another black man thought to be a dangerous Irish republican. "Here comes another Rasta, sarge! He looks like he's come straight from South Armagh with a car-load of Semtex."

But recently progress had started to be made. The police accepted the findings of the Macpherson report and the number of unnecessary "stop and searches" of black youths had dropped dramatically. The fragile, painstaking process of rebuilding bridges between the police and the black community was just beginning. Cue William Hague with his size 10 Dr Marten boots.

For the sake of perceived narrow party advantage between now and election day, he is prepared to stir up racism with a poisonous speech packed with prejudice, factual inaccuracies and straight forward lies. No wonder the father of Stephen Lawrence is so disgusted. The racists who regularly attack Britain's racial minorities need only the slightest encouragement to justify their actions. If the would-be prime minister says that blacks are getting away with crimes because the police aren't allowed to stop them, then young racists will interpret this as a call for them to step in to take action themselves. Hague must know this, but obviously doesn't care.

The time has come for Sir William Macpherson to do another report - this time to uncover the institutional racism inside the Conservative party. If Nelson Mandela had turned up at the Tory conference they would have asked if anyone ordered a minicab. The party that suggests it should govern multi-ethnic Britain does not have a single black or Asian MP. First we had Liam Fox stirring up racism by sounding off about Indian doctors who don't speak English properly, and now Hague is trying to equate crime and black people in the run-up to the election.

Typical - you get one racist move into the Conservative party and then another racist moves in next door and before you know it the whole party's full of them. I've nothing against Conservatives myself - they're good at sport and all that, Seb Coe and Colin Moynihan did us proud at the Olympics, but you have to admit that when it comes to crime; well, all I'll say is that without the likes of Jeffrey Archer and Jonathan Aitken the police wouldn't be under all this pressure in the first place.

Inciting racial hatred is against the law in this country but, of course, you're not allowed to arrest them for it, oh no, that would be politically incorrect. The Conservative establishment have made it impossible for the police to do anything about it. Real equality will only have arrived when the police stop and search William Hague for possession of an offensive speech every time he walks down the road.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Gwen Mellon
fields.standfirst: Free-spirited American who devoted her life and fortune to the health of the poor in Haiti
fields.trailText: Free-spirited American who devoted her life and fortune to the health of the poor in Haiti
fields.body:
The life of the nurse and philanthropist Gwen Mellon, who has died aged 89, was proof that, occasionally, the very rich do give it all up to help the very poor.

In 1956, with her doctor husband, Larry - and using their own private fortune - Gwen founded the L'Hopital Albert Schweitzer at Deschapelles, a remote part of central Haiti. When they arrived in the district, the only health care was two, small government clinics for 185,000 people.

Since then, the hospital, and its outreach centres, have evolved to provide a system of care for 2,500 patients a year and 400 outpatients a day - some of whom arrive on donkeys or bamboo stretchers - as well as offering every sort of community project through an outreach programme, thus bringing hope to the poorest of the poor.

Born in Englewood, New Jersey, to an upper-middle class New York family, Gwen attended a private boarding school in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, and graduated in 1934 from Smith College, Massachusetts. High spirited, beautiful and adventurous, she separated from her first, very conventional, husband, packed her bags, gathered up her three young children and took a job on a ranch in Arizona.

There, she met Larry Mellon, another refugee from conventionality and wealth, and heir to a banking and oil fortune. He had purchased, and personally ran, a small cattle ranch. They married in 1946.

But the pleasures of working under Arizona's azure skies only partially satisfied their spirits. Touched by a Life magazine article about Albert Schweitzer's hospital in west Africa, Larry began corresponding with its founder. When he told his wife that he was thinking of becoming a doctor and practising in the developing world, Gwen replied: "You're right, we don't want to sit around looking at the damn cows all our lives."

Based on Schweitzer's advice and their desire to follow his example, the Mellons started medical training at Tulane University in New Orleans - he as a doctor, she as a medical technician and nurse. Their studies finished, they visited Haiti and located an abandoned banana plantation in Deschapelles, 90 miles north of the capital, Port au Prince. Struck by both the poverty and the strength of the Haitian peasants, and Haiti's unique history and culture, they decided to use Larry's fortune to build a hospital there.

Gwen charmed General Paul Magloire, then Haiti's president, into granting them the permanent use of the plantation, and, abandoning their comfortable life in America, the Mellons moved to Haiti. There, living in adverse and trying conditions, they built and developed their dream. To have constructed and run a modern hospital in one of the most rural and inaccessible sites in one of the world's most impoverished countries was a formidable achievement.

After Larry died in 1989, Gwen took over the management of the hospital. Her office was a table under a mango tree in a courtyard, where she personally screened and talked with almost all the patients. During the violent and turbulent political unrest in Haiti, she was an elegant pillar of strength, calm and sympathy. Even as she grew frail with age, her spirit and mind remained sharp, as did the wit that sparkled in her striking blue eyes.

Last summer she wrote: "I often wonder how it is I am so lucky as to see the sun rise and look forward to what the day will bring. Since the opening of the hospital, we have daily been able to do what Dr Mellon and I came to do - improve the quality of life over the whole district. It is what makes the hospital unique; respect one for an other, and we will strive to keep it so."

Gwen Mellon possessed that rare combination of courage, spirit, intelligence, perseverance (I might add inner and outer beauty) and deep devotion to Haiti and its people. She and her husband's personal fortune was buried in the rich soil of Deschapelles and grew into a modern miracle. It was a rare and inspiring adventure. Her autobiography, My Road To Deschapelles, was published in 1997.

Gwen Mellon was buried in a cardboard box, the way the poorest of the very poor are buried on Haiti. She is survived by her daughter, Jennifer, and two sons, Ian and Michael.

 Gwendolyn Grant Mellon, nurse and philanthropist, born July 22 1911; died November 29 2000

webTitle: Life turns sour in the Soviet Milton Keynes

fields.headline: Life turns sour in the Soviet Milton Keynes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText:
When the Soviet central planners ordered this model
new town built to house the workforce from what had
just become the world's most notorious nuclear power
station, their black sense of irony knew no bounds.
fields.body:
When the Soviet central planners ordered this model new town built to house the workforce from what had just become the world's most notorious nuclear power station, their black sense of irony knew no bounds.

The plant 40 miles to the south, Chernobyl had become a grim byword for catastrophe, but the new flats were in a town called Slavutych or Little Glory.

But 13 years later, one of the great paradoxes of the Chernobyl legacy is that the world's worst nuclear disaster has generated the happiest town in Ukraine - Slavutych.

"We've got tennis courts, swimming pools, good schools, cable television, good hospitals. I'm glad I've brought my kids up here," Sergei Sharshun, a shift leader at the nuclear power plant, says.

The Slavutych birth rate is twice the national average. More than a quarter of the town population are under 16. The average age of the highly educated population of 26,000 is only 30. Income levels are also much higher than elsewhere in the country.

Slavutych may look drab to the western eye, but by the standards of Ukraine this Soviet Milton Keynes is as good as it gets. "We're a very young town," says the deputy mayor, Volodymyr Zhygallo.

But despite being in rude health, Slavutych appears condemned to a premature death.

When the Chernobyl station closed for ever yesterday, it signalled that the good life for the inhabitants of Slavutych is over. The town's raison d'etre has vanished. The future is gloomy. Jobs are scarce. Money is getting short. And the population is anxious.

"Almost all of our budget comes from Chernobyl taxes. There are no alternative sources of money and our state is broke," Mr Zhygallo adds.

A German nuclear engineer working at Chernobyl and living in Slavutych says that the authorities have known for more than five years that they were closing Chernobyl.

But, he shakes his head in disgust, they have done ab solutely nothing to prepare Slavutych for an early grave.

"It's the west that wants Chernobyl closed, not Ukraine," says Igor Oleynich, a Chernobyl engineer. "But what about us? The Americans should give us green cards. I'm going to the French embassy in Kiev to demand visas for me and my family."

Although in independent Ukraine, Slavutych remains a little Soviet island. The forest was cleared north of Chernobyl and the town was built from scratch and in record time within 18 months of the disaster in April 1986.

Almost all the Soviet republics were mobilised to contribute, so that housing schemes in the town are known as Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and so on.

The population, too, is "Soviet" rather than Ukrainian. The pre-disaster workforce lived in Pripyat, now an eery, irradiated ghost town near the plant.

The new workforce of 6,500, almost all of them newcomers, arrived from all over the Soviet Union to populate Slavutych and to take specially sealed commuter trains to work every day through the Chernobyl exclusion zone.

Mr Sharshun is not untypical. "I'm Russian, born in Belarus, grew up in Kazakhstan, studied in Moscow. Now I work in Ukraine," he says.

But half of Chernobyl's jobs will go shortly as a result of the closure. The rest of the jobs are certain to follow.

"These are the people who followed the government's appeal and came here. Now they're told 'thanks, bye-bye'," says Anatoly Nosovsky, who runs a local research centre. "They'll have big problems finding other jobs though they're highly qualified. Saying you're from Chernobyl is like having Aids. You get treated as a social leper."

Mr Oleynich says that even for those who keep their jobs at Chernobyl, the situation will get that much harder. "Who knows if we'll get paid. Will the rubbish get collected? Will there be heating at home?"

Like more than half the Chernobyl workforce, he is an ethnic Russian, originally from the Urals, but does not want to return to Russia. "The standard of living is much higher here and so is the level of culture."

But for how long? Another Chernobyl worker thinks Slavutych will sink rapidly to the level of other rundown Ukrainian towns and will soon suffer "crime, banditry, unemployment and prostitution".

"It's the Ukrainian government and the international community that are closing Chernobyl," says Mr Zhygallo. "Slavutych is their hostage."

fields.headline: Roy Ridgway
fields.trailText: Roy Ridgway, who was awarded the Albert Schweitzer gold medal for his humanitarian work and was part of a Nobel prizewinning peace team, has died aged 84.
fields.body:
Roy Ridgway, who was awarded the Albert Schweitzer gold medal for his humanitarian work and was part of a Nobel prizewinning peace team, has died aged 84. He was also the author of two groundbreaking books on prenatal and perinatal experiences, and the effects of nutrition on babies in the womb and, with his wife, set up a life-saving programme in Russia for children with cystic fibrosis.

Ridgway was born in Wallasey and educated at Rock Ferry school on the Wirral. At 19, he founded and jointly edited the Wirral Magazine. As a conscientious objector during the second world war, he was imprisoned for three months. On release, he trained as a nurse before joining the Friends Ambulance Unit.

After the war he returned to journalism and edited a range of magazines. From 1967-73, he edited New Doctor, a journal for GPs, before becoming a director of the Sparsholt Centre, near Winchester, one of the first places in Britain to teach humanistic psychotherapies.

At Sparsholt, where he gained fresh insights into the effects of prenatal memory, Ridgway began work on The Unborn Child (1987). In 1979, he joined the British Medical Association secretariat and edited its publication, News Review. Two years later, he and others in the medical profession sympathetic to the anti-nuclear cause, founded the Medical Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons, and Ridgway became European public-relations director for International Physicians against Nuclear Warfare (IPNW).

The group prepared two papers describing the scenario of an H-bomb on Boston, Massachusetts, and the effects of radiation fallout on children, and presented them to, among others, President Gorbachev. On the basis of this work, in 1985 Ridgway and four other IPNW members were awarded the Nobel peace prize.

Having dealt with what he saw as "the biggest negative to health", Ridgway wanted to concentrate on the positive. He had gone back to freelance work in 1983, and, that year, had co-founded the combined British and Russian medical exchange programme, now HealthProm, in order to coordinate validated complementary medicine with conventional.

His aim was always holistic; he was an ecologist, and felt that building community life, and a health programme using home-grown produce, was the best way to secure long-term health. In 1992, he founded the International Integregated Health Association (IIHA), and the 1990s also saw the publication of two further books, Preparing For Parenthood and Caring For Your Unborn Child. Both were based on his belief that many attributes and difficulties began to develop in the womb and that a mother's nutrition was crucial to a child's lifelong health.

His wife Dorothea was indispensable to his work. They married just after the second world war and had three children. Their youngest, Tony, who was born in 1955, suffered cystic fibrosis, and Roy and Dorothea spent 29 years working to give him a happy and creative life.

The first IIHA visit to Russia was in 1993. A year later, the Ridgways were in Moscow and took their experiences looking after Tony to the local hospital caring for some children with CF. Their work there mushroomed. Ridgway applied for grants and directed projects, including the Care of Children with Chronic Illnesses and their Families, funded by the European Commission.

Roy was spiritual but not religious, though he was close to the Quakers. A warm-hearted family man, in recent years he figured, in woolly-white hair and beard, as a Santa Claus twinkling among Russian children, a director negotiating with a team of medical consultants, and a comedian merrily goose-stepping across Red Square.

He is survived by Dorothea, a son and a daughter.

Heber Roy Ridgway, journalist and peace campaigner, born May 2 1916; died November 5 2000

fields.headline: Driving ban cut for rail 'victim'
fields.standfirst:
Judge offers sympathy over commuter's 'nightmare'

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Judge offers sympathy over commuter's 'nightmare'
fields.body:
While most commuters fume about the state of the railways, Cliff Newman must secretly be rubbing his hands. A judge yesterday cut the engineer's driving ban after hearing that he could not get to work on time because the train services were so appalling.

Mr Newman, 38, received a three-month ban in October after being caught speeding on his motorcycle at 101mph. It was his third offence.

He was obliged to make the 40-mile trip to work by train instead, but due to delayed and cancelled services found it took him over four hours to make a journey that previously took 45 minutes. Worried that he would lose his job because of his continual lateness, he launched a legal appeal.

At Swindon crown court, Judge Tom Longbotham cut his ban by three weeks, telling him: "Your driving record is atrocious. But taking into account the problems you have had arriving late at work and your tiredness, I will uphold the appeal."

The ruling came as official figures revealed that train punctuality performance was declining even before the Hatfield crash. Just one of the 25 train companies improved its punctuality in the six months ending just before the mid-October derailment compared with the same period in 1999.

Mr Newman said yesterday: "It was a nightmare every day. I never once arrived on time and when I finally got home at night I was exhausted."

He commutes from his home in Swindon, Wiltshire, to his job in Pangbourne, Berkshire. In his Vauxhall Nova it was a 45-minute drive, while on his 1,100cc Honda motorcycle it could take as little as 30 minutes.

But when police spotted him doing 101mph on the A4 at Yatesbury, Wiltshire, in August, he was hauled before magistrates. Because of two previous speeding offences, he was banned for three months from October 30.

His new journey, which involved changing at Didcot, cost him £65 a week in fares. To arrive in time for a 5.45am shift he had to leave home as early as 2am, around the same time he could expect to arrive home if working an evening shift.

"There were so many occasions when the train would just not turn up, then the next two or three after it were also cancelled," he said. "Then the next train that came along would be absolutely packed. It was exhausting.

"I work on a shift rota so the people I was taking over from were having to wait hours for me to arrive. They were very patient, and so were my bosses, but people were starting to question why I was always so late. In the six weeks I took the train I was not on time once, even giving myself a two-hour buffer zone. I was worried I could lose my job."

Mr Newman will now receive his licence on January 8, when he returns to work after a Christmas break.

 A man has been sacked after driving a freight train while four times over the drink-drive limit, it emerged yesterday. The driver was reported to have been travelling from Garelochhead to Mossend, Lanarkshire, when he was stopped by signalmen after taking 45 minutes to cover the first 10 minutes of the journey.

More about transport

webTitle: French kidnapper to get off, because he admits murder

fields.headline: French kidnapper to get off, because he admits murder
fields.trailText:
A man arrested this week for the murder of seven
mentally handicapped young women more than 20
years ago could be released if French police find their
bodies.
fields.body:
A man arrested this week for the murder of seven mentally handicapped young women more than 20 years ago could be released if French police find their bodies.

Emile Louis, 66, a retired bus driver from Auxerre, 90 miles south-east of Paris, has confessed to killing the girls, all of whom lived with foster families and attended special day care centres. They disappeared without trace between 1977 and 1979.

After one of the most bungled investigations in French judicial history, he was detained on Monday on a charge of kidnapping, a crime technically considered to be over once it is proved that the victim is no longer being held.

But in a final absurdity, Mr Louis is very likely to be set free if the kidnapping charge reverts to one of murder following the discovery of the victims' bodies - because under the French criminal code, murder is covered by a 10-year statute of limitations.

"It is a terrible situation," said Pierre Gonzalez de Gaspard, a lawyer acting for the families of some of the victims.

"No one in France would understand how, if a man being prosecuted for kidnapping can face up to 20 years in prison, he can be released the next day under the statute of limitations if he is actually guilty of murder."

The case has prompted outrage in France, not just at the prospect of Mr Louis's release but at the shocking lack of concern it has revealed on the part of the social services.

The police were never officially informed of the girls' disappearances and it was not until a relatives' group was formed in 1996 that the case was taken seriously.

The chief state prosecutor in Auxerre, Marie-Suzanne Le Quéau, announced yesterday that Mr Louis had admitted killing the women, aged between 16 and 22, "after having what he said were fully consensual sexual relations with each of them".

She said the murders were committed over two years during the late 1970s, when Mr Louis - who had a previous conviction for sex offences - regularly transported the victims from their homes to the day care centres.

Ms Le Quéau added that Mr Louis, who was charged and then later released in 1984 during an investigation into the murder of another young woman in care, had told police where he thought he had buried the bodies, and a major search operation was currently under way.

Mr Louis's lawyer, Alain Thuault, said yesterday: "Bizarrely, my client's best hope is that they find the bodies. As soon as they do, the case against him must be dropped."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Franco-German fence-mending
fields.body:
Franco-German fence-mending

Germany and France are to hold an emergency summit next month to try to rebuild the relationship damaged by Germany's drive at the Nice summit to gain more power in EU decision-making because of its larger population.

The Franco-German alliance has been based on exact parity but Germany's population is almost 40% bigger than France's.
John Hooper, Berlin

Tycoon's empire under threat

The tycoon Vladimir Gusinsky came under intensified pressure from the Russian authorities yesterday with the revelation that the Moscow tax office has demanded that his Media Most company - including the influential NTV televi sion station - be shut on the grounds of insolvency.

Media Most officials declared there were no unpaid bills and that the move was part of a Kremlin campaign to close all media outlets critical of the state. Mr Gusinsky remains in prison in Spain and Russia is pursuing his extradition.
Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Canal dredgers strike gold

Two Dutch canal dredgers became celebrities last week when they found three Olympic medals and six championship medals in the mud of a canal near Breda. The medals were stolen six months ago from the home of the former British speedskating champion Wilf O'Reilly.
AP, Breda

Belgians fear return of wolf

Farmers in northern Belgium are hunting for a mysterious beast, thought to be a wolf, which has killed at least 10 sheep in the past few weeks. Wild wolves are thought to be extinct in north-western Europe but the animal could be a cross between a dog and a wolf.
Reuters, Brussels

webTitle: Tragedy of Chernobyl does not end with simple switch-off

fields.headline: Tragedy of Chernobyl does not end with simple switch-off
fields.standfirst:
Ukraine shuts plant at centre of world's worst nuclear disaster but poisoned legacy of accident still wrecks lives

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Ukraine shuts plant at centre of world's worst nuclear disaster but poisoned legacy of accident still wrecks lives
fields.body:
It fell to the control room engineer Oleksandr Yelchishchev to turn a small plastic switch to the off position yesterday, shutting down the last remaining nuclear reactor at Chernobyl for the final time.

It activated an automatic safety system, sending control rods down into the core of the plant. As sombre workers in white protective gowns watch-ed, a dial showed the output from reactor three dropping slowly to zero.

Broadcast live around the world, this simple act marked the conclusion of the tragic history of the Chernobyl atomic power station, site of the world's most devastating nuclear accident 14 years ago.

The exact death toll from the disaster remains unknown, but thousands of people in Ukraine, Russia and Belarus have died as a result and millions more have been poisoned by the heavy cloud of radiation emitted by the reactor.

The Ukrainian president, Leonid Kuchma, gave the order for the plant to be shut down by video link from a strangely garish state ceremony in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev.

"This decision came from our experience of suffering," he declared. "We understand that Chernobyl is a danger for all of humanity and we forsake a part of our national interests for the sake of global safety."

Guests from all over the world were there, as the Ukrainian government tried to create an atmosphere of openness - in pointed contrast to the secrecy surrounding the initial catastrophe.

At 1.26am on April 26 1986, a series of powerful blasts caused by overheated steam inside the plant devastated Chernobyl's fourth reactor and unleashed a radioactive cloud over Ukraine, Belarus, Russia and much of Europe. The disaster was triggered by an attempt to test the unit's full capacity, during which staff decided to temporarily switch off the safety systems.

For days after the explosion, Soviet authorities withheld news of the accident. No one was evacuated from nearby towns and firemen and workers fighting the fire raging at the plant were given little protective equipment.

It was only when scient- ists from Sweden became concerned at unusually high radiation levels that information was prised out of Mikhail Gorbachev's administration. By that time tonnes of radioactive strontium, caesium, iodine and plutonium had spewed from the burning shell of the reactor and were spreading across Europe.

Ukrainian government figures state that more than 4,000 cleanup workers have died and a further 70,000 have been crippled by radiation poisoning. About 3,400,000 people, including 1,260,000 children, are suffering from fallout-related illnesses.

Unofficial statistics put the casualty rates much higher. A World Health Organisation report earlier this year said that a further 50,000 new cases of thyroid cancer were likely to develop in young people living in the worst affected region, known as the Zone.

International safety concerns have not been resolved with Chernobyl's closure. The huge million-tonne concrete sarcophagus constructed over the melted ruins of the reactor is cracking, allowing radiation to leak out. Officials have still to decide how the radioactive dust and nuclear fuel inside should be cleaned up.

Environmental groups have expressed dismay at a decision by the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development to help fund the completion of two new nuclear plants in Ukraine to replace Chernobyl. The bank last week agreed, under strict conditions, to lend £150m to finish partially built plants at Rivne and Khmelnitsky, while the European commission has approved an additional £340m worth of loans.

The plant's workers, most of whom will shortly be unemployed, complain that the repaired reactor was safe to continue working for at least another 10 years and was shut because Ukraine had buckled under western pressure.

Moscow has agreed to allow Norway to inspect an arctic storage area for spent nuclear fuel and radioactive waste. It was previously off-limits because it is near a key submarine base on the Kola peninsula. The Norwegian government said yesterday that it had earmarked £1.5m for cleaning up Andreeva bay, close to Norway's north-east border.

At 1.26am on April 26 1986, a series of powerful blasts caused by overheated steam inside the plant devastated Chernobyl's fourth reactor and unleashed a radioactive cloud over Ukraine, Belarus, Russia and much of Europe. webTitle: Life for millionaire who killed wife

fields.headline: Life for millionaire who killed wife
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman who drowned his handcuffed wife in the bath to avoid a "messy" and expensive divorce was jailed for life yesterday.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman who drowned his handcuffed wife in the bath to avoid a "messy" and expensive divorce was jailed for life yesterday.

Alun Phillips, 36, carried out the attack against a background of an empty marriage that hid jealousy, infidelity and long-held thoughts of murdering the mother-of-three.

Southwark crown court in south London heard that Phillips and his wife, Nadine, were in their town house in Fulham, west London, last May when he half throttled her with his forearm, then handcuffed her arms behind her before forcing her naked into the bath. Their children were asleep nearby.

Over the next few hours he put the finishing touches to an elaborate tale of "an evil intruder" murdering the woman he told the jury he had never stopped loving. He then raised the alarm, claiming he had just found the body. But his plot lacked any signs of break-in and within hours he had been arrested.

He denied murder at his trial last month but was convicted. Sentencing was adjourned for psychiatric reports, which showed that he did not suffer from mental disorder.

Passing sentence, Judge Geoffrey Rivlin QC told Phillips: "This was cold-blooded murder. You had been brooding on this crime for some time and it was committed in the most horrific circumstances."

Earlier, Richard Ferguson QC, defending, told the court he had nothing to say by way of mitigation apart from the fact that during a short chat his client was still showing a "very genuine concern" for his children's future welfare.

During the 2-week trial, Phillips tried to portray himself as an eccentric who loved order and routine almost as much as his family. After a "brief fling" his wife had had a few years earlier, their marriage had returned to its former happy state, he insisted.

Of the night Nadine died, the businessman - who could become Britain's richest prison inmate if, as expected, he inherits up to half of his late father's £30m fortune - claimed he had been upstairs in the soundproof office where he slept alone.

But the jury was told the reality was of a husband who had contemplated killing his wife for nearly half of the seven-year marriage, which began after the radio presenter, Chris Tarrant, helped him to propose live on air. On three occasions, in front of witnesses, Phillips threatened to end his wife's life.

fields.headline: Corporate clairvoyancy a mug's game
fields.standfirst: A cooling economy means next year's company bean count is even more of a lottery
fields.trailText: A cooling economy means next year's company bean count is even more of a lottery
fields.body:
If you work in a well-grooved organisation, next year's budgets will already have been put to bed. They'll be brought out at regular intervals as a stick to beat you with. Surpass them and it'll be suggested that you under-cooked expectations at the outset. Fall short and your capabilities will be called into question. The bad news is that, with the world's economy cooling, they're probably too high before 2001 has even begun.

The annual planning process is a fact of corporate life. Only the most sadomasochistic bean counter can derive any pleasure from the attritional tug-of-war that is involved. No one gives it their best, most honest shot at the outset, because across the table will be a colleague turned adversary whose own success will be measured by his or her ability to tweak up forecasts and chisel out costs. Typically, weeks if not months are wasted in this corporate clairvoyancy.

The stock market is fuelled by derivative analysis. Companies convey expectations of their futures to investment analysts who then strain them through their own forecasting filters. Much of the written work of these analysts is about movements in expectations, gaps between the "realities" of different observers, and risks to both.

Share prices are a function of the expectations of all the participants in the market. The value of a company is typically considered, in turn, to be a function of that business's future profits or the dividends it chooses to pay to investors out of those profits. Visibility differs across industries and companies, but nowhere can anyone have 20-20 foresight.

Small changes in expectations can have dramatic effects on share prices. Knock a couple of % off forecasts for a company's profit growth over the coming 12 months and you lower the base for future profits and call into question the rate of growth in future years. The net effect might be a perceived fall in that company's value many times greater than the reduction in near-term profit expectations.

This phenomenon goes some way to explaining the excruciating annual planning process that companies indulge in. The line between a go/no-go decision is often fine. Once made, investment decisions can be difficult, costly and embarrassing to unwind. To play the planning game as an underling you must develop a Jekyll and Hyde persona - optimistic about new investment projects and stubbornly cautious about ongoing businesses.

Global stock markets have fallen victim to downgrade amplification in recent months. As companies have warned of slower growth their share prices have been hammered. Executives may feel they've been harshly treated but they are one molecule in a giant crystal ball. Together the downgraded prospects add up to a sharp deceleration in the pace of expansion of the world's economy. Official statistics strengthen this economic conclusion.

The recent downbeat statements from quoted companies span the industrial spectrum. Technology no longer appears a guaranteed winner in the real economy (it's months since it seemed so in the investment arena). Microsoft earnings are now expected to expand by only 5% in 2001. Perhaps it's just going the way of IBM a generation ago, outstripped by new technologies. However, forecasts for these new technologies are also being trimmed, suggesting scepticism about their worth and a knock-on from the economic slowdown.

Old economy sectors have also suffered. Shares in some of America's industrial giants are now selling on multiples of around 10 times the most up-to-date forecasts of next year's profits. Cheap as chips? Only if the US economy enjoys a gently cushioned landing. The risks of a painful belly flop remain too high, however.

In an economic slowdown, low valuations for industrial companies usually flash an amber warning of impending profit downgrades rather than a green buy signal. The real, hidden valuation multiples are much higher than those published by investment analysts struggling to keep up with the poor news.

Corrective mechanisms

Before you rush out and liquidate your equity portfolio, remember that economies contain corrective mechanisms. Remember also that the extent of the slowdown is unknown - it may be shallow - and that equity markets have been adjusting to the changing outlook for some months already. Just make sure that your bullshit detector is finely tuned.

The latest US banks to add to the negative newsflow in their industry are Chase and JP Morgan - in the process, as it happens, of merging with each other. Like Bank of America before them, they warn of deteriorating credit quality and the impact of the downturn in equity markets on their investment banking income. Once again, the tech-stock crash lies at the heart of both problems.

The media responded to Chase's signal with a rash of articles flagging a squeeze on 2,000 bonuses for the world's investment bankers and brokers. Chase, though, has a bonus problem of its own making. Its merger with JP Morgan follows only months behind its purchase of Flemings. A number of Flemings employees were furnished with golden handcuffs to secure their commitment to the deal. Now some of them are being made redundant to make way for their erstwhile rivals from JP Morgan. A case of fool's gold, perhaps?

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: Guns for sale - how stolen Israeli weapons arm Fatah's fighters

fields.headline: Guns for sale - how stolen Israeli weapons arm Fatah's fighters
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian rifles and bullets taken from army depots are killing settlers and soldiers. Why is the enemy turning a blind eye?

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Three shots ring out in the still of the afternoon, and three Palestinians run for cover. The Israeli army sniper on the 25 metre-high security tower watches the men below scatter and dive for gaps in the concrete wall.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg at the Rafah border, Gaza Strip
fields.body:
Three shots ring out in the still of the afternoon, and three Palestinians run for cover. The Israeli army sniper on the 25 metre-high security tower watches the men below scatter and dive for gaps in the concrete wall.

As Sergeant Dan Jacobi pulls the trigger, one Palestinian shoves a wooden crate into waiting hands on the Gaza side of the wall: one more lethal cargo slipping past Israeli troops, one more shipment of arms and ammunition for the Palestinian uprising.

With the insurrection entering its 12th week, the West Bank and Gaza are awash with illegal weapons - enough to keep the militiamen of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement fighting for months, the Guardian has learned.

The secret trade obscures an embarrassing fact: that the Palestinians are getting their guns straight from the Israeli army's arsenals. In this increasingly vicious guerrilla war, the guns turned on Israeli troops and Jewish settlers are Israel's own.

Evidence is emerging that arms are being smuggled from Israeli army weapons depots through a criminal world to the Palestinian militias. Jewish and Arab Israeli arms dealers are acting as middlemen.

The steady flow has helped to transform this intifada from a popular uprising into a low-intensity guerrilla war.

During the 1987-1993 uprising the Palestinians' favourite weapon was the rock. Nowadays, as Palestinian gunmen spray settlers' cars with bullets in drive-by shootings and Israeli hit squads assassinate suspected militants, the preferred weapon is the American-made M16 assault rifle, which is used by the Israeli army.

"I could sell a thousand guns a day if I wanted to," says a gun dealer operating from the West Bank city of Nablus. "Especially big pieces like the M16."

Israeli intelligence officials claim that the Palestinian militias - tanzim - have 70,000 guns at the ready: M16s and other automatic rifles mainly, but heavy machine guns, too. "They are not going to run into any shortage of guns or ammunition," an Israeli military official says.

Together the move from rocks to rifles and Israel's early use of live rounds and snipers have driven the death toll inexorably upwards. More than 320 people have been killed in the past 11 weeks the vast majority of them Palestinian. In the first 30 months of the more intense 1987 intifada 670 Palestinians died.

The weapons shaping the present intifada arrive through a variety of channels. At the Rafah border crossing to Egypt, shipments are tossed over the fence by Egyptian dealers, or slid along tunnels burrowed beneath the border road.

Some arms trickle in through Jordan, carried on small boats across the Dead Sea, or by Bedouin trekking over the wind-swept desert hills.

Still more travel in air-conditioned luxury, tucked into the Mercedes and Audis of the most privileged Palestinian officials - the lucky few holding VIP-1 status, giving them immunity from security checks. Others are trafficked by organised criminals.

But, as officials on both sides agree, most of the illegal guns can be traced back to Israeli army stores. Once stolen, they are spirited away to the West Bank and through a series of shadowy transactions into the hands of the tanzim.

A few weeks ago Palestinian gunmen waltzed into an Israeli army tank depot near the West Bank city of Jericho, stripping off four heavy machine guns, and drove off into the desert, Israeli military official says.

That was an unusually dramatic incident; most of the theft is done by stealth and betrayal.

"Inside jobs," says Mr Ali, who counts himself among the leading suppliers of illegal weapons in the West Bank.

He says the most reliable sources are the Israeli army weapons exchanges, where soldiers deposit their guns for maintenance or repair. A raid on these depots typically nets 30 guns for the tanzim : M16s and other automatic rifles, and Uzis. Mr Ali grimaces at the last: Israeli-made guns are not popular with his clients.

He describes an elaborate chain, improbably linking a Palestinian gunman with a corrupt Israeli soldier (or officer) who organises the disappearance of weapons from the army stores.

Mr Ali says the trade hinges on a rogue soldier. "It takes a leader, someone in command, to make it work."

The senior Israeli military official cannot deny it."We have had cases like that. I can't rule it out."

Mr Ali says the betrayal is driven by money or drugs. But once a soldier decides to steal, there are many willing buyers among Israeli criminals, Jewish and Arab. The Israeli gun dealers then exchange the stolen arms for cash or drugs from their Palestinian counterparts, who move them on to small-scale weapons traders or the militias.

The paymaster behind all these transactions is alleged to be the Fatah organisation, which then sells the guns on to the tanzim , or, according to some militia members, doles them out for free.

Moving the guns inside the West Bank has become trickier because of Israel's economic blockade, however - new restrictions ban cars carrying only Palestinian males. Such laws have forced Israeli dealers to making drop-offs in the stoney hills of the West Bank, or employing female couriers to charm their way past soldiers at checkpoints.

A week ago the Balata refugee camp militia, one of the toughest, got an unexpected gift when a Jewish settler drove into the West Bank with a shipment of 12,000 bullets.

"I swear to God a Jewish person passed in front of the Israeli soldiers with this," says Majid al-Massri, the militia commander. "Do you know how much money he made? Thirteen thousand shekels [about £2,150]."

Mr Massri's arsenal includes a wide array of weapons. Aside from the Iraqi-made, nickel-plated pistol at his hip, he has a fondness for a cache of 52 M16s emblazoned with cypress trees - the national symbol of Lebanon - stolen from the South Lebanese Army, Israel's proxy militia, by departing troops during Israel's withdrawal last May.

Mr Massri has no shortage of guns or ammunition to choose; his only problem is price, driven up by the Israeli economic blockade and spiralling demand.

A single M16 round now sells for up to two shekels (about 30p), double the price before the uprising. Rounds for Kalashnikov sell for seven shekels each, out of range for the militias.

Gun prices have also soared. On the street, where prices are customarily quoted in Jordanian dinars, the going rate for a M16 is 3,500 dinars (£3,350), up from 2,000 dinars.

Limited firepower

Nobody expects the trafficking of illegal weapons to end when the intifada stops. Gun running is a product of peace, the result of the loosening of controls over Palestinian enclaves which came with the Oslo agreements.

The peace agreements gave the Palestinians the right to raise police forces in the West Bank and Gaza, but severely limited their firepower. The Palestinian Authority was also obliged to hunt down and confiscate illegal private firearms.

It did not. Over the last six years, guns have become a symbol of family honour. In some West Bank refugee camps they are displayed like university diplomas.

Israel accuses the Palestinians of breaking its promise to round up illegal guns by collecting only a token amount of weapons. "They made no effort to confiscate arms, and the guns stayed in the hands of the tanzim and of Hamas," the senior Israeli military official said.

The Palestinians say this is unfair. "Israel manufactures guns and controls all the borders," says Colonel Kamal al-Sheikh, the Palestinian police chief in Ramallah. "We don't manufacture guns, and we don't control the borders. So tell me, who is responsible for the gun smuggling?"

He argues that the authorities in Ramallah did confiscate illegal guns - albeit a laughable total of 28, some of them of second world war vintage. In times of conflict the rules change, and the Palestinians have no intention of disarming the "tens and thousands" of militiamen now bearing arms, Col Sheikh says. "We are not about to confiscate those while Israeli soldiers and settlers are shooting at Palestinians."

Col Sheikh and other Palestinian officials have a convincing counter-argument to Israel's charges. They claim that Israeli security and intelligence forces keep a close eye on the trafficking of arms to the Palestinian militias, and to the underworld.

But Israel secretly encourages the trade - even now - hoping to provoke a civil war that will see Palestinians turn their guns on each other once the battle with Israel is over and a peace deal struck.

If Mr Arafat agrees to an unpopular deal, he could face armed opponents who resist handing over their guns. That would make it practically impossible for Mr Arafat to enforce an eventual truce, and move beyond the cycle of killing and revenge that now consumes both peoples. Even if there is a deal, the gun could still rule.

Many of the fighters now aiming their guns at Jewish settlements also believe that they are operating with Israel's tacit approval. "If they want to stop a fly from getting to Bethlehem they can, so I don't know why they cannot control the ammunition coming in," says a militia commander directing gunfire against the Jewish settlement of Gilo from the Palestinian town of Beit Jalla.

The commander, who gave only his first name - Mike - added: "You cannot just put 20, 30 or 40,000 bullets in your pocket and just walk in. Someone has to want you to."

"We are not about to confiscate those while Israeli soldiers and settlers are shooting at Palestinians." Col Sheikh and other Palestinian officials have a convincing counter-argument to Israel's charges. They claim that Israeli security and intelligence forces keep a close eye on the trafficking of arms to the Palestinian militias, and to the underworld. But Israel secretly encourages the trade - even now - hoping to provoke a civil war that will see Palestinians turn their guns on each other once the battle with Israel is over and a peace deal struck. If Mr Arafat agrees to an unpopular deal, he could face armed opponents who resist handing over their guns. That would make it practically impossible for Mr Arafat to enforce an eventual truce, and move beyond the cycle of killing and revenge that now consumes both peoples. Even if there is a deal, the gun could still rule. Many of the fighters now aiming their guns at Jewish settlements also believe that they are operating with Israel's tacit approval. "If they want to stop a fly from getting to Bethlehem they can, so I don't know why they cannot control the ammunition coming in," says a militia commander directing gunfire against the Jewish settlement of Gilo from the Palestinian town of Beit Jalla. The commander, who gave only his first name - Mike - added: "You cannot just put 20, 30 or 40,000 bullets in your pocket and just walk in. Someone has to want you to."

webTitle: Struggling museum to become a restaurant

fields.headline: Dining out on the past
fields.standfirst: Museum to become a restaurant
fields.trailText: A struggling regional museum, which like many small museums is facing falling visitor numbers and major building repair bills, will become a bar and restaurant as the best way of saving the listed building and its collection, writes Maev Kennedy.
fields.body:
A struggling regional museum, which like many small museums is facing falling visitor numbers and major building repair bills, will become a bar and restaurant as the best way of saving the listed building and its collection, writes Maev Kennedy.

Blake's Lock, in Reading, Berkshire, is believed to be the first museum in Britain to take such a radical step.

Karen Knight, director of Reading museum services, who persuaded the local authority to accept the plan, said: "This is not a counsel of despair. Rather, this is a 'win win' situation."

The museum now gets under 10,000 visitors a year, and opens only at weekends and bank holidays.

Councillors voted this week to let the Blake's Lock building on a 10-year repairing lease: it needs an estimated £250,000 work, including the roof.

The preferred tenant is Bel and the Dragon, a small chain which has experience of renovating old buildings.

Details have still to be worked out, but it is proposed that most of the collection would be redisplayed in another building on the site.
