webTitle: A host of celebrity critics choose their books of the year

fields.headline: What were you looking at?
fields.standfirst: A host of celebrity critics choose their books of the year
fields.trailText: A host of celebrity critics choose their books of the year
fields.body:
Nick Hornby
Writer

The omission from the Booker shortlist of Zadie Smith's startlingly ambitious, wise, funny and warm White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99) was both depressing and baffling - I'm sure I wasn't the only one chanting "You don't know what you're doing" at the hapless judges. The best non-fiction book I read was Dave Eggers's wonderful, maddening A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99): believe the hype, and the title. There have been two book-length editions of Eggers's extraordinary self-published McSweeney's magazine this year - both of them dazzling, and more intimidatingly imaginative than anything any of the big publishing houses have produced.

Richard Dawkins
Charles Simonyi Professor at Oxford University and author

Steve Grand is the creator of what I think is the nearest approach to artificial life so far, and his first book, Creation: Life and How to Make It (Weidenfeld, £18.99) is as interesting as you would expect. But he illuminates more than just the properties of life: his originality extends to matter itself and the very nature of reality. Not since David Deutsch's The Fabric of Reality (Penguin, £8.99) have I encountered such a compelling invitation to think everything out afresh, from the bottom up.

Maureen Lipman
Actor and writer

I have enjoyed my millennium read-in in a very catholic way. I started with Coetzee's Disgrace (Vintage, £6.99), which I read in South Africa and found chilling, sparse and beautifully written. I did Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Bloomsbury, £14.99) in Ireland and scarcely looked up at the scenery, and Barbara Kingsolver's The Prodigal Daughter (Faber, £17.99) had me spellbound on tour. It's a book which features none of my interests, and I was riveted. Perhaps the most pleasure has come from Persephone's enchanting reprints, particularly Winifred Watson's Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (Persephone, see Small Press, page 11), a fairy story set in 1930s London, and the funny, stoic and dashing poetry of Virginia Graham. I had the most fun with Howard Jacobson's The Mighty Walzer (Vintage, £6.99), which achieved the impossible and still leaves a glow whenever I think of it.

Claire Rayner
Writer and broadcaster

I've spent most of my available reading for pleasure time this year going back to old delights, notably Elaine Morgan, published by Souvenir Press. Her Descent of Woman, Scars of Evolution and Falling Apart: The Rise and Decline of Urban Civilisation are as wise, witty and refreshing as they were when I first read them almost 25 years ago. But I did find two new books which I think could be as re-readable a couple of decades hence. Peter Ackroyd's London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25) fits snugly on my bookshelves alongside Mayhew, H V Morton and Walter Besant. Like them he has an eye for the sheer oddity of London and Londoners, and writes about us with wit and elegance. Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99), which deals with the relationship between brothers of very disparate age, is a great read.

Posy Simmonds
Cartoonist

Judith Thurman's Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette (Bloomsbury, £7.99) is an intelligent, witty and sympathetic portrait of the novelist, libertine, sexual dissident and toast of the belle époque aesthetes. My other choice is The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde, edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis (Fourth Estate, £35). I dipped into them, became enthralled and then read them chronologically. Over 1,500 letters, from the trivial to the tragic, are wonderfully enriched by the footnotes, which illuminate the world in which their writer moved.

Ben Okri
Novelist

This year I chaired the first Caine Prize for African Writing and found a wealth of talents. I recommend a general interest in African writing to widen taste and see how other people live, dream, and overcome. The story that won the prize, Leila Aboulela's "The Museum", is moving, gentle, ironic, quietly angry and beautifully written. My favourite novel of the year deserves evangelism. Joseph Roth's The Radetsky March (Penguin, £8.99) is that rarest of rare things: a masterwork that is a true joy to read.

Edward Bond
Playwright

Our theatre gives its talented young playwrights no chance to develop; instead they create a Theatre of Symptoms. When Sarah Kane's Blasted was staged, the critics attacked it with the panicky rage which is the sign that finally they are writing about something profoundly important. The only contemporary play I wish I'd written, it is revolutionary. The counter-revolution came swiftly: she killed herself. 4.48 Psychosis (Methuen, £6.99) is her suicide note, very personal. But playwrights become as important as she has only if their psyche is public. Neither God nor genes gives us our humanity, we create it through our culture. We have ceased to create: we are dead and kept alive by the life-support machine of our colossal technology. No doubt we will turn it off. 4.48 is a great play: bitterly comic, full of a desire for life. It is also the document of our time. Read it - this suicide note is your obituary.

Susie Orbach
Therapist and writer

The giant talent of Philip Roth taking on post-Vietnam America in The Human Stain (Cape, £16.99) is breathtaking. He is so acute and such a fine storyteller that we feel we all have those thoughts and insights in just the sequence he lays out for us. We learn what we have wanted to turn away from and not see. And then a magical new talent: Zadie Smith's White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99). Rich, unforced, wonderful. Finally, Rebecca Goldstein's Properties of Light (US, Houghton Mifflin, $23), in which the philosopher novelist takes on the anti-materialism of modern physics.

Lewis Wolpert
Biologist and writer

Suicide is terrible, both for the feelings that lead an individual to kill themselves, and for those who remain behind. Kay Redfield Jamison knows suicide almost too well as she only just survived her own attempt. In Night Falls Fast (Picador, £16.99), she focuses on young adults, for whom it is a major cause of death. Depression is a strong predictor of a suicide attempt and one in five of those with a major depressive disorder will attempt to kill themselves. Better understanding and prevention are major issues. An important, moving and informative book.

Helen Boaden
Radio 4 controller

Andrew Greig dedicated his novel That Summer (Faber, £9.99) to "the vanishing generation" of the second world war, and it's a worthy tribute. It's a love story set against the Battle of Britain: the prose is restrained, the plot uncomplicated but the emotion powerful. Len is a gauche young fighter pilot; Stella, a radar operator, is more middle-class, more sophisticated, more wary. The progress of one critical summer and the sweetly tender way they fall in love is told in their alternating voices. You could say that it's a slight tale about ordinary people, but I found myself thinking about it long after weightier tomes had been put aside.

Jenny Eclair
Comedian, novelist

My favourite book of short stories this year was Jeremy Dyson's Never Trust a Rabbit (Duck Editions, £9.99). Dyson is one of the League of Gentlemen misfits and an all-round clever bloke; it's time people stopped being so suspicious of performer/writers. At the moment I want to be Douglas Coupland. His Miss Wyoming (Flamingo, £5.99) is wonderful stuff: he manages to be wacky without being zany. Next year I might try and read some intellectually challenging books but I get headaches rather easily. En route to the Montreal comedy festival I read Tony Parsons's Man and Boy (HarperCollins, £6.99), which made me gulp and sob. It was funny and sad and marvellously emotionally manipulative. A good cover, too. In Corsica I hugely enjoyed India Knight's My Life on a Plate (Penguin, £5.99), as did my 11-year-old, who guffawed all the way through it. I kicked myself along the beach for not writing it myself. I smell a film deal with this one, the lucky cow.

Mike Atherton
Cricketer

Moth Smoke by Mohsin Hamid (Granta, £9.99) is a Pakistani novel about love, death and heroin abuse in contemporary Lahore. It is essentially about a young Lahorian who gets left behind as his more wealthy friend leaves Pakistan for a western education. On his friend's return, he falls in love with his wife, loses his job and slides into drug abuse and a life of crime. It is brilliantly written and examines the restraints many young and westernised Pakistanis must feel within their strictly religious society.

Jonathan Dimbleby
Broadcaster

From Fox Talbot's touching portrait of his wife to a limpid still life by Don McCullin 150 years later, Photogenic (Scriptum Editions, £45) is the chronicle of a fine art. With 300 of the best images culled from the 270,000 owned by the Royal Photographic Society, this visual feast is illuminated by an erudite and entertaining text by Pam Roberts, the curator of the RPS Collection. Arranging her selection by theme - portraiture, social documentary, nature and science, nude and fashion, landscape and architecture - she had this reader spellbound. The pity is that so many of these works are never on show. The RPS (which has just has lost its home in Bath) needs its Tate and its Serota to do for British photography what Sir Nicholas has done for modern art.

Bonnie Greer
Writer and critic

My book of the year is The Total Library: Non-Fiction, 1922-1986 by Jorge Luis Borges (Allen Lane, £20). The surprise here is the vigorous stand that the so-called apolitical Borges takes against machismo, Fascism and anti-Semitism. In this beautifully edited and translated volume there is everything from Lana Turner to Dante, Kafka to King Kong, all of it written in a style which embraces brevity as if it were a religion. No one else encapsulates that sense of lightness, cheerful plagiarism and the idea of circularity quite like he does. The aesthete's aesthete, Borges reminds us that we are what we read, that nothing is new under the sun, and that writing well is the ultimate revolutionary act.

Fay Weldon
Writer

The Real Common Worship, edited by Peter Mullen (Edgeways, £12), is a fascinating compilation of essays comparing and contrasting the form of the Prayer Book since Cranmer's original in 1459 - "One of the handful of key texts," according to Diarmaid MacCulloch, "which have shaped the sound patterns and speech structures through which billions of the human race communicate with one another." And which now, according to some others, is being ruthlessly dumbed down in the shape of the new revised Book of Common Worship to something nearer therapy than liturgy. Does it matter? The contributors think it does, profoundly: readers must make up their own minds.

Ian Rickson
Artistic director of the Royal Court

I have to admit that the book that gripped me most was Thomas Harris's Hannibal (Arrow, £6.99). I found it absolutely compelling. Diane Ackerman's A Natural History of the Senses (Phoenix, £7.99) is a beautiful surprise: a seduction in the art of living sensuously. Finally, I loved the ambition of Zadie Smith's White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99). It has a rambling richness that wonderfully evokes London.

Charles Kennedy
Leader of the Liberal Democrats

My favourite book was Dick Morris's Behind the Oval Office (Random House, £20), a fascinating fly-on-the-wall account from a former Clinton intimate. It is also a case study of New Labour techniques containing warnings about an over-cynical approach to politics. Al Gore should have read it!

Margaret Drabble
Writer

My book of the year is Lorna Sage's remarkable family memoir, Bad Blood (Fourth Estate, £15.99). It's a vividly remembered, honest, generous, shocking story of a 1950s childhood and a teenage love affair. The tone is perfectly judged. The sociological details are fascinating, and the narrative is compelling. It's a fine transformation of pain into something redeeming - I don't think that's too grand a word. A very moving testament.

Jon Snow
Newsreader and reporter

In Wherever Green is Worn (Hutchinson, £25) Tim Pat Coogan goes in search of the still vibrant Irish diaspora - the 70m people across the world determined that they are Irish. It's a circumnavigation from Argentina to Zimbabwe, crisscrossed with Coogan's brilliance as historian, wit and storyteller. No small volume, it's a book I had by my bedside for several weeks that enabled me to spend many nights among the inimitable Irish influences in America, Europe and varied parts of Africa and Latin America.

Esther Freud
Writer

Maggie O'Farrell's first novel, After You'd Gone (Review, £12.99), had me so gripped I had to feign illness in order to devote myself to it entirely. It's a beautifully constructed story of family history, religion, separation and death, all held together by an unashamedly passionate love story. Helen Simpson's short stories Hey Yeah Right Get a Life (Jonathan Cape, £14.99) detail all the things you try to forget once your children have gone to bed. It's a brilliant, painful, funny and courageous book.

Stephen Bayley
Design guru

Life being (usually) more interesting than art, I find I'm reading less and less fiction. This year I've read two enthralling real-life adventure stories, superficially very different but essentially similar. The first is Anthony Bourdain's Kitchen Confidential (Bloomsbury, £16.99), a smart-aleck journey through the grease traps of the New York restaurant scene by a literary chef. If you need to know how to dry-hump an Ecuadorian commis while marinating quail, this tells you how. It is full of similarly repellent detail and quite unputdownably nasty. Jonathan Raban's Passage to Juneau: A Sea and its Meanings (Picador, £6.99) offers a contrast which tests the borders between the sublime and the ridiculous. I never got on with Raban's fussy earlier stuff, but this book about sailing in the Pacific is a beautifully detailed masterpiece.

Lady Antonia Fraser
Historian

Marianne Elliott's The Catholics of Ulster (Allen Lane, £25) turned out to be exactly the book I had always wanted without knowing it. It's a tour de force of scholarship, taking Ulster from prehistoric times up till 1999, and at the same time extremely readable. Almost all the myths I had believed about Ulster and Ireland generally turned out to be untrue. One can't help hoping that the appearance of such a measured and passionate work by a historian born an Ulster Catholic is the harbinger of a positive future for the Six Counties.

Oliver James
Clinical psychologist

Guilt by Kalu Singh in the Icon series Ideas in Psychoanalysis (£3.99) is a brilliantly alive popular account of Freud's view of it (one subheading reads "Can fuck, won't cook: Freud's account of guilt"). The series editor, Ivan Ward, also produced (with Oscar Zarate) a very lively Introducing Psychoanalysis for Icon. As far as fiction goes, anyone familiar with Edward St Aubyn's Patrick Melrose Trilogy will know that he is our purest living prose stylist. This year's A Clue to the Exit (Chatto, £12.99) showed he is becoming more accomplished in plotting and narrative, to great effect.

Susan Greenfield
Scientist

Angela's Ashes (Flamingo, £6.99) is by far and away the book which has most gripped me this year: the subject matter is riveting. From the outset we know we are to hear of a childhood that was, "of course, miserable". However, McCourt's attitude to his mother and father is highly complex and intriguing. I have always been fascinated by the inter-war years as a period which, while social and economic progress was being made, also reflected the anxieties of a world in flux.

Ken Wiwa
Writer

Grudgingly, I have to confess to enjoying the literary oik in Martin Amis, whose memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape, £18) is my book of the year. The Alan B'stard of letters proved that he has few peers when it comes to a bit of intellectual arm-wrestling. His drunken encounter with Salman Rushdie coughed up an unforgettable reference to Rushdie's "extreme hooded-eye treatment -Salman looked like a falcon staring through a venetian blind". At the other end of the human testament is a memoir that puts the verbal fights of our literary lions into sobering perspective. Not available in the UK until next year, Nega Mezlekia's Notes from The Hyena's Belly (Picador USA, $24) roams Ethiopia, a country ravaged by drought and the death squads of a communist junta busy slaughter ing its way through 100,000 youths. It is a startlingly humane, wry and often humorous account of a young man who was conscripted into a guerrilla army as a boy and survived brushes with "reactionary exorcists" to tell a beautiful, often harrowing but mesmerising tale of a haunting and haunted country.

Arnold Wesker
Playwright

In Theatre@risk (Methuen, £16.99), Michael Kustow argues that theatre is at risk because of the conflict between art and commerce, two disparate, uncomprehending worlds. It is a vivid report from the front line and a crackling collage of performances, critiques, profiles and the testimony of leading theatre makers. What drives Kustow's passion is the relevance to life of what he admires. The best enthrals him; the mean, mediocre and absurd appals. It reads like a mesmerising war report of battles lost, won and gloriously fought; an important book to launch an important debate.

Sue MacGregor
Today presenter

Peter Ackroyd's prodigious account of our great city, London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25), is hugely entertaining, but almost did him in: soon after he finished it he succumbed to a heart attack. It is not a chronological history but a biography you can dip into at any point. In the tumultuous hubbub that has long been London's background, for instance, he searches for silence: in the 16th century, you could find it after midnight; in the 18th, off the Strand. Now, when Sundays are like any other day, you may have to go to a cemetery in Tower Hamlets. Sample, read, and marvel.

Terry Eagleton
Professor of English

Anne Carson is a Montreal poet whose volume Autobiography of Red evoked lavish praise from the critics not long ago. Now she has followed it up with Men in the Off Hours (Cape, £10), a wonderfully bizarre, playful, imaginative collection of poems with a hint of Pound's erudite elusiveness about them. This is an audaciously adventurous book, mixing verse, prose poems and brief learned essays. And amid references to Lazarus, Artaud, Catullus and Mandelstam, the poet's own ego, uniquely enough these days, hardly gets a look in.

Howard Brenton
Playwright

At first glance Mark Z Danielewski's House of Leaves (Anchor, £13) seems bizarre: even James Joyce didn't make pages of print look so weird and wonderful. But don't panic, Danielewski is a master storyteller: his narrator, a bar-room Virgil, leads you on a fantastical descent into a maze of American darkness. Refreshingly, Danielewski recognises no cultural divide: his book is both vibrantly streetwise and learned, with a horror plot Stephen King could weep for underlaid by jokes and a metaphysical intensity that is quite new. The great American novelist of the new century is with us.

William Boyd
Novelist

Treat yourself to two exemplary books of poetry: Craig Raine's Collected Poems 1978-1998 (Picador, £20) and Derek Mahon's Collected Poems (Gallery Books, £13.95) are both, in their respective and completely distinctive ways, awesomely impressive. Contemporary poetry doesn't come any better than this: both books are darkly witty and worldly, suffused with a profound and moving humanity, and have a tremendous feel for the resources of language.

Deborah Moggach
Novelist

This has been an extraordinary year for London. The city has opened up for us - museums, galleries, atriums - and become a place to explore. Peter Ackroyd's London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25) is the perfect title to celebrate this new relationship: rich, pungent and vastly informative. I was also impressed by the breadth and scope of Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin , (Bloomsbury, £16.99) though it's marred by a cod villain. My favourite novel of all was Disobedience (Doubleday, £12.99) by the superlative Jane Hamilton, about a boy eavesdropping on his mother's affair. It's not quite published yet - I read an early copy - but it should be in the shops soon.

Bruce Kent
Former CND leader

Almost by accident I came across the 1946 Penguin edition of Ignazio Silone's Bread and Wine (available in the US from Steerforth Press, $27). Set in the persecution days of Mussolini's Italy, it is the story of two friends, one a Marxist disillusioned with his party and the other a priest disillusioned with his church. This novel still has much to say about the relationship between church and state and about discouraged revolutionaries who have not lost their fire.

Michael Grade
Company director

Tom Bower's unauthorised biography, Branson (Fourth Estate, £17.99), was a must-read for me, not least because of my role as a non-executive director of lottery operator Camelot, challenged by Branson's People's Lottery for the next licence. In many ways this book was a much braver undertaking than Bower's previous exposé of the then living and litigious Robert Maxwell. With his latest target, Bower turned his considerable investigative skills away from a well-known sinner to a popular saint. Branson was, before this book, an icon, an entrepreneur who could do no wrong in the eyes of an adoring public and press. He has, over 20 years or so, positioned himself as the consumers' David against the corporate Goliaths (British Airways, Coca Cola, Camelot, record industry giants and others). In the process, he has consistently topped readers' polls as their choice to be mayor of London, Prime Minister and anything else editors decide is worthy of a poll. This is the first serious examination of Branson's business methods and his character; Bower clearly came to loathe the man. The book is a shocking read and, as ever, Bower has done his profession a great service by providing the antidote to their years of unquestioning loyalty to the grinning pullover, as Lord King of BA dubbed him. The unanswered question remains, how on earth did the press give the Virgin king such a free ride for so long? This story will run and run, no doubt making the lawyers rich in the due process. I hope there is a sequel, or at least an updated version as soon as the lawsuits are over.

Hermione Lee
Biographer

The great English novelist Penelope Fitzgerald died this year. Her last book, published posthumously, The Means of Escape (Flamingo, £12.95), is a beautiful collection of eight haunting, dark stories of people who mostly can't speak for themselves or get their own way but who sometimes find touching and unexpected consolations. A more boisterous and explicit writer is Lorna Sage, whose Bad Blood (Fourth Estate, £15.99), a quirky and compelling memoir of a 1950s Welsh childhood, is a great success: funny, odd and a fascinating piece of social history. Finally, the huge New Penguin Book of English Verse edited by Paul Keegan (Penguin, £20) is a wonderfully intelligent, adventurous, rich anthology, essential for confirmed and potential poetry addicts alike.

Zadie Smith
Novelist

I had a few favourites this year. Two non-fiction gems, Edward Platt's modern pastoral Leadville (Picador, £9.99) and Martin Amis's lyrical Experience (Cape, £18), made my spring, but in the end it was young American writing that rocked my world: Mark Z Danielewski's House of Leaves (Anchor, £13), Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99), and, more than anything else, David Foster Wallace's Brief Interviews with Hideous Men (Abacus, £9.99). Foster Wallace is proving to be the kind of writer I was sort of hoping didn't exist -a visionary, a craftsman, a comedian and as serious as it is possible to be without accidentally writing a religious text. He can do anything with a piece of prose, and it is a humbling experience to see him go to work on what has passed up till now as "modern fiction". He's so modern he's in a different time-space continuum from the rest of us. Goddamn him.

Richard Eyre
Director

The most memorable novel I've read this year is The Human Stain by Philip Roth (Jonathan Cape, £16.99), in his Nathan Zuckerman alter ego. Based on a true story of a college professor who managed to conceal his racial origins for a lifetime, it's a dizzying ride around the extremes of political hypocrisy (Clinton and Lewinsky) and political correctness. Roth laces passionate descriptive writing and beguiling storytelling with polemic and satire, covering the topics of Vietnam, race, sex, love, learning, politics, poverty and self-knowledge without ever sacrificing narrative momentum. It's moving, compassionate and extremely funny.

Read the rest of the books of the year here.

Perhaps the most pleasure has come from Persephone's enchanting reprints, particularly Winifred Watson's Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (Persephone, see Small Press, page 11), a fairy story set in 1930s London, and the funny, stoic and dashing poetry of Virginia Graham. I had the most fun with Howard Jacobson's The Mighty Walzer (Vintage, £6.99), which achieved the impossible and still leaves a glow whenever I think of it. Claire Rayner Writer and broadcaster I've spent most of my available reading for pleasure time this year going back to old delights, notably Elaine Morgan, published by Souvenir Press. Her Descent of Woman, Scars of Evolution and Falling Apart: The Rise and Decline of Urban Civilisation are as wise, witty and refreshing as they were when I first read them almost 25 years ago. But I did find two new books which I think could be as re-readable a couple of decades hence. Peter Ackroyd's London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25) fits snugly on my bookshelves alongside Mayhew, H V Morton and Walter Besant. Like them he has an eye for the sheer oddity of London and Londoners, and writes about us with wit and elegance. Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99), which deals with the relationship between brothers of very disparate age, is a great read. Posy Simmonds Cartoonist Judith Thurman's Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette (Bloomsbury, £7.99) is an intelligent, witty and sympathetic portrait of the novelist, libertine, sexual dissident and toast of the belle époque aesthetes. My other choice is The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde, edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis (Fourth Estate, £35). I dipped into them, became enthralled and then read them chronologically. Over 1,500 letters, from the trivial to the tragic, are wonderfully enriched by the footnotes, which illuminate the world in which their writer moved. Ben Okri Novelist This year I chaired the first Caine Prize for African Writing and found a wealth of talents. I recommend a general interest in African writing to widen taste and see how other people live, dream, and overcome. The story that won the prize, Leila Aboulela's "The Museum", is moving, gentle, ironic, quietly angry and beautifully written. My favourite novel of the year deserves evangelism. Joseph Roth's The Radetsky March (Penguin, £8.99) is that rarest of rare things: a masterwork that is a true joy to read. Edward Bond Playwright Our theatre gives its talented young playwrights no chance to develop; instead they create a Theatre of Symptoms. When Sarah Kane's Blasted was staged, the critics attacked it with the panicky rage which is the sign that finally they are writing about something profoundly important. The only contemporary play I wish I'd written, it is revolutionary. The counter-revolution came swiftly: she killed herself. 4.48 Psychosis (Methuen, £6.99) is her suicide note, very personal. But playwrights become as important as she has only if their psyche is public. Neither God nor genes gives us our humanity, we create it through our culture. We have ceased to create: we are dead and kept alive by the life-support machine of our colossal technology. No doubt we will turn it off. 4.48 is a great play: bitterly comic, full of a desire for life. It is also the document of our time. Read it - this suicide note is your obituary. Susie Orbach Therapist and writer The giant talent of Philip Roth taking on post-Vietnam America in The Human Stain (Cape, £16.99) is breathtaking. He is so acute and such a fine storyteller that we feel we all have those thoughts and insights in just the sequence he lays out for us. We learn what we have wanted to turn away from and not see. And then a magical new talent: Zadie Smith's White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99). Rich, unforced, wonderful. Finally, Rebecca Goldstein's Properties of Light (US, Houghton Mifflin, $23), in which the philosopher novelist takes on the anti-materialism of modern physics. Lewis Wolpert Biologist and writer Suicide is terrible, both for the feelings that lead an individual to kill themselves, and for those who remain behind. Kay Redfield Jamison knows suicide almost too well as she only just survived her own attempt. In Night Falls Fast (Picador, £16.99), she focuses on young adults, for whom it is a major cause of death. Depression is a strong predictor of a suicide attempt and one in five of those with a major depressive disorder will attempt to kill themselves. Better understanding and prevention are major issues. An important, moving and informative book. Helen Boaden Radio 4 controller Andrew Greig dedicated his novel That Summer (Faber, £9.99) to "the vanishing generation" of the second world war, and it's a worthy tribute. It's a love story set against the Battle of Britain: the prose is restrained, the plot uncomplicated but the emotion powerful. Len is a gauche young fighter pilot; Stella, a radar operator, is more middle-class, more sophisticated, more wary. The progress of one critical summer and the sweetly tender way they fall in love is told in their alternating voices. You could say that it's a slight tale about ordinary people, but I found myself thinking about it long after weightier tomes had been put aside. Jenny Eclair Comedian, novelist My favourite book of short stories this year was Jeremy Dyson's Never Trust a Rabbit (Duck Editions, £9.99). Dyson is one of the League of Gentlemen misfits and an all-round clever bloke; it's time people stopped being so suspicious of performer/writers. At the moment I want to be Douglas Coupland. His Miss Wyoming (Flamingo, £5.99) is wonderful stuff: he manages to be wacky without being zany. Next year I might try and read some intellectually challenging books but I get headaches rather easily. En route to the Montreal comedy festival I read Tony Parsons's Man and Boy (HarperCollins, £6.99), which made me gulp and sob. It was funny and sad and marvellously emotionally manipulative. A good cover, too. In Corsica I hugely enjoyed India Knight's My Life on a Plate (Penguin, £5.99), as did my 11-year-old, who guffawed all the way through it. I kicked myself along the beach for not writing it myself. I smell a film deal with this one, the lucky cow. Mike Atherton Cricketer Moth Smoke by Mohsin Hamid (Granta, £9.99) is a Pakistani novel about love, death and heroin abuse in contemporary Lahore. It is essentially about a young Lahorian who gets left behind as his more wealthy friend leaves Pakistan for a western education. On his friend's return, he falls in love with his wife, loses his job and slides into drug abuse and a life of crime. It is brilliantly written and examines the restraints many young and westernised Pakistanis must feel within their strictly religious society. Jonathan Dimbleby Broadcaster From Fox Talbot's touching portrait of his wife to a limpid still life by Don McCullin 150 years later, Photogenic (Scriptum Editions, £45) is the chronicle of a fine art. With 300 of the best images culled from the 270,000 owned by the Royal Photographic Society, this visual feast is illuminated by an erudite and entertaining text by Pam Roberts, the curator of the RPS Collection. Arranging her selection by theme - portraiture, social documentary, nature and science, nude and fashion, landscape and architecture - she had this reader spellbound. The pity is that so many of these works are never on show. The RPS (which has just has lost its home in Bath) needs its Tate and its Serota to do for British photography what Sir Nicholas has done for modern art. Bonnie Greer Writer and critic My book of the year is The Total Library: Non-Fiction, 1922-1986 by Jorge Luis Borges (Allen Lane, £20). The surprise here is the vigorous stand that the so-called apolitical Borges takes against machismo, Fascism and anti-Semitism. In this beautifully edited and translated volume there is everything from Lana Turner to Dante, Kafka to King Kong, all of it written in a style which embraces brevity as if it were a religion. No one else encapsulates that sense of lightness, cheerful plagiarism and the idea of circularity quite like he does. The aesthete's aesthete, Borges reminds us that we are what we read, that nothing is new under the sun, and that writing well is the ultimate revolutionary act. Fay Weldon Writer The Real Common Worship, edited by Peter Mullen (Edgeways, £12), is a fascinating compilation of essays comparing and contrasting the form of the Prayer Book since Cranmer's original in 1459 - "One of the handful of key texts," according to Diarmaid MacCulloch, "which have shaped the sound patterns and speech structures through which billions of the human race communicate with one another." And which now, according to some others, is being ruthlessly dumbed down in the shape of the new revised Book of Common Worship to something nearer therapy than liturgy. Does it matter? The contributors think it does, profoundly: readers must make up their own minds. Ian Rickson Artistic director of the Royal Court I have to admit that the book that gripped me most was Thomas Harris's Hannibal (Arrow, £6.99). I found it absolutely compelling. Diane Ackerman's A Natural History of the Senses (Phoenix, £7.99) is a beautiful surprise: a seduction in the art of living sensuously. Finally, I loved the ambition of Zadie Smith's White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99). It has a rambling richness that wonderfully evokes London. Charles Kennedy Leader of the Liberal Democrats My favourite book was Dick Morris's Behind the Oval Office (Random House, £20), a fascinating fly-on-the-wall account from a former Clinton intimate. It is also a case study of New Labour techniques containing warnings about an over-cynical approach to politics. Al Gore should have read it! Margaret Drabble Writer My book of the year is Lorna Sage's remarkable family memoir, Bad Blood (Fourth Estate, £15.99). It's a vividly remembered, honest, generous, shocking story of a 1950s childhood and a teenage love affair. The tone is perfectly judged. The sociological details are fascinating, and the narrative is compelling. It's a fine transformation of pain into something redeeming - I don't think that's too grand a word. A very moving testament. Jon Snow Newsreader and reporter In Wherever Green is Worn (Hutchinson, £25) Tim Pat Coogan goes in search of the still vibrant Irish diaspora - the 70m people across the world determined that they are Irish. It's a circumnavigation from Argentina to Zimbabwe, crisscrossed with Coogan's brilliance as historian, wit and storyteller. No small volume, it's a book I had by my bedside for several weeks that enabled me to spend many nights among the inimitable Irish influences in America, Europe and varied parts of Africa and Latin America. Esther Freud Writer Maggie O'Farrell's first novel, After You'd Gone (Review, £12.99), had me so gripped I had to feign illness in order to devote myself to it entirely. It's a beautifully constructed story of family history, religion, separation and death, all held together by an unashamedly passionate love story. Helen Simpson's short stories Hey Yeah Right Get a Life (Jonathan Cape, £14.99) detail all the things you try to forget once your children have gone to bed. It's a brilliant, painful, funny and courageous book. Stephen Bayley Design guru Life being (usually) more interesting than art, I find I'm reading less and less fiction. This year I've read two enthralling real-life adventure stories, superficially very different but essentially similar. The first is Anthony Bourdain's Kitchen Confidential (Bloomsbury, £16.99), a smart-aleck journey through the grease traps of the New York restaurant scene by a literary chef. If you need to know how to dry-hump an Ecuadorian commis while marinating quail, this tells you how. It is full of similarly repellent detail and quite unputdownably nasty. Jonathan Raban's Passage to Juneau: A Sea and its Meanings (Picador, £6.99) offers a contrast which tests the borders between the sublime and the ridiculous. I never got on with Raban's fussy earlier stuff, but this book about sailing in the Pacific is a beautifully detailed masterpiece. Lady Antonia Fraser Historian Marianne Elliott's The Catholics of Ulster (Allen Lane, £25) turned out to be exactly the book I had always wanted without knowing it. It's a tour de force of scholarship, taking Ulster from prehistoric times up till 1999, and at the same time extremely readable. Almost all the myths I had believed about Ulster and Ireland generally turned out to be untrue. One can't help hoping that the appearance of such a measured and passionate work by a historian born an Ulster Catholic is the harbinger of a positive future for the Six Counties. Oliver James Clinical psychologist Guilt by Kalu Singh in the Icon series Ideas in Psychoanalysis (£3.99) is a brilliantly alive popular account of Freud's view of it (one subheading reads "Can fuck, won't cook: Freud's account of guilt"). The series editor, Ivan Ward, also produced (with Oscar Zarate) a very lively Introducing Psychoanalysis for Icon. As far as fiction goes, anyone familiar with Edward St Aubyn's Patrick Melrose Trilogy will know that he is our purest living prose stylist. This year's A Clue to the Exit (Chatto, £12.99) showed he is becoming more accomplished in plotting and narrative, to great effect. Susan Greenfield Scientist Angela's Ashes (Flamingo, £6.99) is by far and away the book which has most gripped me this year: the subject matter is riveting. From the outset we know we are to hear of a childhood that was, "of course, miserable". However, McCourt's attitude to his mother and father is highly complex and intriguing. I have always been fascinated by the inter-war years as a period which, while social and economic progress was being made, also reflected the anxieties of a world in flux. Ken Wiwa Writer Grudgingly, I have to confess to enjoying the literary oik in Martin Amis, whose memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape, £18) is my book of the year. The Alan B'stard of letters proved that he has few peers when it comes to a bit of intellectual arm-wrestling. His drunken encounter with Salman Rushdie coughed up an unforgettable reference to Rushdie's "extreme hooded-eye treatment -Salman looked like a falcon staring through a venetian blind". At the other end of the human testament is a memoir that puts the verbal fights of our literary lions into sobering perspective. Not available in the UK until next year, Nega Mezlekia's Notes from The Hyena's Belly (Picador USA, $24) roams Ethiopia, a country ravaged by drought and the death squads of a communist junta busy slaughter ing its way through 100,000 youths. It is a startlingly humane, wry and often humorous account of a young man who was conscripted into a guerrilla army as a boy and survived brushes with "reactionary exorcists" to tell a beautiful, often harrowing but mesmerising tale of a haunting and haunted country. Arnold Wesker Playwright In Theatre@risk (Methuen, £16.99), Michael Kustow argues that theatre is at risk because of the conflict between art and commerce, two disparate, uncomprehending worlds. It is a vivid report from the front line and a crackling collage of performances, critiques, profiles and the testimony of leading theatre makers. What drives Kustow's passion is the relevance to life of what he admires. The best enthrals him; the mean, mediocre and absurd appals. It reads like a mesmerising war report of battles lost, won and gloriously fought; an important book to launch an important debate. Sue MacGregor Today presenter Peter Ackroyd's prodigious account of our great city, London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25), is hugely entertaining, but almost did him in: soon after he finished it he succumbed to a heart attack. It is not a chronological history but a biography you can dip into at any point. In the tumultuous hubbub that has long been London's background, for instance, he searches for silence: in the 16th century, you could find it after midnight; in the 18th, off the Strand. Now, when Sundays are like any other day, you may have to go to a cemetery in Tower Hamlets. Sample, read, and marvel. Terry Eagleton Professor of English Anne Carson is a Montreal poet whose volume Autobiography of Red evoked lavish praise from the critics not long ago. Now she has followed it up with Men in the Off Hours (Cape, £10), a wonderfully bizarre, playful, imaginative collection of poems with a hint of Pound's erudite elusiveness about them. This is an audaciously adventurous book, mixing verse, prose poems and brief learned essays. And amid references to Lazarus, Artaud, Catullus and Mandelstam, the poet's own ego, uniquely enough these days, hardly gets a look in. Howard Brenton Playwright At first glance Mark Z Danielewski's House of Leaves (Anchor, £13) seems bizarre: even James Joyce didn't make pages of print look so weird and wonderful. But don't panic, Danielewski is a master storyteller: his narrator, a bar-room Virgil, leads you on a fantastical descent into a maze of American darkness. Refreshingly, Danielewski recognises no cultural divide: his book is both vibrantly streetwise and learned, with a horror plot Stephen King could weep for underlaid by jokes and a metaphysical intensity that is quite new. The great American novelist of the new century is with us. William Boyd Novelist Treat yourself to two exemplary books of poetry: Craig Raine's Collected Poems 1978-1998 (Picador, £20) and Derek Mahon's Collected Poems (Gallery Books, £13.95) are both, in their respective and completely distinctive ways, awesomely impressive. Contemporary poetry doesn't come any better than this: both books are darkly witty and worldly, suffused with a profound and moving humanity, and have a tremendous feel for the resources of language. Deborah Moggach Novelist This has been an extraordinary year for London. The city has opened up for us - museums, galleries, atriums - and become a place to explore. Peter Ackroyd's London, the Biography (Chatto & Windus, £25) is the perfect title to celebrate this new relationship: rich, pungent and vastly informative. I was also impressed by the breadth and scope of Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin , (Bloomsbury, £16.99) though it's marred by a cod villain. My favourite novel of all was Disobedience (Doubleday, £12.99) by the superlative Jane Hamilton, about a boy eavesdropping on his mother's affair. It's not quite published yet - I read an early copy - but it should be in the shops soon. Bruce Kent Former CND leader Almost by accident I came across the 1946 Penguin edition of Ignazio Silone's Bread and Wine (available in the US from Steerforth Press, $27). Set in the persecution days of Mussolini's Italy, it is the story of two friends, one a Marxist disillusioned with his party and the other a priest disillusioned with his church. This novel still has much to say about the relationship between church and state and about discouraged revolutionaries who have not lost their fire. Michael Grade Company director Tom Bower's unauthorised biography, Branson (Fourth Estate, £17.99), was a must-read for me, not least because of my role as a non-executive director of lottery operator Camelot, challenged by Branson's People's Lottery for the next licence. In many ways this book was a much braver undertaking than Bower's previous exposé of the then living and litigious Robert Maxwell. With his latest target, Bower turned his considerable investigative skills away from a well-known sinner to a popular saint. Branson was, before this book, an icon, an entrepreneur who could do no wrong in the eyes of an adoring public and press. He has, over 20 years or so, positioned himself as the consumers' David against the corporate Goliaths (British Airways, Coca Cola, Camelot, record industry giants and others). In the process, he has consistently topped readers' polls as their choice to be mayor of London, Prime Minister and anything else editors decide is worthy of a poll. This is the first serious examination of Branson's business methods and his character; Bower clearly came to loathe the man. The book is a shocking read and, as ever, Bower has done his profession a great service by providing the antidote to their years of unquestioning loyalty to the grinning pullover, as Lord King of BA dubbed him. The unanswered question remains, how on earth did the press give the Virgin king such a free ride for so long? This story will run and run, no doubt making the lawyers rich in the due process. I hope there is a sequel, or at least an updated version as soon as the lawsuits are over. Hermione Lee Biographer The great English novelist Penelope Fitzgerald died this year. Her last book, published posthumously, The Means of Escape (Flamingo, £12.95), is a beautiful collection of eight haunting, dark stories of people who mostly can't speak for themselves or get their own way but who sometimes find touching and unexpected consolations. A more boisterous and explicit writer is Lorna Sage, whose Bad Blood (Fourth Estate, £15.99), a quirky and compelling memoir of a 1950s Welsh childhood, is a great success: funny, odd and a fascinating piece of social history. Finally, the huge New Penguin Book of English Verse edited by Paul Keegan (Penguin, £20) is a wonderfully intelligent, adventurous, rich anthology, essential for confirmed and potential poetry addicts alike. Zadie Smith Novelist I had a few favourites this year. Two non-fiction gems, Edward Platt's modern pastoral Leadville (Picador, £9.99) and Martin Amis's lyrical Experience (Cape, £18), made my spring, but in the end it was young American writing that rocked my world: Mark Z Danielewski's House of Leaves (Anchor, £13), Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99), and, more than anything else, David Foster Wallace's Brief Interviews with Hideous Men (Abacus, £9.99). Foster Wallace is proving to be the kind of writer I was sort of hoping didn't exist -a visionary, a craftsman, a comedian and as serious as it is possible to be without accidentally writing a religious text. He can do anything with a piece of prose, and it is a humbling experience to see him go to work on what has passed up till now as "modern fiction". He's so modern he's in a different time-space continuum from the rest of us. Goddamn him. Richard Eyre Director The most memorable novel I've read this year is The Human Stain by Philip Roth (Jonathan Cape, £16.99), in his Nathan Zuckerman alter ego. Based on a true story of a college professor who managed to conceal his racial origins for a lifetime, it's a dizzying ride around the extremes of political hypocrisy (Clinton and Lewinsky) and political correctness. Roth laces passionate descriptive writing and beguiling storytelling with polemic and satire, covering the topics of Vietnam, race, sex, love, learning, politics, poverty and self-knowledge without ever sacrificing narrative momentum. It's moving, compassionate and extremely funny. Read the rest of the books of the year here.

fields.headline: Fiction paperbacks of the year
fields.trailText: The best novels picked out
fields.body:
The Clay Machine-Gun
Victor Pelevin
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

While other Russian writers wallow in old feuds, Pelevin's response is a fusion of history, pop culture and Eastern philosophy. Pyotr Voyd is having an identity crisis fuelled by Baltic tea ("a vodka and cocaine cocktail first mixed on the Aurora") and psychotropic drugs. Is he the adjutant to Gen Chapayev, legendary civil-war hero, or a patient in Timur Timurovich's psychiatric clinic? Pelevin is a unique and essential writer blessed with a faultless translator.

Towards the End of the Morning
Michael Frayn
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

John Dyson runs the nature notes and crossword section of a failing newspaper, together with past-it friends Bob and Eddy. TV, rather than Murdoch or web-mastery, is the spectre haunting their lunchtimes, and when Dyson gets his chance at late-night punditry he blows it. Though Frayn's portrait of a 1960s newspaper office may seem like fanciful ancient history to today's content providers, much will be instantly familiar.

Triomf
Marlene van Niekerk
(Abacus, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Built on the rubble of Sophiatown, Triomf's nemesis is approaching: South Africa's first democratic election. It is everything the Benades - shrunken Pop, abused Mol, abusive uncle Treppie and epileptic Lambert - have passively opposed for 40 years. Van Niekerk's chronicle of this Afrikaans underclass is a vital tale that captures the bitter, tragi-comic end-game of South African racial politics. It will last as a literary portrait of a rarely seen section of South African society.

Primrose Hill
Helen Falconer
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Books about growing up are all too often written for nostalgic grown-ups, but Falconer's first novel makes you taste the frustrations of being a teenager. If it weren't for HIV, Si and Danny would be blood brothers. They watch the girls and smoke draw, until Danny asks Si to help him murder his mother's violent boyfriend. Then the beautiful, reckless Eleanor gets involved and dreams turn to action. Intense and funny, painful and humane, Primrose Hill is a stunning debut.

The Harvest
Christopher Hart
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The anguish of Lewis Pike, hero of this intense debut, is a welcome slap in the face to the flimsy anxieties of modern urban literature. Hart maps out a strikingly brutal world. Pike, an unemployed 17-year-old, is at home in the paths and fields that his grandparents followed - but his place in a countryside populated by incomers is doomed. Hart's portrait of rural tragedy respects its link to Hardy, but leavens the solemnity with touches of comedy.

Miss
L E Usher
(Quartet, £7)
Buy it at BOL

Miss, a London bookshop-owner with an unconventional past in Australia, befriends Edmunde Maskelyne, a well-known author with the most proper of English literary pedigrees, over Thursday afternoon herbal tea off Marylebone High Street. Then Miss buys a library of books on murders of women and sees a possible way to prick Maskelyne's complacency. Usher confronts the slender boundary between deep love and intense hate within the format of a highly intellectual mystery.

Music & Silence
Rose Tremain
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Tremain's Whitbread prize-winner is the perfect fairy tale for grown-ups: the kind of luscious, swallow-in-one-sitting story you thought had disappeared with childhood. Peter Claire arrives with his lute at the court of Christian IV at the same time as Emilia, a Jutland lady-in-waiting to the king's wife. The melancholic king is out of love, but not so Peter and Emilia. Tremain uses the past to transport the reader and lets us get on with researching Danish history ourselves.

A Certain Age
Tama Janowitz
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

"Florence had been around too long. At thirty-two, without a good background (anyway, an ordinary background, ordinary, pet rather than show quality), without money of her own, having slept with a few too many men - who was going to want her?" Watchers of Sex and the City or Ally McBeal will know the rest, but Janowitz has borrowed a better model - Edith Wharton - for her tale of the modern marriage market. It's well-coiffed head and four-inch stilettoes above the pack.

Tears of the Giraffe
Alexander McCall Smith
(Polygon, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

Botswana is indeed the land of milk and honey in this second helping of tales from Mme Ramotswe's No 1 Ladies' Detective Agency. Whether it's a case of a disappeared American, Mr Matekoni's troubles with his car mechanics or a scheming maid, everything finally comes to a happy end. Cynics might not buy McCall Smith's fulsome praise of old African ways and the "traditionally built" Precious Ramotswe, but this is the most entertaining read of the year.

Ghostwritten
David Mitchell
(Sceptre, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Mitchell's book is not quite a novel, but neither is it strictly a short-story collection. It is a chain of interlocking stories of disparate lives in the global village we all now inhabit, whether that means a Chinese mountain or the jazz dives of New Orleans. Fabulously atmospheric and wryly perceptive, it announced the arrival of a huge new talent last year, and was readers' favourite in the Guardian first book award. Read it in anticipation of his next book, out in the spring.

The melancholic king is out of love, but not so Peter and Emilia. Tremain uses the past to transport the reader and lets us get on with researching Danish history ourselves. A Certain Age Tama Janowitz (Bloomsbury, £6.99) Buy it at BOL "Florence had been around too long. At thirty-two, without a good background (anyway, an ordinary background, ordinary, pet rather than show quality), without money of her own, having slept with a few too many men - who was going to want her?" Watchers of Sex and the City or Ally McBeal will know the rest, but Janowitz has borrowed a better model - Edith Wharton - for her tale of the modern marriage market. It's well-coiffed head and four-inch stilettoes above the pack. Tears of the Giraffe Alexander McCall Smith (Polygon, £8.99) Buy it at BOL Botswana is indeed the land of milk and honey in this second helping of tales from Mme Ramotswe's No 1 Ladies' Detective Agency. Whether it's a case of a disappeared American, Mr Matekoni's troubles with his car mechanics or a scheming maid, everything finally comes to a happy end. Cynics might not buy McCall Smith's fulsome praise of old African ways and the "traditionally built" Precious Ramotswe, but this is the most entertaining read of the year. Ghostwritten David Mitchell (Sceptre, £6.99) Buy it at BOL Mitchell's book is not quite a novel, but neither is it strictly a short-story collection. It is a chain of interlocking stories of disparate lives in the global village we all now inhabit, whether that means a Chinese mountain or the jazz dives of New Orleans. Fabulously atmospheric and wryly perceptive, it announced the arrival of a huge new talent last year, and was readers' favourite in the Guardian first book award. Read it in anticipation of his next book, out in the spring.

webTitle: Nicholas Lezard's books of the year

fields.headline: The year of reading dangerously
fields.standfirst: From bathroom to bookshop, Nicholas Lezard revisits his favourite titles of 2000
fields.trailText: From bathroom to bookshop, Nicholas Lezard revisits his favourite titles of 2000
fields.body:
Although my brief is usually the paperback, there are some hardbacks it would be perverse not to salute. The New Penguin Book of English Verse, edited by Paul Keegan (Penguin, £20) is by some way my favourite book of the year - the book that has stayed longest by the bedside. If you thought you had tired of poetry, then this collection, compendious, judicious and eclectic, will galvanise your appreciation of the canon again. Indeed, its choices are so compellingly well made - that is, all the poems chosen are good - that it almost creates a new canon by itself. One would not have dared hope that an anthology could be so thrilling. I hear that the original selection ran to about 1,700 pages, which the binding machinery was unable to cope with; why not take the poems that didn't make it and publish a 500-page companion volume? Penguin, having taken something of a wobbly course in the past, has got its act together and done some really good stuff this year, particularly in its Modern Classics and Classics lists - an enterprise like this would round off their year nicely.

Martin Amis's Experience (Jonathan Cape, £18) is the title the book rounder-uppers have praised most this year; I dutifully fall into line behind them. Although my policy tends to be to wait for paperback publication, in respect of Amis publications this is not plausibly possible: one's impatience wins out over considerations of budget or space. I have not actually bought it, but seen it on friends' shelves and then sneaked off to their toilets to read it, or gone to the kind of bookshop where one can sit down and read. I have not yet finished it, so if anyone wants to send me a copy for Christmas I would be delighted, as I weary of these furtive occasions - strangely thrilling though they are.

Someone did send me a copy of Will Self's How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury, £15.99), which is a gripping and extraordinary addition to an already outstanding oeuvre that leaves the competition gasping. It's a return to the very origins of his published fiction, a monumentally expanded gloss on the story "The North London Book of the Dead", in which the narrator's mother informs him that the dead do not die, they simply move to another part of London. That was a great joke then; it's now the beginning of his imaginative underworld, the strange folds of London where the dead walk and work. Writers of great genius have to deal with Sheol (to avoid the loaded word "hell") at some point, and Self's stab is terrific, mind-blowing and, one suspects, horribly personal; not so much written as torn out of himself. I'm not sure all of its conceits succeed; but then Self's work has always been too big to be constrained by concepts of formal discipline or the imaginative good manners that may keep critics happy but can hobble a writer badly in the execution of his or her duty.

It's not eccentric to consider Christopher Hitchens the greatest polemical journalist of his day, and in No One Left to Lie To (Verso, £7), he excels himself in his denunciation of the Clintons. Considering who we are about to get as president, it is easy to get misty-eyed about Slick Willy; and he does have the most unusual and commendable virtue of not being that interested in personal gain. But there are many other awful things he has done and hypocrisies he has condoned; the latest edition of this book contains allegations of a particularly startling nature that, if they turn out to be true, will force us to perform a very swift and thorough re-evaluation. Hitchens, as meticulous in research as he is elegant in his prose, has yet to be proven wrong. Watch this space.

The most impressive effort this year must have been Jonathon Green's. A real lexicographer, he has distinguished himself by compiling, virtually single-handedly, the Cassell Dictionary of Slang (Cassell, £15.99), 1,300 pages of erudition, accuracy and linguistic delight. One hardly knows how to begin praising his Johnsonian industry.

Last year I said I couldn't imagine a funnier book than the Onion's Our Dumb Century; the same team has now equalled its insightful, illuminatingly offensive comedy. The Onion's Finest News Reporting (Boxtree, £9.99) reprints some of its greatest stories such as "Jews Ordered Back to Egypt For Pyramid Duty", "Perky 'Canada' Has Own Government, Laws", "Nation's Educators Alarmed By Poorly Written Teen Suicide Notes" and, my personal favourite, "Mother Teresa Sent To Hell In Wacky Afterlife Mix-Up". I could go on quoting the headlines alone almost indefinitely ("Bleary-Eyed Cosmopolitan Staffer Cranks Out 10 Billionth Way To Bring Out The Animal In Your Man"). Satire has rarely been so deft, or the miserable clichés that make up most political and critical thought so doggedly pursued to their logical conclusions.

Marina Warner's No Go the Bogeyman (Vintage, £10.99) is an allusive, highly learned and at times intimidating book about the monsters of our imagination: from Saturn devouring his children to Struwelpeter, from the grotesque to the absurd to the comic, it explores how we scare ourselves and our young - and why. As you can see, it's rather difficult to summarise. But it's awfully clever.

Another paperback which brought more or less unalloyed joy to those who read it, whether originally in this paper or not, was Posy Simmonds's contemporary take on Flaubert, Gemma Bovery (Jonathan Cape, £8.99). Pin-sharp observation in both words and pictures reveal her to be one of the country's slyest creators, smuggling art into our homes under the cover of cartoons.
