fields.headline: What's big in audiobooks - December 2000
fields.trailText: The top ten audiobooks
fields.body:
Comedy and bestselling novels dominate the audio charts, unsurprisingly for Christmas. Virgin's compilation should be a fairly safe stocking-filler - featuring a lineup ranging from Tony Hancock to Monty Python and Pete'n'Dud. In second place is Terry Wogan, whose lilting reminiscences will no doubt give comfort and succour to many a Radio 2 fan in the wee small hours. This is not just a cheap jibe, since reading for audiobooks is becoming an art in itself, with its own stars. As Bill Bryson's narrator, the audiophiliac Canadian actor Kerry Shale must have a fan club who have no idea what he actually looks like. Maeve Binchy's Scarlet Feather is read by her cousin Kate, while Martin Jarvis takes on Dick Francis and Penelope Wilton "does" Ruth Rendell. A suitable heavyweight - Timothy West - delivers the first volume of Simon Schama's History of Britain, covering a modest patch between 3500BC and AD1603.

webTitle: Review:  Fear and Loathing in America by Hunter S Thompson

fields.headline: Night of the Hunter
fields.standfirst: Won't write, can't write:  Ian Penman  punctures the gonzo myth of Hunter S Thompson's collection, Fear and Loathing in America
fields.trailText: Won't write, can't write: Ian Penman punctures the gonzo myth of Hunter S Thompson's collection, Fear and Loathing in America
fields.body:
Fear and Loathing in America: The Brutal Odyssey of an Outlaw Journalist 1968-76
Hunter S Thompson, ed Douglas Brinkley
756pp, Bloomsbury £20

As a writer - bin all that "cultural icon" stuff, all the cartoon strips and cocaine blizzards and Colorado screamin' - it is hard to see Hunter S Thompson as much more than a footnote, a minor stylist, a figure very much of his era who became stranded when times moved on and he refused to budge.

There is one admittedly self-contained work - Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas , not so much his Götterdämmerung as his Huckleberry Finn - and two valuable collections of on-the-hoof journalism, in which Thompson combines moral seriousness with delirious invective, amphetamine urgency and trickster humour. Watergate was like something this Thompson dreamt into existence, coming down one morning from a barking LSD high. But in the quarter of a century since that clammy apotheosis, Thompson has increasingly traded on his totemic reputation.

So how did such a relatively minor figure become the recipient of such monumental reams of hagiography? The answer is that like other "iconic" figures - Pollock, Lennon, Kerouac - so much hip faith was invested in his countercultural status that the market could not stand an overhaul: so much was riding on the assumed verities that to take away the myth became at some point unthinkable. And unthought is precisely what the HST myth continues to be.

The work of some of Thompson's quieter peers - the neurasthenic Joan Didion or the patrician Gore Vidal - can safely be returned to: it has a rich afterlife, because it is good writing which does not depend for 65 per cent of its charge on the writer's "legendary" status, as though he were a race horse or a tornado rather than some poor schlub who sits at a keyboard all day. Thompson has become a writer for non-readers - the lad writer par excellence - just as Oliver Reed is the actor for people who distrust actors and George Best is the footballer for people easily bored by football. This is someone who is celebrated for all the extracurricular fuzz; as if everything (baldly self-parodic work, creeping misogyny, gun worship) might be forgiven - celebrated, even! - because Hunter is (whatever this means) a "survivor". Like people who limp away from terrorist bombings, say?

All that Thompson has "survived" - and that barely - is his own stupidity, his determination to wreck a talent that was never sturdy in the first place. Even the myth - Iron John with a hot fax, a white-line Unabomber with columns instead of bombs - doesn't stand up to much analysis. The action man is a couch potato. The yippie is a Magnum-toting reactionary. (This is all he has ever done, in essence: react.) The adrenaline junkie is a sorry, stranded addict. And the writer ... well, the writer has been off form (or "resting") for so long that the myth can only be sustained by desperate ploys such as this vastly outsized volume of letters.

Fear and Loathing in America is a great doorstop of a book which rises higher than the keyboard I'm currently typing on; fatter than a political fixer's kickback, it kicks off with a surreally respectful foreword by David Halberstam (who you suspect really does know better); a solemn nine-page Editor's Note; and finally an Author's Note (the note is single, and high, and desperate) by HST himself. There's already been one big spring-clean volume of correspondence, and there's an overweening absurdity at work here - like one of those 20-CD box sets by a forgotten 1970s prog-rock band - made all the more absurd by the po-faced faux-academic treatment.

Hiding behind the rocky mountain shadow of these 750 pages is something that might have been edited into a more urgent narrative; but unless you're very interested in the minutiae of 70s American politics or the backroom politics of American publishing it is a gargantuan slog to sustain patient interest through the endless "re: expenses" and in-house gossip. (Freelancers, though, will find a familiar story here of financial despondency, made comforting by the fact that even a superstar like HST has lived a life measured out in overdue and underwhelming cheques.)

It's hard not to conclude that this Big Treatment is designed to disguise the fact that it is a very long time since Thompson wrote anything of interest or value. In the place of actual writing, the HST myth has been farmed out to uncritical biographers, letter-hoarders, editors; we've had the film, the "rescued" neophyte novel (The Rum Diary, correctly considered substandard at the time) and the now-annual harvest of ass-kiss profiles by other hacks flown out to Woody Creek to "do" the ritual and ritually identical profile of the Great Man. Look at the freak! He shoot gun! He snort drug! He mumble word! He fail deadline! The word "freak" - once Thompson's proud self-description (he ran for local office on a "Freak Power" ticket) - now has a sad ring; and the HST of 1969 would surely be disgusted by the freak show that the HST of today has let himself become.

If his only legacy is an unfortunate one of facile me-columnism, there are frustrating hints of the writer he might have worked to become if he hadn't settled for the softcore life. He could have followed a career trajectory like Tom Wolfe's or Thomas McGaune's, except that he was far more obsessed with the idea of writing great books than he was acquainted with the dismal diurnal reality of actually writing them. His solution was the shortcut chemistry of regular amphetamine (and mescaline and dope and whisky) intake, and the recurring epistolary tone here is one in which he decides he MUST WRITE NOW and write VERY IMPORTANT STUFF and A LOT of it. This was the conveniently handy "point" of Gonzo style - no rewrites, just straight synaptic pinball - and is bound up with the crucial self-image of that justifiably paranoid hellion, the "Outlaw Journalist". But beyond a certain point Thompson seems to go blind to the possibility that just maybe things look increasingly "strange" and "crazy" and "brutal" because what he is doing to his bloodstream, and his brain, is strange and crazy and brutal.

There is an interminable exchange of letters with his editor about a proposed (and never written) book on the "death of the American dream". Thompson decides in advance that the dream is indeed dead and despoiled: everything is ugly, corrupt, sick (all the key HST codewords). It is now just a question of filling in the inconvenient blank of the due text, harvesting (or bending) the "facts" to fit his comedown vision. It seems no coincidence that most of these proposals/letters are written as the dawn is coming on and the speed is wearing off, the writer confusing his own imminent comedown for a de facto worldview that is writhingly alive and claustrophobic and up-close pore-magnified UGLY. A worldview in which the writer is so carried away with the chemistry of his own limited rhetoric - or the rhetoric of his freefall chemistry - that any putative subject is lost in a chemico-rhetorical spin in which the flex of action is 24-7 valued over any reflective weight; where trips taken are valued far more than texts produced.

Thompson has joined the select company of other American authors (Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Kerouac) for whom the critical corpus now far outstrips the published work. Can you spot the crucial difference? That's right: Thompson has got posthumous fame while still alive, and this book has the fitting air of an RIP testament, a retrospective trawl, presented as though Thompson were gone, dead, disparu. Which, in a sense, he is.

webTitle: London the second most expensive city in Europe

fields.headline: London the second most expensive city in Europe
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain is the 16th most expensive country in the world in which to shop - and Copenhagen is the only city in Europe where goods cost more than in London, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain is the 16th most expensive country in the world in which to shop - and Copenhagen is the only city in Europe where goods cost more than in London, according to a survey published yesterday.

In the report by a London-based human resources consultancy, ECA International, Britain comes out as the fourth most expensive country in the EU, behind Denmark, Finland and Sweden.

Amazingly, the UK was rated cheapest in the EU in 1996. Japan is the most expensive of 66 countries listed, followed by Korea, Russia, Taiwan, Norway, Hong Kong, Switzerland, Denmark, Argentina and China.

Britain comes between Venezuela in 15th spot and Singapore in 17th, with South Africa the cheapest place in which to shop. Ireland is 39th.

London comes joint second with Helsinki in the list of cities. The survey was based on the prices of nearly 130 items, from tea bags to televisions.

It costs 95% more to shop in Japan than Britain, while South Africa is 45% cheaper than the UK. In Europe, money goes furthest in Hungary (40% cheaper than the UK).

While Britons pay 84p a litre for petrol, Americans pay just 32p. Only motorists in Hong Kong pay more: 95p a litre.

But a loaf of bread costs 95p in the UK - compared to £5.05 in Japan. Scotch whisky costs £15.87 a bottle in Denmark, and £6 in Portugal. A washing machine will set you back nearly £650 in Japan - but in Portugal it is only around £281.

Barry Rodin, chief economist at ECA, said yesterday: "A contributory factor to the UK's sustained high position in the EU league table is the strength of sterling."

fields.headline: Uncle Ebenezer
fields.body:
Phil Willmott's pocket-sized stagings of musicals have become one of the traditional pleasures of Christmas. His shoestring version of The King and I was infinitely more enjoyable than the current lavish West End version, and his Sound of Music is the only one I've ever seen when I haven't had a strong urge to leap on stage and throttle the entire Von Trapp clan.

But this year there is a change of tack. We still have a postage stamp-size stage, a huge, enthusiastic cast that Willmott drills with skill, and a brilliant simple design. But instead of an old musical, Uncle Ebenezer is Willmott's own musical adaptation of A Christmas Carol.

The result isn't necessarily better or worse, but it is different. On the plus side, Willmott has cleverly avoided the problem of creating an entirely new musical score by drawing on favourite carols and songs from Strauss, Grieg, Sullivan, Bach and others, which have been beautifully arranged by Annemarie Lewis Thomas and in many instances Willmott has added sharp new lyrics.

But Willmott's adaptation - which he frames with Scrooge's journalist nephew finding out about the London poor and being horrified just as Dickens was - is far too long.

Moreover, as both writer and director, Willmott can never resist laying on the schmaltz. William Maxwell's Scrooge is just far too much of a lovable teddy bear. A thin coating of sentiment cloaks everything from the plump, jolly paupers, to the rendition of Silent Night as Tiny Tim breathes his last. I am afraid that the cynical will choke with laughter, not tears.

Sometimes, as in the scene in which the young Scrooge (Stuart Piper, excellent) chooses gold over love, Willmott plays it just right. Scrooge's failure to join the dance and its consequences is demonstrated with real theatrical verve and, as always, Willmott's production has a very rough magic about it. You can see that it is all done on the cheap, but with such attention to detail that you believe in entirely.

So, maybe not quite the Christmas cracker we've come to expect at this address, but still an enjoyable evening that Willmott brings to such a rousing climax that you can't help but leave the theatre on a bit of a high.

 Until January 20. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

webTitle: Save hundreds of pounds by changing your online broker

fields.headline: Save hundreds of pounds by changing your online broker
fields.standfirst: A study by Leeds University unit Ecom reveals huge variations in the cost of share deals on the net, says Liz Stuart
fields.trailText: A study by Leeds University unit Ecom reveals huge variations in the cost of share deals on the net, says Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Almost one in three equity investors has dealt online, according to Proshare, the body which promotes share ownership. And, while convenience is a major factor in driving the public to trade over the net, cost is the biggest concern.

Until now, comparing broking fees has been as tricky as calculating the difference between the tariffs of the various utility companies when they first deregulated. But a new research unit attached to Leeds University, Ecom Group, has this month released the results of a study into the cost of trading with your mouse. The results show wide disparities between the lowest-cost providers and the most expensive.

Cheapest across the board is iDealing, which launched earlier this year under a low-cost no-frills banner - there is a £10 flat rate commission on deals and an annual fee of £20 - which Ecom found undercut competitors by up to 75%. An investor with a £10,000 share portfolio making two trades - one sale and one purchase - of £1,000 each month for 12 months can save as much as £547.34 by using iDealing.

The most expensive providers are those applying higher minimum commission rates such as Killik & Co, or those with a high flat charging structure such as Options Direct, which trades under the name of myBroker. Other pricey options include Abbey National, the Charles Schwab European Frequent Traders Club, nothing-ventured.com, Icon Service and E Trade UK.

The report has been delivered to the Financial Services Authority, which is looking at how costs associated with all financial products, however they are bought, can be made more transparent for the consumer. "We think that there ought to be a uniform basis for comparing charges and the FSA says it will consider this," says report author Robert Hudson. A spokesman for the FSA says that changes are likely to come in later next year.

For portfolios of £10,000, other good value web brokers are Direct Sharedeal, Halifax ShareXpress, Barclays Stockbrokers, ShareDeal and ShareDeal Plus, Selftrade and TD Waterhouse.

Ecom also researched the effect of charges on an investor with a portfolio of £20,000, and again iDealing came out top, followed by Directsharedeal, Halifax Share-Xpress and Selftrade. Killik & Co, nothing-ventured.com, Abbey National and myBroker were the most expensive. Barclays, however, drops down the list considerably in this bracket: the Ecom report says this is due to its commission structure being less competitive on larger deals.

The difference in costs between the cheapest and most expensive broker on a portfolio of this size, on two trades a month for a year, is nearly £550. The average amount deducted in charges is £585.

The differentials on a portfolio of £100,000, with one sale and one purchase of £10,000 for a year through different brokers, are even more marked - £2,895 between the cheapest and most expensive. Here Killik & Co is radically more expensive: its charges would effectively cost £3,780, as opposed to the average figure of £1,431. Once again, iDealing.com comes out top, being one of two brokers whose charges in this case are under £1,000: iDeal ing's charges cost the investor £885 and Selftrade's £926.

Mr Hudson says: "A lot of services have special offers when people join, but these are the real underlying costs." Although some investors gain from special offers, these only cloud the market.

But Mr Hudson adds a caveat to these findings, that all these providers offer very different levels of service. "Killik & Co is a bespoke operator giving high levels of professional support to customers, while iDealing makes no bones about the fact that it offers the very basics. Although cost is obviously important, you should also look at the levels of service which different providers offer."

fields.headline: Scharoun Ensemble
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.body:
The members of the Scharoun Ensemble play together at least as often as any regular chamber group - the difference is that most of the time there are 60-odd other musicians with them. Named after the architect of the Berlin Philharmonie building, the Ensemble is formed of players from the hall's resident orchestra, the Berlin Philharmonic. So a performance by the Ensemble gives an audience the opportunity to witness some of the teamwork that makes the Berlin Phil perhaps the best orchestra in the world.

A charged atmosphere was established from the very opening of Dvorak's G major string quintet, Op 77. By adding a double bass to a regular string quartet line-up, Dvorak opened up a new dimension of possibilities. The cello, freed from its obligation to provide the bass line, is able to take up lyrical melodies, as well as to thicken up the texture of accompanying harmonies, and the presence of the bass brings a weight and gravity that can be felt as well as heard.

But this bottom-heavy scoring didn't hold the Scharoun Ensemble down at all. While the tempo of the second movement may have been laid back, there was plenty of tension. In the two later movements the upper strings in particular showed they had the exact measure of their instruments' capabilities, altering their timbre to produce subtle intimations of light and shade.

Schubert's Octet is a favourite of the Ensemble - it was one of the items in their first ever programme together. Yet in this performance they still managed to make it sound fresh. What impressed more than the high standard of individual musicianship was the way in which the playing of all eight often seemed to stem from a single impulse, exemplified by the breathtakingly taut triplet rhythms in the third movement - it must be all those years spent playing Beethoven's 7th.

The discipline of years of orchestral work did show at times; there was perhaps a hint of reluctance from the players to linger over their solos. There were one or two small blemishes, but these were barely consequential. If the Berlin Phil is indeed full of players like these, then conductor-elect Simon Rattle is in for a treat.

webTitle: Circus review: Cirque du Soleil's Quidam

fields.headline: The big top that's big business
fields.trailText:
Cirque du Soleil's Quidam
Battersea Power Station,
London
***
fields.body:
Cirque du Soleil's Quidam
Battersea Power Station,
London
***

Cirque du Soleil, the Canadian outfit that seems intent on doing for the circus what McDonald's has done for the hamburger, has always struck me as having an essentially suburban approach to the art form. This is circus that has been cleaned up, cloaked in dry ice and soft rock, and prettified - there are no Julia Roberts armpits on show here. The combination of the complete denial of the flesh that is an integral part of the circus acts themselves, and the kind of soft-focus spectacle that might grace a Las Vegas night-spot has always seemed like very tasteful and fully clothed soft porn for family audiences.

This latest show is in similar vein, but something rather nastier has crawled in. It is all to the good. From the opening moments when the stage is filled with people in white suits as if cleaning up after some kind of nuclear accident, Quidam is always edging towards creating a performance in which the extra- ordinary feats of the performers - such as the headless man holding an umbrella who glides across the stage like an escapee from a Magritte painting - emerge out of an ordinary world where extraordinary mutations have taken place.

Of course, these mutations might simply be in the imagination: in particular that of a small girl whose everyday existence is suddenly invaded by fantastical creatures, wild, aggressive and capable of contorting their bodies and defying gravity in a way no human could. There is a sense of something unleashed, out of control and transformed. Even ordinary playground skipping suddenly becomes unimaginably thrilling, ropes spinning so fast and in such complex combinations that you blink in both wonder and bewilderment.

The show would be even better if it pursued this bent towards narrative and meaning rather than just falling back on spectacle. But at least Quidam, unlike previous Cirque du Soleil efforts, allows the acts to breathe, and doesn't denigrate its artists by surrounding them with window dressing. When Richard Jecsmen and Carmita Lorador perform their balancing act in which two bodies appear to miraculously meld into one, the focus is entirely on them. Each twitching muscle becomes a tiny show in itself. The whole affair is also greatly improved by getting out of the plush red velvet atmosphere of the Albert Hall and into the big top. It now feels more like circus and less like light entertainment.

Even so this is a pretty plush big top, slathered in sponsorship and ruled by officials who appear to be using Attila the Hun as their role model. And you will pay through the nose to buy into the dream. A programme costs a whopping £6.90, but like the whole show it is glossily packaged.

In the end you pays your money and makes your choice: if you want spectacle it is unbeatable, but as theatre it still has quite a long way to go.

 Until early February. Box office: 020-7627 6060.

This is circus that has been cleaned up, cloaked in dry ice and soft rock, and prettified - there are no Julia Roberts armpits on show here. The combination of the complete denial of the flesh that is an integral part of the circus acts themselves, and the kind of soft-focus spectacle that might grace a Las Vegas night-spot has always seemed like very tasteful and fully clothed soft porn for family audiences. This latest show is in similar vein, but something rather nastier has crawled in. It is all to the good. From the opening moments when the stage is filled with people in white suits as if cleaning up after some kind of nuclear accident, Quidam is always edging towards creating a performance in which the extra- ordinary feats of the performers - such as the headless man holding an umbrella who glides across the stage like an escapee from a Magritte painting - emerge out of an ordinary world where extraordinary mutations have taken place. Of course, these mutations might simply be in the imagination: in particular that of a small girl whose everyday existence is suddenly invaded by fantastical creatures, wild, aggressive and capable of contorting their bodies and defying gravity in a way no human could. There is a sense of something unleashed, out of control and transformed. Even ordinary playground skipping suddenly becomes unimaginably thrilling, ropes spinning so fast and in such complex combinations that you blink in both wonder and bewilderment. The show would be even better if it pursued this bent towards narrative and meaning rather than just falling back on spectacle. But at least Quidam, unlike previous Cirque du Soleil efforts, allows the acts to breathe, and doesn't denigrate its artists by surrounding them with window dressing. When Richard Jecsmen and Carmita Lorador perform their balancing act in which two bodies appear to miraculously meld into one, the focus is entirely on them. Each twitching muscle becomes a tiny show in itself. The whole affair is also greatly improved by getting out of the plush red velvet atmosphere of the Albert Hall and into the big top. It now feels more like circus and less like light entertainment. Even so this is a pretty plush big top, slathered in sponsorship and ruled by officials who appear to be using Attila the Hun as their role model. And you will pay through the nose to buy into the dream. A programme costs a whopping £6.90, but like the whole show it is glossily packaged. In the end you pays your money and makes your choice: if you want spectacle it is unbeatable, but as theatre it still has quite a long way to go.  Until early February. Box office: 020-7627 6060.

fields.headline: It's an inequitable life
fields.standfirst: As many as 1m people are scared they have been caught up in the first major financial disaster of the 21st century.Patrick Collinson, Rupert Jones, Liz Stuart and Tony Levene look to see if they have good reason to panic
fields.trailText: As many as 1m people are scared they have been caught up in the first major financial disaster of the 21st century. Patrick Collinson, Rupert Jones, Liz Stuart and Tony Levene look to see if they have good reason to panic.
fields.body:
The crisis at Equitable Life is being labelled the biggest financial disaster since the collapse of Barings, except this time it directly affects 1m policyholders rather than just pin-striped City bankers.

But don't panic into making an over-hasty decision. Equitable is not insolvent and you have time to find an adviser to help you take a decision.

First port of call should be Equitable Life itself. Their helpline number is 0870 900 8020, and their website has answers to frequently asked questions.

An organisation called IFA Promotion (0117 971 1177) will locate an independent financial adviser close to you, but absolutely insist that your adviser is not commission-based, and pay a fee instead.

The Financial Services Authority has issued a very useful guide for Equitable clients. Several IFAs have already issued guides as well.

These include Towry Law on 0845 788 9933 and BestInvest on 0207 321 0100.

But for an at-a-glance guide to your policy - and which company you may want to transfer to - try this:

Personal pension holders

Equitable's pension plans masquerade under a variety of scheme names - from the relatively obvious "personal pension" through "retirement annuity contract" to "section 32 buyout". However, the same factors apply to all policies.

Firstly, check if the policy is unit-linked or with-profits. If it is unit-linked, heave a sigh of relief - your money is not at risk. But most Equitable policyholders are in 'with profits' plans, which will see lower future investment returns or a 10% penalty if you switch to another provider.

Check also if your policy has a "guaranteed annuity rate" promise in it. If it does, you are one of the 90,000 lucky policyholders who are the big winners from the debacle. Under no circumstances will you want to stop the policy or transfer it. But the vast majority of policyholders do not have the GAR.

What should they do? The answer, according to financial advisers, largely depends on your age and how far from retirement you are.

 Within five years of retirement: don't switch your fund - taking the 10% penalty is not worth it. It probably also makes sense to continue paying contributions to Equitable.

 Within 5-15 years of retirement; stop paying contributions immediately, and set up an alternative, stakeholder-friendly plan for your new contributions. Take advice on switching the existing fund you have built up; younger savers can more easily take the "hit" of the 10% penalty on their fund; older savers may want to leave it where it is.

 More than 15 years to retirement; stop new contributions immediately, set up an alternative, stakeholder-friendly plan for new contributions and switch your existing Equitable savings to the new plan.

Case study

Younger saver, 20-25 years to retirement

Freelance production editor Rachel Hedley, 37, set up an Equitable with-profits pension in July 1999, paying in £250 per month. "I thought I'd got everything sorted out, with a company offering good returns and maximum flexibility.

"Now I don't know whether I should transfer it all, even with the 10% penalty, or wait a couple of years and see what happens."

Recommendation

Alan Stevens, at Portfolio & Pensions Management in Glasgow, says: "She should not put any more money in to her policy at Equitable, and, as she is still in her 30s, I would recommend Norwich Union, which has a good pre-stakeholder friendly plan and invest the money in its UK Growth fund. I would also be comfortable in transferring the existing savings into the NU plan.

Case study

Later saver, 13-17 years to retirement

Susan Greenberg, a freelance journalist, took out a with-profits personal pension with Equitable Life four years ago and has paid in a total of £8,000.

"I have never had a great deal of confidence in financial institutions, but now I totally mistrust the whole system. I started my pension late, when I was 40, and this is my big investment which is why I chose what I thought was the safest company. And I chose a with-profits policy which I thought was safer still."

Recommendation

Donna Bradshaw, at Fiona Price & Partners in London, says: "Don't put any more money in to the Equitable plan and set up a new plan elsewhere; possibly split your money 50/50 between a pension and an ISA. At the moment we quite like Norwich Union, Scottish Equitable and NPI for their pension plans. As regards the existing savings, I'd leave it at Equitable. The company is still solvent and there is no reason to pull out urgently. Let the dust settle; you and your adviser will be able to make a better decision then.

Case study

Older lump sum investor, 10 years to retirement

Nick Shaw has contributed to an Equitable Life with-profits retirement annuity plan - the pre-1988 version of personal pensions - since 1987 and the fund is now worth around £100,000.

He has a guaranteed annuity on this policy although he was not aware of this until the court cases started, and can draw a pension on this plan at any time between 2006 and 2015. He has other pension policies but Equitable was intended to be his main income source in retirement.

Recommendation

Richard Craven, of London based HCF Partnership, says: "Besides the obvious 'don't panic' message - leaving it a few months to see how the land lies is not going to make any difference in this case - Mr Shaw has two obvious advantages over many Equitable policyholders. He has a contract with a guaranteed annuity and he is flexible on his eventual retirement date.

"The guaranteed annuity is very valuable. It could be worth 150% to 200% of the likely rates on other annuities on the day he retires. So any alternative provider's policy would have to grow at between one and a half times and twice the Equitable plan. And that's before counting in the 10% penalty on transfer and the cost of signing up to a new provider. "But he needs to find out whether the guarantee extends to all contributions or just to the small contractual annual amounts he is already paying.

"If incremental or extra amounts don't count for the guarantee, he should consider maximum Isa contributions instead."

AVCs

Around 1.5m workers are boosting the value of their company pension by making additional voluntary contributions (AVCs), and a fair chunk of them will be paying into plans provided by Equitable Life.

Equitable is the UK's biggest provider of AVC top-up pension schemes to 4,000 employers including the National Health Service, BT, the BBC and a number of local authorities.

Pensions departments at companies have been deluged with calls from worried staff seeking advice. Some employers have already issued information about what employees should do, and a number have begun the process of selecting a new AVC provider.

Most Equitable AVC schemes are with-profits, and people paying into these plans will see their investment returns fall in the future. But if they want to move their accumulated AVC funds to another provider, they will have to pay a 10% penalty.

So what should employees do? First of all, wait for the position to become a bit clearer, and check what alternative arrangements your employer may be making.

Case study

Young worker, paying into AVC plan for past two years

Joseph Adams, 32, is a member of his company pension scheme, plus for the past two years he has paid an extra £50 per month into the Equitable AVC offered by his employer.

Recommendation

David Wright, at employee benefits consultancy Alexander Forbes Financial Services, believes 90% of people with Equitable AVCs should stop paying in and redirect future contributions to another provider.

Those people with only a few years to go until they retire would probably be best advised to leave the built-up money where it is, while younger people, such as Mr Adams, with 10 or more years to go until they retire should "seriously consider" paying the penalty and shifting their funds, says Mr Wright.

Case study

Older AVC payer, close to retirement

Richard Ellis, 61, of Hertfordshire, works for an engineering firm and has been paying into an AVC plan provided by Equitable for about seven years. He is trying to maximise his pension pot by paying in as much as he can. He plans to retire in a year's time. Equitable has said that anyone who takes their retirement benefits at the contractual date will not suffer the 10% penalty.

Recommendation

Equitable has confirmed that though Mr Ellis is taking early retirement, he will be able to draw his pension in the normal way and won't have to pay a penalty. But Mr Ellis says it is "a worrying time" and he is angry about suffering the loss of seven months' worth of bonus.

Antony Mattocks-Lewis, at Alexander Forbes, says Mr Ellis should seek financial advice about his options, but it may well be worth him continuing to pay into the Equitable AVC as normal as he is so close to retirement. The alternatives, such as taking out a private top-up policy (known as an FSAVC) probably aren't in his best interests.

With-profits bonds

With-profits bonds, where you invest a lump sum with a life insurer, are particularly popular with older, more cautious investors. Equitable Life has been a leading provider of these bonds but its revised investment strategy, where it will be investing less in stocks and shares, doesn't bode well for the future. Chartwell Investment Management, a Bath-based IFA, says the performance "is undoubtedly going to suffer".

There is a get out of jail free card - but some people won't be able to use it for quite a while. Equitable has confirmed that with older bonds, there will be no 10% penalty if they are cashed in on the fifth anniversary of the date of purchase, and at each anniversary after that. Unfortunately, those people with bonds taken out more recently have to wait 10 years from the date of purchase until there is no penalty for cashing in.

All bond-holders should check their documentation or contact the company to find out their position.

Case study

Invested £10,000 in with-profits bond nine years ago

Bernard Rogers (not his real name), a client of Chartwell, took out an Equitable with-profits bond in April 1991, putting in £10,000. He didn't put any more in, and has been taking an income from it.

Recommendation

Mr Rogers' initial reaction was that he wanted to surrender the bond immediately, but Craig Wetton at Chartwell says his advice would be to stay put for the moment and then get out in April next year, when he can cash in the bond without penalty because it is the 10th anniversary. However, Mr Rogers will still be hit with an income tax bill.

Income drawdown

Income drawdown is one of the most complex areas of pension planning. At retirement people can choose either a conventional annuity, a with-profits annuity or defer buying an annuity by putting their pension pot into an "income drawdown" product which leaves the money invested in shares but lets you take a regular retirement income.

The bald truth is that, for now at least, there is nothing an income drawdown holder can do. The inland revenue-framed rules for drawdown products currently forbid transfers to other providers. So for the time being, drawdown holders must live with the lower investment returns that Equitable is forecasting.

But relief is at hand. Next April it is expected that the transfer rules will be lifted. However, it is currently unclear as to whether Equitable will charge a 10% penalty on drawdown transfers when they are legalised.

Case study

Recently retired, took out drawdown with £329,000 in pension savings

Mike Waller, 59, a former engineer, retired last year and used his lifetime pension savings of £329,000 to buy an Equitable income drawdown plan, from which he takes an income of about £20,000 a year.

"I wasn't that well-versed in the ways of the City, but Equitable seemed a safe and reliable option. I think the House of Lords ruling on the guaranteed annuities was perverse and it has now landed everybody in the situation we are in today. I think the best thing I should do is sit tight."

Recommendation

Russ Devin, at Epsom-based advisers Morgan Nevill, says: "From April 2001 he can choose another provider. If Equitable does not apply a penalty, he should jump ship straight away. If there is a penalty, what will drive it is his attitude to Equitable. Many people will just want out because of its problems and poor publicity. However, Mr Waller is taking a cautious level of income, and it may make sense to stay with Equitable for a couple of years and then review the situation.

But Alan Stevens, of Portfolio & Pensions Management, says Mr Waller was unwise to take the Equitable plan and thinks a transfer, once allowed, should be seriously considered. He would recommend a self-invested drawdown plan split across several funds and companies.

With-profits annuity

With-profits annuities work by leaving the money invested in a with-profits fund, made up of equities, bonds and property. The person taking out the annuity opts for a level of income from their investment, and each year the company awards a bonus, depending on how underlying investments have performed.

Equitable's 65,000 with-profits annuity holders are in the worst position of all - once you have taken out an annuity you can cannot transfer out of it or surrender it and it is the with-profits customers who will effectively be paying for the guarantees with the company issued to its guaranteed annuity customers.

Case study

Semi-retired annuity buyer

Peter Ransley, a freelance writer for television, invested almost £500,000 in an Equitable Life with-profits annuity policy in 1997. It has been paying him an annual income of more than £40,000 since then "and I had been happy with the performance," he says.

Recommendation

Unfortunately, Mr Ransley cannot switch. Equitable Life is predicting that his income may fall by up to 1% following the switch into gilts, but others, including Mr Ransley, think this is a best-case scenario.

"The Doomsday scenario is that in the long run my income will fall by up to 30%. I had put this together for my wife and now I accept she will be very seriously hit," he says.

Marlene Shalton, director of advisers Chambers Morgan Jones in Cardiff, says: "This is a big problem as those with a with-profits annuity do not even have the option to pay the 10% penalty and transfer. Equitable Life should offer some other option to people in this situation."

fields.headline: Tintoretto, Botticelli and Giotto in Paris
fields.standfirst:
Les Primitifs Italiens
Musée Jacquemart-André
Paris
****
fields.trailText:
Les Primitifs Italiens
Musée Jacquemart-André
Paris
****
fields.body:
At one end of the Boulevard Haussmann, the culture of vulgar display is in rude health. There have been orgies and coke sniffing among partying fashion models at Printemps department store. At Galeries Lafayette, you can't move for dog fanciers snapping up scent for their poodles and grim-faced fathers panic-buying PlayStation 2s and Pokémon tat.

At the posher end, on the Monceau plain, where the Rothschilds and other Second Empire types expressed their wealth in hard stone, there is the Musée Jacquemart-André, which is another world. It's a place of sumptuous retreat, where you might take your mother for a light lunch and a spot of nice art.

This, at the worst of times, is an extraordinary place - a cross between Kenwood House and the Wallace Collection in London, with a hint of the Frick Collection in New York. It is here, in a luxurious renovated palace, that two formidable 19th-century collectors - wealthy painter's daughter Nelie Jacquemart and the banker Edouard André - assembled their haul. There's a library teeming with Dutch masterpieces (Rembrandt, Franz Hals, Jacob van Ruysdael). There are Fragonards, Chardins, Vigée Le Bruns, and even a few English paintings.

But the pair were especially taken with Italian art. There's a bombastic Tiepolo fresco on the landing depicting that exciting moment when Henri III in all his pomp met the Doge Contrarini - who had brought along even more pomp of his own. Far better, there is St George sticking it to the dragon courtesy of Uccello and a marvellous bronze of the Martyrdom of St Sebastian by Donatello.

Until now, however, the Jacquemart-André collection of 47 pre-Renaissance Italian paintings from the Trecento and Quattrocento had not been shown to the public. This new exhibition remedies that, and, while there aren't, perhaps, enough Giottos to stand up the curator's thesis that these paintings dramatise that moment when art leapt beyond the stiffness of the dark ages into a new era, this is nonetheless an excellent exhibition.

In fact, there's only one Giotto, his St John the Evangelist, in which, crucially, we see a believably specific man rather than a type: individual personality is something whose depiction is valuable in itself.

The point is even better demonstrated in the second room of the exhibition, devoted to portraiture. Here is Portrait of a Lute Player, controversially attributed to the Florentine artist Francesco Salviati. But the attribution question is a side issue: quite clearly, this beautiful boy with a timid expression comes from a new time in painting - one invented in the workshops of Florence and broadcast around the world.

There are wonderfully mobile portraits by Botticelli, a splendidly homoerotic Martyrdom of St Sebastian by Sodoma (who else?) and, best of all, a grey Ecce Homo by Mantegna. In this last, the colour of Our Lord has drained from his sad-eyed face and he is flanked by ugly, evil men. This is, indeed, a man, weary of his sufferings, poised to die for our sins. For once Mantegna's painting does not approximate to the solidity of sculpture. What an impression this must have made to the faithful in the 1490s.

But, for me, the best picture is in the last room: Adam and Eve by Tintoretto. It's a spectral, brooding picture that recalls Piero di Cosimo and anticipates the epic hoopla of Poussin. Both are holding apples: she curled around a tree, he a satyr-mutant with pointed ears, intrigued by the fruit that spells his and our fall. Darkness is falling around this garden in which real, fluid, human beings - our primitive predecessors - are expressing themselves for the first time. To look at this picture is to see the flowering of realistic painting.

 Until March 25. Details: 00 33 1 42 89 04 91.

There have been orgies and coke sniffing among partying fashion models at Printemps department store. At Galeries Lafayette, you can't move for dog fanciers snapping up scent for their poodles and grim-faced fathers panic-buying PlayStation 2s and Pokémon tat. webTitle: Look for good performers if you jump ship

fields.headline: Look for good performers if you jump ship
fields.standfirst: Putting safety first is obviously understandable if you have lost out. But, reports Phillip Inman, there's more to it than that
fields.trailText: Putting safety first is obviously understandable if you have lost out. But, reports Phillip Inman, there's more to it than that.
fields.body:
Equitable life members looking to jump ship would be forgiven for putting safety first. When the lists of stress inducing moments are compiled in the future, realising that your pension company has committed hari kiri is likely to rank near the top alongside moving house and getting married. Few will want to go through the same experience again.

But safety is only one criteria. Performance and charges should be given the closest scrutiny. Equitable, once a top performer, has slipped in recent years.

The Financial Services Authority warned this week it would be "concerned if advisers were to use the current circumstances to panic people into making unwise decisions".

Despite the warning many financial advisers reckon that thousands of members are clear losers and should consider switching immediately.

Personal pension policyholders without guaranteed annuity rates are likely to be the worst hit. They make up the majority of the with-profits fund and they are likely to pick up the bill for the guarantees afforded to the Guaranteed Annuity Rate policyholders. Unless they are quite close to retirement, advisers are likely to recommend moving the policy.

Brian Dennehy of adviser Dennehy, Weller & Co says the onus is on the FSA to show why members should stay with Equitable before it begins lecturing financial advisers about luring people away. He says that most members are not asking advisers "should I move", but "where should I go", despite the imposition of a penalty fee by Equitable Life - called a market value adjuster - equivalent to 10% of the fund.

He says that an analysis of investment performance and charges over the past 20 years with reviews at five, 10 and 15 years using performance tables provided by Money Management magazine shows that Axa Sun Life, Scottish Amicable, Scottish Mutual and Standard Life stand above the crowd.

Equitable has not performed nearly as well and is only likely to see its performance decline. He says it has trailed behind Standard Life by 1% per annum on average and is likely to fall a further 0.5% over the coming years. Bargain hunters should be looking for a new provider to drop any entry charges when switching and keep management charges in line with the government's stakeholder pension scheme - below 1%. A switch to a rival like Standard Life would wipe out the effect of the 10% charge in five years and improve the pension payout of a member from that point onwards, he says.

Dan Kemp, of adviser Holden Meehan, says the pension marketplace is very competitive and charges have been reduced by some large pension companies. "It is possible to find leading contracts without large upfront costs for both lump sum and regularly paid pensions," he says.

He also rates Standard Life highly but would include Friends Provident and Norwich Union on his list along with Scottish Widows and Scottish Equitable. Mr Dennehy contends all these firms apart from Standard Life have performed poorly over the long term.

Some top performing firms are omitted from our table because they are not included by ratings agency Standard & Poor's in their surveys of financial strength, which means that the three top performing life offices -Liverpool Victoria, Wesleyan Assurance and Royal London -are left off the list despite having good financial strength ratios.

fields.headline: Theftive greetings
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Christmas is a great time for traditions. Drink-driving, fighting over taxis, shouting at strangers in the street, throwing up on trains, it seems everyone wants to make it a really special time of year.
fields.body:
Christmas is a great time for traditions. Drink-driving, fighting over taxis, shouting at strangers in the street, throwing up on trains, it seems everyone wants to make it a really special time of year.

In the same spirit, every year there's a traditional warning from insurance companies that this is the peak season for break-ins, or the "theftive season", as those wits at the Association of British Insurers call it.

Apart from thieves being attracted by the honeypot of presents stacked up under the fairy lights, there's the additional risk caused by so many people going away and leaving their homes unoccupied. An estimated 80% of burglaries take place when properties are empty.

And in anticipation of the annual increase in claims, there are a number of insurance companies which include a temporary increase in cover without any extra charge, for instance Eagle Star will add £5,000 to cover Christmas presents and Axa raises cover by 10% throughout December.

It's worth asking what level of cover your insurance policy offers before you find out the hard way. For instance, you might need an extra "personal possessions" policy to extend your contents insurance to cover presents outside the home, such as in the boot of your car.

A reader in London e-mailed me this week after having her car broken into, and found that her contents insurance didn't cover the presents that were stolen.

There will be tens of thousands of such robberies and burglaries in the next couple of weeks, but it's worth considering this real-life example of what can happen if you think you're insured, but haven't checked the details.

This reader is left without a car while her own is repaired, she's lost her no-claims bonus on her car insurance, she has to buy another load of presents and, to add insult to expense, the mobile phone that was also stolen was used before she could cancel it, leaving her with another bill.

The rise in claims isn't just from an increase in robberies, it's also for the rush of accidents and emergency repairs. Plugs overload, Christmas lights catch fire and over-used appliances break down.

And there are an assortment of accidents that occur when drunk people lurch around small spaces, their blood supply cut off by new clothes two sizes too small.

There's a fairly precise parallel with the queues in hospitals, which soar in the immediate aftermath of Christmas, as the casualties stagger in with seasonally triggered disorders, such as jumper pattern nausea, old people's perfume poisoning and a really sharp pain in the arse from seeing Jim Davidson too often on television.

But you can't take out an insurance policy on the real dangers of Christmas, such as being particularly amusing at an office party and having to pretend afterwards that it was some kind of medical condition.

Embarrassment insurance which, maybe, would promise to buy-off or possibly kill-off all the other guests who saw you, would be a huge winner.

Insurance worries in the US this month have already produced what must be the weirdest social gathering imaginable - the alcohol-free office Christmas party. Insurers were concerned that employers could be liable for any lawsuits following bad behaviour at a boozy office bash, prompting an alcohol and inappropriate snogging ban. But can you imagine anything bleaker?

Of course, there are aspects of Christmas which would be uninsurable, because they always happen. For instance, no-one would sell you insurance on Christmas lights lasting more than a week.

Hangover insurance would never be available to those most in need. And you'd never get cover against buying a tree that's six inches longer than your car.

And we can't insure against feeling miserable in the face of all the jollity, which always makes me think of the gag about Santa's little helper who was given anti-depressants because he was suffering from low self-esteem.

As well as buying insurance against seasonal mishaps, the authorities are also warning us to avoid buying goods that may be counterfeit and unsafe.

Trading standards officers have put out a Christmas dodgy goods warning on unsafe micro-scooters, toy water guns that could blow up under pressure and fake Pokémon watches.

But my own seasonal favourite was a product recall by trading standards officers of a "fairy wand". There was a risk it that it might come apart and leave wires exposed, but I liked the idea of taking it back for a refund on the grounds that it didn't work. Where would Christmas be without the magic?

coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: The Tempest
fields.standfirst:
Almeida,
London
***
fields.trailText:
Almeida,
London
***
fields.body:
It would be a gross understatement to say that the Almeida, shortly to close for refurbishment, ends a decade of high achievement with a splash: more like a deluge. For, in Paul Brown's spectacular design, this must be the most watery Tempest on record. But, though I normally resist aqua-Shakespeare, Jonathan Kent's production is vastly superior to Robert Lepage's wet Dream at the National - the sense of the play still comes through.

On entering the theatre you are confronted by an inlet filled with rocks, crags, planks, fallen beams and even an upstage gangway. For the opening tempest the heavens open, and Ariel later descends from the skies and spends much of the evening in the stage lagoon.

Brown has clearly enjoyed his island fling but, for me, this is not the ideal way to stage the Tempest: it pre-empts the audience's imagination in its aqueous literalism. But Kent does a good job in not allowing the words to get drowned. Under all the spectacular effects it's a traditional production: instead of being a metaphor for colonialism, the play becomes a study of one man's contest with his own internal demons.

This is largely due to the immense subtlety of Ian McDiarmid's Prospero. He is not some cut-price magician but a man who, after 12 years angry exile, is filled with a testy melancholy when his masterplan finally comes to fruition. Watching Miranda fall for Ferdinand, he mutters: "It goes on, I see, as my soul prompts it," as if the reality does not match the expectation. And while, objectively speaking, he has appropriated Caliban's island, he sees himself more as an enlightened tutor betrayed by his pupil: McDiarmid lends sad weight to the idea that all his pains have been "humanely taken".

The other performances accord with McDiarmid's reading. Far from being a figure of dispossessed pathos, Malcolm Storry's Caliban is a randy, unreformed brute who at one point even rubs himself sexually against a surprised Stephano. And although Aidan Gillen's Ariel pines for his liberty what strikes one most is his athletic compliance with Prospero's requests. But, aside from Brown's design and McDiarmid's Prospero, the dominant feature of the evening is Jonathan Dove's music which seems to float across the water with a distant ethereal beauty.

 Until February 17. Box office: 020-7359 4404. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.
